KENNEDY--Michael John, on January 25, 2016 at age 78 of cancer. Civil rights lawyer who fought for the First, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Amendments. Mr. Kennedy, whose career as both a civil liberties and criminal attorney began in California in the 1960s, successfully defended Black Panther Huey Newton on manslaughter and murder charges in Oakland. In San Francisco, he won acquittal for all seven young Mexican Americans, Los Siete de la Raza, charged with murdering a police officer in the city's Mission District. And when Jimmy Mitchell, co-owner of San Francisco's notorious O'Farrell Theatre-which journalist Hunter S. Thompson called 'The Carnegie Hall of Public Sex'-was accused of killing his brother Artie in a drunken rage, Mr. Kennedy succeeded in having the charge reduced from murder in the second degree to manslaughter. In Illinois he represented Rennie Davis, a member of the Chicago Eight accused of conspiracy and inciting a riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention and served as Mr. Davis's lawyer before the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington, D.C. He also represented Bernardine Dohrn who belonged to 1960s radical group, The Weathermen. Other of his clients belonged to the Brotherhood of Eternal Love, the most famous member of which was Timothy Leary, LSD guru to a generation. In Lincoln, Nebraska, Mr. Kennedy won acquittal for a Penobscot Native American charged with assaulting FBI agents at Wounded Knee. Perhaps his most famous trial and certainly the most time consuming-it still remains the longest criminal jury trial in U.S. Federal Court history-was The Pizza Connection; the name came from accusations of drug money laundering through pizza parlors in New York City. When the U.S. Attorney put two warring mafia families on trial, the case played out like a drama between the Capulets and the Montagues with Mr. Kennedy retained as chief council representing one of the godfathers, Sicilian mob boss Gaetano Badalamenti. Wire taps were the basis for charges against six Americans raising money in New York to buy weapons for the IRA in Ireland. As lead council, Mr. Kennedy won an acquittal for all six men. He also won clemency from New York Governor Mario Cuomo for Jean Harris, the private girls' school headmistress who was in prison for the notorious murder of her lover, Scarsdale Diet doctor Herman Tarnower. Mr. Kennedy worked on only one divorce case in his career and although the settlement was sealed, reliable sources reported that Ivana Trump was very pleased. There were many pro-bono cases about which no one has written. And there were many times when people from all walks of life, the high, the low, and the undocumented, sought Kennedy's advice privately and many times he privately reached out to connections, sometimes in the government, sometimes in the underworld. As general council to High Times Magazine for 41 years, Mr. Kennedy and his friend, the magazine's founder, the late Tom Forcade, sought to subvert prohibition of marijuana. When a reporter recently asked Mr. Kennedy how he kept High Times out of trouble for so long, he replied simply that he had never asked or allowed them to do anything illegal but added: "At High Times we will never forget what was done in the name of law enforcement to our scarred arrestees, and those who still rot in prison for daring to try to enjoy themselves peacefully and harmlessly." Mr. Kennedy was the consummate gentleman, with a quick Irish wit and a quick Irish temper. But he very rarely raised his voice, being the personification of Theodore Roosevelt's foreign policy: Speak softly but carry a big stick. The romance between Michael Kennedy and Eleanora, his wife of forty-seven years, is the stuff of fairy tales. Marrying after love at first sight, they never spent a night apart and sometimes signed their names as one word. Although not an attorney, Mrs. Kennedy was her husband's most trusted associate and confidant working entirely behind the scenes on every case, becoming an unofficial voir dire expert. The couple eschewed the label 'socialite' but could be seen often at benefits for Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, the Central Park Conservancy and the United Nations. They gave as many parties as they attended, a number of which were chronicled in New York Magazine and the New York Social Diary. When not working or traveling, Mr. Kennedy spent his time between New York City, his Hamptons home Kilkare, his old Key West cottage in West Palm Beach and his house in Ireland's Black Valley. Michael John Kennedy, who died at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, was born in the state of Washington in 1937. After boarding school in Washington, he attended University of California at Berkeley and Hastings Law School. Besides his wife Eleanora, he leaves his daughters Anna Safir and Lisa Kennedy, his son Scott Hamilton Kennedy, three granddaughters and two grandsons. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday from 2-4 and 6-8pm. The funeral service will be held on Thursday at 10am at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 60th Street and Columbus Avenue. 1/3

MACTAS--Leah, passed away on January 24, 2016 after bravely living through a long period of distress, never complaining and maintaining her characteristic strength and her well-known and admired smile. Leah was a woman who lived her life always "making a difference." The centerpieces of Leah's life were her love for her husband Leonard, her much adored sons Mark, Edward, Jay, Bruce and Seth, their wives, her ten cherished grandchildren and her great- grandchild. She also had the good fortune to be part of a large and wonderful family, including brother and sisters- in-law, cherished niece and nephew, all dearly loved. She will be remembered and missed by all. Her legacy is her gift to her loved ones. Donations in her memory may be made to: Leah Mactas Fund for Children, Temple Emanuel of the Pascack Valley, 87 Overlook Drive, Woodcliff Lake, NJ 07677. Funeral Services are 1pm, Wednesday, January 27, 2016 at Robert Schoem's, W-150 Rte. 4 East, Paramus, NJ, followed by burial at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ. 1/3

FISHMAN--Leonard. The Officers, Board of Governors, The Women's Group, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Leonard Fishman, and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Susan Fishman and their children, Holly and Jon and their families. Robert Sherman, President 1/3

PERLMUTTER--Stephen David, passed away on January 17, 2016 at the age of 68. A loving husband, father, brother, and friend. He is survived by his wife Diane, his daughters Jaclyn and Caren, and his sisters Iris and Susan. A lifetime New Yorker, Stephen grew up in the Bronx, graduated from Bronx Science, CCNY, and Brooklyn Law School, and served the State of New York as an Administrative Law Judge. Stephen was a history buff, a lover of comedies, and an appreciator of musicals. He will be greatly missed. The family extends their gratitude to the physicians and staff at Memorial Sloan Kettering, where donations can be made in Steve's honor. 1/3

RISEMAN--Milton, January 24, 2016, of Radnor, PA. Beloved husband of Judith (nee Schechtman); loving father of Alex (Lori) Riseman and Samantha (Collin) Conoley; cherished grandfather of Ariel, Sophia, Matthew, Declan and Nola. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Wednesday 1:00pm, Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, NY 10595. Shiva will be observed at the late residence. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation (MMRF) or The Melanoma International Foundation (MIF). 1/3

EISENPRESSER--George. We note with sorrow the passing of longtime member, George Eisenpresser, and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl and President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

BOUSVAROS--George M.D.,of Larchmont, NY passed away on January 19, 2016 after a brief illness. He was 86 years old. He was born in Thessaloniki, Greece, the only child of Athanasios and Glykeria Bousvaros. He graduated with the highest honors from the University of Athens Medical School, completed postgraduate training in cardiology in London and Canada, and immigrated to the United States in 1966. During his illustrious career as a physician, he was Chief of the divisions of cardiology at the Veteran's Administration Hospital in Albany and Metropolitan Hospital in Manhattan, and Professor of Medicine at Albany Medical School and the New York Medical College. After giving up his administrative duties, he continued to serve the people of New York as a cardiologist at Lincoln Hospital until he became ill. He was an outstanding husband, father, physician, teacher, and human being. He is survived by his wife Olga, two children Dr. Athos Bousvaros and Maria Tollefson, their spouses Dr. Margaret Lotz and Dr. Terry Tollefson and three grandchildren Sophia, George and Byron. The wake will be held at the Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home in Mamaroneck, NY on Friday, January 29 from 5-9pm. The service and burial will be on Saturday, January 30 at 10am at the Holy Trinity Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, NY. Flowers may be sent to the funeral home. Donations can be made to the Holy Trinity Church, 10 Mill Rd, New Rochelle, NY 10804. 1/3

GREENFELD--Marvin, on January 21, 2016, of New York City, formerly of Alexandria, VA, died peacefully shortly before his 91st birthday. Devoted husband to the late Renee E. Greenfeld and to second wife the late Marilyn Bartick. Loving father to Anne M. Greenfeld, Stephen S. Greenfeld, and the late Lawrence I. Greenfeld, and loving stepfather to Melissa Bartick. A WWII Veteran, he had a long professional career in electrical engineering and management, loved jazz and classical music-he was an outstanding trumpet player-and was an inveterate punster. Our father also frequently contributed to dozens of charitable organizations. Funeral service will be held on Friday, January 29, 2016, 12pm at Judean Memorial Gardens Chapel, 16225 Batchellors Forest Rd., Olney, MD. Interment will immediately follow in Judean Memorial Gardens Cemetery. 1/3

LEWIS--Gladys I.,"Lady Lewis" passed away Thursday, January 21, 2016 in Monroe, NJ. Wife of the late Sir W. Arthur Lewis, she is survived by her daughters, Elizabeth Channon and Barbara Virgil, and their families. Services Saturday, January 30, 2016 at 11:00am at St. David's Episcopal Church, Cranbury, NJ. Visitation Friday, January 29, 2016 from 4-7pm at A.S. Cole & Son Funeral Home, 22 N. SISKIND--Beth, (formerly of Scarsdale, NY), on the morning of January 25, 2016 in her New York City home. Born Beth Diana Mohel August 10, 1940, she spent her first 18 years in New Bedford, MA, graduated from New Bedford High School and earned a bachelor's degree at Skidmore College (1962). A high- light of her time at Skidmore was an 11-week trip to Europe's Festivals of Art and Music which she financed through her successful investments in the stock market beginning at the age of 13. While raising her two boys in Scarsdale, Beth earned a Master's degree from the New School of Social Research. Beth was a dedicated mother, wife and grandmother. A lover of the arts and education, she relished being an angel for plays on Broadway and her most passionate charity work included efforts on behalf of Brandeis University, and Skidmore College. She will be greatly missed by husband Donald, sister Judith Hertz, sons Steven and Edward, their wives Moira and Lucinda and grandchildren Leila, Samuel and James. A service in her memory will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY at 12pm on Thursday, January 28. 1/3

HOUGHTON--Rev. Alanson. The Reverend Alanson Bigelow Houghton died peacefully at his home in Pawleys Island, SC on Sunday, January 24th. He was 85 years old. Alan was born August 3, 1930 in Corning, NY to the late Amory Houghton Sr. and Laura Richardson Houghton. Alan earned multiple degrees including a Master of Business Administration from Harvard University and a Master of Divinity from New York Theological Seminary. Alan spent the early part of his career in business, where he worked for the Corning Glass Works. He then found his true calling and became an ordained Episcopal priest. He served at a number of different churches including Church of the Epiphany (New York City, NY), Christ Episcopal Church (Shaker Heights, OH), Church of The Heavenly Rest (New York City) and St. Stephens Episcopal Church (Charleston, SC). Alan felt strongly about public service and giving back to his country. One of his proudest accomplishments was becoming a United States Marine. Alan also had a passion for philanthropy, and he particularly enjoyed starting and supporting charitable programs in the communities in which he lived. Lastly, Alan loved to write. He was a published author who enjoyed writing cards, prayer books and letters to the editor. Alan was preceded in death by his beloved wife Billie Fisher Carr Houghton, his sister Laura Houghton Beer, and stepsons John Thomas Fisher Carr and Oscar C. Carr III. He is survived by his siblings Elizabeth Weinberg, Amory Houghton Jr., and James Richardson Houghton; his children Alexander Stewart Houghton, Alanson Bigelow Houghton III, Hope Houghton Newell and John Carter Houghton; his stepchildren Blanche Carr Symons, Scott Carr Adams and E'Lane Carr Tipton; and 19 grandchildren and 5 great grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Holy Cross Faith Memorial Episcopal Church in Pawleys Island, SC at 10am EST on Saturday, January 30th. Sign a guest book at www.mayer funeralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the National Parkinson Foundation or a charity of your choice. 1/3

WALRATH--Dale Robert, of Manhattan, NY and formerly Wilton, CT, died on December 31, 2015 at home, at the age of 94. He was a World War II veteran, Mad Man, and devoted husband and father, who succumbed to Alzheimer's after a 12-year dignified struggle. An exemplar of the Greatest Generation, he was raised on a farm in Ohio, graduated from Ohio Wesleyan on scholarship, enlisted in the Army in 1943, and fought on the Western Front throughout Germany, receiving the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Purple Heart before his honorable discharge in 1945. He moved to Connecticut in 1956, embarking on a 33-year career on the creative side with J. Walter Thompson in Manhattan. During his tenure at Thompson he helped develop the "Built Ford Tough" campaign and pioneered broadcast shoots in California. He was the most selfless of men, active in the community post-retirement, while caring for an ailing spouse for years. Survivors include his son Christopher Bret and daughter Rosalind Anne, both of Manhattan, and three grandchildren, Margot, Victoria and Amanda. His courage, dignity, sacrifice for others, vitality, kindness, and extraordinary decency are treasured by all who knew him. 1/3

TUGGLE--Robert. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of its Director of Archives, Robert Tuggle, an invaluable member of the company whose passion for opera defined his life. He served as Director of Archives for more than 34 years, overseeing its many activities including the Archives Database, an exhaustive online compendium with detailed information on every performance in the company's 133-year history. Before coming to the Met, he worked in the education department of the Metropolitan Opera Guild for decades, beginning in 1957 when he was 24 years old. He was the author of The Golden Age of Opera and, at the time of his death, was at work on a biography of soprano Kirsten Flagstad. We extend our sincerest condolences to all those who knew and admired Bob, and whose lives were touched by his work. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3

KENNEDY--Michael John. On January 25, 2016 at age 78 of cancer. Civil rights lawyer who fought for the First, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Amendments. Mr. Kennedy, whose career as both a civil liberties and criminal attorney began in California in the 1960s and culminated in 2009 as Special Advisor to the President of the United Nations, Miguel D'Escoto. He successfully defended Black Panther Huey Newton on manslaughter and murder charges in Oakland. In San Francisco, he won acquittal for all seven young Mexican Americans, Los Siete de la Raza, charged with murdering a police officer in the city's Mission District. And when Jimmy Mitchell, co- owner of San Francisco's notorious O'Farrell Theatre- which journalist Hunter S. Thompson called 'The Carnegie Hall of Public Sex'-was accused of killing his brother Artie in a drunken rage, Mr. Kennedy succeeded in having the charge reduced from murder in the second degree to manslaughter. In Illinois he represented Rennie Davis, a member of the Chicago Eight accused of conspiracy and inciting a riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention and served as Mr. Davis's lawyer before the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington, D.C. He also represented Bernardine Dohrn who belonged to 1960s radical group, The Weathermen. Other of his clients belonged to the Brotherhood of Eternal Love, the most famous member of which was Timothy Leary, LSD guru to a generation. In Lincoln, Nebraska, Mr. Kennedy won acquittal for a Penobscot Native American charged with assaulting FBI agents at Wounded Knee. Perhaps his most famous trial and certainly the most time consuming-it still remains the longest criminal jury trial in U.S. Federal Court history-was The Pizza Connection; the name came from accusations of drug money laundering through pizza parlors in New York City. When the U.S. Attorney put two warring mafia families on trial, the case played out like a drama between the Capulets and the Montagues with Mr. Kennedy retained as chief council representing one of the godfathers, Sicilian mob boss Gaetano Badalamenti. Wire taps were the basis for charges against six Americans raising money in New York to buy weapons for the IRA in Ireland. As lead council, Mr. Kennedy won an acquittal for all six men. He also won clemency from New York Governor Mario Cuomo for Jean Harris, the private girls' school headmistress who was in prison for the notorious murder of her lover, Scarsdale Diet doctor Herman Tarnower. Mr. Kennedy worked on only one divorce case in his career and although the settlement was sealed, reliable sources reported that Ivana Trump was very pleased. There were many pro-bono cases about which no one has written. And there were many times when people from all walks of life, the high, the low, and the undocumented, sought Kennedy's advice privately and many times he privately reached out to connections, sometimes in the government, sometimes in the underworld. As general council to High Times Magazine for 41 years, Mr. Kennedy and his friend, the magazine's founder, the late Tom Forcade, sought to subvert prohibition of marijuana. When a reporter recently asked Mr. Kennedy how he kept High Times out of trouble for so long, he replied simply that he had never asked or allowed them to do anything illegal but added: "At High Times we will never forget what was done in the name of law enforcement to our scarred arrestees, and those who still rot in prison for daring to try to enjoy themselves peacefully and harmlessly." Mr. Kennedy was the consummate gentleman, with a quick Irish wit and a quick Irish temper. But he very rarely raised his voice, being the personification of Theodore Roosevelt's foreign policy: Speak softly but carry a big stick. The romance between Michael Kennedy and Eleanora, his wife of forty-seven years, is the stuff of fairy tales. Marrying after love at first sight, they never spent a night apart and sometimes signed their names as one word. Although not an attorney, Mrs. Kennedy was her husband's most trusted associate and confidant working entirely behind the scenes on every case, becoming an unofficial voir dire expert. The couple eschewed the label 'socialite' but could be seen often at benefits for Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, the Central Park Conservancy and the United Nations. They gave as many parties as they attended, a number of which were chronicled in New York Magazine and the New York Social Diary. When not working or traveling, Mr. Kennedy spent his time between New York City, his Hamptons home Kilkare, his old Key West cottage in West Palm Beach and his house in Ireland's Black Valley. Michael John Kennedy, who died at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, was born in the state of Washington in 1937. After boarding school in Washington, he attended University of California at Berkeley and Hastings Law School. Besides his wife Eleanora, he leaves his daughters Anna Safir and Lisa Kennedy, his son Scott Hamilton Kennedy, three granddaughters and two grandsons. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday from 2-4 and 6-8pm. The funeral service will be held on Thursday at 10am at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 60th Street and Columbus Avenue. 1/3

DRAZEN--Ruth Yorkin. We mourn the loss of Ruth Yorkin Drazen-mother, filmmaker and pioneer in genetics-who died quietly in her sleep on Monday evening at the age of 97. Ruth was born in Washington, PA on May 15, 1918, the daughter of Jesse Sachs Yorkin and Maurice A. Yorkin. Ruth adored classical music from early childhood on, studying piano at the Curtis School of Music with Henry Kaufman. In 1938 she married fellow Curtis student, Mario Berini, and they moved to New York City, where Mario began his career as a tenor with the Met. Their only child, Anton, died in infancy of a rare genetic disease, and Ruth's grief sparked her interest in curing genetic illnesses. She spent years working tirelessly as executive director of The Muscular Dystrophy Association and The National Genetics Foundation. When her second husband, New York attorney Jerome Drazen, died of prostate cancer in 1988, she developed an abiding passion for the subject of humanism in medicine, expressing it through the making of documentary films, which she continued to create into her early nineties. Her first film, "When Doctors Get Cancer," was a sensitive look at doctors treating other doctors, in the hope that it might make more humane the care that physicians gave, when they were able to observe themselves as cancer patients. Five other award-winning films followed, most of them shown on PBS. They included, "The Choice is Yours," the inspirational life of the great psychiatrist, Victor Frankl, "A Wayfayer's Journey; Listening to Mahler;" "Notes From the Edge, the Diary of Peter J. Morgan, M.D.," an intimate narrative of the last two years of the life of a 29-year old physician diagnosed with cancer, and "Healing Through Humanism," a five DVD teaching series devoted to the practice of compassionate medicine. Ruth was an intellectual and spiritual inspiration to everyone she touched, and will be sorely missed. Ruth is survived by a son, Myron Drazen and daughter-in-law, Lucille; a sister, Martha Yorkin Berman; two step-sons, Michael and Roger Drazen and seven grandchildren, Julie, Debra, Jacob, Dylan, Emily, Kate and Zoe Drazen. She was predeceased by a son, Anton Berini, as well as brother Alan "Bud" Yorkin; husbands Mario Berini and Jerome Drazen. Memorial service will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., in Manhattan on Thursday at 11:30am. 1/3

KATZ--Alfred J.,M.D., 78, died on January 24, 2016 at his home in Rockville, MD. He is survived by his wife of 43 years Deborah; his daughters, Rebecca Katz (Matt Scharf) and Emily Katz (Laura Chapman), and grandchildren, Olivia, Benjamin, Leo and Eli. Also survived by his sister Miriam Cohen (Herb Cohen); sister-in-law Joan Rosenbaum (John Gorham); nephew Joshua Galper and niece Satya Welch and their families. Born and raised in the Bronx, beloved son of the late Charlotte (Breuer) and Sirol Katz, Dr. Katz was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, Swarthmore College, and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. A Board certified pathologist/hematologist/blood banker, Dr. Katz had a distinguished career at the American Red Cross for more than 30 years, including as Executive Director of Blood Services at National Headquarters. An avid, top-seeded masters tennis player and a man of great intellect who cared deeply about his family and the world around him, his life was guided by high moral and ethical standards. He will be greatly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. For further information, contact www.sagelbloomfield.com. 1/3

EISENPRESSER--George, passed away on January 22, 2016, surrounded by his beloved wife, Therese, and son, Jackson. He was 98 years of age. George was born on April 23, 1917 in Brooklyn, New York, and attended both City College and Pratt Institute. George was an accomplished businessman, Chairman and CEO of National Die and Button Mould Company. He loved sports, including fishing, golfing, skiing and horse racing. And was a great comrade among his peers. He practiced hatha yoga, deep breathing and exercised throughout his life. He also enjoyed collecting art and adding to his collection-and loaned selected pieces to museums. He had a sense of humor and outstanding charm with elegance and wit. Everyone loved him-children, adults, friends and peers. His writings and his conversations were always enlightening to hear. He was a World War II veteran and fought in battles and campaigns, including Ardennes, Central Europe, Rhineland, Normandy, Northern France, and Belgium. Throughout his life he belonged to many clubs, including the Seawane Country Club and the Lone Star Boat Club. He was a religious man and a member of Central Synagogue. For over 70 years he designed and manufactured varieties of metal stampings-nailheads, studs, rhinestones and settings, metal and covered buttons, buckles, and other metal works. His customers included leaders in the fashion industry, automotive, aviation, and the United States Military. He loved people and could converse with anyone on any level-he would always light up a room. His time in World War II as a French interpreter and radar specialist in the anti-aircraft division, and his participation in the Battle of the Bulge and the invasion of Normandy left him with many great stories that he loved to share. These stories always interested everyone who met him. He is survived by his wife-Therese; sister-Hilda; four children-Jackson/Marina, Marvin/Victoria, Robert, Eileen; two stepchildren-Pamela/Jay, James/Ana; eight grandchildren-Lana/David, Ivy, Abigail, Cooper, Maria, Marella, Brian, Tod; and his loyal dog-Guy. George will be deeply missed. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on January 28th at 10am to celebrate his life and profound contribution. 1/3

EVANS--John C. The Board of Trustees and staff of Dia Art Foundation mourn the loss of John C. Evans and extend our deepest condolences to his family and friends. Nathalie de Gunzburg, Chairman, and Jessica Morgan, Director, Dia Art Foundation 1/3

REICH--Dr. Robert (Bob), a psychiatrist who treated patients in his Upper East Side and Great Neck practices and a clinical assistant professor at Mt. Sinai Medical School, died on Monday at 79. Born in Montreal, he attended McGill University, edited The McGill Daily, and earned his M.D. at the University of Saskatchewan, where he met Mary, his wife of 54 years. As head of Psychiatry for the New York City Welfare Department under Mayor Koch, he waged a prescient fight against the impending homeless crisis. His patients ranged from celebrities to the indigent, and he was deeply committed to each one as an individual. A broad smile and a winning sense of humor told you instantly that you were in the presence of someone who would sympathetically take the full measure of your being. His stamina was superhuman; he worked long hours and still made himself available round the clock until the day he entered the hospital. His involvement was uncommonly broad, running from child to geriatric, from drugs and talk therapy, to being a pioneer in public psychiatry. Lover of hootenannies, Leadbelly, and opera; gourmet and wine connoisseur; tennis player and fan; magnanimous host and storyteller, Dr. Reich is survived by Mary, two children, Jim and Sharon, and three grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Riverside North Chapel in Great Neck, on Friday, January 29, at 11:30 am. 1/3

SISKIND--Beth, (formerly of Scarsdale, NY), on the morning of January 25, 2016 in her New York City home. Born Beth Diana Mohel August 10, 1940, she spent her first 18 years in New Bedford, MA, graduated from New Bedford High School and earned a bachelor's degree at Skidmore College (1962). A high- light of her time at Skidmore was an 11-week trip to Europe's Festivals of Art and Music which she financed through her successful investments in the stock market beginning at the age of 13. While raising her two boys in Scarsdale, Beth earned a Master's degree from the New School of Social Research. Beth was a dedicated mother, wife and grandmother. A lover of the arts and education, she relished being an angel for plays on Broadway and her most passionate charity work included efforts on behalf of Brandeis University, and Skidmore College. She will be greatly missed by husband Donald, sister Judith Hertz, sons Steven and Edward, their wives Moira and Lucinda and grandchildren Leila, Samuel and James. A service in her memory will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY at 12pm on Thursday, January 28. 1/3

MILLINGER--Harvey, 99, passed away peacefully at home, in the company of his family, on January 25, 2016. Loving husband of Sylva Dee, and father of Bruce (Xiao-Fang) and Donald (Gary Clinton). KOSLOW--Howard B.,91, of Toms River, NJ, formerly of East Norwich, NY, passed away, Monday, January 25, 2016, at his home. Funeral Services will be held at 10am, Thursday, January 28 at Temple Beth Am Shalom, 1235 NJ-70, Lakewood, NJ 08701. Burial will follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Route 109-Farmingdale Rd, Farmingdale, NY 11735 at 1pm. The family will be sitting shiva Thursday evening and Friday 10-4pm in NJ. Howard was born in Brooklyn, NY on September 21, 1924. He graduated from James Madison High School where he will be honored on their Wall of Distinction later this year. He was an accomplished artist/illustrator and a lifetime member of The Society of Illustrators (New York). His paintings are part of the Air Force Permanent Collection, the Smithsonian's Air & Space and National Postal Museums, the National Park Service and many private and corporate collections. Prominent works include numerous US postage stamps, paintings for NASA and The US Coast Guard. He was awarded many honors for his paintings. Howard is survived by his wife, Helen, of 66 years with whom he loved to travel; two daughters, Kathi Meyer (Perry) of San Diego, CA, and Amy-Jo Willig (Jeffrey) of Melville, NY; his sister, Helene Mandelbaum; four grandchildren, Elicia and Ben Meyer, David and Andrew Willig, and many nieces and nephews. 1/3

CASCIANO--Joseph, 93, passed on Tuesday, January 26, 2016, at his home, surrounded by his loving wife Lee and daughter Donna. Joseph had two daughters, Andrea and Donna. He was the son of Fiore and Grace. He leaves brother Roger, sister-in-law Nina, grandchildren Sarah and Michael, great-granddaughter Adriana, two nieces, a nephew, five grandnephews and many close friends. He proudly served in the Navy in World War II. Graduated Seton Hall University and Masters program at NYU. He was deputy director, division of human resources at New York Board of Education. Wake will be at Blair Mazzarella Funeral Home, Brooklyn, NY on Thursday, January 28th. Mass at St. Rose Lima Church, Brooklyn, NY, Friday at 10am. He will be laid to rest at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, Friday at 12:45pm. His caring nature will be terribly missed by all. 1/3

MURRAY--Anne McVoy, 91, of New Canaan, died Saturday, January 23, 2016 at Norwalk Hospital. She was the widow of Paul B. Murray, whom she was married to for 67 years. Anne was born in Chicago, IL on October 8, 1924, second youngest of seven children to John and Marie McVoy. She graduated from Manhattanville College New York with a BA in history. Anne is survived by her eleven children, twenty-three grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Friends may call Sunday from 3-5pm at Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan, CT 06840. Interment will take place at a later date in Manchester, VT. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Anne's memory can be made to Crudem Foundation, P.O. Box 804, Ludlow, MA 01056. For directions or online condolences, please visit www.hoytfuneralhome.com. 1/3

PARDEE--Margaret. The Juilliard School is deeply saddened by the passing of violinist and pedagogue Margaret Pardee. A longtime Juilliard faculty member from 1942 until 2008, she also was an alumnus of the school. She was passionate about her art and teaching, and she nurtured her students. Many of her former students have gone on to successful careers as soloists and members of leading orchestras all over the world. Her generous gift of numerous, extraordinary violins and violas to the Juilliard instrument collection will also contribute to the next generation of players. We extend our condolences to her family, friends, colleagues, and students. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Yoheved Kaplinsky, Artistic Director, Juilliard Pre-College Division 1/3

SALKO--Ellen G.,a resident of White Plains, passed away on January 27, 2016 at the age of 79. She was born on October 19, 1936 to the late Gerald and Irma Greenebaum. Ellen was a baker, bookkeeper, author, teacher and homemaker. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Alan Salko. Ellen is survived by her three children; David Salko, Larry Salko, and Judy Bergman, a daughter-in-law, Lisa Salko, as well as six grandchildren, Jake, Lauren, Jennifer, Ben, Michael, and Matthew. A funeral service will be held in the chapel at Ferncliff Cemetery on Friday, January 29th at 10am. 1/3

KATZ--Alfred J.,M.D., 78, died on January 24, 2016 at his home in Rockville, MD. He is survived by his wife of 43 years Deborah; his daughters, Rebecca Katz (Matt Scharf) and Emily Katz (Laura Chapman), and grandchildren, Olivia, Benjamin, Leo and Eli. Also survived by his sister Miriam Cohen (Herb Cohen); sister-in-law Joan Rosenbaum (John Gorham); nephew Joshua Galper and niece Satya Welch and their families. Born and raised in the Bronx, beloved son of the late Charlotte (Breuer) and Sirol Katz, Dr. Katz was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, Swarthmore College, and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. A Board certified pathologist/hematologist/blood banker, Dr. Katz had a distinguished career at the American Red Cross for more than 30 years, including as Executive Director of Blood Services at National Headquarters. An avid, top-seeded masters tennis player and a man of great intellect who cared deeply about his family and the world around him, his life was guided by high moral and ethical standards. He will be greatly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. For further information, contact www.sagelbloomfield.com. 1/3

VIGODA--Abe, 94, passed away peacefully in his sleep at the home of his loving daughter, Carol Vigoda Fuchs. Abe began an iconic and successful career as a talented actor in childhood. Proudly served in the United States Army. Adoring grandfather to Paul, Steven and Kellie (Bergen), and Jamie Fuchs. Delighted great-grandfather to Johnathan. Respected uncle to five nieces and nephews and two great-nieces. Funeral Services to be held on Sunday, January 31, 2016, 12pm, at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam and 76th St., New York. 1/3

HUDNER--Hope Freeman. Artist, Designer, Mother and Friend. Hope F. Hudner died at home in Little Compton, RI on January 14, 2016 following a thirteen month battle with glioblastoma multiforme, a form of brain cancer. Hope is survived by her husband of 40 years, Michael, and her daughter, Bay, who were deeply involved as caregivers and comforters during the past year, and were at her side at the time of her peaceful passing. Hope is also survived by her aunt, Judy Freeman N. Gross; brothers, Ambassador Charles "Chas" W. Freeman, Jr. (Margaret Carpenter) and Robert P. Freeman (Inge Reist); their five children and nine grandchildren (Hope's grand-nieces and -nephews); siblings-in-law, Mr. Kennedy Hudner (Jennifer), Ms. Cornelia Futterman (Michael), and Ms. Kristina Beitman (Harty), and their five children. Hope was born on January 11, 1951 in Nassau, The Bahamas, and lived there until age 10, then alternating time in Southern California with years in Providence and Bristol, RI. Hope was predeceased by her son, Michael Ripley ("Rip") Hudner, and her parents (father, Charles Wellman Freeman, and mother, Carla Park Freeman, who died when Hope was 20 months old). Hope was largely raised by her two sets of deceased grandparents, Hovey T. and Marjorie W. Freeman of Providence and Bristol, and George C. and Fentress K. Park of Wollaston, MA and Roaring Brook, MI. Hope graduated from The Lincoln School, Providence (1969), Smith College (1973), and also acquired an MFA from New York University. The family lived in New York City from 1974 through 1994, and then resided in Little Compton and Providence, RI. Hope was an accomplished artist and designer with a portfolio including work in graphic, interior, jewelry, and apparel design. These efforts led to her 2013 creation of Hope Hudner Designs, focused on elegant silk infinity scarves. Hope was deeply involved in Rhode Island public service, including, at various times, board and/or development responsibilities at Moses Brown School, Women & Infants Hospital, Rhode Islanders Sponsoring Education (RISE), RISD Museum, Perennial Planters, The National Society of the Colonial Dames of America (Rhode Island), and Providence Preservation Society. Hope's social involvements included membership in the Providence Art Club, Colony Club of New York City, Lyford Cay Club, Sakonnet Golf Club, and Sakonnet Point Club. Hope had great admiration for the natural world and actively cultivated a sense of wonder: she was a faithful student of plants and flowers (as evidenced by the thousands of bulbs planted across Rhode Island, Maine, and New York); she loved sailing with her family and friends (countless excursions on Narragansett Bay and longer trips to Maine, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, and Ireland number among the most special); and her keen curiosity led her to explore the far corners of the world, from Spain and Taiwan at age 18 to Antarctica at 49, covering every other continent and many countries in between. Hope had enormous energy, deep intelligence, natural grace, and remarkable warmth. She believed that life presented endless opportunity to learn, remarking on the tenth anniversary of her son's death that, "Each time it rains in our lives, we are given an opportunity for further growth. I am grateful for the challenges in my life as chances to grow and blossom." Hope faced her illness with the same fortitude and poise. While she was indeed a lifelong learner, Hope was perhaps most notable as a teacher of these invaluable lessons to the rest of us. Hope felt a profound duty to embrace everyone she encountered with love and kindness, and she shared this love of people and life like water from a fire hose. All within range were enriched by her presence and generosity of spirit. Hope inspired people to think lovingly and boldly on behalf of the larger community, themselves, and their friends, prompting many to find more inside themselves to enhance their own lives and those of others. A college classmate of Bay's said it beautifully in a recent note to Hope: "You feature prominently as an inspiration for the life I want to live-to pursue my interests, to live fully and with panache, to spend time in nature, and, most of all, to be kind to people. I know I am just one of the many, many people you affect in this way!" A celebration of Hope's life will be held in Little Compton in early June on a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in Hope's memory be made to: the Rip Hudner Memorial Fund at Moses Brown School, Providence; Dr. Patrick Wen's Research in Neuro-Oncology at Dana Faber Cancer Institute, Boston; or a charity of your choice. Above all, the family encourages you to remember Hope by engaging with the world through love and kindness. 1/3

BARSOUM LOSADA--Elisa. Beloved wife, mother, daughter and friend passed on January 25. Wake at Fox Funeral Home, 9807 Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, NY 11375, on January 28 and 29 from 2pm to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please donate to American Red Cross in Elisa's honor. 1/3

FREY--Dale F. The Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation is deeply saddened by the passing of Dale F. Frey, past Chairman of its Board of Directors, one of its greatest champions and dear friend. Through his vision, passion and relentless dedication to cancer research, he had a lasting impact on human life. Under Dale's leadership for over 16 years, the Foundation grew exponentially and funded top young scientists in cancer research whose discoveries have dramatically advanced progress against cancer. He led the Foundation with the same wisdom and entrepreneurial spirit he used as the first Chairman of General Electric Asset Management. In 2010, the Dale F. Frey Award for Breakthrough Scientists was established in his honor to support the most outstanding young cancer researchers in the nation. Our hearts go out to his wife, Betty Ann, and his children and grandchildren. Alan Leventhal, Chair of the Board, and Lorraine Egan, President & CEO. 1/3

DICK--Marion Pokoik. June 7, 1926 -Jan. 28, 2010 In loving memory of my beautiful Mother. Always thinking of you. Your beautiful smile and radiant personality lives on forever. Your Daughter, Gail 1/3

FREY--Dale F.,83, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, January 26, 2016, at home in Weston, CT following a courageous battle with cancer. Born on August 14, 1932 in Manheim, PA, he was the son of the late Franklin William and Mary Adele (Strickler) Frey. Dale was a graduate of Franklin & Marshall College, where he later served as a Trustee and Chairman and supported funding of the college. He received an MBA in Economics and Accounting from New York University. After college, he went on to serve in the U.S. Air Force. Following the U.S. Air Force, he began his 40 year career at General Electric, beginning in 1957, where he served in many positions, including Vice President and Treasurer from 1980 to 1994, as well as Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of General Electric Investment Corporation beginning in 1984. In 1994, he stepped back from his position as Vice President and Treasurer and remained in his positions of General Electric Investment Corporation until he retired in 1997. After retirement, he dedicated his time to numerous boards, including Yankee Candle Co. Inc., Roadway Express, Aftermarket Technology Corp., Praxair, Inc., and Community Health Systems. He was a member of Aurora Capital's advisory board, as well as Chairman of the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation, which he believed fully in. Under his leadership, he raised in excess of $160 million and funded 850 Cancer Researchers. Dale's passions ran deep, which was seen through his love for his family, friends, his career, and his never-ending desire and dedication for helping others. Dale is survived by his wife of 62 years Betty Ann (Heistand) Frey; his younger brother, John Gilbert Frey, and his wife Verdella, of Manheim, PA; sons, Scott Frey of Easton, CT, Philip Frey, and his wife Elizabeth, of Fredericksburg, TX, and Kyle Frey of Fredericksburg, TX; daughter, Susan Frey of Westport, CT; and his grandchildren Megan and Patrick Frey of Fredericksburg, TX. Dale F. Frey's funeral service will be held at the Zion Evangelical Lutheran Church, 2 South Hazel Street, Manheim, PA 17545 on Tuesday, February 2, 2016, from 12:00pm-1:00pm. A celebration of his life will take place at Bent Creek Country Club, 620 Bent Creek Drive, Lititz, PA 17543, from 2:00pm-6:00pm. In lieu of flowers, in Dale's memory, please consider a donation to the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation to support the Dale F. Frey Award for Breakthrough Scientists, One Exchange Plaza, Suite 302, New York, New York 10006. 1/3

BERENBAUM--Alan, 64, a computer scientist, educator and renaissance man, died of an aggressive variety of T-cell lymphoma on January 27 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. He is survived by his devoted partner of 43 years, Eileen M. Lach, and his loving sisters May Berenbaum and Diane Berenbaum. Mr. Berenbaum, who earned his advanced degree in computer science from Princeton, spent more than 25 years as a scientist at Bell Labs, and most recently was the senior architect designing chips for Microchip Technologies. Holder of several patents, he also taught at The Cooper Union. To his extended circle of friends, Alan is remembered as an intoxicating, incisive conversationalist, at ease with subjects from quantum physics to Formula One racing to the absurdities of today's politics. He wore his brilliance with grace and humor. A celebration of his life and spirit will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 1:30pm on Friday, January 29. 1/3

Adoring grandfather of Julie, Amy and Anne Achenbaum, Benjamin and Jake Kounitz, Alex and Torie Bratt. Dear companion of Shirley Lindenbaum. Service Sunday, January 31, 9:45am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alvin A. Achenbaum Fellowship at the Hartman Center at Duke University. 1/3

SLOAN--Howard, WWII bomber pilot, former Chairman of New York Blood Center, died at 91. From a base in East Anglia during World War II, 19 year old Howard Sloan flew 33 missions over Germany. His B-24 was named "The Stork Club." When praised for his bravery, he would invariably respond: "Was there a choice?" Cheers erupted from a crowd on the beach when, piloting his plane home to the states after the war, he dipped his wings over the Inwood Country Club. Mr. Sloan was born in New York City on March 20, 1924. He graduated from the Woodmere Academy and Pawling Preparatory School, and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University, Class of '45W. He and his late wife, Sonny, along with George and Barbara Bush, were the only two married couples on campus. Dreams of business school were dashed by financial necessity and he joined his father's insurance company, Harris, Sloan and Finn. Characteristically, he turned the experience into a colorful one, representing clients such as Restaurant Associates; Richard Burton, who dispatched him to Rome to deliver a diamond he'd bought at auction for Elizabeth Taylor, or Cartier to present a love bracelet to Valentino, who insisted Howard personally fasten it on his wrist. He became an art insurer, developing great interest and knowledge of art in the process, befriending numerous artists and inspiring a lifetime of collecting: Mayan and PreColumbian sculpture, works by artists as diverse as Giacometti and Bill King, Henry Moore and Lindner. He acquired an art gallery, Multiples, for his wife, Sonny, and Marian Goodman to run. In 1990, he was invited by his friend and mentor, Charles Wohlstetter, to become a partner in the latter's acquisitions of hundreds of independent telephone companies from Alaska to California. They formed Continental Telephone, later known as Contel, in 1962. The company then agreed to be acquired by GTE, a combination that created the nation's largest local telephone company. Sloan remained on the Board of GTE until it was restructured as Verizon. In 1968, an American syndicate acquired an 18th century chateau in Bordeaux with Wohlstetter and Sloan installed as new owners. Chateau Bouscaut was the second most beautiful vineyard in Bordeaux, Sloan proclaimed, second, he said, because he didn't want to boast. Among the many American guests who flocked to visit, his favorite was Mary Lindsay, whom he overheard saying to her husband, then mayor of NYC, "John, if I have to see one more vineyard, I'll kill myself." To Sloan's eternal regret, Bouscat was sold in 1980. Mayor Lindsay brought Sloan onto the board of the Vivian Beaumont Theatre in 1984. At that time, according to Andre Bishop, current artistic director, "Nobody would give you a nickel for the Beaumont." It is now one of the leading theatrical companies in New York, if not the world. Mr. Sloan served on the Board until his death on Thursday. In 1977, Sloan joined the Board of Trustees of the New York Blood Center, of which he was Chairman from 1993 to 2000, nominating his successor, Howard Milstein. In January 2013, a congressional extension prepared by Representative Carolyn Maloney in recognition of Mr. Sloan's 15 years of distinguished service and dedication to NYBC's mission, was entered into the congressional record. She cited his humanitarian status and commended his leadership and tireless advocacy. For several years, he presided as Chairman of Northside Center for Child Development, founded by Kenneth and Mamie Clarke, earning a colleague's recent comment, "There was a time this place wouldn't have existed without Howard Sloan." He and his wife are to be honored for their dedication to Northside at a gala in May 2017. Howard Sloan died of kidney failure in Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital on January 21, 2016. Handsome as a film star, he will be remembered for his elegance and extraordinary wit. He is survived by his wife, Barbara; two daughters, Kathryn Roth of Weston, Massachusetts, Gillis Cone of Woodbury, Connecticut; a son, Douglas Sloan, of Palm Beach; a stepdaughter, Paulette Bartlett Robinson, of Los Angeles, and four grandchildren. Interment will be private and a memorial service will take place at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Wednesday, February 10th. 1/3

MANBER--Malcolm Manuel, 89, passed away on January 23, 2016 in New York City. He was born on September 10, 1926 in Chelsea, MA to Gustave and Ida Manber and grew up in New York City. Beloved father of Susan and David Manber, grandfather of Max and Sarina Abraham and brother of Edna Dressner, Malcolm was married for 49 years to Vivienne Marianne Schulman and was a resident of New York City and Rhinebeck, NY. He served as an Army radio operator during World War II and later attended the Columbia Missouri School of Journalism. He enjoyed a renowned career as a science writer at the Bayonne Times, The Newark Evening News, Medical World News and Physicians Weekly. Among many notable articles, Mr. Manber published one of the earliest accounts of the world's first artificial heart transplant performed by Dr. Robert Jarvik. Mr. Manber and his wife took great pleasure in being founding members of the Beekman Arms Antique Market in Rhinebeck where their business, Victorian Cupboard, specialized in English pottery for more than 35 years. Special thanks to the hospice team at NYU Langone for making his last days with family and friends peaceful and serene. Donations in Mr. Manber's name may be made to the American Cancer Society. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Jeffrey M.,55, passed away at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital on Wednesday, January 27, after a battle with lymphoma. Jeff was born in Englewood, New Jersey to Cynthia and the late Leopold Bernstein. He graduated from the Center for Open Education in 1978 and from American University in 1982. Jeff had a long career in the music industry as a producer, composer and writer, known for composing the theme song for the PBS show, "Postcards from Buster." Jeff also played the upright bass, the guitar and African drums. Jeff will be remembered for his humor, wit, passion, intellect, kindness and generosity. He made friends wherever he went. Jeff is survived by his loving wife, Shonda, his son, Noble Archer, three, residing together in New York City, his mother Cynthia, residing in Haworth, NJ, and his sister Debbie, residing with her husband, Paul, in Doylestown, PA. He will be missed by his nieces, Jennifer and Stephanie. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY at 2:00pm on Sunday, January 31. GINSBERG--Robert K.,died peacefully on January 26, 2016 at age 91. He was a devoted and beloved husband, father and grandfather and an accomplished professional engineer. Born May 23, 1924 in New York City to Bill and Tania Ginsberg, he was educated at Lincoln School and Yale University and served as a Lieutenant (jg) in the United States Navy during World War II, seeing extensive combat in the Pacific. He was a lifelong New Yorker who practiced engineering as principal in the firm William Ginsberg Associates, and he was for more than five decades a national leader in the design and construction of newspaper production facilities. He is survived by his beloved wife of 37 years, Nellie Wilson. He was predeceased by his first wife, Helen (1926-71) and is survived by their three children, Nina (Charles Smith) of Richmond, CA, William (Ellen Kelly) of New Haven, CT and John (Kathleen) of New York City. He is also survived by his grandchildren (Alex Smith, Susan Smith Emberley, Emily Ginsberg Dellisant, Julian Ginsberg, Connor Ginsberg, and Nina Ginsberg) and many other dear family members. A superb whistler, he lived with song in his heart and on his lips throughout his nine decades of loves and laughs and friends and joys. Gentle, kind and loving, he will be forever missed. A memorial service will be announced. 1/3

RABINOVITCH--Ralph D. MD. January 17, 1917, died December 23, 2015. Trained at Bellevue in Child Psychiatry under pioneer Lauretta Bender along with late wife Dr Sara Dubo. They co-founded Children's Psychiatric Hospital University of Michigan and Hawthorn Center for State of Michigan, an innovative and nationally renowned institution. KIBEL--Henry. After 96 years of laughing, loving, shouting, learning, teaching, and building, Henry, the beloved patriarch of the Kibel family, passed away peacefully Wednesday night surrounded by family and friends. Henry created a wonderful life for his family and for the many others who benefited from his generosity. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School, William & Mary College and Yale University School of Architecture. He was a naval officer in the South Pacific during World War II. Henry was an architect, a builder and an artist. He built thousands of apartments in New York City. Every part of the development process carried his imprint. Henry was a master of making things-creating gave him joy. Whether he was building an apartment tower or creating illustrations that accompany the recipes of the renowned chef Andre Soltner's cookbook, Henry's passion never stopped. In addition to the building legacy he created, Henry was, in his own words, the inventor of important things: the 12" kitchen cabinet and innovative real estate advertising- including the successful campaign for 85 John Street, 'featuring lousy views and flushing toilets.' The fancy suspender companies will sorely miss Henry, who supported their industry and whose industry supported his pants. Although he oversalted everything, he managed to live to 96. On second thought, his memory was not so great for the last 10 years, so maybe the salt was not so good. Henry is survived by his sister, three children, eight grandchildren, and many nephews and nieces. The funeral will be held on Friday, January 29 at 11:30am at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. We will sorely miss him. The Kibel and Levenson Families 1/3

PARDEE--Margaret. The Juilliard School is deeply saddened by the passing of violinist and pedagogue Margaret Pardee. A longtime Juilliard faculty member from 1942 until 2008, she also was an alumnus of the school. She was passionate about her art and teaching, and she nurtured her students. Many of her former students have gone on to successful careers as soloists and members of leading orchestras all over the world. Her generous gift of numerous, extraordinary violins and violas to the Juilliard instrument collection will also contribute to the next generation of players. We extend our condolences to her family, friends, colleagues, and students. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Yoheved Kaplinsky, Artistic Director, Juilliard Pre-College Division 1/3

A memorial service will be held on the ground floor of his residence, at 339 West 24th St., New York, NY, on January 31 at 3:30pm. 1/3

KNAPP--Rachelle (nee Kolton). Died at 93 after a life filled with learning, love, and family. Holocaust refugee, married Sidney Knapp and earned a Ph.D. from Columbia University. "Madame Knapp" to hundreds of students at The Juilliard School, The Beekman School, and The Aspen Music Festival. Beloved teacher, mother, and grandmother. 1/3

BARRI--Marlene, died January 27th. Radio Advertising Executive. Survived and loved by her sister and brother-in-law Susan and Harry Wagner, her niece Nicole and nephew Brett. Memorial at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, January 29th, 11:30am. 1/3

HAUSSERMANN--Joanne McCoy, has died at age 85 on January 25, 2016, in East Providence, RI. A resident of Wellesley, MA, she was the daughter of the late William D. and Ruby Jordan McCoy, ever dear to them and her survivors, which are her two sisters, niece, nephews, brother-in-law, sister-in-law and extended family, and three stepdaughters. They have known a beautiful woman of loving warmth with an utter devotion to family, and a soaring intelligence. Known to many as Jo, she was an avid reader and much enjoyed music, particularly classical, and political discussions. After graduating from Dana Hall School, her work career began at the switchboard of a Boston financial company, followed by many years at Vance Sanders, and in time, for its general counsel, Arthur Hausserman. Later, a marriage brought great happiness to them both. She was predeceased by her husband and her brother. A service will be held Thursday, February 4, at 11am, Newton Cemetery Chapel, 791 Walnut Street, Newton Center, MA. Her family suggests contributions in Joanne's name to the charity of your choice, but requests no flowers. 1/3

SMITH--Howard. NYU Lutheran's board and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of chair emeritus Howard Smith. As chairman of Lutheran Medical Center and Augustana Center from 1966 until 2004, Smith, who died Thursday at age 85, left an indelible legacy on southwest Brooklyn. With his friend New York City Mayor John Lindsay and the American Lutheran Church, Mr. Smith brokered the 1977 expansion and relocation of Lutheran Medical Center from 4th Avenue and 46th Street to its present location, a former warehouse at 55th Street and 2nd Avenue in Sunset Park. He facilitated the creation of the Sunset Park Family Health Center, now called NYU Lutheran Family Health Centers, the second largest federally qualified health center network in the nation. He created a lasting financial foundation for Lutheran through Health Plus, an innovative government-sponsored insurance program for low-income residents. Lutheran's sale of Health Plus to Amerigroup in 2011 created an endowment that continues to help modernize the health system. Mr. Smith, a lifelong Brooklyn resident, was chairman emeritus of the United Hospital Fund, former president of the Brooklyn Public Library Board of Trustees, and past vice president and director of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Smith received a bachelor's in chemical engineering from Princeton University and served in the U.S. Army. He served 40 years as president of Virginia Dare Extract Company, which was founded by his grandfather Bernard, and was a former director of Dime Savings Bank of New York before it merged with Washington Mutual in 2002. He is predeceased by his wife, Elsie, and survived by his three children, Howard Jr., Jean, and Lilla, and grandchildren. NYU Lutheran mourns as we celebrate Mr. Smith's life and legacy. A wake will be held at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Tuesday, February 2, at 4-8pm. Services will be held at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, 7420 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Wednesday, February 3, at 10 am. 1/3

KIBEL--Henry. After 96 years of laughing, loving, shouting, learning, teaching, and building, Henry, the beloved patriarch of the Kibel family, passed away peacefully Wednesday night surrounded by family and friends. Henry created a wonderful life for his family and for the many others who benefited from his generosity. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School, William & Mary College and Yale University School of Architecture. He was a naval officer in the South Pacific during World War II. Henry was an architect, a builder and an artist. He built thousands of apartments in New York City. Every part of the development process carried his imprint. Henry was a master of making things-creating gave him joy. Whether he was building an apartment tower or creating illustrations that accompany the recipes of the renowned chef Andre Soltner's cookbook, Henry's passion never stopped. In addition to the building legacy he created, Henry was, in his own words, the inventor of important things: the 12" kitchen cabinet and innovative real estate advertising- including the successful campaign for 85 John Street, 'featuring lousy views and flushing toilets.' The fancy suspender companies will sorely miss Henry, who supported their industry and whose industry supported his pants. Although he oversalted everything, he managed to live to 96. On second thought, his memory was not so great for the last 10 years, so maybe the salt was not so good. Henry is survived by his sister, three children, eight grandchildren, and many nephews and nieces. The funeral will be held on Friday, January 29 at 11:30am at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. We will sorely miss him. The Kibel and Levenson Families 1/3

MURPHY--Hon. Francis T.,died peacefully on January 27, 2016 at the age of 88 surrounded by his family. He was married to his beloved Sheila Theresa for 55 wonderful years before her death on September 28, 2014. He is survived by their five children, Timothy F. Murphy and his wife, Pamela; Eileen and her husband, Jeffrey Forsyth; Kathleen and her husband, Lance Scott; Sheila and her husband, Michael Sproule; Annemarie and her husband, Kevin Casey; and his sister Irene McInerney. He was a loving grandfather to Casey, Kaitlyn, Timothy, Matthew, Sean, Patrick, Michael, Brendan, Megan and Liam. After being honorably discharged from the U.S. Navy after World War II, he graduated from Fordham University and New York Law School. A member of the New York judiciary for 40 years, he served 15 years as a trial judge and 25 years as a Justice of the Appellate Division First Department, with the last 20 years as the Court's Presiding Justice. When he left the Court, he joined the New York law firm of Kelley, Drye and Warren as Of Counsel. Throughout his career Judge Murphy was an ardent supporter of providing full legal services and justice to the underprivileged and incarcerated. A gracious man with a generous heart and strong religious beliefs, he took counsel only from his own conscience. The loves of Tim's life were his wife, Sheila, his family, his friends and his life in the law. Friends may call on Sunday, January, 31 from 2 to 4pm and 6 to 8pm at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 575 Fowler Avenue, Pelham Manor, NY on Monday, February 1 at 10am. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery. EBEL--Ruth, 89, of Verona, NJ passed away at her home on Tuesday, January 26, 2016. Born in Newark, NJ, Ms. Ebel was the first female buyer at Bambergers and eventually a Vice President of Macy's. She was a longtime member of Temple Sholom of West Essex. Ms. Ebel is survived by her cousins Ruth and Morris Pilberg, of Los Angeles, California, their daughters Aileen Winter, Jeannette Jackson and Marilyn Mandel, her cousin Robert Gutworth, of Highland Park, New Jersey, his sons Frank and Philip, and daughter Michelle Sass, and cousins David and Hanna Mushinsky, of Tel-Aviv, Israel. Donations may be made in her name to Hadassah, Susan B. Komen, Temple Sholom of West Essex, or PBS. 1/3

PELL--Beatrice Lynette (nee Harber), 95, of Somers, NY, died peacefully in her sleep on January 28, 2016. She is survived by Leonard Pell, her devoted husband of 74 years, dear sister Ruth Drucker (Bernard Gross) of Fort Lee, NJ, beloved children JoAnn Pearlman (Neil) of Somers, NY, Diane Maude Brossoie of Montross, Virginia, and Owen Pell (Pearl) of New York City, and cherished grandchildren and great-grandchildren Seth Pearlman (Jamie), Melissa Miller (Jonathan), James Brossoie, Jason Harris, Nathan Pell, Adam Pell, and Samantha Pearlman, Michelle Pearlman, Maxwell Miller, David Miller, and Alaric Puebla. Bea's energy, intelligence, humor and zest for life were apparent to all who knew her. Her family and friends will miss her deeply, and remember her with great love and affection. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY on Sunday, January 31, 2016 at 10:00am. 1/3

SMITH--Jeri Binder, of New York City, mother and actress, dies at 91 peacefully at home, surrounded by love. She was an extraordinary woman and will be deeply missed! Jeri had a long career in show business, culminating at age 89 with her unforgettable Esurance commercial. Jeri was a devoted mother to her three daughters, Marla, Andrea, and Pamela and to their husbands. She is also survived by five loving grandchildren, her sister and her three nieces. Following a private graveside service, the family will observe Shiva on Sunday, January 31 at Jeri's apartment in New York City from 5-8pm and on Monday, February 1 at the home of Pamela Fisher in Mahwah, NJ from 4-8pm. 1/3
DEUTSCH--David. Happy Birthday David. Beloved husband, father, brother, uncle and papa. We love you so much and miss you every second of every day. 1/3

SMITH--Jeri. Congregation Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her daughters, Marla, Andrea and Pamela. May God comfort their loved ones and may Jeri's memory be for blessing. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch Michael Starr, President 1/3
