GOODMAN--Carol A.,Beloved wife for 60 years of the late Daniel R. Goodman, passed away peacefully at home on January 26, 2016. She is survived by her children, Robert and Kenneth Goodman, Barbara G. Pommer and husband, Russ, and grandchildren, Stacy, Zachary, Tyler and Jacob. Services took place at Temple Beth El 333 SW 4th Ave., Boca Raton, FL on January 29, 2016. Please send donations to the Alzheimer's Association (www.ALZ.org) 1/3

KIBEL--Henry. After 96 years of laughing, loving, shouting, learning, teaching, and building, Henry, the beloved patriarch of the Kibel family, passed away peacefully Wednesday night surrounded by family and friends. Henry created a wonderful life for his family and for the many others who benefited from his generosity. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School, William & Mary College and Yale University School of Architecture. He was a naval officer in the South Pacific during World War II. Henry was an architect, a builder and an artist. He built thousands of apartments in New York City. Every part of the development process carried his imprint. Henry was a master of making things-creating gave him joy. Whether he was building an apartment tower or creating illustrations that accompany the recipes of the renowned chef Andre Soltner's cookbook, Henry's passion never stopped. In addition to the building legacy he created, Henry was, in his own words, the inventor of important things: the 12" kitchen cabinet and innovative real estate advertising- including the successful campaign for 85 John Street, 'featuring lousy views and flushing toilets.' The fancy suspender companies will sorely miss Henry, who supported their industry and whose industry supported his pants. Although he oversalted everything, he managed to live to 96. On second thought, his memory was not so great for the last 10 years, so maybe the salt was not so good. Henry is survived by his sister, three children, eight grandchildren, and many nephews and nieces. The funeral will be held on Friday, January 29 at 11:30am at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. We will sorely miss him. The Kibel and Levenson Families 1/3
MALLETT--Richard D. 88, on December 16, 2015. Beloved husband of Helene, loving father of Anna. 1/3
DEUTSCH--David. Happy Birthday David. Beloved husband, father, brother, uncle and papa. We love you so much and miss you every second of every day. 1/3

KAPLAN--Richard D. Your spirit and generosity will forever remain in our hearts. The joy you brought to all of us was a gift. To his wife Edwina Sandys we send our love and support. Dr. Steven Rose & Dale Coudert The Coudert Institute Board of Directors, Members & the Staff. 1/3

SLOAN--Howard, WWII bomber pilot, former Chairman of New York Blood Center, died at 91. From a base in East Anglia during World War II, 19 year old Howard Sloan flew 33 missions over Germany. His B-24 was named "The Stork Club." When praised for his bravery, he would invariably respond: "Was there a choice?" Cheers erupted from a crowd on the beach when, piloting his plane home to the states after the war, he dipped his wings over the Inwood Country Club. Mr. Sloan was born in New York City on March 20, 1924. He graduated from the Woodmere Academy and Pawling Preparatory School, and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University, Class of '45W. He and his late wife, Sonny, along with George and Barbara Bush, were the only two married couples on campus. Dreams of business school were dashed by financial necessity and he joined his father's insurance company, Harris, Sloan and Finn. Characteristically, he turned the experience into a colorful one, representing clients such as Restaurant Associates; Richard Burton, who dispatched him to Rome to deliver a diamond he'd bought at auction for Elizabeth Taylor, or Cartier to present a love bracelet to Valentino, who insisted Howard personally fasten it on his wrist. He became an art insurer, developing great interest and knowledge of art in the process, befriending numerous artists and inspiring a lifetime of collecting: Mayan and PreColumbian sculpture, works by artists as diverse as Giacometti and Bill King, Henry Moore and Lindner. He acquired an art gallery, Multiples, for his wife, Sonny, and Marian Goodman to run. In 1990, he was invited by his friend and mentor, Charles Wohlstetter, to become a partner in the latter's acquisitions of hundreds of independent telephone companies from Alaska to California. They formed Continental Telephone, later known as Contel, in 1962. The company then agreed to be acquired by GTE, a combination that created the nation's largest local telephone company. Sloan remained on the Board of GTE until it was restructured as Verizon. In 1968, an American syndicate acquired an 18th century chateau in Bordeaux with Wohlstetter and Sloan installed as new owners. Chateau Bouscaut was the second most beautiful vineyard in Bordeaux, Sloan proclaimed, second, he said, because he didn't want to boast. Among the many American guests who flocked to visit, his favorite was Mary Lindsay, whom he overheard saying to her husband, then mayor of NYC, "John, if I have to see one more vineyard, I'll kill myself." To Sloan's eternal regret, Bouscat was sold in 1980. Mayor Lindsay brought Sloan onto the board of the Vivian Beaumont Theatre in 1984. At that time, according to Andre Bishop, current artistic director, "Nobody would give you a nickel for the Beaumont." It is now one of the leading theatrical companies in New York, if not the world. Mr. Sloan served on the Board until his death on Thursday. In 1977, Sloan joined the Board of Trustees of the New York Blood Center, of which he was Chairman from 1993 to 2000, nominating his successor, Howard Milstein. In January 2013, a congressional extension prepared by Representative Carolyn Maloney in recognition of Mr. Sloan's 15 years of distinguished service and dedication to NYBC's mission, was entered into the congressional record. She cited his humanitarian status and commended his leadership and tireless advocacy. For several years, he presided as Chairman of Northside Center for Child Development, founded by Kenneth and Mamie Clarke, earning a colleague's recent comment, "There was a time this place wouldn't have existed without Howard Sloan." He and his wife are to be honored for their dedication to Northside at a gala in May 2017. Howard Sloan died of kidney failure in Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital on January 21, 2016. Handsome as a film star, he will be remembered for his elegance and extraordinary wit. He is survived by his wife, Barbara; two daughters, Kathryn Roth of Weston, Massachusetts, Gillis Cone of Woodbury, Connecticut; a son, Douglas Sloan, of Palm Beach; a stepdaughter, Paulette Bartlett Robinson, of Los Angeles, and four grandchildren. Interment will be private and a memorial service will take place at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Wednesday, February 10th. 1/3

OPPENHEIMER--Inge (Goldschmidt), 86, of Floral Park, New York (formerly of Forest Hills) died after a brief illness in Honolulu, Hawaii on January 24, 2016, surrounded by her loving family. Beloved wife of the late Ernst Oppenheimer. Cherished daughter of the late Elfriede and Rudolph Goldschmidt and sister of the late Gunther Goldschmidt. Devoted mother of Marsha and David, mother- in-law of Paul and Andrea, cherished Oma of Rachel, Alex, Michael, and Samuel, loving Aunt to Eric, Guy and Lisa. Born in Kassel, Germany, Inge survived the Holocaust and immigrated to the United States in 1949. She met her husband in New York City where they lived for 60 happy years of marriage. She received Bachelor's and Master's Degrees from Queens College (Phi Beta Kappa), and worked as a teacher and librarian at John Bowne High School. She was a Gallery Educator and a member of the Speakers Bureau at the Museum of Jewish Heritage NYC. A graveside funeral will be held on Monday February 1, 2016 at 12:00 noon at Beth El Cemetery, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Donations in Inge's memory may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage in NYC. Read Inge's story at: http://comingofagenow.org/ survivor-stories/inges- story/inges-story-page-1/ 1/3

LONDON--Phyllis, beloved wife of Ira, loving mother of Roberta Silverstein, Elyssa London and Suzanne Corbin. Proud and devoted grandmother of her eight grandchildren. Died peacefully on January 29, 2016. 1/3

BERENBAUM--Alan, 64, a computer scientist, educator and renaissance man, died of an aggressive variety of T-cell lymphoma on January 27 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. He is survived by his devoted partner of 43 years, Eileen M. Lach, and his loving sisters May Berenbaum and Diane Berenbaum. Mr. Berenbaum, who earned his advanced degree in computer science from Princeton, spent more than 25 years as a scientist at Bell Labs, and most recently was the senior architect designing chips for Microchip Technologies. Holder of several patents, he also taught at The Cooper Union. To his extended circle of friends, Alan is remembered as an intoxicating, incisive conversationalist, at ease with subjects from quantum physics to Formula One racing to the absurdities of today's politics. He wore his brilliance with grace and humor. A celebration of his life and spirit will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 1:30pm on Friday, January 29. 1/3

FAIRBAIRN--William Todd III, died on January 10, 2016 in Sarasota, Florida at the age of 80. Beloved husband of Ursula for 37 years, proud and loving father of Joyce Sjoberg (Kari), William Todd Fairbairn IV (Kelley), and Mary Morgan (George). Adoring grandfather of Ceara, Melanie, Matthew, Latham, Alexander, Beatrice, and Anabelle. Son of the late William Todd Fairbairn Jr. and Mary Elizabeth Latham. Brother of the late Latham Todd, Anne Fairbairn, and Patti Gibney. Uncle to wonderful nieces and nephews. Friend and colleague to many. He lived life fully with passion, energy, and style. As a boy chorister at the Choir School of St. John the Divine, he sang a solo at the funeral of Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, a U.S. Marine, an IBM executive for 24 years, a serial entrepreneur, a long term relationship with Bach Choir of Bethlehem as singer, board member and supporter, long term member of the Amateur Comedy Club in NYC as his father and step- grandfather had been, and an active community board member in Scarsdale, NYC, Bethlehem and Sarasota. He loved language and words of every form-crosswords, all kinds of word puzzles, limericks, gifting books, reading books with grandchildren and more. So it was no surprise that after returning to NYC in 1996, he enrolled full time in Bill Esper's two year Acting Program and upon graduation, with his deep resonant voice, played numerous stage parts including leading roles in The Late Henry Moss, Cockfighters, Buried Child, Merchant of Venice, The Play About Henry, Long Day's Journey into Night as well as playing Lear in three productions of King Lear. Bill was known for his wonderful, witty sense of humor, his kind heart, his charm and elegance and his broad range of interests. He loved water of all kinds-the ocean, the bay, rivers and lakes. There will be a memorial gathering in Sarasota, Florida on Saturday, April 16 and a service at St. Bart's Episcopal Church, 325 Park Ave. at 50th St., NYC on Friday, April 29 at 11am (visitation and reception before and after). In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in his memory may be made to either the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation (www.themmrf.org/donate) or Comfort Zone Camp (www.comfortzone camp.org). Bill had a big aura and lifted us up with it. We will all miss him deeply. 1/3

KAPLAN--Richard D. The Board and staff of The New York Stem Cell Foundation (NYSCF) mourn the death of our longtime friend Richard D. Kaplan, whose generous support a decade ago played a critical role in starting NYSCF, and whose enthusiastic support of our mission never wavered. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Edwina Sandys; his sisters, Joan K. Davidson, Elizabeth K. Fonseca and Mary Kaplan; his stepsons, Mark P. Dixon and Hugo P. Dixon, and his step-granddaughter, Atalandi M. Dixon. Susan L. Solomon, CEO, New York Stem Cell Foundation 1/3

KRAMBERG--Joachim, died January 13 just two weeks shy of his 102 birthday. Beloved father of Andre and Robert, grandfather of Julia and Ryan, father-in-law of Pamela and uncle of Abe and David. He was born in Tarnopol, Poland January 27, 1914. Holocaust survivor who came to the United States in 1951, bought Maple View Farm in Southington, CT where he learned to raise chickens. Moved the family to New York in 1962 where he became a successful licensed electrical contractor. A remarkable man who exemplified perseverance and a positive attitude, he will be sorely missed by all who knew him. 1/3

JAFFEE--Dwight M.,passed away peacefully on Thursday, January 28, 2016, in San Francisco, CA. He was 72 and lived in Berkeley, CA. Dr. Jaffee was the Willis Booth Professor of Banking, Finance, and Real Estate and Co-Chairman of the Fisher Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the Haas School of Business, University of California, Berkeley. In the early 1990s, he led a joint project between the Haas School of Business and the Graduate School of Management, St. Petersburg University, to establish St. Petersburg's first post-Soviet era school of business. Prior to joining the Haas School of Business in 1991, Dr. Jaffee was a professor of Economics at Princeton University from 1968 to 1990. Dr. Jaffee was an expert on mortgage markets, banking, risk and catastrophe insurance, and international trade. Most recently, he testified in front of Congress and the SEC involving Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae, and the recent banking and housing crisis. He was also an advisor to many central banks throughout Europe. He was the author of more than seven books and 171 papers in the fields of money and banking, finance, and risk and catastrophe insurance. He received many awards, including the 2007 Robert I. Mehr Award from the Journal of Risk and Insurance. Dr. Jaffee will always be known for his mentorship of countless undergraduate and graduate students at both Princeton and Berkeley. Dwight M. Jaffee was born in Chicago on February 7, 1943, to Gertrude and Woodrow Jaffee and grew up in Chicago. He received his B.A. from Northwestern University in 1964 and Ph.D. in Economics from MIT in 1968. In 1997, he married Lynne LaMarca Heinrich, a Senior Consultant and Principal of Marts & Lundy and an Instructor at the Haas School of Business. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his mother, Gertrude of Boca Raton; daughter, Elizabeth, known as Betsy, of Washington, D.C.; son Jonathan of Santa Monica; and two grandchildren. Known for his connoisseurship of fine wine, love of travel, hiking in the hills of Marin County, and loving friendships, Dwight will be missed by many. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that gifts be directed to the Dwight M. Jaffee (1968) Endowed Fund for Graduate Students at MIT, c/o Advancement Office, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139. 1/3

MAXIM--Pearl T.,died on January 24th in Manhattan. Caring and devoted daughter of Benjamin and Sara Tessler. Beloved wife of the late Leslie Maxim. Loving sister, cherished aunt and dear friend to many. A memorial service will be held on March 16, 2016 at 3:30pm at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Pearl's memory to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Sol. Sol Schwartz, of Sarasota, Florida passed away on December 25, 2015 at the age of 84. Sol was a gifted and prolific artist, the founder of the nationally acclaimed Options college counseling program, a talented musician, a dedicated art teacher and guidance counselor at Sheepshead Bay High School. Sol was the de facto "artist in residence" at Tanglewood Music Center in the Berkshires where he created the iconic graphic of Seiji Ozawa now immortalized on Tanglewood's poster. His work has been exhibited at the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, MA, at the Massachusetts College of Art in Boston, numerous galleries, and is to be featured in an upcoming show at Wigmore Hall, London. A selection of his art can be viewed at www.solschwartz.com. The son of Ukrainian Jewish immigrants, Sol grew up on Manhattan's Lower East Side. As a child, he lugged wet wash up tenements to his father's laundry's customers. Sol started drawing at five. He entered New York City's High School of Music and Art. By 16 Sol had joined the New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra. He starred in the play "Tomorrow the World" as a teen. At 35 he studied cello and played in a quartet, and at 60 learned jazz piano. He studied art at Brooklyn College with New York School artists Mark Rothko, Ad Reinhardt, Alfred Russell, and Robert Jay Wolff. Following his graduation in 1952, he taught art and, after receiving a Master's degree in Counseling, served as a guidance counselor at Sheepshead Bay High School. Frustrated by the limited college and financial aid resources available to his students, Schwartz created a program to help the students explore options, navigate applications and obtain aid. Without assistance from the public school administration, Schwartz designed the Options program, obtained mainframe computer access, and researched college and aid data nationwide. He integrated a culture of participation and giving back: seniors worked and assisted the younger students in the Options office. It was the first of its kind in the country. After Options was instituted, students gained entrance to elite universities, graduated without debilitating debt, and achieved significant careers in the arts, investment banking, teaching, medicine and public health. Sol's Options program relocated to New York City's Goddard Riverside in 1985 where Sol built it into the gold standard college access program that today is a key partner to Michelle Obama's Reach Higher Initiative. The program remains as Sol intended it: non-profit, free of charge, available to all, providing the finest level of college and financial aid counseling services, all delivered free with one proviso, that Options' recipients give back to others when they can. After retiring from the school system, Sol returned to his first love: drawing. Combining his love of art with his love of music, theatre and dance, Sol began bringing a sketchbook to performances. Through the years he has sketched Andre Previn, Itzhak Perlman, Emanual Ax, Seiji Ozawa, Yo-Yo Ma, James Levine, Kurt Mazur, Katherine Dunham, Savion Glover, Mark Morris, the Juilliard and Emerson string quartets and others in performance. Sol said he drew during performances to convey "the spirit of the concert that ineffable nature of a great performance. "His art is published in the "Drawing Music" series and other books, all of artists drawn in performance. Sol's work is in many of the performers' homes. His art often includes a written comment from performers, such as cellist Sharon Robinson, who wrote "Sol, thank you for capturing my soul." The unique nature of Sol's art - artists captured in performance - is reflected in the dual introductions to his first book, Drawing Music: The Tanglewood Sketchbooks, with one introduction by Joel Smirnoff, the Juilliard String Quartet's first violinist, who wrote "Schwartz has captured the unique stage and musical personality of each performer. And the sound of music permeates the atmosphere of each portrait...As performers, we as artists are ever grateful that Sol Schwartz has helped our expression linger in the air yet a moment longer. We celebrate him for his work and for his musicality," and the other introduction by art critic Colin Eisler, who wrote "Sol's lyrical lines pay homage to the musician... retracing the mysterious union of individual, instrument and passion...[his] pages let us share the collective joy of hearing and seeing music made, we the beneficiaries of his arresting lines in all their ecstatic freedom and harmony." Sol was dedicated to helping people experience the joy of learning. He was a donor to many organizations, including Shakespeare & Company, Children's Book Project, Theater for a New Audience, Kids4Harmony, Norman Rockwell Museum, Tanglewood, Jacob's Pillow, Ringling School of Art and Design, the Guitar Society, Asolo State Theater, La Musica, Perlman Music Program and the Florida Studio Theater. He also quietly helped many others when he saw an opportunity. The force of his interest in people and life, and his determination to help others was palpable. Sol was a loving husband to his first wife Lillian, a devoted father to Risa and David, and a delighted grandfather to John Cortner. After Lillian's death in 1999, Sol married Elayne P. Bernstein, who shared his passion for the arts and generosity, introducing him to Shakespeare & Company in Lenox. MA where he served as a trustee. In addition to his immediate family, Sol is survived by several cousins and countless friends who will deeply miss him. Memorial services will be held in Sarasota, FL on February 13 at 2pm and in Lenox, MA during the summer of 2016. Condolences may be sent to the family at P.O. Box 73, Lenox, MA 01240. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Sol's honor to the Children's Book Project (www.children sbookproject.org, 3433 21st Street, San Francisco, CA 94110), Shakespeare & Company (www.shakespeare.org, 70 Kemble Street, Lenox, MA 01240) and Kids4Harmony (www.berkshirechildren.org, 480 West Street, Pittsfield, MA 01201). 1/3

HUDNER--Hope Freeman. Artist, Designer, Mother and Friend. Hope F. Hudner died at home in Little Compton, RI on January 14, 2016 following a thirteen month battle with glioblastoma multiforme, a form of brain cancer. Hope is survived by her husband of 40 years, Michael, and her daughter, Bay, who were deeply involved as caregivers and comforters during the past year, and were at her side at the time of her peaceful passing. Hope is also survived by her aunt, Judy Freeman N. Gross; brothers, Ambassador Charles "Chas" W. Freeman, Jr. (Margaret Carpenter) and Robert P. Freeman (Inge Reist); their five children and nine grandchildren (Hope's grand-nieces and -nephews); siblings-in-law, Mr. Kennedy Hudner (Jennifer), Ms. Cornelia Futterman (Michael), and Ms. Kristina Beitman (Harty), and their five children. Hope was born on January 11, 1951 in Nassau, The Bahamas, and lived there until age 10, then alternating time in Southern California with years in Providence and Bristol, RI. Hope was predeceased by her son, Michael Ripley ("Rip") Hudner, and her parents (father, Charles Wellman Freeman, and mother, Carla Park Freeman, who died when Hope was 20 months old). Hope was largely raised by her two sets of deceased grandparents, Hovey T. and Marjorie W. Freeman of Providence and Bristol, and Edward and Fentress K. Park of Wollaston, MA and Roaring Brook, MI. Hope graduated from The Lincoln School, Providence (1969), Smith College (1973), and also acquired an MFA from New York University. The family lived in New York City from 1974 through 1994, and then resided in Little Compton and Providence, RI. Hope was an accomplished artist and designer with a portfolio including work in graphic, interior, jewelry, and apparel design. These efforts led to her 2013 creation of Hope Hudner Designs, focused on elegant silk infinity scarves. Hope was deeply involved in Rhode Island public service, including, at various times, board and/or development responsibilities at Moses Brown School, Women & Infants Hospital, Rhode Islanders Sponsoring Education (RISE), RISD Museum, Perennial Planters, The National Society of the Colonial Dames of America (Rhode Island), and Providence Preservation Society. Hope's social involvements included membership in the Providence Art Club, Colony Club of New York City, Lyford Cay Club, Sakonnet Golf Club, and Sakonnet Point Club. Hope had great admiration for the natural world and actively cultivated a sense of wonder: she was a faithful student of plants and flowers (as evidenced by the thousands of bulbs planted across Rhode Island, Maine, and New York); she loved sailing with her family and friends (countless excursions on Narragansett Bay and longer trips to Maine, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, and Ireland number among the most special); and her keen curiosity led her to explore the far corners of the world, from Spain and Taiwan at age 18 to Antarctica at 49, covering every other continent and many countries in between. Hope had enormous energy, deep intelligence, natural grace, and remarkable warmth. She believed that life presented endless opportunity to learn, remarking on the tenth anniversary of her son's death that, "Each time it rains in our lives, we are given an opportunity for further growth. I am grateful for the challenges in my life as chances to grow and blossom." Hope faced her illness with the same fortitude and poise. While she was indeed a lifelong learner, Hope was perhaps most notable as a teacher of these invaluable lessons to the rest of us. Hope felt a profound duty to embrace everyone she encountered with love and kindness, and she shared this love of people and life like water from a fire hose. All within range were enriched by her presence and generosity of spirit. Hope inspired people to think lovingly and boldly on behalf of the larger community, themselves, and their friends, prompting many to find more inside themselves to enhance their own lives and those of others. A college classmate of Bay's said it beautifully in a recent note to Hope: "You feature prominently as an inspiration for the life I want to live-to pursue my interests, to live fully and with panache, to spend time in nature, and, most of all, to be kind to people. I know I am just one of the many, many people you affect in this way!" A celebration of Hope's life will be held in Little Compton in early June on a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in Hope's memory be made to: the Rip Hudner Memorial Fund at Moses Brown School, Providence; Dr. Patrick Wen's Research in Neuro-Oncology at Dana Faber Cancer Institute, Boston; or a charity of your choice. Above all, the family encourages you to remember Hope by engaging with the world through love and kindness. 1/3

SOMMER--Evelyn M.,91, on January 27, 2016. She worked full-time as a patent attorney for over 60 years, until 10 days before her death. Devoted to her husband of 57 years, Rudolph Sommer, who predeceased her. She leaves three children, Peter Sommer, Cathy Iselin, and Tim Sommer, as well as three grandchildren, Adele, John, and Lucy. Graveside service 2pm, Sunday, January 31, at Spring Grove Cemetery in Darien, CT. Donations may be made in her memory to Cambridge Friends School Playscape, Cambridge Friends School, 5 Cadbury Road, Cambridge, MA 02140. 1/3

RAMOND--Mary Minter Patterson, of New York City, NY, died on Wednesday, January 20, 2016 at her home. She was born on April 9, 1933 in Rocky Mount, VA. She graduated from Hollins College in Roanoke, VA, and attended Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico in Mexico City, Mexico and Universidad Nacional de San Marcos in Lima, Peru. She is survived by her son, Nicholas, Nicholas' wife, Nandini and her grandson, Jackson of Salt Lake City, UT; her sister, Alice Newbill of Wirtz, VA and brother, Dr. Abram Patterson of Roanoke, VA. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Charles. K. Ramond. Mary made a career writing about and promoting business in the Caribbean and Central America, first with her monthly newsletter, Caribbean Report, and later in a number of publications, including Forbes magazine, through her business, Caribbean Business Development. But, what Mary really did was live life to the fullest. She took on every challenge and enjoyed each moment whether it was canoeing down the Amazon, running out of fuel while flying over Mexico or just playing her weekly tennis match. She will be missed by all those who knew her. 1/3

SMITH--Howard, passed away on January 28, 2016 at the age of 85. Devoted husband of the late Reverend Elsie Smith, beloved father of Jean Smith (and Rodnie Nelson), Howard Smith, Jr. (and Pamela Hakim) and Lilla Smith (and Dale Goncher). Proud grandfather of Christopher, Hannah and Natalie. A lifelong resident of Brooklyn, he graduated from Choate and Princeton University. After service in the U.S. Army, he joined Virginia Dare Extract Co., a manufacturer of flavors which was founded by his grandfather. In 1961 he became President of Virginia Dare and retired as Chairman in 2009. Smith had a deep interest in the delivery of health care services in Brooklyn. He joined the Board of Lutheran Medical Center, now NYU Lutheran Medical Center, in 1963 and was elected chairman in 1966. Among many significant accomplishments, he spearheaded the move and expansion of Lutheran Medical Center to a converted factory building and facilitated the creation of the Sunset Park Family Health Center, which grew into one of the largest community health centers in the country. Under the aegis of LMC, he managed the creation of Shore Hill, a rent subsidized apartment complex for senior citizens and later Harbor Hill, another facility for the elderly. He oversaw the development of Lutheran Augustana Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation adjacent to Lutheran Medical Center and established Health Plus PHSP, provider of community based health and medical services. In 2004 he retired as Chairman after more than 41 years of leadership. In 1976 he joined the Board of the United Hospital Fund of New York, the nation's oldest federated charity, and served as chair for nearly two decades. He was a member and past chairman of the boards of the Brooklyn Public Library and the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation and past vice chairman of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. Smith was a director of the Dime Savings Bank of New York until its merger with Washington Mutual in 2002. He is a past director and past president of the Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association of the United States and a past director of the International Food Industry Suppliers Association. Additionally, he organized and served as the chairman of the United Lutheran Appeal for six years and was an active member of the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd for over 75 years. A true visionary who embodied the ideals of civic involvement and volunteer service, he made a lasting impact on his community and will be missed by all he touched. Visiting Tuesday, February 2, 4:00-8:00pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Funeral Service Wednesday, February 3, 10:00am at Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, 7420 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lutheran Augustana Center, 5434 Second Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11220 or United Hospital Fund, 1411 Broadway, 12th Floor, New York, NY 10018. 1/3

BRZECHFFA--Leszek, died suddenly on January 14, 2016. He is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years, Magdalena; his son, Peter (Lisa), his granddaughter, Camille; and his brother, Jerzy Brzechffa. As a five year old in 1940, he was deported by Russia to the Steppes of Kazakhstan from Lwov, Poland, with his mother, Bronislawa, grandmother, and one year old brother. They remained there for six years. His father, Roger, had been one of the 14,000 Polish army officers shot and buried in the Katyn massacre in the same year. He returned to Poland after the war with his family. He graduated with a Master's degree in chemistry from the Gdansk Polytechnic Institute. He met and married Magdalena, also a chemist in 1958. In July 1967, he defected from Poland with his wife and son and successfully immigrated to America within four months. In December 1967, he found a permanent position as a research scientist at Sandoz Pharmaceuticals and retired in 1995. He was a very caring, loving husband, father and grandfather. He loved life, always smiled, was extremely positive and friendly to all he met. He was passionate about sailing, tennis, opera and traveling around the world with his lovely wife. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, February 6, 2016 at 11am, at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ. 1/3

MUNOZ--Michael Henry, M.D.,64, passed away in the early morning hours of Tuesday, January 19, at his home in Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey. He was battling a rare blood disorder known as amyloidosis. Michael was born on February 14, 1951 at Fitkin Memorial Hospital in Neptune, New Jersey. He grew up in Colts Neck, New Jersey, where he helped his family run the Colts Neck General Store. He graduated from Peddie School, Syracuse University, and received his medical degree and Masters of Public Health from Harvard Medical School. He was a diplomat of the American Board of Ophthalmology, a Diplomat of the National Board of Medical Examiners, and a Fellow of The Academy of Ophthalmology. He was a Lieutenant in the United States Public Health Service. Michael had a large collection of comic books dating back to his childhood. He also was an avid collector of antique cars and frequently attended car shows. He enjoyed jazz, astronomy, and old war movies. He was predeceased by his parents, William and Frances Munoz, and his older brother, Eric Munoz, M.D. He is survived by his wife, Andrea Joy Munoz, their children, Daniel, Rachel, and William, his sister Wendy Lerrick, and numerous nieces, nephews, and cousins. Donations can be made to The Valley Chabad Friendship Circle of Woodcliff Lake, NJ or The Amyloidosis Foundation. 1/3

WALRATH--Dale Robert, of Manhattan, NY and formerly Wilton, CT, died on December 31, 2015 at home, at the age of 94. He was a World War II veteran, Mad Man, and devoted husband and father, who succumbed to Alzheimer's after a 12-year dignified struggle. An exemplar of the Greatest Generation, he was raised on a farm in Ohio, graduated from Ohio Wesleyan on scholarship, enlisted in the Army in 1943, and fought on the Western Front throughout Germany, receiving the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Purple Heart before his honorable discharge in 1945. He moved to Connecticut in 1956, embarking on a 33-year career on the creative side with J. Walter Thompson in Manhattan. During his tenure at Thompson he helped develop the "Built Ford Tough" campaign and pioneered broadcast shoots in California. He was the most selfless of men, active in the community post-retirement, while caring for an ailing spouse for years. Survivors include his son Christopher Bret and daughter Rosalind Anne, both of Manhattan, and three grandchildren, Margot, Victoria and Amanda. His courage, dignity, sacrifice for others, vitality, kindness, and extraordinary decency are treasured by all who knew him. 1/3

MILLINGER--Harvey, 99, passed away peacefully at home, in the company of his family, on January 25, 2016. Loving husband of Sylva Dee, and father of Bruce (Xiao-Fang) and Donald (Gary Clinton). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Temple Sinai of Roslyn, Roslyn Heights, NY. He was a kind and gentle man, and family and friends were exceptionally fortunate to have shared his life for so many years. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

JOHNSON--J. Robert. Age 79, died January 14, 2016, of complications of Parkinson's Disease in Charlotte, NC. Born and raised in New York City, Bob was a graduate of Manhattan's Stuyvesant High School and went on to attend the University of Pennsylvania where he was a member of the Sigma Chi Fraternity and the Sphinx Senior Society, the oldest and most prestigious honor society of the University of Pennsylvania. Upon his graduation from Penn in 1958, he went on to earn his Juris Doctorate degree from New York University's School of Law and was a captain in the United States Coast Guard. Mr. Johnson practiced law in New York City before finding his true calling on Wall Street. Mr. Johnson's career began at Kuhn Loeb which later merged with Lehman Brothers in 1977. He was a partner at Lehman Brothers which was the pinnacle of his work life. He absolutely loved the camaraderie of his Lehman partners and associates and retired shortly after the "Great House of Lehman" merged with Shearsonmerican Express in 1984. In the ensuing years he pursued business ventures, was active in various charities and loved following his grandchildren's sporting adventures. A lifelong New Yorker, Bob moved to Charlotte, NC to be closer to his two daughters and his grandchildren. He is survived by his son Hal Johnson of Mill Valley, CA and Telluride, CO, his daughters, Brooks Johnson and Jennifer Miller of Charlotte, NC and his eight grandchildren: Reilly and Summer Johnson, Chase and Dylan Johnson, Mitchell Morrow and Cole, Cade and Cameron Miller. He is also survived by his sister Carole Bayer of Tucson, AZ and his many relatives in Gothenburg, Sweden. No services are planned but the family will come together to celebrate his life this summer per his request. 1/3

GINSBERG--Robert K.,died peacefully on January 26, 2016 at age 91. He was a devoted and beloved husband, father and grandfather and an accomplished professional engineer. Born May 23, 1924 in New York City to Bill and Tania Ginsberg, he was educated at Lincoln School and Yale University and served as a Lieutenant (jg) in the United States Navy during World War II, seeing extensive combat in the Pacific. He was a lifelong New Yorker who practiced engineering as principal in the firm William Ginsberg Associates, and he was for more than five decades a national leader in the design and construction of newspaper production facilities. He is survived by his beloved wife of 37 years, Nellie Wilson. He was predeceased by his first wife, Helen (1926-71) and is survived by their three children, Nina (Charles Smith) of Richmond, CA, William (Ellen Kelly) of New Haven, CT and John (Kathleen) of New York City. He is also survived by his grandchildren (Alex Smith, Susan Smith Emberley, Emily Ginsberg Dellisant, Julian Ginsberg, Connor Ginsberg, and Nina Ginsberg) and many other dear family members. A superb whistler, he lived with song in his heart and on his lips throughout his nine decades of loves and laughs and friends and joys. Gentle, kind and loving, he will be forever missed. A memorial service will be announced. 1/3

FAIRBAIRN--William III. The Amateur Comedy Club notes with sorrow the passing of its esteemed senior member, William Fairbairn III on January 10th, 2016. Bill's bold and glowing presence made us merrier and made us better. Deepest condolences to his devoted wife, Ursula. 1/3

OPPENHEIMER--Inge. We deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, Inge. We had a close and devoted friendship for almost six decades as we raised our families and enjoyed each other's children and grandchildren. We will miss her greatly. Susi Leiter and Barbara Marks 1/3

BROWN--Ann Fitzpatrick, of Stockbridge, MA, age 66, died peacefully at home January 28th. Beloved mother of Alexander, sister of Nancy, aunt of Casey, creator of Blantyre Relais, her joie de vivre, generosity and elegant spirit will be deeply missed as will the love and light she shared with all. Calling hours February 7th, 3pm-5pm at Blantyre, Lenox, MA. Service on February 8th at 2pm, First Congregational Church, Stockbridge, MA. To view the full obituary go to: finnertyandstevens.com 1/3

PELL--Beatrice Lynette (nee Harber), 95, of Somers, NY, died peacefully in her sleep on January 28, 2016. She is survived by Leonard Pell, her devoted husband of 74 years, dear sister Ruth Drucker (Bernard Gross) of Fort Lee, NJ, beloved children JoAnn Pearlman (Neil) of Somers, NY, Diane Maude Brossoie of Montross, Virginia, and Owen Pell (Pearl) of New York City, and cherished grandchildren and great-grandchildren Seth Pearlman (Jamie), Melissa Miller (Jonathan), James Brossoie, Jason Harris, Nathan Pell, Adam Pell, and Samantha Pearlman, Michelle Pearlman, Maxwell Miller, David Miller, and Alaric Puebla. Bea's energy, intelligence, humor and zest for life were apparent to all who knew her. Her family and friends will miss her deeply, and remember her with great love and affection. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY on Sunday, January 31, 2016 at 10:00am. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Annette. A passion for music set Annette Kaufman on a fairy-tale course from North Dakota to a conservatory in NYC where she met and fell in love with Louis Kaufman, married him at the age of 18-and seldom left his side for the next 62 years. Mr. Kaufman, a Hollywood legend, played principal violin in over 500 films including Casablanca and Gone with the Wind. In his 2003 memoir, A Fiddler's Tale, he wrote that upon his proposal of marriage, Annette replied that she would like to be his accompanist. For the next 62 years, she was. They lived in Los Angeles, CA in a house designed for them by Lloyd Wright where, at the age of 101, Mrs. Kaufman died peacefully on January 25, 2016. The Kaufmans were well known in the Los Angeles pre-and post-war cultural scene. They were the first collectors of Milton Avery and, being softhearted and generous, helped many struggling painters during Depression-era America. In Brussels after the war, they were shown an obscure piece of music by Vivaldi, The Four Seasons; Mr. Kaufman became the first person to record it. A generous benefactor to many cultural institutions including the Library of Congress, the National Portrait Gallery and the Portland Art Museum, Annette was a vivid raconteur of a time in Europe and Los Angeles that, while largely faded from memory, lived on in her ebullient recounting of it. 1/3
VERBY--Stanley M. 11/12/17 - 2/2/14 May 27th would be our 75th wedding anniversary. Love and miss you more each day. Marjorie 1/3

MANBER--Malcolm Manuel, 89, passed away on January 23, 2016 in New York City. He was born on September 10, 1926 in Chelsea, MA to Gustave and Ida Manber and grew up in New York City. Beloved father of Susan and David Manber, grandfather of Max and Sarina Abraham and brother of Edna Dressner, Malcolm was married for 49 years to Vivienne Marianne Schulman and was a resident of New York City and Rhinebeck, NY. He served as an Army radio operator during World War II and later attended the Columbia Missouri School of Journalism. He enjoyed a renowned career as a science writer at the Bayonne Times, The Newark Evening News, Medical World News and Physicians Weekly. Among many notable articles, Mr. Manber published one of the earliest accounts of the world's first artificial heart transplant performed by Dr. Robert Jarvik. Mr. Manber and his wife took great pleasure in being founding members of the Beekman Arms Antique Market in Rhinebeck where their business, Victorian Cupboard, specialized in English pottery for more than 35 years. Special thanks to the hospice team at NYU Langone for making his last days with family and friends peaceful and serene. Donations in Mr. Manber's name may be made to the American Cancer Society. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

LONDON--Phyllis. Our hearts go out to Ira and his family. We will miss our beautiful friend. She was charismatic, witty and wise. Her joy for life never diminished. Carole and Jack, Helen and Larry and Adrianne 1/3

GROEL--Berdine, 80, of New Vernon, NJ, passed away peacefully at home on January 24, 2016. Berdine was predeceased by his beloved wife Susan. Berdine is survived by his daughter, Jennifer G. Beimfohr (Douglas); son, Frederick C. Groel (Pinelopi); grandchildren, Margaret, Emily, Katharine, Lucy, Maxwell and Christopher; and sister, Marjory Ward (James). A memorial service will be held at The First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, 2 Lee's Hill Road, New Vernon, on Saturday, February 6th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon or the Princeton Class of 1957 Classmate Fund, c/o Classmate Fund President, Sheppard H.C. Davis, Suite 1000, 401 Atlantic Avenue, Virginia Beach, VA 23451. Condolences for the family may be offered online: bradleyfuneralhomes.com. 1/3
BERZON--Betty. 1928 - 2006 Gone ten years now. Still loved - Still missed. 1/3

SMITH--Jeri Binder, of New York City, mother and actress, dies at 91 peacefully at home, surrounded by love. She was an extraordinary woman and will be deeply missed! Jeri had a long career in show business, culminating at age 89 with her unforgettable Esurance commercial. Jeri was a devoted mother to her three daughters, Marla, Andrea, and Pamela and to their husbands. She is also survived by five loving grandchildren, her sister and her three nieces. Following a private graveside service, the family will observe Shiva on Sunday, January 31 at Jeri's apartment in New York City from 5-8pm and on Monday, February 1 at the home of Pamela Fisher in Mahwah, NJ from 4-8pm. 1/3

HALPER DICKSON--Sari. January 30, 2009. Seven years. An extraordinary mother, wife, sister and daughter. Sorely missed and adored by Zachary, Aleks and Diana, Barbara, Shauna, John, Joe. She is our song. 1/3

LEVY--Bernard, passed away peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 98. He was born in New York City on February 10, 1917 and attended New York University. Bernard was predeceased by his wife of 69 years, Laura Redfield Levy, who shared a love of life, travel, and dogs. He is survived by his sons Dean (Janice), Jonathan (Carol), and daughter Marcia Roesch (Geoffrey), and his seven grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren). Bernard was one of the most prominent dealers in early American furniture, first as a partner in the firm of Ginsburg & Levy, founded in 1901, and then from 1973 until his death with the firm Bernard & S. Dean Levy, Inc., of New York. Over the nearly 70 years as an active dealer, he was able to acquire and place a number of the most recognizable pieces in both private and public collections. He was a friend and advisor to many of the great early collectors, many of whose gifts now form the core of major museum collections. These include The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Bayou Bend Collection, The Winterthur Museum and Historic Deerfield among many other institutions. He was always eager to share his knowledge and enthusiasm with collectors, curators, other dealers and especially his family. His eye for the very finest in Americana will be missed. Bernard was an avid and accomplished tennis player winning many local and regional tournaments. Into his seventies he remained active in competitive tennis attaining a national ranking. Anyone who played with or against him can attest to a strong will and a wicked drop shot. Also, he always had a good joke to tell and enjoyed making others laugh. He will be greatly missed. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Lewis G.,65, died Friday, January 29th at Stamford Hospital. Son of the late Edward Schwartz and Davida Schatz Edelson, Lew grew up in Meriden and West Hartford, Connecticut. He graduated from the Kingswood School (1968), Yale College (1972), and Cornell Law School. Lew began his legal career as an Assistant District Attorney in Manhattan, later becoming a litigator at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. After returning to Connecticut, Lew became a partner specializing in employment law and litigation at Schatz & Schatz, Ribicoff & Kotkin, a firm started by his maternal grandfather that later merged with Shipman & Goodwin. In 2001, Lew joined Gartner, serving as Senior Vice President, General Counsel, Corporate Secretary, and Chief Compliance Officer, where he just celebrated his 15th year. Despite his myriad academic and professional accomplishments, Lew enjoyed no job more than his years as a coach and president of the North Stamford Little League. Lew's enthusiasm and love for life was boundless. He was an avid cyclist, wine enthusiast, and lifelong Yankee fan and 30-year season ticket holder. Lew's travels brought him to dozens of countries, and his network of friends and colleagues stretches around the world. Lew's most extraordinary role was as husband to Marjorie and father to sons Ethan and Alex, all of whom survive him and cherish his memory. The burial was private. For those wishing to honor him, please consider a donation to Stamford Hospital, sharecancersupport.org, or a charity of your choice. 1/3

MAZZEO--Alberto Daniel Died peacefully at Calvary Hospital in The Bronx on January 29, 2016 after a year-long illness. He had the constant and loving support of his spouse Mitch Mondello, neighbors, friends, UN colleagues and family in Argentina and Italy. Alberto's generosity of spirit, courage and optimism was exemplified by his answer whenever anyone asked him how he was: "I'm OK, I'm getting better." And of course by his exuberant laughter and love of Malbec. In accordance with Alberto's wishes, his ashes will be scattered in the Hudson River and the Rio de la Plata, the rivers flowing through the two cities that he considered home. A memorial Mass and Interment will take place in Zaccanopoli, his ancestral home in Calabria. 1

MANDEL--Kenneth, 76, of Briarcliff Manor, NY, passed away January 26, 2016 after a courageous battle with cancer. Ken was a loving husband to his wife of 52 years, Carole Leshne Mandel, and a devoted father to his daughters Wendy, Laura, and Jodi, and their spouses Yale, Jeff, and Kenny. He loved and adored his eight grandchildren, Josh, Arielle, Taylor, Jordan, Ethan, Emma, Matthew, and Maya. He is also survived by his mother, Olga, to whom he was a devoted son, and by his brother, Richard. He graduated from New Rochelle High School and went on to study at Cornell University and New York University. Ken held an array of sales positions that showcased his people skills, intellect and wit, culminating in the successful leadership of Mandel Investments until his retirement in 2013. He loved fishing and boating with his grandchildren, playing golf, spending time with his friends, and getting to know people. His greatest love was his family, especially spending family vacations at the Jersey Shore and Hamptons. Ken had a wonderful sense of humor, a gift for storytelling, and he left a lasting impression on those he met. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

BLACKWELL KONOWITCH --Judith, 59, of Irvington, NY. Grew up in Manhasset, Long Island. She work diligently to improve education. Survived by her beloved husband and best friend Paul Konowitch, her loving children Jeffrey and Margo Konowitch, her loving mother Marie Blackwell Deppen and devoted sister Nancy Semels (Daniel). Visiting Sunday (today) 5-7pm Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. Service Monday 7:00pm Temple Beth Shalom, 740 N. Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Memorials to the Judith Blackwell Konowitch Scholarship Award, Checks should be made to the Dobbs Ferry Schools Foundation, JBK Award, DFSF Treasurer, 505 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522. 1/3

SMITH--Howard. NYU Lutheran's board and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of chair emeritus Howard Smith. As chairman of Lutheran Medical Center and Augustana Center from 1966 until 2004, Smith, who died Thursday at age 85, left an indelible legacy on southwest Brooklyn. With his friend New York City Mayor John Lindsay and the American Lutheran Church, Mr. Smith brokered the 1977 expansion and relocation of Lutheran Medical Center from 4th Avenue and 46th Street to its present location, a former warehouse at 55th Street and 2nd Avenue in Sunset Park. He facilitated the creation of the Sunset Park Family Health Center, now called NYU Lutheran Family Health Centers, the second largest federally qualified health center network in the nation. He created a lasting financial foundation for Lutheran through Health Plus, an innovative government-sponsored insurance program for low-income residents. Lutheran's sale of Health Plus to Amerigroup in 2011 created an endowment that continues to help modernize the health system. Mr. Smith, a lifelong Brooklyn resident, was chairman emeritus of the United Hospital Fund, former president of the Brooklyn Public Library Board of Trustees, and past vice president and director of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Smith received a bachelor's in chemical engineering from Princeton University and served in the U.S. Army. He served 40 years as president of Virginia Dare Extract Company, which was founded by his grandfather Bernard, and was a former director of Dime Savings Bank of New York before it merged with Washington Mutual in 2002. He is predeceased by his wife, Elsie, and survived by his three children, Howard Jr., Jean, and Lilla, and grandchildren. NYU Lutheran mourns as we celebrate Mr. Smith's life and legacy. A wake will be held at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Tuesday, February 2, at 4-8pm. Services will be held at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, 7420 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Wednesday, February 3, at 10 am. 1/3

SAWITSKY--Arthur, MD. 1/31/1916 - 5/28/2009. Happy 100th Birthday! Extraordinary father, husband, friend, physician. We wish you were here to celebrate with us. We love and miss you every day and carry you in our hearts. Love, B, KHALEM 1/3

SMITH--Howard. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the death of our chairman emeritus, a health care visionary and dedicated civic and business leader. Over six decades, Howard passionately championed innovations in hospital care and community health that are now understood broadly as essential to health reform. His ability to see opportunity and make important and timely decisions, was anchored by his deep belief in the imperative of community service. UHF benefited enormously from his skillful and steadfast leadership as our wise and caring chairman for 17 years and almost 40 years of active engagement on our board. He leaves an enduring legacy in health care and an indelible mark on his beloved Brooklyn and UHF. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children and remember with affection his wife, Rev. Elsie Smith, who shared and extended his commitment and dedication. J. Barclay Collins II Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr. President 1/3

FEINMAN--Sheldon, 89, on January 27, devoted husband of the late Beverly and Liz, beloved father of Andrew (Aviva) and Joshua (Debra); adoring grandfather of Amanda and Melissa. A special man who exemplified perseverance and positive attitude, he will be missed by all. 1/3

STREIT--Jean. January 25th we lost bright, beautiful Jean Streit, a talented actress, loving wife of the late Honorable Saul Streit, Justice of New York Supreme Court, loving mother of the late Saul Jr., warm hearted, witty friend to so many others. Memorial services to be held at Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, New York, 11am on February 12th. 1/3

MURPHY--Hon. Francis T.,died peacefully on January 27, 2016 at the age of 88 surrounded by his family. He was married to his beloved Sheila Theresa for 55 wonderful years before her death on September 28, 2014. He is survived by their five children, Timothy F. Murphy and his wife, Pamela; Eileen and her husband, Jeffrey Forsyth; Kathleen and her husband, Lance Scott; Sheila and her husband, Michael Sproule; Annemarie and her husband, Kevin Casey; and his sister Irene McInerney. He was a loving grandfather to Casey, Kaitlyn, Timothy, Matthew, Sean, Patrick, Michael, Brendan, Megan and Liam. After being honorably discharged from the U.S. Navy after World War II, he graduated from Fordham University and New York Law School. A member of the New York judiciary for 40 years, he served 15 years as a trial judge and 25 years as a Justice of the Appellate Division First Department, with the last 20 years as the Court's Presiding Justice. When he left the Court, he joined the New York law firm of Kelley, Drye and Warren as Of Counsel. Throughout his career Judge Murphy was an ardent supporter of providing full legal services and justice to the underprivileged and incarcerated. A gracious man with a generous heart and strong religious beliefs, he took counsel only from his own conscience. The loves of Tim's life were his wife, Sheila, his family, his friends and his life in the law. Friends may call on Sunday, January, 31 from 2 to 4pm and 6 to 8pm at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 575 Fowler Avenue, Pelham Manor, NY on Monday, February 1 at 10am. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Judge Murphy's name to The Province of St. Mary (for the work of the Capuchin Franciscan Friars) at 210 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10001 or donate online at: www.capuchin.org 1/3

LANEY--Christina B. Christina Bertrand Laney, age 83, of New York City died January 21, 2016. A classic "New Yorker," in every sense of the word, Christina was a native of the Upper West Side for over 50 years. She was an avid Riverside Park gardener, a frequent face at Fairway, and knew every sidewalk crack and crevasse of the Upper West Side. The daughter of Vera Federoff, of Ryazan, Russia, and Bertrand J. Laney, of New York City, Christina was born in Hankow, China, on December 28, 1932, her family fleeing China in 1940, shortly after the Japanese offensive. A true explorer, Christina traveled the world with her family, attending schools in China, Panama, El Salvador, and finally, at the University of Texas, and at New York University. It was in 1953, that Christina, in her own words, "found her Nirvana"-New York City. For over 30 years, she was involved in the entertainment industry, acting in small movie and television roles, then working behind the scenes in public relations, advertising, and film production. At United Artists, Christina was the Assistant to the Director of Special Projects for six years. She also worked for the Writer's Guild. Christina was a Vice President of Women of the Motion Picture Industry, and won their Dottie Reeves Humanitarian Award for Community Service. Christina's hobbies were manifold. Her diminutive size and powerhouse personality made her a natural spelunker. She was a member of the National Speleological Society for many years. A talented artist and poet in her own right, Christina supported Women in Motion Pictures, and the Curtain Club. She championed dozens of causes including: The Humane Society, The New York Historical Society, Sierra Club, The Wilderness Society, World Wildlife Fund, The Nature Conservancy, and the ASPCA. Christina was a lifelong volunteer for groups such as Channel 13, The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, and, for 50 years, the Riverside Park Conservancy, where she was honored for her volunteer contribution in her beloved garden on 78th Street and Riverside Drive. Before there was Google, there was Christina. A voracious reader and a fount of knowledge about a myriad of subjects, especially New York City, family and friends could always rely on Christina for an irrefutable answer. Into her 80s, Christina was a brilliant, plucky, feisty spitfire who continued to stimulate her mind by regular attendance at jazz concerts, museums, art galleries, and theater. She was a devoted sister, aunt, cousin, and friend-a tiny woman with a huge spirit, who will be deeply missed. Christina is survived by her older sister, Kera Toline Rogers of Charleston, SC; niece Catherine Anna Toline, husband Leo Lentsch; nephews, John Colin Toline, and son John, Mark Anderson Toline, wife Ann, and son North, and Paul Alexander Toline; and cousins, Barbara Laney Swenson of Hanover, New Hampshire, Ainslie Drummond of Florida, and Irene Morgan Kay of Australia. Christina's ashes will be interred in Moline, Illinois, with her parents and Russian grandmother, Barbara (Babi) Federoff. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Christina B. Laney to: Riverside Park Conservancy, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 455, New York, NY 10115. 1/3

BARNETT--John M.,passed away on Friday, January 29, 2016. He was 74. Funeral services will be conducted on Monday, February 1, 2016 at Temple Sinai, 208 Summit Ave., Summit, NJ with Interment following at Beth Israel Cemetery, Cedar Knolls, NJ. He was a Vice President for Springs Mills at its headquarters in New York City for almost 25 years. He was also a fine artist. He is survived by his wife, Diane Barnett, a daughter Jennifer (Eric) Hedrick, a son Zachary Barnett and his partner Darrin Banks, along with grandchildren Abby, Nate and Finn. Services are being handled by Ross' Shalom Chapels, 49 Whippany Road, Whippany, NJ. For more information visit: www.rosschapels.com. 1/3

HARRISON--Nora M.,on January 29, 2016 of Douglas Manor, NY. Loving mother of Robert, Lynn, and David. Dear grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of six. Loving sister of the late Jane. Calling hours at The Fairchild Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Monday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:30am at St. Anastasia RC Church (corner of Northern Blvd and 245th St.), Douglaston. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: info@lighthouseguild.org. 1/3

KELLER--Dolores Elaine, Ph.D. (nee Greenstein) of Piermont NY, born October 29, 1926, died January 29, 2016. Dr. Keller's Ph.D. from NYU, Chair of Biology, Pace University; taught Animal Behavior & Human Sexuality; pioneering Sex Therapist; researcher in microbiology, marine biology, primate behavior. Author/artist/musician. Wife of late Martin E. Keller; mother of Steven E. Keller, Ph.D. (Marjorie); late Kevin E. Keller, Ph.D. (Laurel Burns); Wendy K. Epstein, M.D. (Hon. Larry Lynn); beloved grandmother of Caroline, Daniel, Michael, Christina, Bryan, Brendan, Patrick and Emily; great-grandmother to Madelyn, Lyla, Keegan, Kevin and Brendan. Services private. 1/3

SMITH--Howard, passed away on January 28, 2016 at the age of 85. Devoted husband of the late Reverend Elsie Smith, beloved father of Jean Smith (and Rodnie Nelson), Howard Smith, Jr. (and Pamela Hakim) and Lilla Smith (and Dale Goncher). Proud grandfather of Christopher, Hannah and Natalie. A lifelong resident of Brooklyn, he graduated from Choate and Princeton University. After service in the U.S. Army, he joined Virginia Dare Extract Co., a manufacturer of flavors which was founded by his grandfather. In 1961 he became President of Virginia Dare and retired as Chairman in 2009. Smith had a deep interest in the delivery of health care services in Brooklyn. He joined the Board of Lutheran Medical Center, now NYU Lutheran Medical Center, in 1963 and was elected chairman in 1966. Among many significant accomplishments, he spearheaded the move and expansion of Lutheran Medical Center to a converted factory building and facilitated the creation of the Sunset Park Family Health Center, which grew into one of the largest community health centers in the country. Under the aegis of LMC, he managed the creation of Shore Hill, a rent subsidized apartment complex for senior citizens and later Harbor Hill, another facility for the elderly. He oversaw the development of Lutheran Augustana Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation adjacent to Lutheran Medical Center and established Health Plus PHSP, provider of community based health and medical services. In 2004 he retired as Chairman after more than 41 years of leadership. In 1976 he joined the Board of the United Hospital Fund of New York, the nation's oldest federated charity, and served as chair for nearly two decades. He was a member and past chairman of the boards of the Brooklyn Public Library and the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation and past vice chairman of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. Smith was a director of the Dime Savings Bank of New York until its merger with Washington Mutual in 2002. He is a past director and past president of the Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association of the United States and a past director of the International Food Industry Suppliers Association. Additionally, he organized and served as the chairman of the United Lutheran Appeal for six years and was an active member of the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd for over 75 years. A true visionary who embodied the ideals of civic involvement and volunteer service, he made a lasting impact on his community and will be missed by all he touched. Visiting Tuesday, February 2, 4:00-8:00pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Funeral Service Wednesday, February 3, 10:00am at Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, 7420 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lutheran Augustana Center, 5434 Second Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11220 or United Hospital Fund, 1411 Broadway, 12th Floor, New York, NY 10018. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Sylvia. (nee Solender) Age 98 of Manhattan, passed away January 30, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Louis A. Shapiro for 50 years; mother of Felice Shapiro Friedman, Nina Shapiro-Perl and Paul Shapiro; cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. A graduate of Oberlin College in 1938, a teacher at the Westbury Friends School, and leader in community arts and library programs in Westbury and Royal Palm Beach, Florida. Sylvia was a person of extraordinary character and grace, and a source of inspiration to all who knew her. Services will take place at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue on Tuesday, February 2nd at 11:00am. Contributions may be made to Metropolitan Jewish Health System, MJHS.org. 1/3

JOHNSON--Broaddus Jr.,a longtime resident of Bedford, NY, gently passed away on Tuesday, January 26th, at the age of 93. Known by family and friends as "Speed," he served as a Lieutenant in the Army Air Force and later graduated from Yale University in 1948. He worked in advertising sales at NBC in New York for most of his business career. Later he followed his calling and was ordained as a Deacon in the Episcopal Church at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in 1992. He fulfilled his responsibilities through St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford and in surrounding communities with dedication and compassion until very recently. A devoted husband, father, and grandfather, he is survived by his wife of 66 years, Kate deForest Johnson, and children, W. Macy Johnson, Andrew B. Johnson, and Kate Knapp Johnson and their families, including seven grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by all. Services will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY on Saturday, February 6th at 10:30am, followed by a reception in the Parish House at the Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Matthew's Episcopal Church. 1/3

PISCITELLI--Peter, of Bronx, NY, passed away on January 30, 2016, at the age of 85. Born and raised in the Bronx, Pete was a devoted husband and father, and a highy-respected public servant as a lawyer and lobbyist. His career dated back to service in the administrations of Mayors Robert F. Wagner, John V. Lindsay and Edward I. Koch, under whom he served as the city's chief representative in Albany as it dealt with the municipal fiscal crisis. He went on to a long career in private practice, representing such clients as the New York Hotel Association, the Broadway League of Theaters and the U.S.S. Intrepid. Pete is survived by his wife of 61 years, Frances, and his son Anthony (Skip) Piscitelli. A wake will be held on Tuesday at the Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY, from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. Friends may call on the family. Funeral Mass will take place Wednesday at 9:45am at St. Margaret of Crotona Church, 6000 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY. Burial at Calverton National Military Cemetery will be private. In lieu of flowers, Pete's family suggests donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or Calvary Hospital. 1/3
LEVINE--Carolyn M.,of Roslyn, New York on January 30, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Lee R. Levine. Mother of Ira (Betsy) and Bill (Carol). Grandmother of Rose and Ruby. 1/3

REISMAN--Donald, of Bayside, Queens and Boynton Beach, Florida, passed peacefully in his sleep Sunday morning, January 31st. Donald was a devoted husband, father, brother, grandfather, uncle and greatuncle to his adoring family. Service Tuesday, 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. 1/3

COOK--Dr. Leonard. One of the world's leading psychopharmacologists passed away Saturday, January 30, 2016 at the age of 91. He is recognized as the discoverer of several early drugs for psychiatric disorders and as a pioneer in the development of methods to identify and study drugs for treatment in psychiatry. Leonard is credited for his role in the establishment of the modern field of psychopharmacology, including his pioneering work in Central Nervous System drugs. Dr. Cook graduated from Yale University in 1951 with a PhD in pharmacology, starting his career at Smith Kline & French Laboratories, then in 1969 served as Director of Pharmacology at Hoffman La Roche, then in 1983 led the research in the Central Nervous System area for the pharmaceutical business at DuPont Merck. Schoenberg Memorial Chapel. 1/3

NEVINS--William Glasson, the son of Martha Nevins and the late Theodore Clare Nevins Jr., of Essex Fells, NJ died on Tuesday, January 26, 2016 at the age of 57. Known as Billy to most, he was a longtime resident of New York City and Nantucket Island. Billy graduated from The Choate School and Boston College with a degree in Economics. He went on to work at Lehman Brothers, where he spent 20 years primarily as a senior salesman. He was an active member of The Players Club in New York City. Billy was a founding member of Secession Golf Club, Beaufort, SC. He was a passionate art collector and was an integral part of the New York art scene. Billy is survived by his mother Martha Nevins, his brother Theodore Clare Nevins III, his sister Audrey Nevins and her husband John McNamara and his sister Martha J. Nevins and her husband Michael Pawasarat, and his vast family of close friends. The memorial service will be held February 3, 2016 at St. Peter's Church in Essex Fells, NJ at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders or The Nantucket Cottage Hospital. 1/3

PISCITELLI--Peter. Ed Koch's Saturday lunch club has lost a great friend and raconteur. Pete was a significant figure in city and state politics for six decades and a devoted colleague to all of us. He will be sorely missed. John LoCicero, George Arzt, Peter Aschkenasy and Arnie Kriss 1/3

PISCITELLI--Peter, of Bronx, NY, passed away on January 30, 2016, at the age of 85. Born and raised in the Bronx, Pete was a devoted husband and father, and a highy-respected public servant as a lawyer and lobbyist. His career dated back to service in the administrations of Mayors Robert F. Wagner, John V. Lindsay and Edward I. Koch, under whom he served as the city's chief representative in Albany as it dealt with the municipal fiscal crisis. He went on to a long career in private practice, representing such clients as the New York Hotel Association, the Broadway League of Theaters and the U.S.S. Intrepid. Pete is survived by his wife of 61 years, Frances, and his son Anthony (Skip) Piscitelli. A wake will be held on Tuesday at the Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY, from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. Friends may call on the family. Funeral Mass will take place Wednesday at 9:45am at St. Margaret of Crotona Church, 6000 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY. Burial at Calverton National Military Cemetery will be private. In lieu of flowers, Pete's family suggests donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or Calvary Hospital. 1/3

SUSSILLO--Joseph M.,on January 31, 2016. Veteran, U.S. Army. Graduate of St. John's Law School. Practicing attorney in Bay Ridge for over 35 years. Distinguished delegate at the Republican National Convention. Active in federal, state, and city republican concerns. Member of the Armand J. Starace Republican Club, Knights of Columbus Council 8048 and many other civic and fraternal organizations. Loving husband of the late Margot (nee Curley). Dear brother of the late William, Pauline, Nicholas, and Gerard. Beloved uncle to four nieces and four nephews. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 9:30am at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. 1/3

HALPIN--William Curtis, died peacefully at home on January 26 after prolonged battles with advanced prostate cancer. Born August 22, 1929, he was the son of the late John Hadden Halpin and the late Josephine Roll Young. Having attended Monclair public schools, he graduated from Dartmouth College in 1951. He served in the U.S. Air Force from 1951 to 1955 as a radar observer in B-59 sorties over North Korea. Having joined Oxford University Press in 1955, he remained for 26 years, retiring in 1981 as Executive Vice President of the New York office. Relocated to Key West, Florida, he co-founded the Real Estate Company of Key West Inc. There he was active on the boards of the Key West Art and Historical Society and the Hospice-VNA of the Florida Keys. He subsequently retired to Fort Lauderdale, FL, where he lived with his longtime partner of 21 years, Calvin Victor Temenski. They were married in 2015. He was predeceased by his parents, his brother, Robert T. Halpin of Dallas, Texas and his sister, Sally H. Knaus of Oneonta, New York and survived by his brother, the Honorable Judge Jack Halpin, ten nieces and nephews and many grand-nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date in the summer of 2016 in Essex, New York. Details to be announced. 1/3

SMITH--Howard. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mou-rns the passing of Howard Smith, former Board Chairman of Lutheran Medical Center and the United Hospital Fund, and the embodiment of volunteer leadership that defines health care in New York. Mr. Smith became Chair of Lutheran Hospital (now NYU Lutheran) in 1966, and drove its transformation into the principal health care provider in Southwest Brooklyn and the sponsor of the nation's largest hospital-based community health center, the Sunset Park Family Health Center. He also served on the Board of the United Hospital Fund for more than 25 years, including 19 as Chair. A lifelong Brooklynite-he was also Chair of the Brooklyn Public Library and its Foundation, and Vice-Chair of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and the Dime Savings Bank- Mr. Smith was unyielding in his commitment to ethics, tolerance, a more just world, and improving the health of all New Yorkers. We extend our deepest condolences to his children Howard Jr., Jean, and Lila, their spouses and children, and Howard's many friends and colleagues. Wendy Z. Goldstein, Chair, GNYHA Kenneth E. Raske, President, GNYHA Lee H. Perlman, GNYHA Bruce C. Vladeck, Ph.D., GNYHA 1/3
PISCITELLI--Peter. Connelly McLaughlin & Woloz mourns the loss of our dear friend Peter Piscitelli-a political legend and a great man. 1/3

SHERMAN--Muriel F.,95, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, February 2, 2016 in West Palm Beach, FL. She was predeceased by her late beloved husband Louis. They were married for 63 wonderful years. Muriel was a strong and vivacious woman who grew up in New York City, a daughter of the late Louis and Ida Kroman. She was a proud graduate of the second graduating class of Queens College majoring in music and education and a charter member of the Iota Alpha Pi sorority. She taught briefly in the NYC school system. Muriel was a life member of Hadassah and had many friends. She was a devoted daughter, sister, wife, mother, grandmother, great-grand- mother and aunt. She loved to read the New York Times. She raised her family in Hollis Hills, NY and in Long Beach, LI. In 1978 she moved to Boca Raton and Delray Beach with her husband. The last five years she lived independently at the Tradition Of The Palm Beaches. Muriel is survived by her sister Shirley Saperstein, sons, Rabbi Alan (Marilyn) Sherman, Michael (Ruth) Sherman and Cantor Glenn Sherman; grandchildren, Pamela (Spencer) Linden, Larry (Rachael) Sherman, Joshua (Andrea) Sherman, Laura (Avi) Fisher, Jonathan Sherman, Steven (Lisa) Sherman, Traci Sherman and fiance' Brendon Cohen, Hannah Sherman, Amy Diem, Rena Diem, Shira Diem and Ryan Schroeder; great-grandchildren, Gabby Linden, Jacob and Julia Sherman, Joseph, Emma and Jack Sherman, Lila Fisher, Jenna, Alexa and Andrew Sherman and Taeva Schroeder. Services on Thursday, February 4, 2016, 11:00am at IJ Morris Funeral Chapel, 9321 Memorial Park Rd. in West Palm Beach. A reception and shiva will be held at the Tradition Of The Palm Beaches, 4920 Loring Dr., West Palm Beach, beginning at 3:00pm on Thursday. Shiva will also be held Friday 11:00am-3:00pm at The Lexington Club, Delray Beach. 1/3

ROSENTHAL--Irwin M. The volunteers and staff of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America join with the IBD community in mourning the passing of Irwin M. Rosenthal, co-founder of CCFA, philanthropist, entrepreneur, and attorney. Motivated by his wife Suzanne's struggle with Crohn's disease, Irwin co-founded the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America. It was the combination of Irwin's tenacity, compassion and love for his wife that put CCFA on the road to success. His impact on the lives of patients with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis is immeasurable. Donations in his honor can be made to CCFA's Irwin M. and Suzanne R. Rosenthal IBD Resource Center at online.ccfa.org/ IrwinRosenthal. Our sincere condolences to his family. 1/3

MEARS--DeAnn, 83 years old, died January 31, 2016. Ms. Mears spent her life in the theatre. She was well known for her leading roles in the American Conservatory Theatre, where she played in "Tiny Alice," "Tartuffe," and "The Royal Family" among others. On Broadway she appeared in "Abelard and Heloise" with Diana Rigg, "Tiny Alice," "Too Good to be True" (standing by for Lillian Gish) and "Showboat" at City Center in 1954. She also performed in "Dear Liar" at the Roundabout Theatre with Jerome Kilty, who wrote the play. She was known for her work in films, ("Presumed Innocent" and "The Loneliest Runner") and her television work on Beacon Hill. She appeared in many episodes of "Law and Order" and acted, sometimes along with her husband, Frank Savino, (who predeceased her) in many of the fine repertory theatres in the United States. She studied with Uta Hagen. She died at her home in New Milford, CT of complications of emphysema and COPD. She will be dearly missed by all who knew her. 1/3
