MUELLER--John Cochran, 80, died on January 21, 2016. He was born in Lancaster, PA, but was a lifelong resident of New York City and Fire Island. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University (1956) and the University of Pennsylvania Law School (1959), he practiced law with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy for a number of years, during which time he also served in the U.S. Army reserve. His great love was the theater and he was the consummate theatergoer and supporter, not only attending plays but providing financial support to a number of off-Broadway plays over the years. He served on several non-profit boards, including Urban Stages and Plays for Living. He had a wonderful sense of humor, was a marvelous pianist and a very talented photographer, was a most loyal friend and possessed a gift for bringing people together. He had a magnificent collection of motion pictures on tape and disc, which he organized alphabetically by studio. He was a member of Holland Lodge No. 8, F. & A.M. and for a number of years was a member of The Players and The Yale Club of New York City. John is survived by his brother, Paul A. Mueller, Jr. and his wife, Jane, of Lancaster, and three nieces, Anne M. Leahy, Southern Pines, NC, Catherine M. Boyer, Oxford, New Zealand, and Elizabeth G. Mueller, La Jolla, CA, and four grand-nieces and a grand-nephew. He was buried in a private ceremony in Lancaster. A memorial service will be scheduled in New York City in the spring. Memorial remembrances can be made to Urban Stages, 555 8th Avenue, Room 1800, New York 10018. 1/3

LOVETT--Laurence D. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Laurence D. Lovett, who was a distinguished member of the Board for more than 45 years. Mr. Lovett served as a Managing Director from 1971-1989 and as an Honorary Director from 1989 until his death. He chaired the Executive Committee in 1975-76, served as Vice President from 1976 to 1986 and as Vice Chairman from 1986 to 1989. In addition, he was President of the Metropolitan Opera Guild from 1971 to 1979, and Guild Chairman from 1979 to 1986. He was also active in the Metropolitan Opera National Council. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Judith-Ann Corrente, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager 1/3

GROSS--Martin L. Martin L. Gross of New London, NH and Ocean Ridge, FL died on Tuesday, January 26, 2016 in Ushuaia, Argentina following a stroke suffered en route to Antarctica. He was 77 years old. Martin's adventures began in New York City where he was born on October 22, 1938. As a young child, Martin and his older brother, Woolf, were dispatched to summer camps and later to working cattle ranches in Utah during the summer months to escape the polio outbreaks that plagued New York City in the years following World War II. After high school, Martin headed north to Cambridge, MA where he attended both Harvard College and Harvard Law School, graduating from the latter in 1964. Before embarking on his first job as a law clerk in New Hampshire, Martin and his first wife, the late Caroline Lord Gross, purchased a Volkswagen pop-up camper and drove to Alaska with Martin's mother, Harriet. Harriet slept in the camper; Martin and Caroline slept outdoors in a tent. After several weeks of abysmal weather the camper was coated with a thick layer of adobe-colored mud. When the trio returned to Concord and washed the car for the first time, it was in pristine condition. Thereafter, Martin never worried much if his car was dirty. Following his clerkship, Martin joined the Concord, New Hampshire law firm of Sulloway & Hollis, P.L.L.C. from which he retired (while maintaining senior counsel status) in 2015 after more than 50 years of distinguished service to his clients and to the New Hampshire Bar. As with everything else in life, Martin viewed the practice of law as an adventure. He delighted in besting his adversaries and often developed long and lasting friendships with them. His in-house writing boot camps were legendary and his wit and charm were ever present at the office and in the courtroom. While working full-time as a Sulloway lawyer, Martin served three terms as the mayor of Concord. During these years, Martin developed a real talent for cooking. This was driven by necessity since Caroline's busy schedule at the State House meant she was often home late. Undeterred by a complete lack of training (and by a lifelong aversion to cookbooks) Martin channeled his inner top chef and produced thousands of wonderful meals for friends and family. The informal "Sunday Suppers" he enjoyed with his close friends Malcolm and Susan McLane, Liz and Dennis Hager and other dear Concord friends were a social staple. Six years after the loss of his beloved Caroline in 1993, fate intervened and Martin met his second wife, Deirdre Sheerr-Gross, architect, New London, NH. The meeting occurred at Chicago's O'Hare Airport where both were waiting to board a flight back to New Hampshire. It would turn out to be a kismet flight on United Airlines (friendly skies indeed!) with Deirdre sitting in seat 2B and Martin (who always flew coach and never paid for upgrades) inexplicably seated in seat 3B directly behind Deirdre. Seeing that seat 2A was open, Martin leaned over and graciously asked Deirdre "Can I buy you dinner?" They have been having dinner together ever since. This episode gave Martin plenty of fodder for his expansive repertoire of bad puns...."United" Airlines.... 2B or not to be.... Martin made the most of it. Six months later, in July 2000, Martin and Deirdre were married. During their 15 year marriage, Martin and Deirdre traveled the world. Despite temporary setbacks (Martin's surgeries, lost luggage, etc.) they visited South America, Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Central America and multiple European countries. This past September, Martin and Deirdre rented an Airstream trailer and toured Grand Teton and Yellowstone parks; they did not have to sleep outdoors. Over the past few years, one of Martin's happiest endeavors was building a warm winter getaway in Ocean Ridge, FL. He loved living in a house designed by his wife, Deirdre. Two weeks ago, Martin and Deirdre left for Antarctica; a trip that was to be Martin's last great adventure. While southbound on his way to Antarctica on a cruise ship he suffered a stroke and had to be transferred to a passing northbound vessel. That ship docked safely in Ushuaia (the cruise's point of origin) where Martin underwent surgery to relieve a subdural hematoma. Despite excellent care and a successful surgery, Martin contracted an infection from which he did not recover. Martin loved the spontaneity and unpredictability of travel. He would have appreciated the irony of his last great adventure. Martin is survived by his wife, Deirdre Sheerr-Gross, of New London, NH; his brother, Woolf Gross (spouse Lucy) of Arlington, VA; a nephew, William Gross, of Arlington, VA; two cousins, John and Charles Gross, both of New York City, and his brother-in-law (affectionately referred to as "hermano west," Hugh McCrystal (spouse Polly). In addition, Martin is survived by dozens of close friends including his childhood friend, Peter Soloman (who Martin always introduced as "the man I've never not known"), Will and Sherry Rogers and their two daughters, Anne and Catherine (who were Martin's goddaughters and who lovingly called him "Uncle Martin"), Peter and Jean Burling, Rick and Karla Karash, Alex Bernhart and Myra Mayman, Merwyn and Carol Bagan, and others too numerous to name. In honor of Martin's extraordinary service to his community, donations can be made to the New Hampshire Charitable Foundation (on whose board he served for many years), to the Capitol Center for the Arts, to New Hampshire Public Radio, or to the charity of one's choice. Funeral arrangements and information about a celebration of Martin's life will be announced at a later date. 1/3

KOHNOP--Pearl, 97, on January 30, 2016. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Benjamin Kohnop. An avid reader and bridge player, she is survived by three generations of loving nieces and nephews. Services private. Donations in her memory to Dysautonomia Foundation, 315 West 39th St., #

GOLDMAN--Harriet, 92, loving mom, grandma, and great-grandma, role model, nurse, tennis champ, community advocate, and sunrise swimmer at Quisisana died February 3, 2016 and now is reunited with the love of her life, Dr. Abe Goldman. We miss her greatly. Stefan, Eric, Enid and Doris 1/3

FADEM--Edna Mae, of New Rochelle, NY, 88, died peacefully on February 2, 2016, surrounded by her beloved husband of 67 years, Leroy "Lee" and her family. The daughter of the late Charles and Patricia Raizen, "Sunny" lit up every room she entered. She loved life and her passions were family, gardening, music, world affairs and travel with Lee. Sunny, an honors graduate of Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA, is also survived by her children Steven Fadem and Laurie Baskin, Barbara and Jeff Hayden, Kathy Ivrey and Diane and Jeff Kennedy; her adored brother Roy and his children Jill and Robert Serling and David Raizen and Bettina Baloia and their children. Her greatest legacy is her grandchildren, Rachel and Chloe Fadem; Mark, Daniel and Sarah Hayden; Caitlin and Carly Ivrey and Cody Kennedy, who were all madly in love with their Grandma Sunny and she loved them back with an intense fervor. She taught all of us what it means to be loving and caring and how to overcome any adversity with a smile, tenacity and grit. She will be missed in ways she will never understand. Funeral Services Friday, February 5 at noon at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY. Contributions may be made in Sunny's memory to Temple Israel or a charity of one's choice. 1/3

MULLEN--Thomas P.,63, passed away peacefully on February 1, 2016, at his home in New York City. He was Founder and Managing Partner of Park Li Group, a global strategic management consulting practice. He is survived by Nancy, his loving wife of 27 years; daughters Katie, of Brooklyn, and Samantha, of New York City; and brothers Doran, of New York City; Joseph and sister- in-law Nancy, of Franklin, MA; and Michael, of Sinking Spring, PA. Friends may call at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York, NY on Friday, February 5, from 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in memory of Thomas Mullen to the PMP Research Foundation, info@pmpcure. org. Online condolences may be made to perazzofuneral home.com. 1/3
BETTIS--Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Bettis, associated with The New York Times from February 29, 1988 until retiring on January 1, 2006. 1/3

SANDERS--Reva M.,died February 2. A devoted, fiery, and deeply loved woman. A NYC teacher for 30 years and teacher to her family and friends for a lifetime. Service at Riverside Chapel, Friday, February 5 at 11:15am. 1/3

STOBER--Gerald, M.D. The Greenberg and Menin families mourn the passing of Dr. Gerald Stober, the beloved husband, father and grandfather with whom we have had the privilege of celebrating more than three decades of holidays and family milestones. His loving presence and quick wit will be dearly missed. 1/3

BADER--Elizabeth (Oppenheimer), New York, NY, age 87. Devoted mother, grandmother, and gentle spirit, beloved by all. Born in Aub, Germany in the shadow of Nazism, she went on to lead a full and happy life. Arriving in New York on the S.S. Manhattan, she lived first in Washington Heights, then in Valley Stream, Long Island, and finally on the Upper East Side. She went from darning socks for ice cream money to helping out in her parents' hardware store to a career in publishing, fashion and publicity before her marriage to her husband and soulmate, Richard. She was devoted to him, and he to her, for 58 years until his death in 2013. She enjoyed art, theater, ballet, film, bridge, historical novels, and chocolate, not necessarily in that order. Most of all, she cherished family and friends and loved spending time at her summer home in Seaview, Fire Island. She was refined yet unpretentious, stylish yet traditional, wise yet always young for her age, and her warmth, charm, and originality were a delight. Active until the end, she died after a brief battle with lymphoma. She is survived by her son David, daughter Nancy Gardiner, son-in-law Nat, and grandchildren Eliza Stensland and Charlotte Gardiner. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington DC 20024 or to Mount Sinai Hospital, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029. The family will receive friends on Thursday, February 4, from 7-9pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, with a service on Friday at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell. 1/3

MAIDMAN--Gail Ann Lowe. On January 31, 2016 our dear Mother and Momma Gail moved from our earthly hugs and kisses to becoming our everlasting guiding light. Shine bright beloved Mom. Adoringly, Evan Adam, Regina (nee Teplitsky), Esme Jemma and Theodore Mason Lowe Haymes 1/3

SOLOMON--Seymour, son of the late Tillie and Max Solomon, brother of the late Herbert and Henry, died on February 1, 2016 at the age of 93. Devoted husband of Ruth for 64 loving years. Beloved father of Marc and Raquel and daughter-in-law Nancy. Adoring grandfather of Eric. A 1943 graduate of CCNY with a Master's Degree in Social Work from NYU. Former Assistant Commissioner of Probation for the City of New York. Wonderful, loyal and generous to family and friends. We will love you and miss you always. 1/3

MAIDMAN--Gail Ann Lowe. On January 31, 2016 of New York, NY, peacefully, surrounded by family, Gail left the world of the living and joined her parents in the Garden of G-D. Magnificent and beautiful Gail's time came too soon for her loved ones. Her kindness, beauty, graciousness, wit, and elegance, will shine on. Beloved wife of Richard H. M. Maidman, devoted ex-wife of Stephen D. Haymes. Nurturing mother of Evan A. Haymes (Regina) and Starr H. Kempin (Jacques). Kind stepmother of Patrick (Jacqueline, deceased) Maidman, Mitchel (Arlene) Maidman and Dagny (Molly) Maidman. Loving Momma Gail of Esme, Theodore Haymes and Sterling Kempin. Loving Step-Momma Gail to Allison, Beatrice, Jonathan, Harrison, Julia, Ezra, Sage and Cassidy Maidman. For Shiva information please call 212-755-2595. Celebration Service to be held Wednesday, April 6, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. 1/3

GLAUBERMAN--Alex J.,(Jack), died February 2, 2016, at age 97. Survived by his beloved wife of 70 years, Estelle (Kaplan). Devoted and loving father of Marcia and Carol. Born in New York City on July 3, 1918, he graduated from City College of New York in 1937 and Columbia Law School in 1942. He was a World War II veteran who served as a cryptanalyst in the Signal Intelligence Corps stationed in New Delhi, India. A respected attorney in New York City until his retirement at the age of 92, he will always be remembered for his integrity, intellect, good counsel and quick wit. A private service will be held on Friday. 1/3
HECHT--Irwin. February 4, 2012. Forever loved and always in our hearts. Your Loving Family 1/3

ROSEMAN--Vera Chelnik, of McLean, Virginia and Winston-Salem, NC passed away peacefully on February 3, 2016. Born in Harlem, NY, July 25, 1921, Vera was the youngest daughter of Charles and Pauline Chelnik. Her siblings Mildred and Martin Chelnik predeceased her, as did her loving husband of 52 years, Alfred M. Roseman. She moved to Virginia in 2011 to be near her two sons, who survive her, Geoffrey L. (Jeanne Johnson) of Silver Spring, MD and Russell P. (Janet Silverman Roseman) of McLean, VA, together with their children, Deborah (Andrew Clevenger) of Falls Church, VA and David (Karin) of Philadelphia, PA. Funeral services and interment February 5, 2016, 11:30am, Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, NY. Donations can be made to a charity of choice. 1/3

BADER--Elizabeth. Darling Lizzie, my wonderful friend and neighbor for half a century. I will miss you so much. Heartfelt condolences to David, Nancy and family. With love, Edie and all the Scheurer's. 1/3

SOMERSTEIN--Dr. Saul, 90, died on February 3, 2016 at his home. Saul was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather who loved his family unconditionally. He served in the 100th Infantry Division during WWII and later attended NYU Dental School. Many of his patients went on to become lifelong friends of the family. Service at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Friday at 11:00am. Our loss will be felt by all who knew him. 1/3

KRAUSKOPF--John. Died February 3, 2016 after long struggle with Parkinson's. Beloved husband and best friend of Sharon Greene, loving father of David Krauskopf-Greene, Jill, Lynn and Sara. Greatly respected scientist, colleague, mentor and friend to so many around the world. We will miss him terribly. 1/3

STOBER--Gerald Stanley, M.D.,of Great Neck, NY, died February 3, 2016 from complications of heart surgery. He was 89 years old. Born December 19, 1926 in Montreal, Canada. He was the third of four sons of Sarah and Jacob Stober. Gerry was the beloved husband of Ruth (nee Benjamin), the adored father of Jill Lafer (Barry), Lori (deceased) and Clifford (Wendy) and loving grandfather of Joshua (Marissa), Peter, Casey, Haley and Sara. Beloved brother of Morton, Julius and David. Gerry was a brilliant and dedicated OB/GYN who practiced in Queens, NY. He attended McGill University and McGill Medical School and came to NY for his residency where he met Ruth in 1954 and married in 1955. In his life he was totally devoted to his family and to his patients. In 1976 he was the first obstetrician in New York State to perform a Caesarean Section with the husband present in the delivery room. Those who knew him in the operating room still talk about his tremendous surgical skills and his ability to teach his successors. He cared deeply about women's reproductive healthcare and took great pride in his daughter Jill's position as Board Chair of Planned Parenthood Federation of America. He was one of the founding physicians of Booth Memorial Medical Center, now New York Hospital of Queens. His patients adored him and there are many Gerrys and Geralds named after him. He was a man of determination, integrity, principles and dignity. He believed in mind, body and spirit and practiced this philosophy throughout his life. He horseback rode, skated, skied, played tennis and was often spotted jogging and biking through the streets of Great Neck. He retired in 1990 and traveled the world with his wife, Ruth and spent his time with his grandchildren. He was proud of his knowledge of Shakespeare, constantly quoting him as well as much of classical literature. He was a voracious reader and an astute investor, one of his talents and loves. He was a wordsmith and enjoyed studying the derivation of words and their meanings. His knowledge of history and literature were legendary in our family. He took cooking lessons and enjoyed cooking and wines. He loved the opera, hockey and a good dramatic play. Most of all, he had a great sense of humor and an appreciation and a love of life. He loved his jokes and repeated them often! He will be missed by his family and friends but his memory and life lessons will live on in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 123 Williams Street, New York, NY 10038. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 11:30am, Thursday, February 4th. 1/3

WORTSMANN--Barbara (nee Levie), 80, of Wynnewood, PA, formerly of Queens, NY, on Monday, February 1, 2016 at Penn Hospice at Rittenhouse, Philadelphia, PA after a long illness. For many years, Barbara compassionately worked in medical offices in Manhattan. She managed physicians' offices, helped with patient care, and visited patients in the hospital during the AIDS crisis. After retiring, Barbara volunteered at the Museum of Natural History in New York, the Museum of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia, and the Philadelphia Zoo. Barbara also took art classes and was a talented water colorist, sketch artist, and maker of mosaics. She is survived by her daughter, Erica Rachlin (Mark); her sons, Joel Wortsmann, and Edward Wortsmann; her grandchildren, Jessica Wortsmann, Jaime Wortsmann, and Jonathan Rachlin. Barbara is also survived by Gilbert Wortsmann. She was preceded in death by her daughter-in-law, Judith Wortsmann. At Barbara's request, her body will be donated to the University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine. In lieu of flowers, donations in Barbara's memory to the Penn Wissahickon Hospice are welcome at www.pennmedicine.org/ homecare/services/hospice or Abramson Cancer Center at www.pennmedicine.org/ giving. 1/3

MAIDMAN--Gail Ann Lowe. On January 31, 2016 our dear Mother and Momma Gail moved from our earthly hugs and kisses to becoming our everlasting guiding light. Shine bright beloved Mom. Adoringly, Evan Adam, Regina (nee Teplitsky), Esme Jemma and Theodore Mason Lowe Haymes 1/3

WOLFSON--Cyril Z.,age 90, died peacefully, December 14, 2015, at his home in NYC. Cyril was born April 2, 1925. Cyril served his country in the army during WWII, and was discharged with full honors. He was also involved in the mining of Uranium in Moab, Utah. He became a real estate executive with Herbert Charles & Co. He then partnered with Sheldon Evans. He was a member of the real estate board of New York. His proudest achievement was to develop and construct the Sheraton Old Town Inn in Albuquerque, NM. Cyril was an inspiration and mentor to many of those who were fortunate to know him. He married his first wife Edith Varsa who predeceased him in 1999. He is survived by his beloved wife, Soledad Wolfson. He will be dearly missed by his step-children, family, and friends. He was cremated with his ashes being interred on January 2, 2016 at the Long Island National Cemetery following a military burial funeral. A memorial service will follow. 1/3

GOLDMAN--Harriet, 92, loving mom, grandma, and great-grandma, role model, nurse, tennis champ, community advocate, and sunrise swimmer at Quisisana died February 3, 2016 and now is reunited with the love of her life, Dr. Abe Goldman. We miss her greatly. Stefan, Eric, Enid and Doris 1/3
FADEM--Edna Mae. Fenway Golf Club expresses profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Edna Mae Fadem, and extends sincere condolences to her entire family. Bruce Haber, President 1/3

STOBER--Gerald Stanley, M.D.,of Great Neck, NY, died February 3, 2016 from complications of heart surgery. He was 89 years old. Born December 19, 1926 in Montreal, Canada. He was the third of four sons of Sarah and Jacob Stober. Gerry was the beloved husband of Ruth (nee Benjamin), the adored father of Jill Lafer (Barry), Lori (deceased) and Clifford (Wendy) and loving grandfather of Joshua (Marissa), Peter, Casey, Haley and Sara. Beloved brother of Morton, Julius and David. Gerry was a brilliant and dedicated OB/GYN who practiced in Queens, NY. He attended McGill University and McGill Medical School and came to NY for his residency where he met Ruth in 1954 and married in 1955. In his life he was totally devoted to his family and to his patients. In 1976 he was the first obstetrician in New York State to perform a Caesarean Section with the husband present in the delivery room. Those who knew him in the operating room still talk about his tremendous surgical skills and his ability to teach his successors. He cared deeply about women's reproductive healthcare and took great pride in his daughter Jill's position as Board Chair of Planned Parenthood Federation of America. He was one of the founding physicians of Booth Memorial Medical Center, now New York Hospital of Queens. His patients adored him and there are many Gerrys and Geralds named after him. He was a man of determination, integrity, principles and dignity. He believed in mind, body and spirit and practiced this philosophy throughout his life. He horseback rode, skated, skied, played tennis and was often spotted jogging and biking through the streets of Great Neck. He retired in 1990 and traveled the world with his wife, Ruth and spent his time with his grandchildren. He was proud of his knowledge of Shakespeare, constantly quoting him as well as much of classical literature. He was a voracious reader and an astute investor, one of his talents and loves. He was a wordsmith and enjoyed studying the derivation of words and their meanings. His knowledge of history and literature were legendary in our family. He took cooking lessons and enjoyed cooking and wines. He loved the opera, hockey and a good dramatic play. Most of all, he had a great sense of humor and an appreciation and a love of life. He loved his jokes and repeated them often! He will be missed by his family and friends but his memory and life lessons will live on in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 123 Williams Street, New York, NY 10038. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 11:30am, Thursday, February 4th. 1/3

WILSON--William. William Smith Wilson III, 83, beloved brother, father and grandfather, died in Manhattan on Monday, February 1, 2016 from cardiac arrest. Born in Baltimore in 1932, he was raised in Maryland, attended the University of Virginia for his B.A., Yale University for his Ph.D. and taught college as a professor of English in Queens College, City University of New York from 1962 until his retirement in the early 1990s. While raising three children in Chelsea he published a collection of short stories, "Why I Don't Write Like Franz Kafka" (1975), and the novel "Birthplace" (1982). The son of sculptor and painter May Wilson, he was deeply involved in the post-war New York art world, the subject of his numerous published essays. Survivors include his sister, Betty Jane Butler, children Katherine, Ara and Andrew and grandchildren Jack, Alex, Augusta and Josephine. Contributions may be offered in his honor to PBS public television (www.thirteen.org), the High Line (https://www.thehighline.org/donate) or the Baltimore Museum, (https://artbma.org/give- join/give.html#
ROSEMAN--Vera. In loving memory. She was a devoted wife, mother, sister, grandmother and aunt. A wonderful sensitive lady. She will be missed. With Love, The Chelnik Family 1/3

ROTH--Shirley Karp, died peacefully on February 3, 2016. An elegant lady who showed great strength and wisdom. Beloved wife of Theodore, then briefly Norman. Exceptional mother to Jane and son-in-law Larry. Giving grandmother to Kimberly, Laurie and James. Great-grandmother to Sydney and Etan. Always a wordsmith and lover of languages, Shirley loved to see the humor in life. Rest peacefully, we will miss you terribly. 1/3

SOMERSTEIN--Dr. Saul, 90, died on February 3, 2016 at his home. Saul was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather who loved his family unconditionally. PILKONIS--Pamela A.,died peacefully on February 3, 2016. Pam was the beloved daughter of the late Raymond and Julia Pilkonis, sister of Paul (Elaine) and Pat (Robin), aunt to Julia (Ran) and their three children. Pam was raised in Manchester, CT. She graduated from Wellesley College in 1971 and pursued further training in fine arts at Boston University. She spent more than two decades in Provence, France, where she was a sculptor, painter, and educator at the Lacoste School of the Arts. Most recently she lived and worked in New York City. A memorial service celebrating Pam's life will be held at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Pam's memory be made to: Dr. Anne Moore Research Fund/memo line: Attn: Dr. Linda Vahdat; Mailing address: Dr. Linda Vahdat, 425 East 61st Street, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10065. 1/3

Magnificent and beautiful Gail's time came too soon for her loved ones. Her kindness, beauty, graciousness, wit, and elegance, will shine on. Beloved wife of Richard H. M. Maidman, loving ex-wife of Stephen D. Haymes. Nurturing mother of Evan A. Haymes (Regina) and Starr H. Kempin (Jacques). Kind stepmother of Patrick (Jacqueline, departed) Maidman, Mitchel (Arlene) Maidman and Dagny (Molly) Maidman. Loving Momma Gail of Esme, Theodore Haymes and Sterling Kempin. Loving Step-Momma Gail to Allison, Beatrice, Jonathan, Harrison, Julia, Ezra, Sage and Cassidy Maidman. For Shiva Information, please call 212-755-2595. CONNORS--James P.,Jr., longtime Judge in Eastchester and Bronxville resident passed away at the age of 86 years. He had been suffering from Alzheimer's Disease. Jim was born on May 31, 1929 to James P. Connors, Sr. and Kathryn Ryan Connors in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Jim grew up in Yonkers and in Eastchester, attending Iona Grammar and High schools and earning a degree in Economics from Fordham University in the Bronx in 1950 where he was the school's squash champion his senior year. He earned his JD from St. John's Law School in Queens in 1953. Jim was drafted into the Army's JAG office later in 1953 and stationed in Hokkaido, Japan. Private Connors went 3-0 defending fellow soldiers accused of various charges, earning several letters of commendation for his service and a promotion to the rank of Sargent. After his military service, Jim launched a nearly 60 year career in private law practice, the bulk of which as a Partner with Smith, Ranscht, Pollock, Manos & Connors in White Plains, NY. He most recently was of counsel to the law firm of Bertine, Hufnagel, Headley, Zeltner, Drummond & Dohn in Eastchester. Jim was active in local Republican politics throughout his career, serving as President of the young Republicans of Westchester County. He also served as the Town Justice of Eastchester from 1983-2011 and was legal counsel and Board Member to the Tuckahoe Savings & Loan and its successor companies. Jim is survived by his devoted wife of 57 years, the former Margaret Gallagher of Larchmont and his sons James Patrick, III (Angela- d. 2015) of Mount Vernon, Michael (Kendall) of Piedmont CA, Mark (Kelly) of Bronxville and Paul (Leeanna) of Croton-on-Hudson and nine grandchildren. Jim was reunited in God's graces with his daughter Meg, who passed away from Hodgkins Disease in 1985 at the age of 25. He is also survived by his brother John of Wilton CT, his close cousin Mary Jo McLoughlin of Garden City, LI and numerous nieces and nephews. Jim recently shared with Peggy how thankful he felt for all the blessings he had enjoyed in his life. He loved his family and he loved his community. Jim worked hard to have a positive impact on both-succeeding wonderfully on both fronts. And no Memorial Day Parade in Bronxville was complete without Jim marching in his straw bowler. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 4-7pm Saturday and Sunday. A Mass of Resurrection will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville, NY where Jim spent his life actively participating as an altar server, a Parish Council member and, until last month, as a Lector on Monday, February 8 at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Jim's honor to the following: Inner-City Scholarship Fund, innercityscholarshipfund.org or Doctors Without Borders, doctorswithoutborders.org 1/3

WORTSMANN--Barbara (nee Levie), 80, of Wynnewood, PA, formerly of Queens, NY, on Monday, February 1, 2016 at Penn Hospice at Rittenhouse, Philadelphia, PA after a long illness. For many years, Barbara compassionately worked in medical offices in Manhattan. She managed physicians' offices, helped with patient care, and visited patients in the hospital during the AIDS crisis. After retiring, Barbara volunteered at the Museum of Natural History in New York, the Museum of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia, and the Philadelphia Zoo. Barbara also took art classes and was a talented water colorist, sketch artist, and maker of mosaics. She is survived by her daughter, Erica Rachlin (Mark); her sons, Joel Wortsmann, and Edward Wortsmann; her grandchildren, Jessica Wortsmann, Jaime Wortsmann, and Jonathan Rachlin. Barbara is also survived by Gilbert Wortsmann. She was preceded in death by her daughter-in-law, Judith Wortsmann. At Barbara's request, her body will be donated to the University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine. In lieu of flowers, donations in Barbara's memory to the Penn Wissahickon Hospice are welcome at www.pennmedicine.org/ homecare/services/hospice or Abramson Cancer Center at www.pennmedicine.org/ giving. 1/3

FADEM--Edna Mae. Of New Rochelle, NY, 88, died peacefully on February 2, 2016, surrounded by her beloved husband of 67 years, Leroy "Lee" and her family. The daughter of the late Charles and Patricia Raizen, "Sunny" lit up every room she entered. She loved life and her passions were family, gardening, music, world affairs and travel with Lee. Sunny, an honors graduate of Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA, is also survived by her children Steven Fadem and Laurie Baskin, Barbara and Jeff Hayden, Kathy Ivrey and Diane and Jeff Kennedy; her adored brother Roy and his children Jill and Robert Serling and David Raizen and Bettina Daloia and their children. Her greatest legacy is her grandchildren, Rachel and Chloe Fadem; Mark, Daniel and Sarah Hayden; Caitlin and Carly Ivrey and Cody Kennedy, who were all madly in love with their Grandma Sunny and she loved them back with an intense fervor. She taught all of us what it means to be loving and caring and how to overcome any adversity with a smile, tenacity and grit. She will be missed in ways she will never understand. Funeral Services Friday, February 5 at noon at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY. Contributions may be made in Sunny's memory to Temple Israel or a charity of one's choice. 1/3

HOLTZ--Jill M. Gone 4 years, too soon. Miss you and think of you each and every day. You are always in our hearts. Mom and Dad 1/3

ROSEMAN--Vera Chelnik, of McLean, Virginia and Winston-Salem, NC passed away peacefully on February 3, 2016. Born in Harlem, NY, July 25, 1921, Vera was the youngest daughter of Charles and Pauline Chelnik. (Jeanne Johnson) of Silver Spring, MD and Russell P. (Janet Silverman Roseman) of McLean, VA, together with their children, Deborah (Andrew Clevenger) of Falls Church, VA and David (Karin) of Philadelphia, PA. GRUNWALD--Ilse. On February 3, 2016 at 93 years of age, Ilse Grunwald died peacefully at home surrounded by her loving family. Born May 11, 1922 in Ludwigshafen, Ilse escaped Nazi Germany at the age of 16 and after a year in England, arrived in NYC, December 23, 1939. Together with her mother, father, and brother, she started a small watch import firm, the J. Kalberman Co. After the war ended her new husband Ernest joined the firm and together they grew the business which eventually became Belair Time Corp., a thriving private label watch manufacturer. A fierce and savvy businesswoman, Ilse was devoted to growing her company and her beautiful family. A loving mother to Elaine and Alan. Cherished daughter, wife, sister, aunt, cousin, mother-in-law and grandmother. Married for 70 years, she is survived by her husband Ernest. Her strong spirit and loving generosity will never be forgotten. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 7 at 9:30am, Freeman Funeral Home, 344 Rt. 9 N., Manalapan, NJ 07726, followed by Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations to a charity of your choice. 1/3

MARCUS--Amy L.,originally from New Jersey and longtime resident of New York City, passed away peacefully on February 5. Beloved daughter, sister, aunt, friend will be remembered for her smiles and laughter. Beloved member of Town and Village Synagogue, Times Squares Dancers of New York. Graduated from Beth Israel Nursing School and Pace College. Amy worked at Beth Israel and the 92nd Street Y's Senior Program. Amy will be missed by many! She is survived by a sister, a brother, four nieces, three nephews. Services will be held February 7th, at "The Riverside," 180 West 76th St., New York at 10am. 1/3

GUSTIN--Brenda. Hard to imagine we lost this beautiful woman one year ago on February 7. We love and miss you every day Mom. "You are the light that shines on me. You always were and you'll always be." Nick Gustin Ken Gustin 1/3

MAIDMAN--Gail Ann Lowe. On January 31, 2016 our dear Mother and Momma Gail moved from our earthly hugs and kisses to becoming our everlasting guiding light. Shine bright beloved Mom. Adoringly, Evan Adam, Regina (nee Teplitsky), Esme Jemma and Theodore Mason Lowe Haymes 1/3

PANUSH--Hyman, 100, on February 5, 2016. Beloved husband of the late Miriam and Zelda, devoted father of Miriam, Donnie, Ben-Zion, Bashie and David. Adored grandfather of Elana, Adina, Moshe, Sippy, Yitzy, Zerlina, Lucy, Michelle and Jake. Great-grandfather of Dovi, Aliza and newborn baby girl. Service Sunday, February 7, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

DALEY--Patrick, died February 5, 2016. Patrick Daley, Senior Vice President and Publisher, Scholastic Education, is mourned by his colleagues and friends who were honored to publish the brilliant and engaging reading programs he developed that helped transform the lives of millions of students. As a young classroom teacher in Burlington, VT, Patrick got some advice that would change his life: you must do whatever it takes to get them to read. He joined Scholastic in 1988, vowing to create the highest-quality, most engaging reading materials that would help even the most profoundly struggling readers to read with joy. Patrick was the editor of Scholastic Action magazine, which serves at-risk students and went on to develop READ 180, the premier reading intervention program for grades 3-12. His passion for helping children learn to read was his driving force. He put his heart and soul into READ 180 and other programs designed to serve the diverse populations of children who needed stories in which they could find themselves. It is thanks to Patrick Daley and his big ideas, bigger energy, and huge heart that millions of children have learned to read. His wisdom and passionate dedication to children will remain with all who knew and worked with him. Patrick is survived by his loving husband Daryl Hair and two sisters, Mary and Kathy along with extended family. Richard Robinson CEO, Scholastic 1/3

LOVETT--Lawrence D. Venetian Heritage Inc. and Fondazione Venetian Heritage Onlus mourn the death of its Founding Chairman, Lawrence D. Lovett, who was a distinguished member of the boards for more than 15 years. Larry served in the US Army from 1954-1956. He graduated Harvard College with honors and Harvard Law School in 1954. He began his career as a cargo ship and tanker broker in New York and went on to become VP of Eastern Steamship Lines. He then joined his family companies as President of Burgoyne Properties Company, Suwance Steamship Company and the Piggly Wiggly Corporation simultaneously. Larry was devoted to the arts, primarily the Metropolitan Opera. He served as President of the Board of the Metropolitan Opera Guild from 1971-1979 and Chairman from 1979 to 1986. He was President of the Metropolitan Opera Association Board, Chairman of its Executive Committee and Chairman of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. In 1996 he devoted himself to restoration projects in Venice and in 1998 founded Venetian Heritage, raising funds for the preservation of Venetian art and architecture in Venice and those regions of the Mediterranean rim subject to Venetian influence. On behalf of the board, we extend our sincere condolences to his family. We will miss him. Pierre Durand, Venetian Heritage Inc., Chairman and President; Valentina Nasi Marini Clarelli, Fondazione Venetian Heritage Onlus, President 1/3

MAIDMAN--Gail Ann Lowe. On January 31, 2016 peacefully, surrounded by family, Gail left the world of the living and joined her parents in the Garden of G-D. Magnificent and beautiful Gail's time came too soon for her loved ones. Her kindness, beauty, graciousness, wit, and elegance, will shine on. Beloved wife of Richard H. M. Maidman, loving ex-wife of Stephen D. Haymes. Nurturing mother of Evan A. Haymes (Regina) and Starr H. Kempin (Jacques). Kind stepmother of Patrick (Jacqueline, departed) Maidman, Mitchel (Arlene) Maidman and Dagny (Molly) Maidman. Loving Momma Gail of Esme, Theodore Haymes and Sterling Kempin. Loving Step-Momma Gail to Allison, Beatrice, Jonathan, Harrison, Julia, Ezra, Sage and Cassidy Maidman. For Shiva Information, please call 212-755-2595. Celebration Service to be held Wednesday, April 6, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Donation can be made to either: The Gail Ann Lowe Maidman Scholarship Fund at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts c/o Susan Zech, President, 120 Madison Avenue, NYC, NY 10016 or to The Gail Ann Lowe Maidman Fund at the Jewish Communal Fund, 575 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10022. 1/3

ST. LIFER--Herbert W.,of Larchmont, NY, 85, died peacefully on February 4, 2016. Loving and beloved husband of Barbara (Sisholz) and adored father of Nancy and Elizabeth (Steven Ostrow). Fun loving uncle and cherished friend. He will be missed by all who knew him. Funeral Sunday, February 7, 2016, 11:30am, at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck, NY 10543 (www.zionchapel.com). The family will be receiving at his home Saturday evening from 7:30-9:00pm and Sunday afternoon following the funeral service until 4:00pm. Charitable contributions to Alzheimer's Disease Research or the American Lung Foundation would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

BLOCK--Jeffrey L.,died January 12, 2016 in Westport, CT, beloved husband of Helen for 35 years. He was the proud father of Mike Meredith and Gabriel and the grandfather of three. He also leaves his much respected brother Elliot and soulful sister Diane. Jeff will be remembered for his disarming wit, keen intelligence and kind disposition. He was an avid basketball player often challenging and surprising far younger opponents. A skilled skier, he shared his love for adventure with friends and their grown children. He was a sensitive man who wrote stirring poetry for the delight of the select few with whom he shared this talent. After a long career at PriceWaterHouseCoopers. where he succeeded with creativity, grit and indomitable initiative, Jeff dedicated his time and energy to the grass roots organization Save Westport Now. Donations in Jeff's memory may be made to: www.specialolympics.org and www.nationalparks.org 1/3

ISRAEL--Deborah. Longtime resident of Glen Cove, NY. Wife of the late, Leo, adored mother of Fred, Steve (Marsee), Michael (Michele), and David (Lucretia). Most loved grandmother of Isa, Samantha, Jake, Harrison, Sam, Sarah, Blake, William, and Daniel. Service Sunday, 9:00am, at Gutterman's 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Interment to follow at Washington Memorial Park, Coram, NY. 1/3

GREENSPAN--Florence. With sadness, Mrs. Karen Zarembski of Baltimore, MD and Mr. Eric Greenspan of Brooklyn, NY announce the passing of their beloved mother, Mrs. Florence Greenspan. Florence Wolf was born on December 28, 1920. She later married Julius Greenspan and had two children, Eric and Karen. She also had six grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren. Her children wish to remember her as a deeply loving mother and patriotic American who worked more than two decades with the Coast Guard. She was a lover of all things music -- whether it was taking her children to Broadway shows or jogging down Avenue J with her headphones on. The funeral is set to take place this Sunday, February 7th at the IJ Morris Funeral Home at 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11210. 1/3

GILLETTE--Joan, of New York, NY, 81, on February 2, 2016 of complications from cancer. Joan was the daughter of the late Helen and Leonard Glickman. Joan married Stanley C. Gillette with whom she had a daughter, Patty Gillette of Sleepy Hollow, NY. For 40 years Joan and Stan had a loving and happy marriage. Following Stan's death, Joan found love again with Bob Pitofsky, to whom she had been engaged when she was 18. Joan is survived by her daughter Patty, her stepson Richard Gillette, her grandchildren Kyle and Blake Norman, Jasara Myles and Holly Martin and four great-grandchildren. Memorial service Sunday, February 7, 1pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory to Memorial Sloane Kettering at https://giving.mskcc.org/find -and-donate-giving-page. 1/3

FADEM--Edna Mae. Of New Rochelle, NY, 88, died peacefully on February 2, 2016, surrounded by her beloved husband of 67 years, Leroy "Lee" and her family. The daughter of the late Charles and Patricia Raizen, "Sunny" lit up every room she entered. She loved life and her passions were family, gardening, music, world affairs and travel with Lee. Sunny, an honors graduate of Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA, is also survived by her children Steven Fadem and Laurie Baskin, Barbara and Jeff Hayden, Kathy Ivrey and Diane and Jeff Kennedy; her adored brother Roy and his children Jill and Robert Serling and David Raizen and Bettina Daloia and their children. Her greatest legacy is her grandchildren, Rachel and Chloe Fadem; Mark, Daniel and Sarah Hayden; Caitlin and Carly Ivrey and Cody Kennedy, who were all madly in love with their Grandma Sunny and she loved them back with an intense fervor. She taught all of us what it means to be loving and caring and how to overcome any adversity with a smile, tenacity and grit. She will be missed in ways she will never understand. Contributions may be made in Sunny's memory to Temple Israel or a charity of one's choice. 1/3

KOHNOP--Pearl, 97, on January 30. Devoted wife of the late Dr Ben Kohnop. Proud Hunter College grad. Avid reader, bridge and scrabble player, she enjoyed theater, art, ballet, music. Loving daughter, sister, doting aunt to three generations. She is missed by nieces and nephews, the joy of her life. Cedar Park Paramus February 7. FamilialDysautonomia.org 1/3

Jerry will be missed by his extended family and friends. Service Sunday, February 7, 12 noon at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, or the World Jewish Congress. 1/3

DRAPER DOWNER--Harriette "Heidi." February 2, 2016. A passionate filmmaker with great joie de vivre. She is survived by children Elizabeth and Ahab and four grandchildren. 1/3

GLAUBERMAN--Alex J.,(Jack), died February 2, 2016, at age 97. Survived by his beloved wife of 70 years, Estelle (Kaplan). Devoted and loving father of Marcia and Carol. Born in New York City on July 3, 1918, he graduated from City College of New York in 1937 and Columbia Law School in 1942. He was a World War II veteran who served as a cryptanalyst in the Signal Intelligence Corps stationed in New Delhi, India. A respected attorney in New York City until his retirement at the age of 92, he will always be remembered for his integrity, intellect, good counsel and quick wit. A private service was held on Friday. 1/3

FADEM--Edna Mae. Of New Rochelle, NY, 88, died peacefully on February 2, 2016, surrounded by her beloved husband of 67 years, Leroy "Lee" and her family. The daughter of the late Charles and Patricia Raizen, "Sunny" lit up every room she entered. She loved life and her passions were family, gardening, music, world affairs and travel with Lee. Sunny, an honors graduate of Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA, is also survived by her children Steven Fadem and Laurie Baskin, Barbara and Jeff Hayden, Kathy Ivrey and Diane and Jeff Kennedy; her adored brother Roy and his children Jill and Robert Serling and David Raizen and Bettina Daloia and their children. Her greatest legacy is her grandchildren, Rachel and Chloe Fadem; Mark, Daniel and Sarah Hayden; Caitlin and Carly Ivrey and Cody Kennedy, who were all madly in love with their Grandma Sunny and she loved them back with an intense fervor. She taught all of us what it means to be loving and caring and how to overcome any adversity with a smile, tenacity and grit. She will be missed in ways she will never understand. Contributions may be made in Sunny's memory to Temple Israel or a charity of one's choice. 1/3

LEMLE--Muriel Charlotte Eckstein, nickname "Peggy," 95, passed away at home on February 6, 2016 after a long illness. She was devoted wife of Clarence "Bob" for 50 years until he passed away July 1997, proud mother of Stuart (wife Marian), Russell (Victoria) and Craig (Amy), kvelling grandmother of Jon (Molly), Cliff (Jamie), Tracey (Marcus), Casey (Ed), Elise (Devin), Julia and Kyle and loving great-grandmother of Vivienne and Madison. Born January 21, 1921 in New York City to Harry and Bertha Eckstein with brother Phillip, she grew up in Weehawken, NJ, received bachelors and teaching degrees from Beaver College. She moved to White Plains in 1951 and lived there for the remainder of her life. She was a dedicated contributor to civic activities, including leadership of numerous White Plains school system parents' organizations and a decades-long volunteer and member of the Board of Directors at White Plains Hospital. She will be dearly missed for her expansive generosity, loyalty and thoughtfulness by all who knew her. Private graveside service for the immediate family is February 8. Donations in her memory may be made to White Plains Hospital or the charity of choice. 1/3

REDDING--Marie Reiman, 90, of Murphysboro, Illinois, died peacefully on January 27, 2016. She was born on March 28, 1925. Marie worked hard, played well, traveled the world, enjoyed the people she met, survived breast cancer, and truly loved her life. Her only child survives her, Alexandra R. Marshall of Millbrook, NY, New York City and Houston, Texas. She is also survived by her grandson, Dr. Douglas B. Marshall, his wife Dr. Amrita B. Ahuja, and their son, her great- grandson, Ved Rehman Marshall of Houston, TX, currently residing in Northfield, Minnesota; three sisters, one brother-in-law, various nieces, nephews, great-nieces and nephews, and a great-great-niece and nephew. For the last decade of her life, Marie wintered in Houston with her daughter, other family members, and friends as possible. She was treasured by many and will be greatly missed. 1/3

FINBERG--Laurence, M.D.,leader in Pediatrics, dies at 92. Born May 20, 1923 and died January 22, 2016. A Chicago, IL native, Dr. Finberg earned his M.D. at the University of Chicago (1946) and launched his career in academic pediatrics on faculty at Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine (1951-1963). An excellent researcher and valued teacher, Dr. Finberg became a pioneer and expert in fluids and electrolytes. His work led to seminal approaches for treating severe dehydration, malnutrition and other conditions in children. Professor & Chairman of Pediatrics at Albert Einstein College Of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center (1963-1982) he later became Professor & Chairman of Pediatrics (1982-1994) and Dean of the School of Medicine (1988-1991) at SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY. When retired he taught at both University of California, San Francisco and Stanford University School Of Medicine. His leadership at Downstate and Kings County Hospital produced a thriving and nationally respected Department proudly serving Brooklyn's disadvantaged communities. With great respect and fond remembrance, the SUNY Downstate Department of Pediatrics mourns the loss of Dr. Finberg, an extraordinary leader, devoted pediatrician, gifted clinician, educator and internationally respected researcher. Through his knowledge, wisdom, integrity, teaching and lasting influence on generations of pediatricians, Dr. Finberg made a real difference and improved the lives and health of countless children worldwide. 1/3

ST. LIFER--Herbert W.,of Larchmont, NY, 85, died peacefully on February 4, 2016. Loving and beloved husband of Barbara (Sisholz) and adored father of Nancy and Elizabeth (Steven Ostrow). Fun loving uncle and cherished friend. He will be missed by all who knew him. Funeral Sunday, February 7, 2016, 11:30am, at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck, NY 10543 (www.zionchapel.com). The family will be receiving at his home Saturday evening from 7:30-9:00pm and Sunday afternoon following the funeral service until 4:00pm. Charitable contributions to Alzheimer's Disease Research or the American Lung Foundation would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

MEARS--DeAnn, 83 years old, died January 31, 2016. Ms. Mears spent her life in the theatre. She was well known for her leading roles in the American Conservatory Theatre, where she played in "Tiny Alice," "Tartuffe," and "The Royal Family" among others. On Broadway she appeared in "Abelard and Heloise" with Diana Rigg, "Tiny Alice," "Too Good to be True" (standing by for Lillian Gish) and "Showboat" at City Center in 1954. She also performed in "Dear Liar" at the Roundabout Theatre with Jerome Kilty, who wrote the play. She was known for her work in films, ("Presumed Innocent" and "The Loneliest Runner") and her television work on Beacon Hill. She appeared in many episodes of "Law and Order" and acted, sometimes along with her husband, Frank Savino, (who predeceased her) in many of the fine repertory theatres in the United States. She studied with Uta Hagen. She died at her home in New Milford, CT of complications of emphysema and COPD. She will be dearly missed by all who knew her. 1/3

STOBER--Gerald Stanley, M.D.,of Great Neck, NY, died February 3, 2016 from complications of heart surgery. He was 89 years old. Born December 19, 1926 in Montreal, Canada. He was the third of four sons of Sarah and Jacob Stober. Gerry was the beloved husband of Ruth (nee Benjamin), the adored father of Jill Lafer (Barry), Lori (deceased) and Clifford (Wendy) and loving grandfather of Joshua (Marissa), Peter, Casey, Haley and Sara. Beloved brother of Morton, Julius and David. Gerry was a brilliant and dedicated OB/GYN who practiced in Queens, NY. He attended McGill University and McGill Medical School and came to NY for his residency where he met Ruth in 1954 and married in 1955. In his life he was totally devoted to his family and to his patients. In 1976 he was the first obstetrician in New York State to perform a Caesarean Section with the husband present in the delivery room. Those who knew him in the operating room still talk about his tremendous surgical skills and his ability to teach his successors. He cared deeply about women's reproductive healthcare and took great pride in his daughter Jill's position as Board Chair of Planned Parenthood Federation of America. He was one of the founding physicians of Booth Memorial Medical Center, now New York Hospital of Queens. His patients adored him and there are many Gerrys and Geralds named after him. He was a man of determination, integrity, principles and dignity. He believed in mind, body and spirit and practiced this philosophy throughout his life. He horseback rode, skated, skied, played tennis and was often spotted jogging and biking through the streets of Great Neck. He retired in 1990 and traveled the world with his wife, Ruth and spent his time with his grandchildren. He was proud of his knowledge of Shakespeare, constantly quoting him as well as much of classical literature. He was a voracious reader and an astute investor, one of his talents and loves. He was a wordsmith and enjoyed studying the derivation of words and their meanings. His knowledge of history and literature were legendary in our family. He took cooking lessons and enjoyed cooking and wines. He loved the opera, hockey and a good dramatic play. Most of all, he had a great sense of humor and an appreciation and a love of life. He loved his jokes and repeated them often! He will be missed by his family and friends but his memory and life lessons will live on in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 123 Williams Street, New York, NY 10038. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 11:30am, Thursday, February 4th. 1/3
LEVY--Dinah. After 101 years of a joyful life, Dinah Levy passed away on January 31, 2016. Mother of Farrel and Jonathan Levy, grandmother of Julia Duffy, Emma Tung and Caroline Levy. 1/3

MAIDMAN--Gail Ann Lowe. On January 31, 2016 our dear Mother and Momma Gail moved from our earthly hugs and kisses to becoming our everlasting guiding light. Shine bright beloved Mom. Adoringly, Evan Adam, Regina (nee Teplitsky), Esme Jemma and Theodore Mason Lowe Haymes 1/3

GROSS--Ronald Martin, was born in Cleveland, OH on October 19, 1933. He died at home in Stamford, CT surrounded by his family on January 31, 2016 at the age of 82. Ron was the son of Pearl Dolinsky Gross and Herman Gross. He spent his childhood in Lima, OH where he graduated from Lima Central High School. He attended Ohio State University, earning a bachelor's degree in Biology in 1955. After graduation, Ron worked at Battelle Memorial Institute decoding sensitive intelligence information for the United States government. He graduated from Harvard Business School in 1960. Subsequently, his professional life was marked by over 50 years of distinguished business and civic accomplishment. Ron spent his entire professional career in the pulp and paper industry. He served in various roles at Champion International from 1960-1968. In 1968 he moved his family to Vancouver, Canada where he became the C.E.O. of Canadian Cellulose Corporation at the age of 39. His accomplishments there were noted in an article on the front page of The New York Times business section in 1977, "Dramatic Turnaround of a Canadian Pulp Enterprise." While in Canada, he served on the boards of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, the Pulp and Paper Research Institute of Canada, the Canadian Forestry Association of British Columbia, and the Advisory Board, Division of International Business Studies, University of British Columbia. In 1978, he moved his family to Stamford, CT, starting a long career with ITT Rayonier where he served as C.E.O. for 17 years. During his tenure as C.E.O., he successfully spun off Rayonier, Inc. as an independent, public entity on the NYSE. Towards the end of his business career he served on several corporate boards, including the Brinks Company, Corn Products International, and Lukens Steel. He was a long time member of the board of directors of the American Forest and Paper Association and was a member of the Investment Policy Advisory Committee of the U.S. Trade Representative. He served as the Chairman of Rayonier's board until 1998. Ron's life was filled with civic and charitable endeavors. He served as President of Congregation Beth Israel in Vancouver, Canada and of Temple Beth El in Stamford, CT. He also served as President of the United Jewish Federation of Greater Stamford, New Canaan and Darien, served on the board of the United Way and as Chairman of the U.S. Savings Bond Campaign for Fairfield County. Ron is survived by his wife of 53 years Grecia Levin Gross, son Bradley Gross and his wife Stephanie Phillips of New York City, son Dr. Bennett Gross and his wife Jacqueline Sherman of San Diego, CA, brother James Gross of Tryon, NC, and his three grandchildren, Eli, Anderson, and Benjamin. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. 1/3

SCHOTTLAND--Stanley Adrian. If success can be measured by happiness, then Stan Schottland was a very successful man. He had a charmed life and in every way, the American dream. Stanley Adrian Schottland was born May 27th, 1919 in New York City to Ruth and Charles Schottland. He was predeceased by his older brother Jack. Stan attended DeWitt Clinton High School, but after his father died during his senior year, he chose to leave to go to work and help support his family. The year was 1936. Stan enlisted in the Army the day after Pearl Harbor, was promoted to Lieutenant and landed on Omaha beach in July 1944 as part of George Patton's army. He fought bravely and was wounded in action in September of that year. During his training state side, he met the love of his life Ellen Bordley Schottland in Sebring Florida. Ellen and Stan were married on December 24, 1944 in Chestertown, MD. They had three sons: Charles (Buck), Steven and Peter who they adored. Married more than sixty years, what a life they shared together. Stan and Ellen made friends all across the country where they owned homes including Bronxville, NY, Chestertown, Maryland, Rochester, NY, Gladwyne, PA, Cordillera, Colorado, Kiawah Island, SC, Hobe Sound, Florida and Naples, Florida. Soon after the war, he went back to work for Schenley Distillers where he began his career as an office boy years earlier. Stan was employed by Schenley for 27 years, including his three years while serving in the Army. With Stan's tenacious drive, he rose to the position of President of their Bourbon Division. In 1963, his career was flourishing but Stan was determined to own his own company. In 1966, he joined hands with a small bag manufacturer named American Bag and Paper located in Philadelphia and together they purchased Northern Packaging in Rochester, NY. Three years later, Stan was invited to come to Philadelphia and take over American Bag and Paper as a partner and CEO. In 1986, he bought out his partner with his three sons and grew the company to what is today American Packaging Corporation. American Packaging is one of America's largest privately owned flexible packaging companies employing over 800 families. Stan's philanthropic efforts were significant. With a passion for young talent and leadership skills, Stan founded several programs at the College of Charleston and Washington College. Another passion of Stan's was the health and well-being of children. American Packaging is one of the founding companies supporting Paul Newman's Hole in the Wall Gang Camp. While his military career was formidable, his business success quite remarkable and his charitable passions to be respected, at the end of the day, family was everything to him. Stan absolutely adored his elegant lady Ellen, his sons Buck, Steven and Peter, his 10 grandchildren and his 10 great-grandchildren. Most summers were spent on the Eastern Shore of Maryland surrounded by friends and family. In his later years after Ellen's passing, he had the blessing of companionship with a wonderful lady named Betty Flora. Stan touched so many people along the way and will be truly missed by all. God bless " Stan the man, Dad , Grandpa and GG Pop ". A Funeral Service will be held on Sunday, February 14 at 1:00pm at St. Paul's Kent Episcopal Church, Chestertown. A visitation will be held on Saturday evening February 13 from 5:00-7:00pm at Fellows, Helfenbein, and Newnam Funeral Home 130 Speer Road Chestertown, MD 21620. Interment will be following the service in St. Paul's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the Hole in the Wall Gang Camp in Stan's name: www.holeinthewallgang.org, 555 Long Wharf Dr, New Haven, CT 06511, (203)772-0522. www.fhnfuneralhome.com 1/3

GRUNWALD--Ilse. On February 3, 2016 at 93 years of age, Ilse Grunwald died peacefully at home surrounded by her loving family. Born May 11, 1922 in Ludwigshafen, Ilse escaped Nazi Germany at the age of 16 and after a year in England, arrived in NYC, December 23, 1939. Together with her mother, father, and brother, she started a small watch import firm, the J. Kalberman Co. After the war ended her new husband Ernest joined the firm and together they grew the business which eventually became Belair Time Corp., a thriving private label watch manufacturer. A fierce and savvy businesswoman, Ilse was devoted to growing her company and her beautiful family. A loving mother to Elaine and Alan. Cherished daughter, wife, sister, aunt, cousin, mother-in-law and grandmother. Married for 70 years, she is survived by her husband Ernest. Her strong spirit and loving generosity will never be forgotten. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 7 at 9:30am, Freeman Funeral Home, 344 Rt. 9 N., Manalapan, NJ 07726, followed by Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations to a charity of your choice. 1/3

BOYD--Karen Johnson, 91, of Racine, Wisconsin, died January 29 in her home following a brief illness. Born in Racine, May 16, 1924, she was a lifelong resident of Racine and of Cable, Wisconsin. She was the daughter of Herbert F. Johnson and Gertrude B. (nee Brauner) Johnson. She studied at Bennington College in Vermont. Mrs. Boyd was known internationally for her support of artists and arts education and particularly for her work on behalf of contemporary American craft artists. A longtime supporter of the Racine Art Museum (RAM), she has been a major contributor of artworks to RAM's collection, establishing the basis for what is now the largest contemporary craft collection in any United States art museum. Mrs. Boyd grew up in Wingspread, the home designed by Frank Lloyd Wright for her family in 1937. She loved the house so much that she commissioned her own Wright home, the Keland House, in 1954. That was the home she died in. In 1982, Mrs. Boyd opened Perimeter Gallery in Chicago which became one of the city's most respected contemporary art galleries, known and respected throughout the United States. She loved visiting museums and galleries and helping artists share their ideas with others by supporting exhibitions and publications. Her support of artists and cultural education for the general public were acknowledged numerous times including receipt of: Wisconsin Governor's Award in Support of the Arts and Wisconsin Visual Art Lifetime Achievement Award; Award of Distinction from the American Craft Council; and the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Museum of Arts and Design, New York City. She was featured in Art & Antiques magazine's annual 100 Top Collectors and in numerous articles in American Craft magazine. Although she was a world traveler, Mrs. Boyd most loved being with her family and friends in one of her two homes. She is preceded in death by her parents, her first husband Willard H. Keland, an infant son Willard H. Keland Jr., her daughter Andrea Kristine Moore (Tres), and her only sibling, her brother, Samuel C. Johnson. She is survived by her husband of nearly 34 years, Dr. William B. Boyd and three children: Katherine Nikolina Keland (John Krewal), Karen Henrietta Keland, Harold William Keland (Roxana), her granddaughter, Onnolee Keland, her sister-in-law Imogene Johnson, cousins, nieces, nephews, and a large extended family of friends. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service, Saturday, February 27, 2016, 2:00pm at First Presbyterian Church, 716 College Avenue, Racine. In lieu of flowers, memorials to the Racine Art Museum or the First Presbyterian Church of Racine are suggested. Maresh- Meredith and Acklam Funeral Home, 803 Main St, Racine, WI 53403, (262) 634-7888. Please send condolences to: meredithfuneralhome.com 1/3

KRUPP--Rosalind Mehr, of Verona, North Caldwell and Maplewood, NJ, born March 20, 1920 in New York City, died on February 5, 2016. She married Arthur Louis Krupp in 1942, and enjoyed a loving marriage for over 70 years until his death in May of 2013. She was predeceased by beloved brothers and sisters, Stan Mehr, Seymour Mehr, Gloria Bass, Rhoda Young and her grandson Josh Krupp. She is survived by her sons, Jan Krupp (Jan) of Napa, California, Bart Krupp (Pat) of Montclair, NJ, and Fred Krupp (Laurie Devitt) of Norwalk, CT, as well as her grandchildren Edward (Monika) and Staci Krupp (Grant Gerber), Sarah (Marcus Young) and Marcus Krupp, and Alex (Casey Hallen), Zach (Heidi) and Jackson Krupp, as well as great-grandchildren Emma, Phillip and Nathan Krupp, Estelle and Max Gerber. Rosalind graduated from Hunter College and received a Masters degree in History from Montclair State College. For many years she thrived teaching history at Verona High School, and then adult education. She was an avid gardener, and always enjoyed reading, whether The New York Times or a good history book. In later years she was often delighted to hear from former students who told her of the impact she had on their lives by inspiring them to believe in their own abilities. A graveside service will be held at noon on February 7 at Menorah Cemetery, 601 Passaic Ave, Clifton NJ, with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a contribution to the cause of your choice. 1/3

PAYNE--Evelyn, 66, died peacefully in her home in Hampton Bays on Friday, February 5, 2016. She was surrounded by her large loving family. Evelyn leaves behind her beloved spouse and best friend, Elizabeth Osgood. She is survived by her mother, Helen Rathkamp, brother, Walt Rathkamp, sister, Pat Kolbus and sister-in-law, Alice Leshinski. Evelyn was Auntie Mame to her many nieces, nephews, great nieces and nephews. She was a Partner in PS Direct, Inc. She will be dearly missed by her family, many friends and colleagues. The wake will be held Sunday, February 7 between 2pm and 7pm at J. Ronald Scott Funeral Home, 20 Ponquogue Avenue, Hampton Bays, NY. The funeral will be held Monday, February 8 in the morning at the Funeral Home. The family request that donations be made to the American Heart Association. 1/3

WILSON--William. William Smith Wilson III, 83, beloved brother, father and grandfather, died in Manhattan on Monday, February 1, 2016 from cardiac arrest. Born in Baltimore in 1932, he was raised in Maryland, attended the University of Virginia for his B.A., Yale University for his Ph.D. and taught college as a professor of English in Queens College, City University of New York from 1962 until his retirement in the early 1990s. While raising three children in Chelsea he published a collection of short stories, "Why I Don't Write Like Franz Kafka" (1975), and the novel "Birthplace" (1982). The son of sculptor and painter May Wilson, he was deeply involved in the post-war New York art world, the subject of his numerous published essays. Survivors include his sister, Betty Jane Butler, children Katherine, Ara and Andrew and grandchildren Jack, Alex, Augusta and Josephine. Contributions may be offered in his honor to PBS public television (www.thirteen.org), the High Line (https://www.thehighline.org/donate) or the Baltimore Museum, (https://artbma.org/give- join/give.html#

NITZE--Sheila MacNeille, age 79, died peacefully on December 26th in the home of her son Peter in Seattle surrounded by three of her children. She is survived by her children, Peter A. Nitze, Andrew H. Nitze, Amanda G. Sanfilippo, and Benjamin M. Nitze; her eight grandchildren; her three great-grandchildren; and her brother John R. MacNeille, III. Sheila was born in New York in 1936 to John R. MacNeille and Cynthia Goodwin MacNeille, and grew up with her sister and brother on a sheep farm in Pittstown, New Jersey. She attended Harvard University, marrying Peter P. Nitze in 1957 as a junior, before graduating with two young boys in 1959. The family moved to New York in 1960, where Sheila became engaged with the civil rights and peace movements, working for the Kennedy campaigns and the Black Panthers. Sheila volunteered for Amnesty International and the American Friends Service Committee for many years, and later in life, for Tibet House. She was a brilliant and beautiful woman, committed to social justice, whose varied friendships spanned cultural divides. Sheila was also a poet, a dancer, and a lifelong teacher of children and young adults whose lives were not as fortunate as hers. She worked for Floating The Apple Inner City Youth Boatbuilding Project, teaching grant writing and English literature. She also taught at the Correctional Educational Consortium, tutoring students who came through rehabilitation and parole programs. Her dedication to education as a form of liberation from social injustice and poverty was tireless. Sheila will be remembered for her vibrant spirit and her extraordinary presence. She could make a stone laugh out loud. Her sharp humor and distinct style, her love of dance, and the Irish language and culture were her passion and solace in life. She will be missed and dearly remembered by her family, and by all those who encountered her resilient and powerful spirit. 1/3

SMITH--Philip B. The partners of iQ Venture Advisors mourn the death of Phil Smith, our founder, leader, and mentor. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife Linda and to the Smith family. 1/3

O'NEILL--Mary Jane. The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration mourns the loss of its former executive director (1980-2000) Mary Jane O'Neill, the fifth director in the history of the organization which was founded in 1944. Her leadership in the field here and on a national level earned her the Eye Bank Association of America's (EBAA) prestigious Heise Award in 1997 and the Mary Jane O'Neill Fellowship in International Eye Banking was established in her honor in 2002. During her years leading The Eye-Bank, more than 25,000 New Yorkers received the beautiful gift of sight. Her legacy will live on in the vision of others. The Board of Directors and Patricia Dahl, Executive Director/CEO The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration 1/3

ROBERTS--Nancy G.,formerly of Westbury, NY, died on Saturday, January 30th at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, MA after a brief illness. She was 79. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Nancy was the wife of the late Arthur Roberts. Prior to her retirement in 2005, Mrs. Roberts had worked as a guidance counselor in the New York City Public School System for nearly 40 years, working in several schools during her career, including P.S. 1 and P.S. 41 in Manhattan. Mrs. Roberts earned her undergraduate degree from Fordham University and a Master's Degree in Education from New York University. She is survived by her son, Charles Roberts, her brother, John Gerardi and a sister, Kathleen Wicks. She was predeceased by her daughter Roanna Roberts in 2013. If desired, memorial donations in Nancy's name may be made to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, the Soup Kitchen in Provincetown or the Provincetown Rescue Squad. 1/3

CEDARBAUM--Miriam Goldman. Died peacefully on February 5, at the age of 86. Judge Cedarbaum is survived by her two sons and daughters-in-law, Daniel Goldman Cedarbaum (Caryn Jacobs) and Jonathan Goldman Cedarbaum (Alice Winkler), her four grandchildren, Jacob Cedarbaum, Samuel Goldman Cedarbaum, Louis Cedarbaum and Dahlia Cedarbaum, and by her beloved companion Bob Ehrenbard.
