Kaplan Center for Jewish Peoplehood: kaplancenter.org or Barnard College: barnard.edu/barnard-giving. 1/3

MacCRATE--Constance. Constance "Connie" Trapp MacCrate, long time resident of Plandome, Long Island, New York, passed away on January 21, 2016 at the age of 95. Beloved wife of Robert; sister to Harry, Virginia, and Jackie; mother to Christopher, Barbara and Thomas; mother-in-law to Kari, Chuck, and Claire; grandmother to Ryan, Kyle, Samantha, Matthew, Elisa, Kristia, Danielle, Caitlin, Juliet, and Isobel, and great grandmother to Brandon, Charlotte, Maverick, Daemon, Wade, and Aurora. She was the guiding light of the MacCrate family. Born in Laconia, New Hampshire in 1920 to Judge Harry Trapp and Florence McGloughlin Trapp, she lived her life as a true New Hampshirite, following the state motto: Live Free or Die, and taught by example humility, kindness, and resolve (some say stubbornness) to all who met her. Devoted to children and education, she volunteered for many years at Shelter Rock School, taught Sunday school at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, and never missed a game or recital or anything else her kids participated in, always offering her unfaltering support. She was a true constant in her family's lives. Connie matriculated from Mount Holyoke College in 1942, went on to work at Harvard Business School, and met her husband, Robert MacCrate, while he was attending Harvard Law School. They were married on May 4,1946 in Laconia, New Hampshire, and spent the next 69 years together, until her passing with Robert at her side. She was remembered privately by the family. Those who would like to share in her remembrance may send memorial gifts to The Legal Aid Society of New York (www.donate.legal-aid.org); questions regarding these gifts may be directed to Connie's granddaughter Caitlin MacCrate (cjmaccrate@ gmail.com), who is running the New York City Half Marathon to benefit the Legal Aid Society in her grandmother's honor. 1/3

LOVETT--Lawrence D. Venetian Heritage Inc. and Fondazione Venetian Heritage Onlus mourn the death of its Founding Chairman, Lawrence D. Lovett, who was a distinguished member of the boards for more than 15 years. Larry served in the US Army from 1954-1956. He graduated Harvard College with honors and Harvard Law School in 1954. He began his career as a cargo ship and tanker broker in New York and went on to become VP of Eastern Steamship Lines. He then joined his family companies as President of Burgoyne Properties Company, Suwance Steamship Company and the Piggly Wiggly Corporation simultaneously. Larry was devoted to the arts, primarily the Metropolitan Opera. He served as President of the Board of the Metropolitan Opera Guild from 1971-1979 and Chairman from 1979 to 1986. He was President of the Metropolitan Opera Association Board, Chairman of its Executive Committee and Chairman of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. In 1996 he devoted himself to restoration projects in Venice and in 1998 founded Venetian Heritage, raising funds for the preservation of Venetian art and architecture in Venice and those regions of the Mediterranean rim subject to Venetian influence. On behalf of the board, we extend our sincere condolences to his family. We will miss him. Pierre Durand, Venetian Heritage Inc., Chairman and President; Valentina Nasi Marini Clarelli, Fondazione Venetian Heritage Onlus, President 1/3

KIETA--Arlene Marie, 1993- 2016. Arlene M. Kieta passed away after a courageous battle with COPD on January 25, 2016 in New York City. Born on July 30, 1933 in Chicago, IL to Bruno Charles and Marie Ester Fedro Kieta. Among her many accomplishments: former beauty queen, model, convention narrator, Broadway, film, and television actress including game show co-host, radio disk jockey, and, as a successful Entrepreneur, she established her own public relations firm specializing in fashion, food, and travel sectors. Arlene was a stunningly beautiful woman matched only by her inner beauty. Arlene had a continuous involvement in philanthropic endeavors partially including: Polish Assistance League; Light House for the Blind; Metropolitan Opera; Guggenheim Museum of Modern Art; NYC Public Library; Notre Dame High School (Arlene Kieta Communications Scholarship); Father Wasson's "Friends of the Orphans" (board member and supporting a Godchild in ten different countries); and Knights of Malta, "Lady of Justice." Arlene was preceded in death by her loving parents and dear brother Raymond. She is survived by her close and loving brother Dennis L. (Cindy), his children, Kristine M., Derek R. (Emily), Kimberly A. Cermak (Jeff), Cody K., and stepson Ryan Rasmussen, along with five great-nieces and nephews; numerous relatives, godchildren, and lifelong friends. A Memorial Mass will be held at Our Saviour Catholic Church (38th and Park) on Friday, February 12th at 10:00am, with private interment later in Chicago. Please do not send flowers, as Our Saviour Church will not display flowers during Lent. In honor of Arlene's giving spirit, the family requests any memorial contributions be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3

SPELMAN--Laurence A.,retired New York attorney, died Sunday, January 31, at his home in Sarasota, FL. He was 87. He leaves his devoted wife Dorothy; sister Marcia and husband Burt de Fren; daughter Erika; son Paul and his wife Erin; grandchildren Emily Figueroa, Jeremy, Billy and Janie Spelman. He was a graduate of Columbia College and Law School and NYU (LLM). Spelman was associated with Davis Polk Wardwell and later was a partner at Robinson Silverman, et al. where he specialized in estates and matrimonial law. He was a member of the New York and Florida bars. He played the banjo, and loved sports, jazz, theatre and classical music. He also loved to regale friends with songs and poetry. His life will be celebrated in March in Sarasota, Florida. 1/3

RANSOM--Louise Bristol, born November 23, 1921 in New York City, died peacefully in Shelburne, VT on December 10, 2015. The daughter of Lawrence and Bell Bristol of Pelham, she was predeceased by her husband, Robert C. Ransom, who died in 1986. Louise was a graduate of the Brearley School and Vassar College '42. She lived in Bronxville for 35 years and in Vermont for another 35. Following the death in 1968 of her oldest son, Mike, in Vietnam, Louise began an extensive effort to end that war and to address the many issues that followed in its wake. Louise was a doer and a leader, and she inspired others to do and lead as well. She is survived by a sister, five sons, five grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. There will be a memorial service for Louise on April 23 at 2:00pm, at Wake Robin in Shelburne, Vermont. 1/3

WILSON--William S. The Ray Johnson Estate mourns the passing of William S. "Bill" Wilson, who died on February 1, 2016. Bill, called "Ray Johnson's Boswell" by New York Times writer Michael Kimmelman, was one of Johnson's closest friends and his unwavering champion. He generously welcomed students and scholars to his extraordinary Johnson archive and wrote brilliant essays that provided deep insight into Johnson, his era and his work. Always generous with sharing his profound knowledge, Bill returned questions posed to him from all over the world through ever inspired and voluminous emails, phone calls and letters. He was truly a correspondent extraordinaire. There is no doubt that his legacy and work will only continue to expand its reach in the future. The Ray Johnson Estate is profoundly grateful for the many thrilling conceptions and inceptions, on Ray Johnson and in all of his art scholarship, with which Bill has left us. The art world, this estate, and his many friends and family, have lost a cherished friend and mentor. Richard L. Feigen, Chairman Frances F. L. Beatty, President, Richard L. Feigen & Co. 1/3

BLOCK--Jeffrey L.,died January 12, 2016 in Westport, CT, beloved husband of Helen for 35 years. He was the proud father of Mike Meredith and Gabriel and the grandfather of three. MUELLER--John Cochran, 80, died on January 21, 2016. He was born in Lancaster, PA, but was a lifelong resident of New York City and Fire Island. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University (1956) and the University of Pennsylvania Law School (1959), he practiced law with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy for a number of years, during which time he also served in the U.S. Army reserve. His great love was the theater and he was the consummate theatergoer and supporter, not only attending plays but providing financial support to a number of off-Broadway plays over the years. He served on several non-profit boards, including Urban Stages and Plays for Living. He had a wonderful sense of humor, was a marvelous pianist and a very talented photographer, was a most loyal friend and possessed a gift for bringing people together. He had a magnificent collection of motion pictures on tape and disc, which he organized alphabetically by studio. He was a member of Holland Lodge No. 8, F. & A.M. and for a number of years was a member of The Players and The Yale Club of New York City. John is survived by his brother, Paul A. Mueller, Jr. and his wife, Jane, of Lancaster, and three nieces, Anne M. Leahy, Southern Pines, NC, Catherine M. Boyer, Oxford, New Zealand, and Elizabeth G. Mueller, La Jolla, CA, and four grand-nieces and a grand-nephew. He was buried in a private ceremony in Lancaster. A memorial service will be scheduled in New York City in the spring. Memorial remembrances can be made to Urban Stages, 555 8th Avenue, Room 1800, New York 10018. 1/3

CONNORS--James P.,Jr., longtime Judge in Eastchester and Bronxville resident passed away at the age of 86 years. He had been suffering from Alzheimer's Disease. Jim was born on May 31, 1929 to James P. Connors, Sr. and Kathryn Ryan Connors in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Jim grew up in Yonkers and in Eastchester, attending Iona Grammar and High schools and earning a degree in Economics from Fordham University in the Bronx in 1950 where he was the school's squash champion his senior year. He earned his JD from St. John's Law School in Queens in 1953. Jim was drafted into the Army's JAG office later in 1953 and stationed in Hokkaido, Japan. Private Connors went 3-0 defending fellow soldiers accused of various charges, earning several letters of commendation for his service and a promotion to the rank of Sargent. After his military service, Jim launched a nearly 60 year career in private law practice, the bulk of which as a Partner with Smith, Ranscht, Pollock, Manos & Connors in White Plains, NY. He most recently was of counsel to the law firm of Bertine, Hufnagel, Headley, Zeltner, Drummond & Dohn in Eastchester. Jim was active in local Republican politics throughout his career, serving as President of the young Republicans of Westchester County. He also served as the Town Justice of Eastchester from 1983-2011 and was legal counsel and Board Member to the Tuckahoe Savings & Loan and its successor companies. Jim is survived by his devoted wife of 57 years, the former Margaret Gallagher of Larchmont and his sons James Patrick, III (Angela- d. 2015) of Mount Vernon, Michael (Kendall) of Piedmont CA, Mark (Kelly) of Bronxville and Paul (Leeanna) of Croton-on-Hudson and nine grandchildren. Jim was reunited in God's graces with his daughter Meg, who passed away from Hodgkins Disease in 1985 at the age of 25. He is also survived by his brother John of Wilton CT, his close cousin Mary Jo McLoughlin of Garden City, LI and numerous nieces and nephews. Jim recently shared with Peggy how thankful he felt for all the blessings he had enjoyed in his life. He loved his family and he loved his community. Jim worked hard to have a positive impact on both-succeeding wonderfully on both fronts. And no Memorial Day Parade in Bronxville was complete without Jim marching in his straw bowler. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 4-7pm Saturday and Sunday. A Mass of Resurrection will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville, NY where Jim spent his life actively participating as an altar server, a Parish Council member and, until last month, as a Lector on Monday, February 8 at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Jim's honor to the following: Inner-City Scholarship Fund, innercityscholarshipfund.org or Doctors Without Borders, doctorswithoutborders.org 1/3

WENDT--Lorna. Lorna Joyce Jorgenson Wendt of Stamford, Connecticut, passed away surrounded by her family on Thursday, February 4, 2016 due to complications associated with Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Leukemia. It was a brief illness diagnosed less than six months ago. Survived by her two daughters Sarah Wendt (Andrew Regier) and Rachel Nash (Derek Nash), and her three adored grandchildren Riley, Audrey and William. In addition, she leaves behind her loving partner of seventeen years, Spencer Dean Wallin, and her siblings Karen Rudrud, Kathy Seyberth, Ruth Nordal, Ronald Jorgenson and Rick Jorgenson, among many loved family members and dear friends. She is pre-deceased by her mother and father, Esther and J. Obert Jorgenson, and her sister Rachel Jorgenson. Born in Minot, North Dakota in 1943, Lorna spent her childhood primarily in Wisconsin. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin, Madison with a B.A. in Music. After living in Boston, Houston, Atlanta and Miami with her husband and two daughters, the family moved to Stamford, CT in 1975. Courageous, determined, feisty, strong and giving are words that describe Lorna's legacy and influence on many. She was a pioneer in the quest for equality before, during and after marriage. Lorna started a national discussion on fairness and equality in all relationships when her 32 year marriage ended and she publicly defended her role as an equal partner. Realizing there was a need to help others understand the many facets of equality, Lorna founded and led the Equality in Marriage Institute from 1998 until its closure in 2008. The mission of this work and the important discussions will live on through MORE, the Money, Relationships & Equality initiative at the University of Wisconsin her alma mater. This program was launched as part of the University School of Human Ecology's 4W Initiative, of which she was named Chair. Lorna had a lifelong commitment to many civic and nonprofit organizations, serving on the boards of Outward Bound International, the Stamford Symphony, and the Greenwich Choral Society. She was a founding benefactor of the Women's Philanthropy Institute, which is now a part of the School of Philanthropy at Indiana University. A lifelong musician, she taught music, sang with many choirs and was a former member of the Board of Visitors for the School of Music and the College of Letters and Science. Lorna shared her love of exploration and belief in experiential education with her family and friends, travelling the seven continents and setting foot in more than 150 countries, leaving lifelong memories. A memorial service will be held at 1pm on Saturday, February 20th at St. John's Lutheran Church in Stamford. In lieu of flowers, the family is asking donations be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, the Lorna Jorgenson Wendt Legacy Fund of MORE or to the Young Women's Leadership Network. 1/3

DALEY--Patrick, died February 5, 2016. Patrick Daley, Senior Vice President and Publisher, Scholastic Education, is mourned by his colleagues and friends who were honored to publish the brilliant and engaging reading programs he developed that helped transform the lives of millions of students. As a young classroom teacher in Burlington, VT, Patrick got some advice that would change his life: you must do whatever it takes to get them to read. He joined Scholastic in 1988, vowing to create the highest-quality, most engaging reading materials that would help even the most profoundly struggling readers to read with joy. Patrick was the editor of Scholastic Action magazine, which serves at-risk students and went on to develop READ 180, the premier reading intervention program for grades 3-12. His passion for helping children learn to read was his driving force. He put his heart and soul into READ 180 and other programs designed to serve the diverse populations of children who needed stories in which they could find themselves. It is thanks to Patrick Daley and his big ideas, bigger energy, and huge heart that millions of children have learned to read. His wisdom and passionate dedication to children will remain with all who knew and worked with him. Patrick is survived by his loving husband Daryl Hair and two sisters, Mary and Kathy along with extended family. Richard Robinson CEO, Scholastic 1/3

He introduced many music lovers among his large circle of friends to the Society and left an indelible legacy on which we continue to build. He will be much missed. 1/3
GRESHAM--Archie Lewis. May 6, 1944-July 12, 2015. Beloved son, brother, friend, father, uncle and grandaddy. His laughter and friendship will be missed. 1/3

TISHMAN--John, New York, NY, age 90. Devoted father and grandfather and legendary builder. Born and raised in New York, the City he loved and devoted his life to improving. Graduated from the University of Michigan at the age of 20 as an electrical engineer and a commissioned officer in the Navy. Remained active with his alma mater for the rest of his life. He joined the family real estate business in 1948. During a long career, he pioneered the industry of construction management. As a builder he oversaw the construction of many iconic projects, including three of the first four 100+ story buildings in the world, including the original World Trade Center. As a former teacher, he was a leading philanthropist, who dedicated resources to education, arts and science. He was a former Chairman of the board of trustees of The New School. He has served on the Boards of Directors of other prominent New York institutions, including Carnegie Hall. In 1997, he was named a "Living Landmark" by the New York Landmarks Conservancy. He was predeceased by his wife, Suzanne in 2005. He is survived by his daughter Katherine Blacklock, his son Daniel R. Tishman and his daughter-in-law Sheryl Crockett Tishman, and three grandsons, Joshua Tishman, Gabriel Tishman and Kyle Blacklock. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The New School. After a private service, the family will receive friends on Monday, February 8, from 5:30-8:00pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. A public memorial will be held at a later date. 1/3

MILLER--Irwin Bernard, aged 88, born 1927 (forever known as Bud) peacefully passed amongst his family on January 29, 2016 in Miami due to complications from COPD. He was born in Newark, NJ, the youngest son of Herman and Rose Miller. A serial jokester he never revealed his generous, kind and loving side. Quietly and privately he took care of friends, family and employees in need. After graduating Weequahic High School, he joined the army as WWII was ending and the Korean war beginning. Taking his brother's advice he did not re-up and was honorably discharged. Using the GI Bill, he attended NYU and received a degree in Mechanical Engineering. After working for his brother for several years he went out on his own. Then he joined with two good and complimentary-minded men to form Miller Proctor Nickolas, a company that sold and serviced industrial and commercial heating products. Business associates described him as an innovator and having a strong business acumen, which helped MPN thrive and prosper. He was proud of what he had helped create and was sad to retire. Colleagues and employees were saddened to see him go. His company was family. Bud's real-time family fulfilled his life. In 1964, he married Patricia Breckir and they moved from NYC to Huntington, Long Island where they began raising a family. After 10 years they moved to Mt. Kisco, NY, where they lived for 28 years. He was a proud father and worked hard at being a good one, being generous, loving, a disciplinarian when necessary, and equally bragging when deserved. Upon raising their children, Bud and Pat retired to Ocean Reef, FL and Rockport, MA. Among friends he was one of the most loyal and honorable you could have. After fifty one years of marriage and many days with his loved ones and friends, fishing, playing tennis, exercising, tinkering, singing, riding his scooter, reading voraciously, napping in his chair, sending jokes via email, and vividly expressing his opinions he is survived by his wife, Pat, their three children Jane, (Bart), James, Luke (Jen), his five grandchildren, Olivia, Lily, Owen, Zaneta and Clementine, his nephews Michael and Richard and his "girly" Sugar the dog. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to People For The American Way, The ASPCA, Doctors Without Borders or any humanitarian cause of your choice. 1/3

FITZSIMONS--John J. The Board of Directors of 950 Park Avenue notes with sadness the death of our board president on January 22, 2016. We will miss our leader and good neighbor. Our thoughts are with John's family. 1/3

HALPIN--William Curtis, died peacefully at home on January 26 after prolonged battles with advanced prostate cancer. Born August 22, 1929, he was the son of the late John Hadden Halpin and the late Josephine Roll Young. Having attended Monclair public schools, he graduated from Dartmouth College in 1951. He served in the U.S. Air Force from 1951 to 1955 as a radar observer in B-59 sorties over North Korea. Having joined Oxford University Press in 1955, he remained for 26 years, retiring in 1981 as Executive Vice President of the New York office. Relocated to Key West, Florida, he co-founded the Real Estate Company of Key West Inc. There he was active on the boards of the Key West Art and Historical Society and the Hospice-VNA of the Florida Keys. He subsequently retired to Fort Lauderdale, FL, where he lived with his longtime partner of 21 years, Calvin Victor Temenski. They were married in 2015. He was predeceased by his parents, his brother, Robert T. Halpin of Dallas, Texas and his sister, Sally H. Knaus of Oneonta, New York and survived by his brother, the Honorable Judge Jack Halpin, ten nieces and nephews and many grand-nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date in the summer of 2016 in Essex, New York. Details to be announced. 1/3

MOORE--Alan G. Kane Lodge No. 454, F. & A. M. mourns with profound sadness the death of our esteemed Brother and Life Member, Alan G. Moore, DSA on December 28, 2015. Born August 14, 1942 in Newark, NJ, he was raised at Kane Lodge on December 5, 1978 and served the craft faithfully for 38 years. A CPA and tax consultant for decades, Brother Moore served as Secretary and was a member of the Nominating Committee for many years. He will be missed by all who knew him. Mikhail Geller, Assistant Secretary Roger A. Becker, Master 1/3

ANLYAN--William G.,M.D. Dean and Chancellor of Duke University Medical Center 1964-1990, Chancellor of Duke University 1990-1995, and later, trustee of the Duke Endowment for 24 years, died at age 90 on January 17, 2016. Anlyan presided over a major expansion of Duke University Hospital and nearly four million square feet of new or renovated facilities. He oversaw the transformation of Duke's medical school into one of the country's foremost medical centers. An innovator in medical education, he instituted new programs such as the Physician's Assistant Program. During his first year as Dean he procured grants for all 100 medical students. Dr. Anlyan was extraordinarily sensitive to human emotion, and was recognized as a charismatic communicator, able to listen and identify with all. Anlyan grew up in Alexandria, Egypt, the son of a British civil servant. In 1943 he entered Yale College, graduating Magna Cum Laude in 15 months. In 1949 he graduated from Yale with his medical degree. In 1999, he received the Distinguished Alumni Service Award from the Association of Yale Alumni in Medicine. Anlyan was the first chairman of the Association of American Medical Colleges, a founding member of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, chair of Research America and a recipient of the Abraham Flexner Award for his contributions to medical education. Active in the World Health Organization, he led a delegation to China in 1975. He was author or editor of nine books and more than 100 medical articles. Survivors include his wife, Alexandra Hufty Anlyan of Durham, NC and Palm Beach, FL; his children and their spouses, Elaine and William G. Anlyan, Jr. of Wilmington, NC, Harriet and J. Peter Anlyan of Durham, NC and Louise Anlyan Harris and Ramsey Dabby of Tenafly, NJ; seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A memorial service was celebrated February 6 at Duke University. Online memorials at: www.hallwynne.com. 1/3

CEDARBAUM--Miriam Goldman. With heartfelt sadness, the Trustees and Administration of Barnard College mourn the passing of the Honorable Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum '50, who was a devoted alumna, a Barnard Trustee from 1993 to 2004, and an active trustee emerita. In 1991, she received the College's highest honor, the Barnard Medal of Distinction, for the stellar example she set for women in the legal profession, for her wise and profound counsel, and for all she has done for her alma mater. Barnard honors the memory of this extraordinary woman and extends its deepest sympathies to her family and many friends. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald, Chair, Board of Trustees Debora Spar, President 1/3

WINSLOW--Eunice J.,of Locust Valley, NY on February 2, 2016. Wife of the late Scudder. Mother of Rolla Bruce Campbell, Eunice Graham Strigaro, the late Alison Fraser Swain and Cynthia Coit Waters. Sister of Priscilla Johnson McMillan, the late Stuart Holmes Johnson Jr. and Frank Coit Johnson II. Grandmother of April, Brooke, Caroline, Elisabeth, Allison, Stephen, Madeline, Randall, William and Timothy. Great-grandmother of five. Service at St. John's of Lattingtown, Tuesday, February 9th at 11am. Interment private. DodgeThomas.com. 1/3

DUBIN--Randi. Randi Thulin Dubin, who was admired by family and friends for her vivacious spirit, compassionate nature and resilience, died peacefully in her sleep at her home in East Hampton, NY at the age of 61. She was born on June 14, 1954, on Staten Island, NY. She received a BA in psychology from the City University of New York and a MA in counseling at Columbia University. She lived in Manhattan with her husband, Michael Dubin, whom she married in 1982. She and her husband raised three daughters, Krista, Erika and Karoline, who each regard her as their best friend. Randi was selflessly devoted to her daughters and had the ability to make others feel part of the family. She was known as a film aficionado, a gifted chef and a close confidante. Randi had a lifelong interest in advocating for animal rights, adopting four rescue animals and volunteering with Camp Rusk, a foundation for retired horses. While struggling with a motor neuropathy, she inspired us with her sharp wit and vibrant sense of humor. Her ashes will be scattered onto Accabonac Harbor off the dock of the Dubins' Hamptons property. In addition to her daughters and her husband, she is survived by her parents, Einar and Louise Thulin of Staten Island, NY, and two brothers, Richard Thulin of Bethlehem, PA, and John-David Thulin of Southampton, NY. A memorial service will be held on Sat February 20th at 10:30am in Manhattan at St. Jean Baptiste Church (184 East 76th Street). 1/3

LOVETT--Lawrence Dow, passed away at the age of 86 on February 1, 2016 in Monte Carlo, Monaco after a brief illness. Larry was born and raised in Jacksonville, Florida. He graduated from Lee High School in 1947, Harvard College in 1951, and Harvard Law School in 1954. Following his service in the United States Army, Larry spent the next 25 years helping his family build and amass a vast and diverse portfolio of businesses in the oil tanker, grain and cargo shipping, cruise line, grocery, real estate, and shipyard industries. An accomplished pianist himself, Larry was dedicated to the arts. For over 45 years, he was a distinguished member of the Metropolitan Opera Board: Managing Director from 1971 to 1989; Honorary Director from 1989 until his death; President of the Metropolitan Opera Guild from 1971 to 1979; Guild Chairman from 1979 to 1986; Metropolitan Opera National Council. He was also Chairman of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center from 1988 to 1993, and a board member of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. For more than 30 years, Larry lived in Venice, Italy, and was actively involved with restoration projects there. In 1998, he founded Venetian Heritage, whose mission is to safeguard the cultural heritage found in the architecture, music, and art in Venice and other places throughout the former Venetian Empire. Larry was a true gentleman - gracious, kind, and generous - who was well known and well loved. He will be remembered as a man of many talents, a devoted and loyal friend, and a welcoming and impeccable host. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Donations may be made to Venetian Heritage, 232 East 59th Street, 5th Floor, New York, New York 10022. 1/3

RUTENBERG--Alice, 93 years old, died on February 1, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Bill and Marsha and Jon and Debbie. Cherished grandmother of Craig (Stephanie), Diana, Michael (Stacey), Jamie, and Lauren (Jay). Loving great-grandmother of Jonah and Lyla. Graveside services Sunday at 11am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. 1/3

RAPPAPORT--Dollsey G. We celebrate the life of Dollsey Gottfried Rappaport, sweet sister of Elissa Gottfried Epstein (Lovey), and aunt of Jill Epstein White, Mark Epstein, Debra Epstein and great-aunt to their children. Dollsey was above all an incredible mother to Nanette Rosenberg and Marjorie Rozman. Her wonderful grandchildren and great-grandchildren were the jewels of her life. She was amazing with them, and left a legacy of love of family and devotion to her religion. She was lucky to live to have great- grandchildren who lovingly called her GG. She got her wish to live long enough to welcome the family's newest addition Sammy, and knew another grandchild was on the way. She will also be remembered as a magnanimous philanthropist, and generous supporter of United Jewish Appeal and the State of Israel. Our parents Lola Mishkin Gottfried and Charles Gottfried were the inspiration of our family and are remembered now, as always. 1/3

TABB--Stephen (Steve), passed away on Saturday, February 6th at the age of 89. He was born in Brooklyn, New York. He is survived by his wife, Jeanette Tabb, and his four daughters, sons-in- law and grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at noon on Monday, February 8th. 1/3

MacCRATE--Constance. Constance "Connie" Trapp MacCrate, long time resident of Plandome, Long Island, New York, passed away on January 21, 2016 at the age of 95. Beloved wife of Robert; sister to Harry, Virginia, and Jackie; mother to Christopher, Barbara and Thomas; mother-in-law to Kari, Chuck, and Claire; grandmother to Ryan, Kyle, Samantha, Matthew, Elisa, Kristia, Danielle, Caitlin, Juliet, and Isobel, and great grandmother to Brandon, Charlotte, Maverick, Daemon, Wade, and Aurora. She was the guiding light of the MacCrate family. Born in Laconia, New Hampshire in 1920 to Judge Harry Trapp and Florence McGloughlin Trapp, she lived her life as a true New Hampshirite, following the state motto: Live Free or Die, and taught by example humility, kindness, and resolve (some say stubbornness) to all who met her. Devoted to children and education, she volunteered for many years at Shelter Rock School, taught Sunday school at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, and never missed a game or recital or anything else her kids participated in, always offering her unfaltering support. She was a true constant in her family's lives. Connie matriculated from Mount Holyoke College in 1942, went on to work at Harvard Business School, and met her husband, Robert MacCrate, while he was attending Harvard Law School. They were married on May 4,1946 in Laconia, New Hampshire, and spent the next 69 years together, until her passing with Robert at her side. She was remembered privately by the family. Those who would like to share in her remembrance may send memorial gifts to The Legal Aid Society of New York (www.donate.legal-aid.org); questions regarding these gifts may be directed to Connie's granddaughter Caitlin MacCrate (cjmaccrate@ gmail.com), who is running the New York City Half Marathon to benefit the Legal Aid Society in her grandmother's honor. 1/3

CEDARBAUM--Miriam Goldman. With profound sadness, we mourn the passing of the Honorable Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, who was the devoted sister of the late Ruth Goldman Schapiro, the aunt of Jane and Robert Schapiro (Lillian), great-aunt to Rebecca, Ruth, and Sarah Schapiro, and sister-in-law to Linda N. Schapiro and close friend to Linda's children, Joshua Solomon (Geula), Abigail Solomon (Jason Teuscher), and Kate Solomon (David Wasserman). She will always be a source of wisdom and inspiration to all of us. 1/3

MITTENTHAL--Richard, 89, died January 23, 2016 in Sarasota, FL. Arbitrator of labor- management disputes for almost his entire 58 year career, he served as umpire in major industries, including steel, automotive, beverage and government service. Mittenthal wrote many papers on the craft of arbitration, including an oft-cited article on past practice. He served as President of the National Academy of Arbitrators (1978-79) and received a lifetime achievement award from the Michigan Bar in 2015. Raised in NYC, he graduated Cornell University and New York University law school. He was predeceased by his loving wife of 61 years, Joyce Janeway. They married in 1953 and moved to Detroit, MI where he spent the majority of his life and career. He was not only devoted to his work, but to being husband and father. He loved tennis, practiced poetry and was a fervent football fan. The rigor he displayed in his work carried to all aspects of his life. He was driven to know the "you" of you, your values, the reasoning underlying them, your deep thoughts. And his courage in sharing all those things about himself encouraged you to feel sufficiently accepted and secure to respond in kind. In his 1979 NAA presidential address, he quipped that he'd experienced a dream where he saw the headline on his own obituary. It read: "Arbitrator seeks immortality; grievance denied." He is survived by four children, Marilyn, Robert, John and Peter, and four grandchildren. Donations to American Cancer Society. 1/3

TISHMAN--John. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of John Tishman, legendary builder and a distinguished and prominent philanthropist who devoted his life to making his hometown New York City a better place to live and work. A pioneer and leader of the construction management industry, John supervised the building of many world class projects including the construction of three of the four earliest 100 plus story skyscrapers: the original World Trade Center and the John Hancock Center in Chicago, IL. We express our heartfelt condolences to his son, REBNY Governor and Executive Committee member Daniel Tishman, his daughter Katherine Blacklock and the entire Tishman family. Rob Speyer, Chairman John Banks, President 1/3

BRADLEY--David William, former Maine journalist and NYNEX executive, died at his home in Georgetown, ME on February 1, 2016. Born August 3, 1941 in Somerville, MA, he was the son of Richard and Eleanor (Sullivan) Bradley. In 1972 he joined the New England Telephone Company in their Employee Communications department. He held several positions with New England Telephone and New York Telephone, ending his career in 1997 as the Director of Video Services for NYNEX in New York City. He leaves behind his wife of 51 years, Elizabeth Emerson Bradley and his two daughters, Jennifer Bradley Petersen and Rebecca Jane Sethi as well as their husbands, Edward Petersen and Harneet Sethi. He also is survived by four grandchildren: Joshua and Benjamin Petersen and Hannah and Amelia Sethi. His sister Carolyn Bradley Whittaker of Hemet, CA also survives him, as do several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Tate House Museum Preservation Fund would be appreciated. 1/3

TISHMAN--John. The New School mourns the loss of John L. Tishman, a longtime trustee and former chair of The New School and real estate magnate who helped transform the face of the university's campus and the New York City skyline. At the helm of Tishman Realty & Construction, Mr. Tishman left his mark on a number of iconic American landmarks, from the World Trade Center and the renovation of Carnegie Hall in New York City to The John Hancock Center in Chicago and Walt Disney Company's EPCOT Center in Orlando. Serving on the board of trustees of The New School from 1981 until his death and also as chairman of the board from 1995 until 2001, Mr. Tishman generously led the way for the creation of several key projects at the university, including the Tishman Environment and Design Center and the University Center. His vision and leadership made a profound impact on The New School and his legacy will live on to benefit generations of students. We extend our condolences to the Tishman family, including his son, Daniel, and his daughter-in-law, Sheryl Crockett Tishman; his daughter, Katherine Blacklock; and his three grandchildren. 1/3

KURZWEIL--Edith D.,died peacefully on February 6, four days after a stroke. A Holocaust survivor, prolific scholar, and editor, Edith was born in Vienna in 1924. KRUPP--Rosalind Mehr, of Verona, North Caldwell and Maplewood, NJ, born March 20, 1920 in New York City, died on February 5, 2016. She married Arthur Louis Krupp in 1942, and enjoyed a loving marriage for over 70 years until his death in May of 2013. She was predeceased by beloved brothers and sisters, Stan Mehr, Seymour Mehr, Gloria Bass, Rhoda Young and her grandson Josh Krupp. She is survived by her sons, Jan Krupp (Jan) of Napa, California, Bart Krupp (Pat) of Montclair, NJ, and Fred Krupp (Laurie Devitt) of Norwalk, CT, as well as her grandchildren Edward (Monika) and Staci Krupp (Grant Gerber), Sarah (Marcus Young) and Marcus Krupp, and Alex (Casey Hallen), Zach (Heidi) and Jackson Krupp, as well as great-grandchildren Emma, Phillip and Nathan Krupp, Estelle and Max Gerber. Rosalind graduated from Hunter College and received a Masters degree in History from Montclair State College. For many years she thrived teaching history at Verona High School, and then adult education. She was an avid gardener, and always enjoyed reading, whether The New York Times or a good history book. In later years she was often delighted to hear from former students who told her of the impact she had on their lives by inspiring them to believe in their own abilities. A graveside service will be held at noon on February 7 at Menorah Cemetery, 601 Passaic Ave, Clifton NJ, with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a contribution to the cause of your choice. 1/3

GERSON--Daniel R.,died peacefully on February 6 at his home in Los Angeles after battling brain cancer. He was 49 years old. Raised on the Upper West Side, Dan was a third generation New Yorker. He grew up with a love of tap dancing and drumming throughout his childhood, and starred in musical theater performances at his high school, Ethical Culture Fieldston School in the Bronx and at Cornell University. After graduating from Cornell, he received an MFA from NYU film school and ultimately chose writing as his vocation. Daniel began his career as a staff writer for the former NBC sitcom, Something So Right. He then transitioned from television to feature films, co-writing the screenplay for the highly successful Pixar Animation Studios movie, Monsters, Inc., as well as the prequel, Monsters University, followed by Walt Disney Animation Studio's Big Hero 6, which won the Oscar for Best Animated Feature Film in 2015. Daniel expressed a unique zest for life, its big and little moments, and brought that spirit to all of his loved ones. His sense of humor was exceptional. Beyond his creative talents, what distinguished Daniel was a profound commitment to honesty, fairness and concern for the less fortunate. He was a fiercely loyal, loving and caring human being. The humanity, humor, and compassion that he brought to his writing, he brought to his family and friends in equal measure. The heart of his life was his family, his deep love for his wife of 20 years, Beau Stacom, his two children, Claire and Asher, his parents, Mary-Joan and Charles Gerson, his sister, Jessica Gerson, and her children, Daisy and Henry, as well as nieces and nephews. Daniel was a remarkable father, who enriched his children's lives at every opportunity and enabled them to believe the best about themselves. Anyone whose life he touched benefitted from his love, his honesty and his wit. Services will be held in Los Angeles. Donations in Daniel's memory may be made to: Dr. Linda Liau, Brain Tumor Program at UCLA, https://giving.ucla.edu/Campaign/Donate.aspx?SiteNum =203&fund=603580 1/3

SCHOTTLAND--Stanley Adrian. If success can be measured by happiness, then Stan Schottland was a very successful man. He had a charmed life and in every way, the American dream. Stanley Adrian Schottland was born May 27th, 1919 in New York City to Ruth and Charles Schottland. He was predeceased by his older brother Jack. Stan attended DeWitt Clinton High School, but after his father died during his senior year, he chose to leave to go to work and help support his family. The year was 1936. Stan enlisted in the Army the day after Pearl Harbor, was promoted to Lieutenant and landed on Omaha beach in July 1944 as part of George Patton's army. He fought bravely and was wounded in action in September of that year. During his training state side, he met the love of his life Ellen Bordley Schottland in Sebring Florida. Ellen and Stan were married on December 24, 1944 in Chestertown, MD. They had three sons: Charles (Buck), Steven and Peter who they adored. Married more than sixty years, what a life they shared together. Stan and Ellen made friends all across the country where they owned homes including Bronxville, NY, Chestertown, Maryland, Rochester, NY, Gladwyne, PA, Cordillera, Colorado, Kiawah Island, SC, Hobe Sound, Florida and Naples, Florida. Soon after the war, he went back to work for Schenley Distillers where he began his career as an office boy years earlier. Stan was employed by Schenley for 27 years, including his three years while serving in the Army. With Stan's tenacious drive, he rose to the position of President of their Bourbon Division. In 1963, his career was flourishing but Stan was determined to own his own company. In 1966, he joined hands with a small bag manufacturer named American Bag and Paper located in Philadelphia and together they purchased Northern Packaging in Rochester, NY. Three years later, Stan was invited to come to Philadelphia and take over American Bag and Paper as a partner and CEO. In 1986, he bought out his partner with his three sons and grew the company to what is today American Packaging Corporation. American Packaging is one of America's largest privately owned flexible packaging companies employing over 800 families. Stan's philanthropic efforts were significant. With a passion for young talent and leadership skills, Stan founded several programs at the College of Charleston and Washington College. Another passion of Stan's was the health and well-being of children. American Packaging is one of the founding companies supporting Paul Newman's Hole in the Wall Gang Camp. While his military career was formidable, his business success quite remarkable and his charitable passions to be respected, at the end of the day, family was everything to him. Stan absolutely adored his elegant lady Ellen, his sons Buck, Steven and Peter, his 10 grandchildren and his 10 great-grandchildren. Most summers were spent on the Eastern Shore of Maryland surrounded by friends and family. In his later years after Ellen's passing, he had the blessing of companionship with a wonderful lady named Betty Flora. Stan touched so many people along the way and will be truly missed by all. God bless " Stan the man, Dad , Grandpa and GG Pop ". A Funeral Service will be held on Sunday, February 14 at 1:00pm at St. Paul's Kent Episcopal Church, Chestertown. A visitation will be held on Saturday evening February 13 from 5:00-7:00pm at Fellows, Helfenbein, and Newnam Funeral Home 130 Speer Road Chestertown, MD 21620. Interment will be following the service in St. Paul's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the Hole in the Wall Gang Camp in Stan's name: www.holeinthewallgang.org, 555 Long Wharf Dr, New Haven, CT 06511, (203)772-0522. www.fhnfuneralhome.com 1/3

The wake will be held Sunday, February 7 between 2pm and 7pm at J. Ronald Scott Funeral Home, 20 Ponquogue Avenue, Hampton Bays, NY. The funeral will be held Monday, February 8 in the morning at the Funeral Home. The family request that donations be made to the American Heart Association. 1/3

We extend our heartfelt condolences to John's daughter, Katherine Blacklock; his son, Daniel R. Tishman; his daughter-in-law, Sheryl Crockett Tishman; his grandchildren, Joshua, Gabriel, and Kyle; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

ORGELFINGER--Caroline Mary, nee Iannone, died on February 1, 2016 of congestive heart failure at Heartlands Senior Living in Severna Park, Maryland. The youngest child of John and Carmela Iannone, she was born January 13, 1922 in Staten Island, NY. She attended Tottenville High School, graduating in 1939 with highest honors in the secretarial program, and worked in New York City. On April 3, 1948, she married Louis Orgelfinger, III, who predeceased her. During their 63-year marriage, they resided in Glen Oaks, Richmond Hill, and Munsey Park, NY, and Waynesville, NC, as well as traveling extensively. A lifelong Yankees fan, Caroline was an avid reader, and enjoyed playing golf, cross- stitching and crossword puzzles. She leaves two daughters, Gail Orgelfinger (Charles Hanna) of Severna Park, and Joan Jarrard (Ted Keller) of Flora, Indiana; a grandson, Steven L. Jarrard and great-granddaughter, Lilly Ann Jarrard; three nieces, a nephew, and many great- and great-great nieces and nephews. 1/3

TISHMAN--John. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of John Tishman, legendary builder and a distinguished and prominent philanthropist who devoted his life to making his hometown New York City a better place to live and work. A pioneer and leader of the construction management industry, John supervised the building of many world class projects including the construction of three of the four earliest 100 plus story skyscrapers: the original World Trade Center and the John Hancock Center in Chicago, IL. We express our heartfelt condolences to his son, REBNY Governor and Executive Committee member Daniel Tishman, his daughter Katherine Blacklock and the entire Tishman family. Rob Speyer, Chairman John Banks, President 1/3

TISHMAN--John L. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague John L. Tishman, a longtime Carnegie Hall Trustee and a true giant in New York's construction industry. John joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1987 and served the Hall with devotion for nearly two decades. John was the visionary chairman and CEO of Tishman Realty & Construction Co., Inc., which has played a central role in virtually all of Carnegie Hall's major capital projects, beginning with the historic renovation and restoration of Carnegie Hall, completed in 1986, and continuing with the Hall's expansion into the adjacent Carnegie Hall Tower, completed in 1990; the construction of Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall, completed in 2003; and the renovation of Carnegie Hall's Studio Towers, completed in 2014. John will forever occupy a very special place in Carnegie Hall's history. We express heartfelt condolences to his son Daniel and his daughter Katherine, and to the entire Tishman family and their loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive/Artistic Director 1/3
SAVAGE -- Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94. Miss every wonderful, impossible, incredible thing about you. Always will. Love, Vicki 1/3

Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine; David A. Tanner, Chair, Board of Trustees, Montefiore Health System; Roger W. Einiger, Chair, Board of Trustees, Albert Einstein College of Medicine 1/3

GELB--Lueza Thirkield. Died peacefully on February 7th at home surrounded by family after a long illness. She was 84. Born May 8, 1931, in Plainfield, NJ, she was a daughter of E.B. and Constance Thirkield (Harris). She is survived by her husband of 63 years, Bruce S. Gelb. The couple met in 1951 when she was maid-of-honor and he was best man at his brother's wedding. A graduate of Wells College, she raised four children before earning a doctorate in history from Columbia University. She taught at Pace University and Marymount-Manhattan College. She also lectured on European history to the United States diplomatic community in Brussels while her husband served as Ambassador to Belgium under George H.W. Bush. An expert skier and sailor, she was the author of "Schroon Lake," an award- winning memoir of her childhood in the Adirondacks. Survivors include her children, John (Sherry), Jody (Jacek Jarkowski), Richard and Connie (Scott Otteman); grandchildren, Nathaniel, John Jr. (Morgana), Serena, Dora and Daniel; brother, Dwight Thirkield; nieces and nephews, Larry (Anki), Lucy (Frank Sisto), Jane and Jimmy (Jenny); Mario, Joe, Mary Jo, Connie, Rose, Sal and John; Wes and Tim. She was predeceased by her nephew, Kenneth Thirkield, sister, Mary Belle DiGrazia, brother-in-law, Richard L. Gelb, cherished granddaughter, Lueza Jarkowski, and daughter-in-law, Tana. A prolific journaler, she donated her private papers to the Schlesinger Library in Cambridge, MA. A funeral service will be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest at 2 East 90th Street on Friday, February 12th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lueza's memory to Citymeals on Wheels (www.citymeals.org) or The Wild Center at Tupper Lake, NY (www.wildcenter.org). The family would like to thank Barbara Neary, Catherine Higgins, Mary Clarke, Lara Dobrovolsky, Rena Iljavi and Carmel Seymour for their compassionate care. 1/3

COLCORD--Ray. December 24, 1949-February 5, 2016. Beloved husband to Maddy, father to Alex, brother to Marc, brother-in-law to Tom, and friend and mentor to all. Prolific Emmy-nominated composer for television and film, respected past President of the Society of Composers and Lyricists, a former governor of the Television Academy, and an appointee of the Library of Congress to the National Film Preservation Board. Memorial Service at 3pm Tuesday, February 9th at the Church Of The Hills, Forest Lawn, Hollywood Hills, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research. 1/3

TISHMAN--John L. The University of Michigan and its College of Engineering pay tribute to the life of esteemed graduate, John L. Tishman (BSE EE 1946; DEng Hon 2000) upon his passing. From the time he first stepped onto the field as manager of the 1945-1946 football team, until his death on February 6, 2016, he never wavered in his love of his alma mater. His counsel to deans and presidents; his leadership on the 55M Campaign during the 1960s, Capital Campaign Planning Committee in the 1970s and Honorary Chairmanship of the College's 150th Anniversary Campaign in the 2000s; his generosity of heart to staff and students-these were among his many contributions that spoke to the quality of character that was his hallmark. In 1998, the College was pleased to award John its highest distinction, the Alumni Society Medal, honoring the profound effect his leadership in construction management had on the construction industry. The University was proud to bestow upon him an honorary Doctor of Engineering degree in 2000 in recognition of his transformative contributions to construction management as well as his civic and philanthropic activities. Through the John L. Tishman Fellowship, John L. Tishman Professorship of Engineering, Tishman Hall and the Tishman Construction Management Program, his spirit will forever grace his University. The Michigan torch now passes to Dan, his son; Kate, his daughter; and his grandsons. We send our deepest sympathy to them and the rest of John's family. 1/3

VAN HULSTEYN--Grace Gibson, co-inventor of the "Savaface" nose warmer, dies at age 78. Stunned by the bitter winds that swirled around Bryn Mawr College during the winter of 1958, Grace van Hulsteyn and her college friend Betsy Nelson crouched a colorful wool contraption that fit over the nose and was secured at the back of the head. Fellow classmates asked for examples and eventually the devices caused a bit of stir in ever widening circles until one of the apogees of pop culture stardom in the 1950s, the TV show What's My Line, got wind (so to speak) of the phenomenon and the young inventors appeared on the March 23, 1958 broadcast. Their claim to faddish fame was discovered by panelist Arlene Francis, but the pair returned to school with their noses held high. After a three year battle with ALS, Miss van Hulsteyn, suffered a stroke, thereby denying ALS its victory over her. She passed away December 12, 2015 at the New York Visiting Nurses facility, The Haven. Grace pursued many interests: ceramics, law practice, french horn, living in Rome, travel, working on her beloved barn and property in Cochecton, NY. Grace would have become annoyed if they were all to be mentioned, as she was extremely "frugal" and this obituary is "pay by the word." Grace was preceded in death by her father John "Max," mother Yildiz and brother John. She is survived by you, the reader, as well as by longtime friend and companion Rudy, brother David (wife Peggy), niece Lisa (husband Jim), nephew Dave (wife Debra), and a lot of great friends, all of whose lives she made much more interesting and amusing, if a bit exasperating at times. Her family and friends wish her to rest in peace, though she hated to rest. May she toil and tinker in peace. Contributions can be made to the Yildiz van Hulsteyn Fund Of The Bryn Mawr College Library, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania. 1/3

BARAS--Robert. Robert "Bob" Baras, 85, passed away peacefully at his home in Westport, CT on February 7, 2016 surrounded by his family, friends and his loving caregivers. Robert was born in Brooklyn, NY to Esther (Hertan) and Solomon Baras. Both were Romanian immigrants. He was raised in the Bronx and graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School, and then attended City College. Robert was a longtime resident of Manhattan, and Tourettes-sur-Loup, France. Bob was happily married to his wife of 49 years, Francine Baras. After building a large textile company, Inwood Knitting Mills, which he sold to National Distillers in 1969, Bob was able to realize his lifelong dream, his true passion for painting. He attended School of Visual Arts and received a BFA with honors. Bob spent the next 40 years painting and living his dream. His last show was at The White Gallery in Lakeville, Connecticut in May of 2015. Bob was also a photographer and left a large body of work. Robert is survived by his beloved wife, Francine Baras, daughters Lise Baras and Nicole Baras Feuer, and his son Lloyd Baras. Bob adored his three grandchildren, Adam Feuer, Eric Feuer, and Jonathon Baras. He was predeceased by his daughter, Ilene Marback. Bob also lost his brother Irwin Baras in World War II. Funeral services will take place on Thursday, February 11, 2016 at 11:00am at the Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

DAVIS--Melvin Jerome, 93, of Floral Park, NY, died on February 7, 2016. Born January 18, 1923 in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved son of the late Bessie and Sidney Davis. He was predeceased by Beatrice, his cherished wife of 67 years, and is survived by adoring daughters Deborah, Jamie Germaine (Greg Ross) and Susan Pereira (Vanderlei); grandchildren Jenna and Paul (Michelle); great-grandsons Brodie and Keegan and nieces and nephews. Mel was a graduate of Brooklyn College and completed additional graduate studies in Social Work at the University of Pittsburgh. He was a respected market research executive at several major advertising agencies before opening his own firm, M.J. Davis Research. Mel loved music and theater and was an active member of the Roslyn Community Theater. He sang in the choir of Temple Sinai of Roslyn for 40 years and also served on various Temple committees. Mel gave generously of his time as a volunteer with both the Service Corps of Retired Executives (SCORE) and the International Executive Service Corps (IESC), which sent him on worldwide assignments. Mel and Bea spent many happy summers at their cottage on Prince Edward Island, Canada. Family was paramount in Mel's life and his happiest times were having family gathered together for holidays and celebrations. Mel will be remembered for his generosity, gentle manner and witty sense of humor. Funeral services at Temple Sinai of Roslyn on Wednesday, February 10th at noon. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at Mel's home. Donations may be made to a charity of choice. 1/3

GERINGER--Leonard J.,died at home on February 8, age 91, surrounded by his loving family-daughters, Kim and Wendy, sons-in-law, Colin and Bob, and grandchildren, Rachel, Alex, Adam (Erica) and Ethan. He was predeceased by his wife of 61 years, Eda. Leonard was a pioneer in the home lighting industry, a painter, sculptor, designer and collector, an avid student of American and world history and politics, and a lover of the performing and visual arts. He was a generous supporter of many progressive causes. Funeral Wednesday, February 10 at 12:30pm at Temple Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. Memorial donations to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, hospiceofwestchester.com 1/3

COOPER--Henry S.F.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and staff of The New York Society Library mourn the loss of Henry S.F. Cooper Jr. A Library member since he could read, Henry joined the Board in 1971. He served as chair 1985-1992 and last year was elected Trustee Emeritus. Henry evinced a love for the traditions of the Library. In celebration of our 250th anniversary, he co-wrote a splendid history of the Library. Godspeed to you, Henry. We have been fortunate to know you as colleague and friend. 1/3

DUKE--Robin Chandler. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are saddened by the death of our dear friend and colleague Robin Chandler Duke, a humanitarian leader and tireless advocate for refugees, women's rights, family planning and reproductive health. Robin, who was U.S. ambassador to Norway from 2000 to 2001, was a longtime member of the IRC Board of Directors and later of the IRC Overseers. In death she joins her beloved husband, Angier Biddle Duke, a former U.S ambassador and president of the IRC, who died in 1995. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. A celebration of Robin's life will be held in New York City in the spring. International Rescue Committee, Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board; Timothy Geithner, Chair, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President 1/3

WASCH--Susan Beck, died peacefully at her home in Middletown, CT on February 5, 2016. Daughter of the late Madeline Childress Beck and T. Edmund Beck, she was born in Mt. Vernon, NY on May 20, 1935. She graduated from the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, NY in 1953. She met her husband-to-be, William K. Wasch, at church and they married in Scarsdale in 1958. In 1964 they moved to Middletown, CT where Bill began his career in Wesleyan's Alumni office. This was the start of a long relationship with the university. In Middletown, she was an energetic member of The Church of the Holy Trinity, the Literary Club and the Middletown Garden Club. She was a passionate advocate of women's education as a 65 year old Ada Comstock Scholar at Smith College, and as a trustee of the Masters School. In her last decade, she and Bill focused their energy on the creation of the Wasch Center for Retired Faculty at Wesleyan. She was inducted into the American Platform Tennis Association Hall of Fame in 1996 for her many national championships, most significantly with her mother and her brother John. Susan was known for her bright smile, her quiet faith, her generosity, and her tenacious love and support of her family. She is survived by her husband William Karl Wasch, her four children: Christina Eleanor Wasch of Middletown, CT, William Karl Wasch Jr. of Munich, Germany, Heidi Helm Wasch of Seattle, WA, and Frederick Childress Wasch of Pennington, NJ. She also leaves behind six grandchildren and her older brother Thaddeus Edmund Beck, Jr. of Glasgow, VA. Visiting hours will be held at Doolittle Funeral Home, 14 Old Church Street, Middletown, CT on February 12th from 5-7pm. A memorial service is being planned for early May. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Church of the Holy Trinity; to the Wasch Center for Retired Faculty at Wesleyan University; or to the Susan B. Wasch Riverfront Development Fund of the Middletown Garden Club, c/o Robert Rickenback, 275 Blue Rd, Middletown, CT 06457. To share memories or send condolences to the Wasch family, please visit www.doolittlefuneral service.com. 1/3

CEDARBAUM--Miriam Goldman. With profound sadness, we mourn the passing of the Honorable Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, who was the devoted sister of the late Ruth Goldman Schapiro, the aunt of Jane and Robert Schapiro (Lillian), great-aunt to Rebecca, Ruth, and Sarah Schapiro, and sister-in-law to Linda N. Schapiro and close friend to Linda's children, Joshua Solomon (Geula), Abigail Solomon (Jason Teuscher), and Kate Solomon (David Wasserman). She will always be a source of wisdom and inspiration to all of us. 1/3

BLACK--Hillel, on February 8th at the age of 86. He fought for every moment, savoring life until the end. A man of words and expression, he will be remembered for his contributions and guidance to writers around the globe. He is survived by his children David, Leora and Harry, and daughter-in-law Melissa, grandchildren Benjamin, Jacob and Mitchell. Donations in Hillel's memory may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3
BROMLEY--Stephen B.,Dearest, miss you always and love you forever. Your Pat 1/3

DAVIS--Melvin Jerome, 93, of Floral Park, NY, died on February 7, 2016. Born January 18, 1923 in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved son of the late Bessie and Sidney Davis. He was predeceased by Beatrice, his cherished wife of 67 years, and is survived by adoring daughters Deborah, Jamie Germaine (Greg Ross) and Susan Pereira (Vanderlei); grandchildren Jenna and Paul (Michelle); great-grandsons Brodie and Keegan and nieces and nephews. Mel was a graduate of Brooklyn College and completed additional graduate studies in Social Work at the University of Pittsburgh. He was a respected market research executive at several major advertising agencies before opening his own firm, M.J. Davis Research. Mel loved music and theater and was an active member of the Roslyn Community Theater. He sang in the choir of Temple Sinai of Roslyn for 40 years and also served on various Temple committees. Mel gave generously of his time as a volunteer with both the Service Corps of Retired Executives (SCORE) and the International Executive Service Corps (IESC), which sent him on worldwide assignments. Mel and Bea spent many happy summers at their cottage on Prince Edward Island, Canada. Family was paramount in Mel's life and his happiest times were having family gathered together for holidays and celebrations. Mel will be remembered for his generosity, gentle manner and witty sense of humor. Funeral services at Temple Sinai of Roslyn on Wednesday, February 10th at noon. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at Mel's home. Donations may be made to a charity of choice. 1/3

VERDY--Violette. The George Balanchine Foundation mourns the loss of the ebullient ballerina, Violette Verdy. Brilliant on stage; Violette displayed remarkable talent during her performing career. Later, as an inspired teacher and coach, she passed on her profound knowledge of the roles created for her by Mr. Balanchine. The Foundation was fortunate to have captured on film some of her insights, keen intelligence, warmth and delightful personality for its Video Archive Series. Violette will be greatly missed. 1/3

CEDARBAUM--Miriam Goldman. The judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York are deeply saddened by the death of our colleague, and extend our sympathy to her family. Loretta A. Preska, Chief Judge 1/3

ESBIN--Jerry. Happy Birthday Jerry. February 10th. We miss you very much and always think of you whenever we celebrate anything. With Love From Your "Crew": Judy, Scott, Beth, Randi, Peter and the best of all: Tyler Jared, Zachary Morton, Casey Brooke, Bennett Jacob and of course, Sydney Jaye 1/3

SNYDER--Phoebe (Peggy) Leibowitz, of New York City, born in Baltimore, MD in 1922, economist trained at the University of Chicago, and mother of three, passed away peacefully on February 6. Wife of William Snyder, who predeceased her in 1998, she is survived by her children and spouses, Adam, Patricia, Trinka, Bruce, Dana and Jim. Also survived by her four grandchildren and spouses, Benjamin, Sarah, Melanie, Renato, Lili, and Kasey; and two nephews and spouses Alex, Maria, Daniel, and Kathleen; and their children Isabelle, Dylan, Mattie and Lucas. They will all miss her guidance on how to live life. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Young Center for Immigrant Children's Rights. 1/3

TISHMAN--John. The Board and Staff of NRDC mourn the passing of John L. Tishman, the beloved father of our esteemed chairman, Daniel R. Tishman. A University of Michigan graduate who served in the United States Navy, John was a father of the modern American construction industry. He supervised the construction of some of the world's most iconic skyscrapers, including the John Hancock Center in Chicago, IL and the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York. Tishman Realty and Construction Company was in the vanguard of the sustainable design movement, and the New School named its Tishman Environment and Design Center in honor of his achievements. We extend our deepest sympathies to Dan, his wife Sheryl, sons Josh and Gabe, and Dan's sister, Katherine Blacklock and her son Kyle. Rhea Suh, President NRDC; John H. Adams, Trustee & Founding Director; Frances Beinecke, former President 1/3

KERBS--John S.,of Old Greenwich, CT, formerly of New York City, passed away on February 4, 2016. Born November 9, 1926, the youngest son of Jeanne E. Kerbs and William Kallman Kerbs, brother of Edward A. Kerbs and Carlee Kerbs Walker, and loving husband of Hildegard Johnson Kerbs, all of whom predeceased him. John was a paradigmatic member of that greatest generation. Although he lost a leg and very nearly his life at the age of 15 in an accident at a camp in Vermont, John never complained and scarcely acknowledged that misfortune, quickly returning to his studies at The Lawrenceville School and Yale University. As a young adult, John was active in such adventurous pursuits as hunting, racing midget cars, and flying airplanes before embarking on a career as a stock broker, financial consultant, and businessman. His passion for electronics and technology first developed when he worked with a team of Lawrenceville students rebuilding aircraft engines during WWII, was widely known among his family and friends. Devoted father to his three sons and their wives, Edward and Jean Kerbs, Thomas and Karen Randles Kerbs, and John J. Kerbs and Jennifer Jolley, loving grandfather to John, Julia and Jennifer, John also leaves behind his devoted sister-in-law, Brynne Johnson Solowinski, and numerous nieces and nephews. Services at 3pm on Saturday, February 20th, at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St. in Greenwich, CT. He will be missed. 1/3

VERDY--Violette. The entire New York City Ballet family mourns the passing of Violette Verdy, our dear friend and colleague, and one of the great ballerinas of the 20th century. Born in France, where she began an acclaimed international career, Violette danced with New York City Ballet from 1958 until 1977. During that time her unique gifts inspired both George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins to create roles for her in such masterpieces as "Emeralds," "Liebeslieder Walzer," "Tschaikovsky Pas de Deux," and "Dances at a Gathering." Also a renowned teacher, Violette has touched the lives of countless young dancers with her knowledge, charm, grace, and joie de vivre. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

VERDY--Violette. She was a breath of fresh air, a bright light, the colors of a rainbow. She surrounded you with warmth, talking, smiling and laughing all at the same time. Her presence was electric, as a performer and friend. Once you saw her in a ballet, you never forgot her performance. Fortunately, our memories will live. The George Balanchine Trust 1/3

DUKE--Robin Chandler. The trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and Museum note with sadness the passing of friend and former trustee Robin Chandler Duke, a member of our board from 1980-93. A United States ambassador and champion for the rights of women worldwide, Mrs. Duke represented the best of humanitarianism and public service. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Honorary Chairman, Peter Lawson-Johnston Chairman, William L. Mack President, Jennifer Blei Stockman Director, Richard Armstrong 1/3

TISHMAN--John. AECOM is saddened by the death of John L. Tishman. A renowned builder, he broke new ground in construction management and transformed an industry. He oversaw the development of numerous national icons, including the original World Trade Center Twin Towers in his hometown of New York City. Furthermore, he dedicated his life to philanthropy and building a better world. Skylines across the country reflect his important legacy. VERDY--Violette. The School of American Ballet mourns the loss of a beloved family member. Having served as principal guest teacher since 2007, Violette's bond with SAB extends to the 1950s, when as a glamorous star of New York City Ballet she frequently took classes and guest taught at the direction of George Balanchine. She was instrumental to the launching of SAB's national recruiting program in partnership with the Ford Foundation in the 1960s and 1970s, traveling thousands of miles on the School's behalf to discover talented future dancers nationwide. Our students and all who encountered Violette were touched by her extraordinary generosity of spirit and joyful willingness to share her special gifts. She will be missed enormously. 1/3
