TISHMAN--John. AECOM is saddened by the death of John L. Tishman. A renowned builder, he broke new ground in construction management and transformed an industry. He oversaw the development of numerous national icons, including the original World Trade Center Twin Towers in his hometown of New York City. Furthermore, he dedicated his life to philanthropy and building a better world. Skylines across the country reflect his important legacy. On behalf of the board of directors, leadership team and employees, we express our deepest sympathy to his son Dan Tishman, AECOM Vice Chairman, his daughter Katherine Blacklock and the entire Tishman family. Mike Burke, Chairman and CEO 1/3

VERDY--Violette. She was a breath of fresh air, a bright light, the colors of a rainbow. She surrounded you with warmth, talking, smiling and laughing all at the same time. Her presence was electric, as a performer and friend. Once you saw her in a ballet, you never forgot her performance. Fortunately, our memories will live. The George Balanchine Trust 1/3

GALLEN--Jill, died at home, peacefully in her sleep, on February 9th at the age of 80. Jill loved her family, her friends, her books, the ballet, and the opera. Most of all, she loved and cared for her husband of 54 years, Richard, who passed away in 2013. She is survived by her two loving children, Jonathan and David, her devoted and admiring daughter-in-law, Amy, and her six adoring grandchildren: Hannah, Samuel, Grace, Harry, Sarah and Nicholas. There will be a service at 10am on Friday, February 12th at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. 1/3
DUKE--Robin. Friend, mentor and remarkable human being. You will be greatly missed. Connie Spahn 1/3

PRESSER--Rhoda. The Board of American Friends of Shalva mourn the passing of Rhoda Presser, mother of board member Mitchell Presser. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mitchell and the entire family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Norm Alpert and Carol Levin, Co-Presidents; Kalman Samuels, Shalva Founder and Chairman; Leo Klein, Executive Director 1/3
MOORE--James (Jay). Feb. 11, '44 - Oct. 7, '13. Happy birthday to the best husband, father and grandpa ever! Love, Barb and Jon 1/3

HENDLER--Richard. Richard G. Hendler, 86, Boca Raton, Florida, died February 10, 2016 from complications of a brain hemorrhage. He was preceded in death by his parents, Jack and Esther Hendler; a brother, Sherwin Hendler; and his beloved wife, Marcia Silberstein Hendler. He is survived by his three sons, Jeffrey (Doreen), Paul (Shelly), and Steven (Janice); seven grandchildren, Isaac (Alison), Jack (Abby), Eric, Sonia Friedman (David), Sam (Meredith), Matt and Sadye; and four great-granddaughters, Arianna, Eva, Molly and Lily. Also surviving is his cherished life partner, Alma Herman, with whom he shared a most wonderful life together during the last ten years. Funeral, Friday, February 12, 2016, 11:00am, Jewish Community Center, Harrison, New York. The family requests no flowers. Contributions may be made to favorite charity. 1/3

PLATONI--Nora Barilli, of the Bronx, on February 10, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Bruno Platoni, loving mother of Richard, of the Bronx and Michael (Mary Ryan-Platoni), of Bronxville. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 5pm Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Friday, February 12 at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the St. Jude Children's Hospital, Stjude.org. 1/3
FORREST--Bradley. Time will never lessen our pain. Our hearts remain broken. Our world shattered. With everlasting love to our beautiful son. Mom & Dad 1/3

TISHMAN--John L. The New York Building Congress Board of Directors is greatly saddened by the death of John L. Tishman, Chairman Emeritus of Tishman Realty & Construction Co., Inc., whom we remember as one of the fathers of modern construction management. He was a man of undisputed integrity and generosity and never wavered in his personal support of the institutions that make New York truly great. John was a leader in our industry and his legacy will live on through his iconic projects and philanthropic endeavors. Richard Cavallaro, Chairman Richard T. Anderson, President 1/3
LUBASCH--Arnold. A distinguished colleague and a splendid person. We will all miss his honesty and devotion. Peter and Deirdre Millones 1/3

WOLFF-- Michael. 1940-2016. We mourn the loss of Michael Wolff who passed away peacefully on Sunday, February 7, 2016. Mike was a friend and mentor to many. His enthusiasm for life was contagious. Mike is survived by his devoted wife, Maria, his loving sister, Lois Hoffman, his daughters and sons-in-law, Jennifer (Jeff) Finnerty and Allison (Wes) Arnett and five adoring grandchildren. Services will be held Thursday, February 11 from 11am-1pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, 70th Street. The family will accept visitors immediately following at Le Triomphe, 245 E. 58th Street, third floor. 1/3

VERDY--Violette. The entire New York City Ballet family mourns the passing of Violette Verdy, our dear friend and colleague, and one of the great ballerinas of the 20th century. Born in France, where she began an acclaimed international career, Violette danced with New York City Ballet from 1958 until 1977. During that time her unique gifts inspired both George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins to create roles for her in such masterpieces as "Emeralds," "Liebeslieder Walzer," "Tschaikovsky Pas de Deux," and "Dances at a Gathering." Also a renowned teacher, Violette has touched the lives of countless young dancers with her knowledge, charm, grace, and joie de vivre. She will be greatly missed. 1/3
KRAMER--Barbara. In loving memory. We will never forget you. Love, Leslie 1/3

VERDY--Violette. The School of American Ballet mourns the loss of a beloved family member. Having served as principal guest teacher since 2007, Violette's bond with SAB extends to the 1950s, when as a glamorous star of New York City Ballet she frequently took classes and guest taught at the direction of George Balanchine. She was instrumental to the launching of SAB's national recruiting program in partnership with the Ford Foundation in the 1960s and 1970s, traveling thousands of miles on the School's behalf to discover talented future dancers nationwide. Our students and all who encountered Violette were touched by her extraordinary generosity of spirit and joyful willingness to share her special gifts. She will be missed enormously. 1/3

PERKINS--William O.,Jr. William O. Perkins, Jr., "Billy" son of the late Eva Trotman Perkins and William Osborne Perkins, Sr., was born in Jersey City, New Jersey on January 12, 1940. After a long illness Billy passed away peacefully on February 5, 2016 in Teaneck, New Jersey surrounded by his loving family and his devoted aide. Several years after the death of his mother Eva, when Billy was a young boy, his father married Roslyn Ellis. She loved young "Billy" and he remained a devoted stepson until her death in 2005. As a young boy Billy excelled in sports. He ran track and played football. He graduated from Henry Snyder High School in Jersey City in 1959. Billy was recruited by the University of Iowa (Hawkeyes), and awarded a scholarship to play college football. He was drafted by The Dallas Cowboys while he was an undergraduate at Iowa. Due to an injury, he left Texas and was picked up by the New York Jets where he played for one season. Billy re-enrolled in Iowa and completed his undergraduate degree and enrolled in Seton Hall Law School in 1965. While attending Seton Hall Law School and working part time, he played on weekends for The Westchester Bulls, the Giants farm team. In 1968 Billy received his J.D. degree from Seton Hall University. William O. Perkins, Esq. opened his law office in 1970 in The Trust Company Bank building in Jersey City. He maintained his law practice there until 2000. After leaving his practice Billy went to work for the Jersey City Board of Recreation until 2010. Billy served as State Assemblyman, 31st District from 1973 - 1976 and as Chairman of the Assembly's Judiciary Committee in 1975. He was selected as a delegate to the American Council of Young Political Leaders (ACYPL) while he was an Assemblyman and traveled throughout the former Soviet Union with other elected officials. Billy loved his native Jersey City and believed in serving the community. He was beloved by many and touched numerous lives through his community involvement. Billy served as Adjunct Professor of Constitutional Law at St. Peter's College; served on the Boards of Jersey City State College (now New Jersey City State University), NAACP, Hudson County Legal Services, St. Aloysius Academy, Hudson Repertory Dance Theater and the Hudson County Bar Association. He was Assistant Football Coach of St. Peter's College, the Jersey Jets, P.A.L.; a sponsor of Little Leagues and Babe Ruth League baseball teams. Billy leaves to cherish his memory his daughters: Joyce Person-Perkins of Bayonne, New Jersey and Tia Sinclair Bell (Ronald) of Monmouth County, New Jersey; his sons: William O. Perkins, III of U.S. Virgin Islands and Grantlin Morgan Perkins of Canberra, Australia; his grandchildren: Asia Metsagharun (Toritseju) of London, U.K.; James S. Robinson of Bayonne, New Jersey; Khalis Bell, Sephton Zyrell Person-Perkins, Erin Skye Perkins and Brisa Maxine Perkins. He is also survived by his loving sisters: Sandra "Dimples" Clark, Maxine West, and Doris Haggenmiller; and his Uncle Augustus "Gus" M. Perkins. Billy was predeceased by his brother, Fredrick Perkins and his sister, Jacqueline Franklin and a stepbrother Albert Ellis. He also leaves to mourn his loss a host of cousins, nieces, nephews and many loving longtime friends. Visitation will be held at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 625 Pavonia Avenue, Jersey City, NJ 07306, on Friday, February 12, 2016, from 4 to 8pm. Family and friends are requested to assemble at Christ the King Catholic Church, 768 Ocean Avenue, Jersey City, NJ, 07304, on Saturday, February 13, 2016, at 10am for the Funeral Mass. Interment will follow in Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington, NJ. www.mclaughlinfuneral home.net 1/3

ZEIDMAN--Helen. Helen Sue Flatow Zeidman, beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother passed away Saturday, February 6, 2016. She was preceded in death by her loving husband of 61 years, Lewis. Sue was born and raised in New York City. She attended New York University where she graduated with a degree in marketing and obtained her Masters degree in Psychology from Queens College. She was an active volunteer and leader in her community of Harrison, NY. Sue was a past president of her local chapter of Hadassah, past president of the sisterhood and a Board member and officer of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison. In addition, Sue spearheaded the sandwich drive in her home town, which provided thousands of meals for those in need. Sue was loved and admired by all she touched. She is survived by her daughter Laurel (Alan), Clarks Summit, PA; son, Mark (Margaret), Palm Beach, FI; grandchildren, Drs. Jessica Zeidman Ziperstein (Dr. Joshua); Steven Glassman (Christin), Joseph Zeidman (Laura), Adam Glassman; and six great-grandchildren, as well as many nieces and nephews. 1/3

DUKE--Robin Chandler. The trustees and staff of the United States - Japan Foundation note with deep sadness the passing of our beloved founder, Robin Chandler Duke, on February 6. Ambassador Duke understood in 1980 that Japan and the United States were moving into an era of unnecessary friction over trade and other issues, friction that threatened our alliance. With characteristic energy and vision, she approached Mr. Ryoichi Sasakawa, a Japanese philanthropist, and persuaded him to make a generous contribution of $45 million to endow what has become today the US-Japan Foundation in New York. In the past 35 years this foundation has donated more than $90 million to our core programs, enhancing K-12 education in each country about the other, bringing young leaders from both nations together into lasting networks of communication and friendship, and more recently, strengthening the role of women in both nations. Robin Duke played a critical role in building a strong board of trustees, infusing the board and staff with her dynamism and practical knowledge of international affairs, and her strong conviction that Japan and the U.S. share the same values. Her legacy will last well into the future. We miss her vibrant presence. James Lintott, Chairman of the Board; George R. Packard, President 1/3

Loving husband, father to Howard and Richard, and daughters-in-law Joan and Hope and grandfather to Harrison, Ilana and Ashley, uncle and great- uncle. He was a force of nature and lived by his own standards and rules, and was a loyal friend to many. Predeceased by his parents Philip and Julia Whitman and by the love of his life, Helen Whitman on January 15, 2016 after 69 years of marriage. Graveside services will take place on Sunday, February 14, 2016 at 12:30pm at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. 1/3

TISHMAN--John. AECOM is saddened by the death of John L. Tishman. A renowned builder, he broke new ground in construction management and transformed an industry. He oversaw the development of numerous national icons, including the original World Trade Center Twin Towers in his hometown of New York City. Furthermore, he dedicated his life to philanthropy and building a better world. Skylines across the country reflect his important legacy. On behalf of the board of directors, leadership team and employees, we express our deepest sympathy to his son Dan Tishman, AECOM Vice Chairman, his daughter Katherine Blacklock and the entire Tishman family. Mike Burke, Chairman and CEO 1/3

KIRSHENBAUM--Wendy, 60. Our beautiful, courageous and gracious Wendy has left us much too soon after a valiant battle. Daughter of the late A. Hyman Kirshenbaum M.D., Judy Kirshenbaum Milstein and stepfather Monroe Milstein. Loving mother to Adam and Jordan (Joanna) Lipstadt and the most amazing grandmother to Isabel and Alexander Lipstadt. Sister to Barry (Corrine) Kirshenbaum. Loving dear friend of Joe Swedroe. Funeral services at Plaza Jewish Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva at Kirshenbaum and Milstein home. 1/3
LEWIS--Richard. Remembering the love of my life - charming, witty, generous. Missing you every moment of every day. Harriet 1/3

DUKE--Robin, Hon. Appeal of Conscience Foundation mourns Ambassador Robin Chandler Duke, long-time trustee, who with her husband Ambassador Angier Biddle Duke, past Chairman of the Board, were committed to strengthening religious freedom, human rights and tolerance. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, President Archbishop K. Barsamian, Cardinal T. McCarrick, Vice Presidents 1/3

ALLENTUCK--Professor Jack, died on Friday, February 5th peacefully in his sleep. He was a nuclear physicist who did global nuclear power plant safety inspections the world over. He was a Professor of Electrical Engineering and received undergraduate degrees from CCNY, and Post Graduate degrees from Columbia University, New York City, NY. He retired from Brookhaven Laboratories where he was employed for more than three decades. He is survived by his wife, Marcia Epstein Allentuck, a daughter Isa, several grandchildren, three nephews and numerous grand-nieces and nephews. He was interred at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, NY. 1/3

FIELD--Joel, 83, of White Plains, NY passed away February 10, 2016. He is survived by his wife Harriet, his son Adam; daughter Margie (Sandberg) and grandsons Aaron and Jakey (Sandberg). Joel worked as an attorney for many years. Funeral services will be held on Friday, February 12, 12:00pm at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. The family will be observing Shiva at the family residence on Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday from 2pm - 6pm. 1/3

BASSETT--Leslie. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Leslie Bassett, whose nobility of spirit is exemplified both in his music and his person. 1/3

PRESSER--Rhoda. Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design, Jerusalem, mourns the passing of Rhoda Presser, beloved mother of our esteemed and devoted board member Mitchell Presser. Our thoughts are with Mitchell, Lauren and the entire family at this difficult time. Ilan Kaufthal, Chairman Bathsheva Rifkin, President 1/3

GALLEN--Jill, died at home, peacefully in her sleep, on February 9th at the age of 80. Jill loved her family, her friends, her books, the ballet, and the opera. Most of all, she loved and cared for her husband of 54 years, Richard, who passed away in 2013. She is survived by her two loving children, Jonathan and David, her devoted and admiring daughter-in-law, Amy, and her six adoring grandchildren: Hannah, Samuel, Grace, Harry, Sarah and Nicholas. There will be a service at 10am on Friday, February 12th at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. 1/3

DOYLE--Thomas L.,Jr. M.D., KGCHS, KM, on February 10, 2016 of Forest Hills, NY. Dearest husband and best friend of Betty Ann (nee Mulvihill). Proud father of Thomas L. (Denise), Kathryn Chapar (George) and Christopher (Maureen-deceased). Loving Poppi to Nicholas, Molly and Peter T. Chapar, Kristin and Kelly Doyle and William T., Megan, John and Grace Doyle. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church on Tuesday at 10:30am. Interment St. John Cemetery. 1/3

CHAPEY--Regent Dr. Geraldine D.,on February 9, 2016 of Belle Harbor, NY. Beloved wife of the late Robert J. Chapey. Proud and devoted mother of Dr. Geraldine M. Chapey and Dr. Roberta Chapey. Dr. Chapey served for 15 years on the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, Dean of Graduate and Undergraduate School of Education at St. John's University, President of School Board 27, Professor at CUNY, Trustee for Cathedral College and for numerous professional and community organizations. Reposing at the Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Visiting Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 9:45am at St. Francis De Sales R.C. Church, 129-16 Rockaway Beach Blvd, Belle Harbor, NY. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, New York. 1/3
SOPHER--Irene Posner. Passing time deeply enriches our memories of your unparalleled devotion to "your boys." Hank and Joe 1/3
MAIDMAN--Gail Ann Lowe. Always in my heart. Sincere condolences to Richard, Star, Jacques, Regina and Evan. Susan Kalt 1/3

WEINER--Joyce Goldman, passed away at age 69 on October 24, 2015 in Glen Allen, Virginia. Joyce didn't cook but she mixed a mean Cosmopolitan. BRAUN--Harvey Daniel. The world feels a little emptier today. A brilliant, loving, generous and beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, nephew and friend, Harvey Daniel Braun of Livingston, NJ, died on Thursday, February 11 surrounded by loving family. He was 76 years old and courageously battled amyloidosis, a rare heart condition, for five and a half years. Harvey was the treasured son of the late Jerome and Sylvia Braun of the Bronx, New York. He is survived by his much-loved wife of 55 years, Susan Kovner Braun, his devoted daughters and sons-in-law, Debbie Gray, Rachel Braun Scherl, Andy Gray and Zev Scherl, four loving grandchildren, Joshua Gray, Zachary Gray, Jenny Braun Scherl, Samuel Braun Scherl, brother, Philip Braun, and aunt, Florence Braun. Harvey received his Bachelors in Engineering from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and his MBA from Carnegie Mellon. He spent his entire career at Deloitte, where he retired as a senior partner and member of the management committee. He was an industry leader in retail and consumer products, a respected colleague and mentor to hundreds of professionals. Harvey will be remembered for his kindness, sense of humor, generosity, patience, competitive spirit and love for life and family. Harvey's family expresses their special thanks to Dr. Mathew Maurer of New York-Presbyterian Hospital who provided expert and passionate care. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 14th at 11am at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Harvey's memory can be sent to Amyloidosis Research of Dr. Mathew Maurer, Payable to: Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York, Memo: Maurer Research, Office of Development--CUMS, Attn: Jamie Bienstock, 630 West 168th Street, Room 2-421, New York, NY 10032 or to Jewish Federation of Greater MetroWest New Jersey Annual Campaign; 901 Route 10; Whippany, NJ 07981. 1/3

RAPPAPORT--Dollsey G. We celebrate the life of Dollsey Gottfried Rappaport, sweet sister of Elissa Gottfried Epstein (Lovey), and aunt of Jill Epstein White, Mark Epstein, Debra Epstein and great-aunt to their children. Dollsey was above all an incredible mother to Nanette Rosenberg and Marjorie Rozman. Her wonderful grandchildren and great-grandchildren were the jewels of her life. She was amazing with them, and left a legacy of love of family and devotion to her religion. She was lucky to live to have great- grandchildren who lovingly called her GG. She got her wish to live long enough to welcome the family's newest addition Sammy, and knew another grandchild was on the way. She will also be remembered as a magnanimous philanthropist, and generous supporter of United Jewish Appeal and the State of Israel. Our parents Lola Mishkin Gottfried and Charles Gottfried were the inspiration of our family and are remembered now, as always. 1/3

DUKE--Robin Chandler. The trustees and staff of the United States - Japan Foundation note with deep sadness the passing of our beloved founder, Robin Chandler Duke, on February 6. Ambassador Duke understood in 1980 that Japan and the United States were moving into an era of unnecessary friction over trade and other issues, friction that threatened our alliance. With characteristic energy and vision, she approached Mr. Ryoichi Sasakawa, a Japanese philanthropist, and persuaded him to make a generous contribution of $45 million to endow what has become today the US-Japan Foundation in New York. In the past 35 years this foundation has donated more than $90 million to our core programs, enhancing K-12 education in each country about the other, bringing young leaders from both nations together into lasting networks of communication and friendship, and more recently, strengthening the role of women in both nations. Robin Duke played a critical role in building a strong board of trustees, infusing the board and staff with her dynamism and practical knowledge of international affairs, and her strong conviction that Japan and the U.S. share the same values. Her legacy will last well into the future. We miss her vibrant presence. James Lintott, Chairman of the Board; George R. Packard, President 1/3

VERDY--Violette. The George Balanchine Foundation mourns the loss of the ebullient ballerina, Violette Verdy. Brilliant on stage; Violette displayed remarkable talent during her performing career. Later, as an inspired teacher and coach, she passed on her profound knowledge of the roles created for her by Mr. Balanchine. The Foundation was fortunate to have captured on film some of her insights, keen intelligence, warmth and delightful personality for its Video Archive Series. Violette will be greatly missed. 1/3

ROTHMAN--Judith Lee. We mourn the loss of our beloved Judy who passed away on February 9th, surrounded by lifelong friends. Her wisdom, guidance and love will be an inspiration to all who knew her. She will be in our hearts forever. 1/3

STACKHOUSE--The Rev. Dr. Max L.,(July 29, 1935 - January 30, 2016). A graduate of DePauw University and Harvard Divinity School, and ordained by the United Church of Christ, he was an internationally recognized theologian in the field of Christian Social Ethics. He authored or edited 25 books and hundreds of articles. He was the Herbert Gezork Professor at Andover Newton Theological School, then the Rimmer and Ruth de Vries Professor of Reformed Theology and Public Life at Princeton Theological Seminary, where he was also director of the Abraham Kuyper Center for Public Theology. He held numerous international visiting professorships and served as president of the American Theological Society and the Society for Christian Ethics. He is survived by wife Jean Stackhouse and a loving family. 1/3

LEE--Robert Morton. 88, renowned automobile and antique arms collector, explorer and conservationist passed away January 28, 2016 in Reno, NV surrounded by friends and his devoted wife, Anne Brockinton Lee. He was born in Woodmere, Long Island, NY on October 2, 1927. He was taught a love of nature and the outdoors by his parents, Dr. William F. Lee and Sally W. Lee. He graduated from Oakwood Friends School in Poughkeepsie and attended Lehigh University in Pennsylvania majoring in Engineering and Business. He served in the U.S. Army. Mr. Lee was a "Renaissance Man" who presented a multi-faceted talent to the world. He turned his hand to many things and rarely failed. He was a premier fly-tier; successful builder-developer; excellent rifle shot and fly-fisherman; safari outfitter and PH in Africa; designer and manufacturer of a multitude of outdoor equipment, fine luggage and clothing; a patron of the arts; a merchandiser and marketing wiz; an author of many books; an explorer and natural scientist with museum accreditation; a classic car and antique gun collector nonpareil. During his life, his inquisitive nature, keen intelligence and sense of fearless daring carried him ever further, pushing back horizons and challenging the new or unthinkable. At age fourteen, Bob Lee designed a unique telescopic sighting, called the Lee Mount and at age seventeen designed and manufactured a range of several ultra-high-velocity rifle cartridges. Lee was one of the first Americans to have a hunting concession in Africa (Lee Expeditions, Ltd.) and the first PH to open Portuguese Angola to foreign hunters. He was a conservationist long before it became fashionable. While living in Angola in 1960s, he was instrumental in obtaining government protection for lion, cheetah, black rhino and their habitats. He designed the first ecologically sound wildlife management program in Africa with the then Portuguese Provincial government (Angola) to counteract the decimation of the big-game population by over-hunting and poaching. The result: there was more game there when he left than when he arrived! This was a cause Mr. Lee championed around the world during his lifetime. In 1965, with the outbreak of the Angolan civil war, Lee returned to New York and founded Hunting World, a luggage, leather goods, outdoor clothing and sporting specialties company. His products were designed to his exacting specifications and mercilessly field- tested. He developed a nearly indestructible lightweight material called "Battue". Between 1980 and 1984, after six years of negotiations with the government of the People's Republic of China, Mr. Lee became the first Westerner to gain access to and lead three scientific expeditions into the rugged Tien Shan mountains and Chinese Pamirs - known as "The Roof of the World" - where he rediscovered the fabled Marco Polo sheep, Ovis ammon poli, on Chinese soil and documented their migration. He was successful in convincing the Xinjiang (Shin-jiang) Provincial government to institute protection for many of its wonderful species and his reports were responsible for the creation of the Tashgorgan Wildlife Reserve in the Pamirs. These expeditions and conservation achievements are memorialized in his 2nd book, China Safari (1988). Bob Lee was a Fellow of Exploration in The Explorers Club, a member of the Boone & Crockett Club founded by Theodore Roosevelt in 1887, a Life Member of the National Rifle Association, a member of the Visiting Committee of the Arms and Armor Department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a research associate in Mammalogy, Museum of Natural History, at the University of Kansas, and an Affiliate Professor of Management at The University of Montana, where he lectured graduate students on the problems involved in saving our ancient forests in the Pacific Northwest, clear-cutting and lack of regrowth in the Rocky Mountain states and the responsibilities of business and industry with respect to the environment. In 1988, Lee created an endowment for graduate studies in wildlife management at The University of Montana. His gift was the largest single donation ever received and resulted in three scientific expeditions to the Qinghai (Ching-Hy) Province of China, on the Tibetan Plateau, to study increased population management for wild yak and musk deer. In 1999, Lee was presented with the C.J. McElroy Award from Safari Club International for his contributions to hunting and conservation. The Robert M. Lee Foundation has awarded large sums to various conservation organizations. In 1991, he funded the endowment of the Robert M. Lee Gallery of American Arms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. Mr. Lee was a collector of antique Colts, Winchesters, European Arms and Armor and Modern Sporting guns, selections of which are featured in his book series, The Art of the Gun (2002-2003) and Magnificent Colts (2011). An Exhibition of his many Collections was held at Sotheby's New York in June 2013. An avid car collector, Lee won the coveted "Best of Show" award at Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance, the world's premier automobile competition, in 2006 and 2009; "Best of Show" at The Quail: A Motorsports Gathering, in 2006 and 2012; and "Best of Show" at Amelia Island Concours in 2014. Online condolences may be shared at: waltonsfuneralhomes.com. 1/3
FEAREY--Jacqueline D.,96, of New Canaan, CT, died peacefully January 16, 2016. Service 2pm, May 22, 2016, St. Mark's Church, New Canaan. 1/3

BRAUN--Harvey Daniel. The world feels a little emptier today. A brilliant, loving, generous and beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, nephew and friend, Harvey Daniel Braun of Livingston, NJ, died on Thursday, February 11 surrounded by loving family. He is survived by his much-loved wife of 55 years, Susan Kovner Braun, his devoted daughters and sons-in-law, Debbie Gray, Rachel Braun Scherl, Andy Gray and Zev Scherl, four loving grandchildren, Joshua Gray, Zachary Gray, Jenny Braun Scherl, Samuel Braun Scherl, brother, Philip Braun, and aunt, Florence Braun. Harvey received his Bachelors in Engineering from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and his MBA from Carnegie Mellon. He spent his entire career at Deloitte, where he retired as a senior partner and member of the management committee. He was an industry leader in retail and consumer products, a respected colleague and mentor to hundreds of professionals. Harvey will be remembered for his kindness, sense of humor, generosity, patience, competitive spirit and love for life and family. Harvey's family expresses their special thanks to Dr. Mathew Maurer of New York-Presbyterian Hospital who provided expert and passionate care. SPENCER--Michael Jon, Founder and Executive Director of Hospital Audiences, Inc. (HAI) for over 40 years, passed away on November 30, 2015 in New York City at the age of 77 due to complications arising from pneumonia. He is survived by his daughter, Joanna Spencer; granddaughter Katherine "Katie" MacAaron; sister Caryle Wells; son-in-law David MacAaron; brother-in-law Arthur Wells; nephew Andrew Wells; many cousins; and numerous pets including dogs, cats, horses, goats and chickens. He was the son of Joseph and Ethel Spencer. Michael was born on Valentine's Day, 1938, in Brooklyn, NY. He spent his formative years in Los Angeles, CA, where he attended Fairfax High School, and became friends with schoolmate Phil Spector. Later, he became a sessions pianist as well as music contractor for Spector. His playing can be heard on the original classics "Be My Baby" and "Pretty Little Angel Eyes." In his youth he also studied classical piano with Serge Tarnowsky, who had been Vladimir Horowitz's teacher. As a teenager, he and another friend found Bela Lugosi listed in the telephone book, which began a friendship with the actor famed for portraying Dracula, that culminated in Michael being a pallbearer at Lugosi's funeral. Michael graduated Phi Beta Kappa from UCLA with a degree in Economics, then moved back to the East Coast to attend Harvard Law School. However, he chose to leave after three months to resume piano studies, at Mannes College of Music in New York City. Soon after, he married fellow Mannes student Ruth Albert. Over the next few years, Michael gave many weekly performances for patients in long term, chronic psychiatric hospitals around New York City. It was during this period that he attended a Ravi Shankar concert at a huge hall with only a handful of people in attendance. He realized that he could have filled the empty seats in the hall with very appreciative patients from the hospitals nearby where he performed regularly. He began requesting free, unused tickets, bringing his first busload of 200 patients to a Senior Musicians Orchestra concert in 1967. It was this event that shaped his destiny and Michael decided that he would dedicate his life to patients in hospitals, uplifting their lives and bringing them out of their grim existences. Working from his dining room table, he began his quest for funding, operating on a "never take no for an answer" and "it's now or never" approach. In 1969, Hospital Audiences Inc. (HAI) was incorporated. The organization grew, expanded and flourished over the years, reaching over 14 million people, in a wide variety of programs. In addition to serving the original hospital clientele, HAI consumers grew to include underserved populations such as residents in homeless shelters, at-risk youth, adults in rehab programs, frail elderly, the incarcerated, and the physically and mentally challenged. Decades ago, Michael described his work as bringing "chicken soup to the soul." Under his guidance, and by always thinking out of the box, exceptional things happened, such as transporting patients on gurneys to cultural events on the HAI buses which he helped design, or bringing wounded soldiers from Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, DC to NYC for a weekend of cultural and special events. He was the recipient of many awards, among them an Honorary Doctorate from Hobart-William Smith College, and numerous awards from the City and State of New York. Michael was a passionate musician, playing his Bechstein piano for hours daily, and choosing to celebrate his 75th birthday in Slovakia with his daughter Joanna, playing the Rachmaninoff Piano Concerto #

MARSHALL--Dr. Richard, was born July 30, 1933 in Long Beach, New York and grew up in New York City. He received his B.A. from Wesleyan University, Middletown, Connecticut, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and his M.D. degree from Yale University. After an internship in internal medicine at Washington University in St. Louis, MO, Dr. Marshall worked in the laboratory of Nobel Prize winner Marshall Nirenberg at the National Institutes of Health. In 2009 Dr. Marshall was awarded the NIH Molecular Biology medal for his contributions to deciphering the genetic code of the mechanism of protein synthesis. During his long career, Dr. Marshall served as the Director of Neonatology at Children's Hospital, St. Louis, MO and at the University of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark, N.J. He is the author of numerous articles on genetics and pediatrics. Dr. Marshall is survived by his wife of 57 years, Judith, his children Linda and Katherine (Noah Pinko) and his grandchildren, David, Eitan, Michael and Eleanor. He is also survived by his brother, Donald Marshall. Dr. Marshall will be lovingly remembered for his outgoing and caring personality and his wide interests in literature, the arts, sports and people. Funeral services were private. Memorials may be made to Congregation Beth Shalom, 772 W. 5th Ave., Naperville, IL 60563 or Wesleyan University, 318 High St., Middletown, CT 06459, in memory of Carl Schorske. 630-355-0264 www. beidelmankunschfh.com 1/3

POPOFF--William, was a beloved husband, father, and grandfather who passed away on February 1, 2016. He was born in 1921 in the Bronx to Sarah and Julius Popofsky, joining his older brother Abe. He attended James Monroe High School, and ran the mile in the old Madison Square Garden. He enlisted in the Air Force during WWII and was the bombardier for the crew of "Catherine the Great," a B-17 Flying Fortress and part of the 96th Squadron in the Second Bomb Group. On his 30th mission his plane was shot down by enemy gunfire. He'd survive that plane crash, slamming nose-first into the Mediterranean Sea. But he would take with him the memory of that night, as he watched his plane sink, without all his brothers accounted for. He subsequently flew 21 additional missions, being honored with the Purple Heart and many additional air medals. Returning from the war, William started a family with his beloved wife Edna, graduated from Brooklyn Law School, and began a 30-year career as an attorney with the Federal Trade Commission. He was a courageous survivor. William was diagnosed with cancer four times, battling his way back to health each time. After 65 years of marriage to Edna, he had to face his final battle when she passed away in November 2010. He is lovingly remembered by his son and daughter, Josh and Leslie, and his grandson Ross. He will forever be in our hearts. 1/3

CLUNN--Andrew, died peacefully at The Osborn in Rye, NY on February 2, 2016. He was born in Kent, England in 1928, and came to New York in 1951 while working for Matson Navigation Company. In 1963 he became an apprentice to David Webb, the famous jeweler, with whom he worked for 12 years as a salesman, and then director of sales, becoming Webb's right-hand man working with the Duchess of Windsor, Elizabeth Taylor, and Diana Vreeland, among others. Following Webb's death in 1975, Andrew moved back to England. In 1980 he opened his own atelier, Andrew Clunn Ltd., on Madison Avenue in New York where he was a private jeweler and designer creating unique and distinctive jewelry for some of the most distinguished families in Europe and North America. Andrew's stylish designs became a favorite among prominent women in society and fashion. There are no known survivors, other than his many devoted friends. At Andrew's request, there will be no services. Memorial contributions may be made in the name of Andrew Clunn to the following organizations he supported during his lifetime: The Bideawee Home Association of New York; the ASPCA of New York; The Mabel Mercer Foundation; Carnegie Hall; and, WMNR Fine Arts Radio, Monroe, Connecticut. 1/3

one day on our blue planet . . . in the Antarctic Written and illustrated by Ella Bailey. 32 pp. Flying Eye Books. $16.95. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7)
 
Part of a stylish new illustrated series devoted to the daily lives of young animals, this snapshot of an Adélie penguin chick shows her as adorable — and also a brave adventurer. It’s the day she first leaves her parents and journeys out to sea, swimming like a champ as she navigates Antarctic waters filled with predators and prey. Bailey covers the basics in a tone that’s informative but delighted by the improbabilities of penguins. Her friendly, big-eyed creatures look as if they’re having a blast.

TARKA--Chester S.,passed away with loving hospice care on October 7, 2015, after a brief hospitalization. Born in Chicago, IL, February 9, 1919, he lived in Manhattan since 1950. A decorated Army Veteran of more than four years without home leave during World War II, including the Normandy invasion and the Battle of the Bulge, he rose to the rank of Sergeant in an artillery division under General Patton. Upon return to the United States, he studied at the University of Chicago and finished with a Master of Fine Arts degree from the Art Institute of Chicago. Beginning in 1955, he was an artist in the Division of Vertebrate Paleontology at the American Museum of Natural History. There, he supported the research of curators and scientists for more than 60 years. He was an extraordinary artist and scientific illustrator and a consummate teacher of photography and illustration to generations of students. His work improved the quality and impact of their publications immensely. Before the existence of computerized fossil images, he developed new techniques for the photographic representation of skeletal material brought from the field by paleontologists. He traveled and painted in France, enjoyed tennis and Classical music, and read widely in the fields of art, history, and philosophy. He needed little more than suggestion to engage in hours of conversation over wine and good cheese. Along with close staff friends and colleagues at the AMNH, Chester is survived by three nephews and several great- nieces and nephews in the greater Chicago area and in Colorado, and cousins in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts. He was buried with military honors in a private ceremony Tuesday, October 13 at the Gerald B.H. Solomon Saratoga National Cemetery in Schuylerville, NY. 1/3

BRACKMAN--Jody, passed away at home on February 9, 2016. Born July 2, 1952 in Newton, MA to Gerald and Marietta Hermanson, Jody was a beloved mother, wife, sister, daughter, aunt and dog parent. A respected attorney, public trustee, notorious free spirit, and the most devoted, caring and charitable person anyone could have had the privilege of knowing. Jody loved everyone and made it her mission to ensure everyone in her life knew it well. She is survived by her loving family: husband Robert, son Adam, daughter Emily, her brother Andrew and family. A celebration of Jody's life will be held on February 15, 2016 at 1pm at 746 Mamaroneck Ave, Mamaroneck, NY 10543. 1/3

BOWDITCH--Phebe Alexander, died peacefully at home with her family on February 9, at the age of 82. She is survived by her children from her marriage to Peter Bowditch, Dr. Phebe Lowell Bowditch of Creswell, OR and Richard Lyon Bowditch of Brooklyn, NY. She was especially proud of her three granddaughters, Alexandra Scott and Charlotte Louise Bowditch, and Elizabeth Lowell Sibley-Bowditch. Raised in Atlanta and in Rye, NY, Phebe graduated from Vassar College in 1954. She lived most of her life in New York City where she worked for almost forty years as a realtor at Brown Harris Stevens. A member of the Cosmopolitan Club and the Essex Fox Hounds, Phebe spent most of her free time with her numerous friends, and in the company of her horses and her cat. Services will be held at 3pm on Monday, February 22nd at St. James Church at 865 Madison Avenue in New York City. 1/3

GOLLANCE--Robert B.,M.D. Robert B. Gollance M.D., 78, beloved father, of Wayne, NJ and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, passed away on January 20, 2016. He was an avid photographer who traveled extensively to places such as Africa, the North and South Poles, and The Galapagos Islands. He was on a photography excursion in Asia at the time of his passing. Dr. Gollance was born in Brooklyn, attended Harvard College, and Columbia Medical School. He served as a captain in the Army in Seoul, Korea, where he established Korea's first eye bank. He was a distinguished Ophthalmologist loved by generations of his patients. He will be remembered for his keen sense of humor. He was pre-deceased by his devoted wife of 44 years, Carmen (Cote) Gollance. He is survived by his son, Stephen Gollance M.D., who will carry on the practice. He is also survived by his daughter in law, Dana Gollance and his sister, Barbara Smoliar. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in honor of Dr. Robert Gollance to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY, 10028 or through their website, www.metmuseum.org Proceeds will be used for photography acquisition. A private memorial will be held. 1/3

MITTENTHAL--Richard, 89, died January 23, 2016 in Sarasota, FL. Arbitrator of labor- management disputes for almost his entire 58 year career, he served as umpire in major industries, including steel, automotive, beverage and government service. Mittenthal wrote many papers on the craft of arbitration, including an oft-cited article on past practice. He served as President of the National Academy of Arbitrators (1978-79) and received a lifetime achievement award from the Michigan Bar in 2015. Raised in NYC, he graduated Cornell University and New York University law school. He was predeceased by his loving wife of 61 years, Joyce Janeway. They married in 1953 and moved to Detroit, MI where he spent the majority of his life and career. He was not only devoted to his work, but to being husband and father. He loved tennis, practiced poetry and was a fervent football fan. The rigor he displayed in his work carried to all aspects of his life. He was driven to know the "you" of you, your values, the reasoning underlying them, your deep thoughts. And his courage in sharing all those things about himself encouraged you to feel sufficiently accepted and secure to respond in kind. In his 1979 NAA presidential address, he quipped that he'd experienced a dream where he saw the headline on his own obituary. It read: "Arbitrator seeks immortality; grievance denied." He is survived by four children, Marilyn, Robert, John and Peter, and four grandchildren. Donations to American Cancer Society. 1/3

WEINRIB--Jerome (Jay, Jerry). February 18, 1929-February 13, 2016. Chairman of ABC Carpet. Loving husband to Bunny Weinrib. Beloved father of Paulette Cole, Madeline Weinrib, partner Graham Head, and the late Steven Weinrib. Devoted husband to their mother, the late Norma Weinrib. Cherished grandfather of Lena Pearl Cole and the late Kyle and Jeremy Cole. Father-in-law to Evan Cole. Loving stepfather to Ellen and Dan Crown, Stephen, Gary and Jill Podell and joyful step-grandfather to Adam, Amanda, Alexandra and Austin Crown, Samantha and Justin Podell. Brother-in-law to Gloria and Dan Pilot and uncle of Ken and Sara Pilot. Devoted son of the late Lena and Max Weinrib. Services Tuesday, 11am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

FINK--Sherwin "Rocco", of Hillsdale, New York, on February 12, 2016, at age 93. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the death of Sherwin. He grew up in Brooklyn but spent much of his life in the Berkshires, where in 1975, he and his wife, Phylis, founded the clothing store Gatsbys in Great Barrington, Massachusetts. He graduated from Baruch College, CCNY, in 1945. His passion for life was boundless, and he lived each moment to the fullest. He truly cherished every day as he did his wife; his children, Robin H. Fink, Pamela Fink, and Jonathan Fink; his daughter-in-law, Amy Brusiloff; and his grandchildren, Schuyler Fink and Harrison Fink. 1/3
SOKOLOW--Mel. Beloved, adored and missed forever. Love and hugs , Diane, Betsy, Alec and Sam 1/3
KALKSTEIN--Goldie B.,peacefully on February 13, 2016. Beloved mother, grandmother, sister and aunt. Services were held. 1/3

CLARICK--Donald E.,80, of Miami Beach, FL, passed away February 12, 2016, after a long, courageous battle with kidney and heart disease. Don was a loving husband to his wife of 55 years, Betty Jane, and a devoted father to Rob, Greg and Alison, and their spouses Carolyn, Jodi and Jonathan. He adored his six grandchildren, Talia, Sasha, Emma, Benjamin, Julia and Eli. He eagerly followed his children's and grandchildren's pursuits and celebrated every family event. He is also survived by his sister, Roberta Rosenfeld of Orange County, CA. Don grew up in Elizabeth, NJ, was a graduate of Columbia University and earned a law degree at the University of West Virginia. Don practiced law and then held an array of business positions that showcased his people skills, deal-making abilities, keen intellect and wit. He was devoted to Judaism (a legendary Seder leader), ever curious about American history and engaged in politics since his days aiding the Kennedy campaign in New Jersey. His relentless optimism, generosity, and humor (and kibitzing) left a lasting impression on everyone who knew him. We always will love and miss him dearly. 1/3

HALSEY--George Dawson, 90. Distinguished physical chemist and professor at the University of Washington died in Seattle, WA on January 15, 2016. He is survived by the mother of his three children, Yadviga, his children Bill, Julia Baker and Sarah, four grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. 1/3

BOWDITCH--Phebe Alexander, died peacefully at home with her family on February 9, at the age of 82. She is survived by her children from her marriage to Peter Bowditch, Dr. Phebe Lowell Bowditch of Creswell, OR and Richard Lyon Bowditch of Brooklyn, NY. She was especially proud of her three granddaughters, Alexandra Scott and Charlotte Louise Bowditch, and Elizabeth Lowell Sibley-Bowditch. Raised in Atlanta and in Rye, NY, Phebe graduated from Vassar College in 1954. She lived most of her life in New York City where she worked for almost forty years as a realtor at Brown Harris Stevens. A member of the Cosmopolitan Club and the Essex Fox Hounds, Phebe spent most of her free time with her numerous friends, and in the company of her horses and her cat. Services will be held at 3pm on Monday, February 22nd at St. James Church at 865 Madison Avenue in New York City. 1/3

BRACONI--Frank. A man of peace who fought for his country in WWII died at 92. William James said we cannot know human nature until the last man has lived and had his say. Frank's life spoke that human nature is honest, generous and kind. 1/3

FIELD--Josh. The Board of Directors of 165 East 72nd Street mourn the loss of our President and friend, Josh Field. Josh worked tirelessly on behalf of our building. We are grateful for his efforts and for his dedication to the residents and staff. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. 1/3
WEINRIB--Jerome. My dearest Jay, how can I tell you how much I have loved you. You are now gone from me and in a better place but, one day, we will be together again. Love, your wife, Bunny 1/3
SCHULMAN KLOTZ--Brenda Feb. 11, 1938 - Feb. 15, 2007. In memory of my twin sister Bren. My first love, my other half. My sadness never leaves me. Requiescat in pace, Brenda. Evelyn 1/3

KAUFMANN--Peggy Weil, of Sun City, AZ on February 2nd, 2016, formerly of Fort Lee, NJ and Lynbrook, LI. Devoted wife of Richard (deceased), beloved mother of James (Zilma) and Robert (Frances) Kaufmann. Loving grandmother of Laura (Gregg Arst), David (Sarah), Tessy and Julie. Silver Life Master at Bridge. Graduate of Cornell University. Loved by all who knew her. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Barnaret Temple Social Action Fund, 747 Rt. 208, Franklin Lakes, NJ 07407. 1/3

PETERS--Margery Antle (nee Watson), age 92, died at home in New York on January 28, 2016. Born in Colorado, raised in California, she moved to Manhattan in the 1940s, married and was a corporate wife and mother. In later life she became Director of the Library of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen in New York, retiring in 1997. She was a world traveler, a beachcomber and a gracious friend. Survivors include her brother, K.G., her daughters, Nancy and Carol and her son-in-law, Paul. 1/3

MENDELSON--David, 80, on February 13, 2016. Services will be held at 11:30am, Tuesday, February 16, at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ. Interment in Cedar Park Cemetery. A more detailed obituary can be found at: bernheimapter kreitzman.com 1/3
KROLL--Arthur H. 12/2/39 - 2/15/10 An extraordinary man who is missed, loved, and remembered. Lois & Pamela Kroll, family and friends 1/3

Don grew up in Elizabeth, NJ, was a graduate of Columbia University and earned a law degree at the University of West Virginia. Don practiced law and then held an array of business positions that showcased his people skills, deal-making abilities, keen intellect and wit. He was devoted to Judaism (a legendary Seder leader), ever curious about American history and engaged in politics since his days aiding the Kennedy campaign in New Jersey. His relentless optimism, generosity, and humor (and kibitzing) left a lasting impression on everyone who knew him. We always will love and miss him dearly. 1/3
FIELD--Josh. We will miss you so much dear friend. You will always be in our hearts. The Weisgal Family 1/3

WEINRIB--Jerome (Jay, Jerry). February 18, 1929-February 13, 2016. Chairman of ABC Carpet. Loving husband to Bunny Weinrib. Beloved father of Paulette Cole, Madeline Weinrib, partner Graham Head, and the late Steven Weinrib. Devoted husband to their mother, the late Norma Weinrib. Cherished grandfather of Lena Pearl Cole and the late Kyle and Jeremy Cole. Father-in-law to Evan Cole. PERLMAN--Claire Field, age 91, died Monday, February 15. Daughter of the late Helen and Sam Field, Claire was born in New York City and lived in Woodmere. She was married to the late Sidney Perlman. Claire's belief in helping others made her an active volunteer: typing books in Braille, serving as vice president and board member of the Samuel Field YM-YWHA for many years. Claire was a generous donor to numerous charitable organizations including UJA Federation of New York, The Samuel Field YM-YWHA, and Israel Goldstein Youth Village and Ramat Hadassah in Israel. Claire is survived by her daughter, Toni Young, son John (Maxine) Perlman, and stepson, Jim Mindling, as well as five grandchildren, Mitchell Young (Katka), Ann Young Saban (Hanoch), Betsy Perlman, Sam Perlman, and Natasha Mindling. She had two great-grandsons, Giladi Shmuel Saban and another who will be named at his bris on February 17, 2016. Special thanks are given to her outstanding team of caregivers in her final years, Patricia Muir, Dawn Hutchinson, Gladys Barnes, Valerie DaCosta, and others. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Samuel Field YM-YWHA, or the charity of your choice. Funeral services handled by Riverside Chapel: 516-295-3100. 1/3

STUCKY--Steven. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the passing of faculty member Steven Stucky. Steven recently joined the composition faculty in September 2014 and immediately had a profoundly positive impact on the entire institution. With great integrity and creativity, he brought an extraordinary energy to all that he addressed. His legacy will live on through his students and his many important compositions. We extend our condolences to his wife, Kristen, and his children, Matthew and Maura, and his many friends. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Robert Beaser, Chair, Juilliard Composition Department 1/3

STUCKY--Steven. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the passing of faculty member Steven Stucky. Steven recently joined the composition faculty in September 2014 and immediately had a profoundly positive impact on the entire institution. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Robert Beaser, Chair, Juilliard Composition Department 1/3

LAPIDUS--Leonard, 86, on February 13, 2016. A Notice and Eulogy Writ in His Own Hand. Leonard was an economist with a career in bank regulation with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, New York State Banking Department, The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, The National Credit Union Administration, and the US Treasury. He was President of the Depositors Insurance Fund, a private fund insuring deposits of savings banks in Massachusetts from 1981-1994. He was a graduate of CCNY (1951) and earned a Ph.D. at New York University (1975). He served in Korea as a sergeant in the Army for a year during the war. He had a restless intelligence, an intense affect, a sharp wit, and a laugh that filled the room. He had many friends whom he cherished and some enemies of whom he was singularly proud. He fell in love with Jackie 20 minutes after meeting her and never stopped loving her for their 35 years of marriage; he asks her forgiveness for being easier to love than to live with. A private remembrance will be held at a later date. If he wanted you there, you will receive an invitation for good food, good wine, a few laughs, and a few tears. If you wish, a donation may be made to Friends of Acadia (www.friendsofacadia.org) to JSSA Hospice (www.jssa.org /service/jssa-hospice) or the charity of your choice. 1/3

FRIEDLANDER--Eva. Eva Friedlander, age 74, died suddenly at home on December 24, 2015 after a prolonged struggle with ovarian cancer. Born in England to Holocaust refugees, Eva immigrated to the US as a child with her parents. She attended Hunter College and received her Ph.D. in anthropology from Brown University. Her areas of research expertise included gender and development, public health, disability studies, international development policy and participatory program evaluation. Eva was close to her brother, David Friedlander, who predeceased her in August 2010. She is survived by her beloved nephew, George, sister-in-law Edi, her cousins: Alan, Doris, Joe Renee, Marcia, Margaret, Richard, and numerous dear friends and colleagues. A memorial service for Eva will be held at the UN Chapel, 777 United Plaza, NY, NY 10017 on Saturday, February 27, 2016 at 12:00pm. 1/3

SCHAIN--Arthur, February 15, 2016. Roberta's beloved husband of 44 years. Michael's loving father and friend. 1/3

HSIA--Sven Erik, 75, passed away February 13. Born in Stockholm to Sung-Yo and Suzanne (Chow) Hsia. Sung-Yo was from a prominent diplomatic family in Shanghai. Survived by his devoted wife, Ay-Whang Hsia. His early years were spent in Sweden, and in 1950 Sven and his recently widowed mother immigrated to New York City. An alumnus of Phillips Academy (Andover), Yale, University of Virginia School of Law, and NYU Stern School of Business. His early career was with the Wall Street firms of Bache & Co., Evans & Co., and White Weld, among others. In 1980 Sven founded Kensington Capital Management, Ltd., which merged with the Roosevelt Investment Group in the early 1990s, where he was a Managing Director. Sven retired in 2015. His interest in education led him to participate in the following organizations: The Duke of Edinburgh Foundation, East Side House Settlement, Youth Foundation of New York, Holland Lodge Foundation, and Thomas J. Watson Library at The Metropolitan Museum of Art. He was a member of the Union Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his name to the Youth Foundation and the East Side House Settlement. A memorial service will be held in the spring. 1/3

DeRIGHT--Robert E.,Jr. Born Wilmington, DE, 1938, died February 2016 from lung failure. Survived by wife Marilyn Goler (brother Ed), son Daniel (Elizabeth) and daughter Kate (Paul; granddaughters Tillie and Greta), sisters Martha DeRight and Mary Lu Geiger (Dale), plus many nephews and nieces. Graduate of Salesianum (Wilm), Reed College, Yale Law School; Army Language Corps (Chinese). Longtime legal malpractice lawyer with Epstein, Becker & Green. World traveler, history reader, bridge player, theater, opera, film and wine lover. Wry, brilliant, loyal, mischievous. Service 1pm, Ballard Funeral Home, White Plains, NY, Saturday, February 20. Tributes to Oxfam America. 1/3

SPIEGEL--Richard (Dick), gasoline distributor passed away on Tuesday. He is loved by his wife Rhoda, his children Robert (Jill), Jeffrey (Meredith) and Jodi, son-in-law Barry, as well as eight adoring grandchildren. The funeral will be held at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY on Thursday at 11:30. 1/3

VAN MUNCHING--Leo, Jr.,retired beer-importing executive and longtime Darien, CT resident, died after a long illness. He was 89. Born in 1926 in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, Leo and his family immigrated to the United States in 1933. His father, the late Leo van Munching of Greenwich, came as a representative of the Heineken brewery, eventually establishing Van Munching & Company as the exclusive US importer of Heineken brands. Drafted into the United States Navy while in high school, Leo served as a Seabee in the 35th Special Naval Construction Battalion on Oahu, Hawaii from 1944 to 1946. Upon discharge, he enrolled in the University of Maryland on the G.I. Bill, receiving a degree from the College of Business and Management in 1950. After graduation, he went to work for the family business, eventually becoming president of Van Munching & Company, a role he remained in until his retirement in 1993. During his time with Van Munching & Company, no other brand approached Heineken's position as the largest-selling imported beer. In recognition of his outstanding contributions and personal dedication to US-Netherlands trade relations, and his promotion of goodwill for the Netherlands in the United States, Queen Beatrix honored Leo with The Order of Orange-Nassau in 1982. Six years later, the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in the United States also recognized his role in the expansion of trade between the two countries, presenting him with the George Washington Vanderbilt Award. Leo's efforts as a philanthropist, often anonymous, were made out of appreciation for the opportunities he and his family enjoyed in America. In 1983, he supported the restoration of the Statue of Liberty in memory of his mother, Mia. He donated Van Munching Hall, dedicated in 1992, to house the University of Maryland School of Business, in part to thank the university for its kind treatment of the veterans of World War II. Leo's fervent commitment to supporting education led him to a long-standing relationship with Kolbe Cathedral High School in Bridgeport. His support of that school, both as a benefactor and member of the Advisory Board, prompted the Diocese of Bridgeport to honor him with the Order of St. Augustine Medal of Service in 2012. Leo also established the Van Munching Rehabilitation Unit at Stamford Hospital, was a leadership donor to the construction of the new Darien Library, which opened in 2009, and was a founding donor to the Margaret M. Dyson Vision Research Institute at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was an active supporter of several Darien-based charities, and a member of the Wee Burn Country Club. Leo is survived by his wife of 62 years, Peggy, and their eight children: Leo, III (Laura) of San Francisco, CA, Jan Phillips (Charles) of Bonita Springs, FL, Pieter of Darien, Paul (Heather) of Bath, England, Maria of Newport, RI, Anne Ardery (Peter) of Darien, Philip (Christina) of Darien, and Christopher (Kimberly) of Darien. He is also survived by thirteen grandchildren, Kyle, Charlie, Brennan, Annebet, Max, Anneka, Lily, Mia, Megan, William, Anna, Maggie, and Leo, IV, and two great-grandchildren, River and Rory. In addition, he is survived by his sister, Anne Wilsey, of Greenwich. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Thomas More Church in Darien, CT on February 20th at 10:30am. Memorial donations can be made to the Kolbe Cathedral High School, 33 Calhoun Place, Bridgeport, CT 06604, attention Jo-Anne Jakab, Principal. 1/3

STUCKY--Steven. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, a brilliant orchestral composer, renowned teacher, and exemplary force in contemporary art music. 1/3

ANDREWS--Dr. Zelle Whitmarsh. Died on February 2, 2016 at White Plains Hospital. Zelle's lifelong commitment to feminism, reproductive freedom, LGBT issues, civil liberties, her Congregational church, the Democratic Party, animals, the environment and the teaching of history brought her more honors in each field than can be listed. Her biography can be found in Barbara Love's book, "Feminists Who Changed America 1963-1975." Zelle will be remembered as one who spoke for justice and fairness always. She was unwavering in her commitment to help those in need and she was not intimidated by challenges many would find too great. She is survived by her partner of seventeen years, Deborah West Zipf and by Peter Durbin, her nephew and Ann Durbin Eby, her niece. 1/3

CROSS--Mary S.,79, died peacefully at home on Friday, February 5, 2016. Born in Louisville, KY, she had been a resident of Princeton, NJ since 1975. Mary spent summers in Nantucket, and it was there that she met her late husband, Theodore L. Cross, in 1973. Mary graduated from Hollins College where she had studied at the Sorbonne in Paris for a year. Mary was a photographer who authored photojournalistic books including "Behind the Great Wall" (1979), "Egypt" (1991), "Morocco: Sahara to the Sea" (1995), "Vietnam: Spirits of the Earth" (2001), and "Sacred Spaces: Turkish Mosques & Tombs" (2013). She was a trustee of the American University of Cairo for twenty years. She was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, a member of the Boards of Directors of Network 20/20, the Princeton Arts Council, the American School of Tangier and the Near East Foundation. Mary sat on the advisory council of the Department of Comparative Literature at Princeton University. Daughter of the late William A. and Dorothy (Smith) Stoll, she is survived by three daughters and their spouses: Stuart Warner and David Paltiel, Ann Warner Anderson and Ken Anderson, Polly Warner and Christopher Crawford, and eight grandchildren: Daniel, Benjamin, Madeline, Claire, Deirdre, Theodore, Eliza and Alexandra. Those wishing to make a charitable contribution in Mary's memory are asked to donate to HomeFront (www.homefrontnj.org), an organization dedicated to helping the homeless in Southern New Jersey, the Trenton Area Soup Kitchen (www.trentonsoupkitchen. org), Doctors Without Borders or Planned Parenthood. A memorial service will be held on April 10th at 2pm at Chancellor Green on the Princeton University Campus. For any additional information you may contact the Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, Princeton. 1/3

COHEN--Linda Salzman, of Durham, NC passed away on February 15, 2016. A native of Long Island, Linda graduated from the University of Cincinnati, Hofstra University, and the College of St. Rose. A career educator and administrator, Linda spent over 20 years as Special Education Administrator for the Massapequa School District. Her passion and dedication to the students she served and the teachers she mentored was without comparison. She is survived by her loving husband of 44 years Jeffrey, children Nina and Peter Garlington, Eric Cohen and Sandi Kronick, grandchildren Ava Garlington, Ella Cohen and Nathan Cohen, and sister Ellen Waserstein. A funeral will be held on Friday, February 19 at 1:00pm at Brown-Wynne Funeral Home in Raleigh, NC at 1701 East Millbrook Road. There will be a further celebration of Linda's life on Sunday, February 28 at 3:00pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, NY. 1/3

PAOLELLA--Edward C.,74 years old and a retired professor at Brooklyn College who taught for more than 30 years, passed away on February 11, 2016 after battling Leukemia. Professor Paolella was known as a witty, brilliant and provocative teacher. He was a bibliophile who donated more than 10,000 volumes to Brooklyn College. Edward was predeceased by his father Nicholas Paolella, his mother Dorothy Edlavitch-Paolella, and his sister Rhoda Dimino. Edward is survived by his brother Lawrence Paolella and his sister-in-law Margaret Ryan of Walla Walla, WA, his nieces Gillian Paolella, and his great-niece Ravenna, niece Jonna Paolella and her husband David Kliphon, nephews, many cousins, relatives and dedicated lifelong friends. Memorial Services will be held on April 9, 2016 at a venue to be determined. For information, email rmontelione@aol.com. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Services & Advocacy for GLBT Elders (SAGE), 305 Seventh Ave, 15th Floor, New York, NY 10001 ("SAGE"), or St. Jude's, 262 Danny Thomas Place, Memphis, TN 38105 or the charity of your choice. 1/3

LOWENSTEIN--Harry, 96, died at home in New York. A successful businessman, at 17 he was smuggled into Palestine to fight for the establishment of Israel, served with the Jewish Brigade in WWII, then arrived penniless in the US. When retired he became regional and New York director of SCORE. Devoted father and granddad, he joined his loving wife Ruth on Valentine's Day. 1/3
DOSIK--Sherry. 2/17/04. With love always. Morty, Jill, Jon, and wife Tara and your grandsons Spencer and Jack 1/3

GREENWALD--Irwin Daniel. Sept. 6, 1918 - Feb. 17, 2013 Dad, It has been three years since your passing and not a day goes by when you are not uppermost in our hearts and minds. We miss your wisdom, warmth and gentle ways especially when times are difficult. You would continue to be so proud of your grandsons, Sam and Evan, as well as their wives, Randi and Carolyn, and you would derive such overwhelming pleasure from your great-grandchildren, Brett, Brooke, Riley and Isla. Mom and I believe that Louie and Licorice are by your side. We love you. Your wife, Doris and daughter, Ronny 1/3

GARTLIR--Shirley, 96, died peacefully at home on February 15 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Born in Queens, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Graduate of Cornell University. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 72 years, Bernard, and survived by children Lois and Kenneth, daughter-in-law June, eight nieces and nephews and treasured friend Judy Spence. Donations in Shirley's memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County Foundation. 1/3

SPIESS--Bernard, beloved husband, brother, father, grandfather, mensch and friend, died Sunday, February 14, in Boynton Beach, FL. Bernie was born June 19, 1935 in Manhattan to Gussie and Irving Spiess. He graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School and City College of New York. He loved golf, jazz, politics, and spending time with his family. He is survived by Joyce, his beloved wife of 57 years; sister Lorraine Goldberg; devoted children Steven (Liora), Philip (Marcia), and Jennifer Parks (Dennis); adoring grandsons Alexander, Robert, Noah, Ryan, Joshua, and Isaac, and countless other friends and family. Bernie touched the lives of all who met him with his trademark generosity and loyalty. Funeral services will be held at 10:15am, Wednesday, February 17 at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 11115 Jog Road, Boynton Beach, FL. 1/3

KIRSCHENBAUM--Bernard, 91, of New York City, died on February 16. In the spring of 1943 his botany studies at Cornell were interrupted when he enlisted in the Army as part of the Fighting 69th Regiment of New York State. On April 19, 1945, he helped liberate the Leipzig-Thekla Concentration Camp. On April 25, 1945, he was a part of the historic meeting of the American and Russian ground troops at the River Elbe in Germany. In 1946 he returned to Cornell and transferred to Bauhaus-based Institute of Design in Chicago where he graduated in 1952. In 1954 he and a friend from Cornell, Bill Wainwright, founded Geodesics with Bucky Fuller as honorary president. In 1957 he began building the first residential geodesic dome ever built. He designed a pattern of diamonds and triangles for the dome floor that was an undiscovered tessilation later known as Penrose tiles after a later discovery by Roger Penrose. Bernie enjoyed success as a sculptor and professor of sculpture, receiving a Guggenheim Fellowship and two National Endowment for the Arts Fellowships. He had dozens of exhibitions of his work in the United States, Sweden, Belgium and Finland. Bernie is survived by his beloved wife, Susan Weil Kirschenbaum, his two children, Christopher Rauschenberg and Sara Kirschenbaum; daughter-in-law Janet Stein; two grandchildren, Sage Bedell and Flint Kirschenbaum; his sister, Frances Brandt, and her husband, children, and grandchildren, all of whom loved and esteemed him. The family would like to thank Isaac Amponsah for his excellent care of Bernie. We are comforted by the caring showed us during his struggle with "heart failure," but was actually, a triumph of love. Donations in honor of Bernie may be sent to Blue Sky Gallery, or Wanas Sculpture Garden. Services will be held on February 18, at 11:30am at "The Riverside" in NYC. 1/3

FISHMAN--Edna, died peacefully at home on February 15th, at age 100. She was a lifelong New Yorker, a beloved daughter, sister and cousin, and a valued friend to multiple generations. She lived a fully engaged and independent life on her own terms, and will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral services will take place at Plaza Jewish Memorial, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, Thursday, February 18th at 11:00. 1/3

MOROFF--Libby, died suddenly in New York on February 17, 2016, at the age of 79, following emergency cardiac surgery. She was born June 26, 1936 in Reading, PA, the daughter of Ralph and Sadie Levinson. She graduated from her beloved Oakwood Friends School in Poughkeepsie and was President of its Board of Managers for the past several years. She earned her B.A. from Barnard College, and a Master's Degree in Economics from Columbia University. She devoted her adult life to furthering the principles of social justice and equality for all. Her long career as an activist included a stint as Executive Director of the New York State Democratic Committee in the 1980s, and Political Director in the Manhattan Borough President's Office following that. She is survived by her husband Saul Moroff, her daughters Margaret Moroff and Diane Moroff, her sister Ruth Preven, and her grandchildren Noah and Sadie Reuter, whom she loved dearly and who loved her in return. She had the love, respect, and admiration of all who knew her. Her family will be at home in their Manhattan apartment Friday and Saturday, February 19 and 20, from 6 to 9pm. Contributions in her memory may be made to Oakwood Friends School, 22 Spackenkill Road, Poughkeepsie, NY 12603. A memorial celebration of her life will be held at a later date. 1/3
GLICKMAN--Donna. 2/18/07 You are still the first person I want to call. Love and miss you every day. Love, Susie 1/3

SAITO--Kikuo, a major color-field painter also known for his poetic theater works that incorporated costumes, light, music, and dance, died on February 15 at age 76. Kikuo was born in Tokyo in 1939, and moved to New York City in 1966, where he attended the Art Students League, an institution at which he later taught. His work, currently represented by Leslie Feely, is in the permanent collections of the MoMA and Whitney, among myriad other museums worldwide. Kikuo was married to Eva Maier until her death in 1997, and is survived by his second wife, Mikiko Ino, and the many students whom he chose to be his children. A viewing will be held this Friday, February 19, at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. 1/3

JAHARIS--Michael. Mr. Michael Jaharis, 1928-2016, entrepreneur, philanthropist, humanitarian and distinguished member of the Hellenic American and Greek Orthodox community passed away peacefully February 17, 2016, in his home with his family by his side. He was 87 years old. Michael Jaharis was a model of how to offer time, energy and intelligence in pursuit of a better world. He is survived by his wife Mary (nee Spyros), children Steven and Kathryn, and grandchildren Melina, Michael, Valerie, Wilder, and Ava, as well as by the millions of people whose lives he has positively impacted. Visitation hours and a funeral service will be held at the Archdiocesan Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity at 337 East 74th Street, New York City. Visitation hours will be on Friday, February 19, 5:00pm - 9:30pm; the funeral service will take place on Saturday, February 20th at 11:00am. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to tile Rebuilding of St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church or the Cancer Programs at Columbia University Medical Center. 1/3

JAHARIS--Michael. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Michael Jaharis, a treasured friend and generous Benefactor to the Museum with his wife Mary, an Honorary Trustee. Together they have been steadfast supporters of the Department of Greek and Roman Art and the Department of Medieval Art and The Cloisters since 1984. Their multi-faceted giving has touched on many areas of the Met, from gifts of works of art to funds in support of acquisitions, capital projects, education initiatives, publications, and special exhibitions. In recognition of their generous contributions toward the masterplan for the Greek, Roman, and Byzantine Galleries, the Museum's grand vaulted gallery for the display of classical art and the galleries for Byzantine art were designated the Mary and Michael Jaharis Galleries. Michael was an unfailingly warm and committed member of the Met family, and he will be deeply missed. We offer our condolences to Mary and to the entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Daniel H. Weiss, President 1/3

Michael was committed to advancing scientific understanding of cardiovascular disease and lipid disorders, a legacy that endures through the Mary and Michael Jaharis - Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D., D. Phil, Atherosclerosis and Lipids Research Fund and the Mary and Michael Jaharis Cardiovascular Diseases Laboratories, which he and his wife Mary generously established. Bibliowicz, Chairman, Board of Overseers Weill Cornell Medicine 1/3

SCHORR-- Alvin L. The Community Service Society (CSS) mourns the death of Alvin L. Schorr, 94, who served as General Director of CSS from 1973 to 1977, and received many awards and honors over a distinguished career fighting poverty on many fronts. He died on February 13, in Charlotte, NC. Born in New York City in 1921, Mr. Schorr graduated from City College of New York and Washington University in St. Louis where he received his Master's Degree in Social Work. After working for several years in social service agencies he began a career in policy. In 1963, he headed up analysis of poverty in the United States with a focus on the relationship of family and income development. Two years later he moved to the Office of Economic Opportunity where he did research, planning and allocation of government funds in the fight against poverty. By 1968, Schorr was a professor of social policy and director of the Center for Studies of Income Maintenance Policy at Brandeis University. He would later establish a similar center at New York University where he served as dean of the School of Social Work from 1970 to 1973. When he took over CSS in 1973, the anti-poverty organization was transitioning from an agency working primarily with disadvantaged families to one focused on aiding the poor in their own communities -- in housing projects, schools, community centers and neighborhoods. Among the many awards Schorr received was the Distinguished Service Award (1966), the Distinguished Alumnus Citation (1970) from Washington University's George Warren Brown School of Social Work, the Michael Schwerner award for civil rights leadership (1972), and an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters from Adelphi University (1975). He was a Fulbright Senior Research Scholar in England in 1962-63. With great sadness we mark his death, and extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. 1/3
