LANDAU--David, beloved husband of Miriam and proud father of Dr. Mark (Linda) Landau and Laura (Andrew) Freedman and grandfather of four, passed away on Saturday, February 6, 2016 at age 90. David was a courageous Holocaust survivor and carried his remembrance with quiet dignity. He was born in 1925 in Kybartai, Lithuania. Confined for three years in the Kovna ghetto, then imprisoned with his father in Dachau, David was liberated by the United States Army and reunited with his father in a Displaced Person's camp. David received a mechanical engineering degree from Munich Institute of Technology. In 1950, after President Truman allowed DPs to enter the US, David sailed to America. He served in the US Army from 1951-53, then returned to school earning a Masters degree in engineering from Stevens Institute of Technology, in New Jersey. He pursued a successful career as a mechanical and consulting engineer. David was proud of Israel as a free nation in the same way that he valued his freedom as an American citizen. 1/3

HOCHMAN--Bert, died peacefully on February 17, surrounded by loving family. Born November 23, 1925, Bert graduated Boys High in Brooklyn and Brooklyn College, class of 1946. After college he joined the Brooklyn Eagle, rising from copy boy to Night City Editor. He worked in the public relations department at Lever Brothers from 1955 until retirement. Predeceased by sister Anita Rosenzweig. Bert was remarkably loyal, kind and disarmingly funny. He will be greatly missed by wife of 65 years, Estelle, son Steven, daughter Gail and grandchildren Emily and Jonathan Hochman, Jacob and Elena Levi. Services 11:15, Sunday, at "The Riverside" West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

KIRSCHENBAUM--Bernard. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Bernard Kirschenbaum, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Bernard's wife, Susan Weil; his sister, Frances Brandt; his children, Sara and Christopher; his daughter-in-law, Janet Stein; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

SAITO--Kikuo, a major color-field painter also known for his poetic theater works that incorporated costumes, light, music, and dance, died on February 15 at age 76. Kikuo was born in Tokyo in 1939, and moved to New York City in 1966, where he attended the Art Students League, an institution at which he later taught. His work, currently represented by Leslie Feely, is in the permanent collections of the MoMA and Whitney, among myriad other museums worldwide. Kikuo was married to Eva Maier until her death in 1997, and is survived by his second wife, Mikiko Ino, and the many students whom he chose to be his children. A viewing will be held this Friday, February 19, at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. 1/3

JAHARIS--Michael. Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of our good friend and advisor Michael Jaharis. He and his wife, Mary, and their family have been extraordinarily generous benefactors of many programs across the Medical Center, including our new Medical and Graduate Education Building, which will open later this year. Mr. Jaharis served as a member of our Board of Advisors, where his friendship, candor and wise counsel will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, their children, grandchildren, and the extended Jaharis family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Chief Executive, Columbia University Medical Center Roy Vagelos, M.D. Chair, Board of Advisors Columbia University Medical Center 1/3

JAHARIS--Michael. 1928 - 2016. Mr. Michael Jaharis, entrepreneur, philanthropist, and humanitarian community passed away peacefully on February 17, 2016 in his home with his family by his side. Born and raised in Evanston, Illinois, Michael was the son of Greek immigrants, Michael and Katerina Jaharis, from the island of Lesvos. Shortly after his college graduation from Carroll University in June 1950, Michael was called to serve in the US Army during the Korean War and was deployed to help run the medical and pharmaceutical supply in Austria. After his service, Michael joined Miles Laboratories as a Sales Representative in the Ethical Drug Division (Prescription Drug), and earned his JD as a night student at DePaul University. Michael rose through the ranks at Miles to be appointed Vice President and Executive Legal Counsel for Food and Drug Law, where he also became involved in marketing for the company. In 1972, Michael became president and CEO of Key Pharmaceuticals, where he led his team to develop pharmaceutical breakthroughs such as sustained-release Theo-Dur, which became the nation's best selling asthma remedy, and Nitro-Dur, the first transdermal sustained-release product to release nitroglycerin through the skin. In 1988, Michael founded Kos Pharmaceuticals, where he led his team to pioneer innovative drug therapies to treat cardiovascular disease; the first product Niaspan, which raised HDL levels and improved the lives of millions of people. After selling Kos, he co-founded Vatera Healthcare Partners LLC, a New York City-based investment group focused on taking active positions in healthcare companies that develop innovative products for unmet and underserved medical needs in a broad range of therapeutic areas. In 1986, Michael and Mary founded the Jaharis Family Foundation, Inc. He was member of several non-profit and education boards: Trustee Emeritus of Tufts University, Chairman of the Board of Overseers for Tufts School of Medicine, Columbia University Medical Center Board of Visitors, and Member of the Board of Overseers of the Weill Cornell Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences. He and his wife were Benefactors of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Metropolitan Opera. They were Scholarship Sponsors of DePaul University College of Law in Chicago and developed the Mary and Michael Jaharis Center for Health Law at DePaul University. At Tufts University School of Medicine, they endowed the Jaharis Family Center for Biomedical and Nutrition Sciences, the Jaharis Family Chair in Family Medicine, and multiple Scholarship Funds. Through The Jaharis Family Foundation, he was also a Benefactor of Columbia University Medical College and Weill Cornell Medical College. He received an Honorary Doctor of Public Service degree from Tufts and Crown Award from Columbia University Medical. Proud of his Greek ancestry and Greek Orthodox faith, Michael served as Vice Chairman of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Council, Founding Member of Faith Endowment for Orthodoxy and Hellenism and Founding Member and Executive Committee Member of Leadership 100. The Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America made Michael an "Archon Exarchos of the Order of St. Andrew the Apostle," one of the highest honors bestowed upon laity on behalf of His All Holiness, Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew. Most recently, Michael and Mary directed their philanthropic efforts to supporting humanitarian initiatives to provide food, medical care and education to children and elderly living in Greece during the ongoing financial crisis and to support the refugee families fleeing to Greece. Michael Jaharis was a model of how to offer time, energy and intelligence in pursuit of a better world. He is survived by his wife Mary (nee Spyros), children Steven and Kathryn, and grandchildren Melina, Michael, Valerie, Wilder, and Ava, as well as by the millions of people whose lives he has positively impacted. Visitation hours and a funeral service will be held at the Archdiocesan Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity at 337 East 74th Street, New York City. Visitation hours will be on Friday, February 19, 5:00pm - 9:30pm; the funeral service will take place on Saturday, February 20th at 11:00am. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Rebuilding of St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church or the Cancer Programs at Columbia University Medical Center. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert. All sixty employees of Sage Realty Corporation, its Directors and Officers, deeply mourn the loss of their President, Robert Kaufman. We could ask for no greater leader and mentor. Robert joined Sage Realty in 1949 shortly after graduating from New York University in its first class offering a Bachelor in Science in Real Estate. In his 67-year career at Sage, he built the firm into one of the preeminent real estate companies in New York City, along with his father, William and his brother, Melvyn. He oversaw the development of over 6 million square feet of office space that still stands to this day in Manhattan. Even greater is the human legacy of respect, love and admiration held by all those who worked with him in this company and in the real estate industry. The Employees of Sage Realty Corporation 1/3

KRONFELD--Harvey S.,Harvey S. Kronfeld, 86, attorney, of Haverford PA and Naples FL died on February 14, 2016 in Philadelphia. He was husband of 61 years of Janet (nee Lubowitz), father of Linda, Andrew and Julia Kronfeld, grandfather of Lily and Claudia Kronfeld and Natalie and Samantha Gay, brother of Adele Cohen and Gerald Kronfeld, and son of Samuel and Lena Kronfeld. He was a graduate of University of Delaware, class of 1949 and Harvard Law School, class of 1952. After beginning his career in Philadelphia at the law firm Wolf Block, he joined the office of general counsel at Ford Motor Company and then returned to private practice in Philadelphia with a specialty in antitrust and class action litigation. In 1987 a spinal cord injury brought him to Magee Rehabilitation Hospital. With Janet's help he resumed a full life, notwithstanding a pivot from tennis to golf. He served on the Magee Hospital Board of Trustees for over 20 years, on the Magee Foundation Board since it began in 1998, and chaired the Hospital's oversight committee. He was recognized in 2010 with the Magee Humanitarian Award for his dedication to helping others, the example he set, and support of individuals with disabilities. He was also on the Board of the American Jewish Committee where he led an initiative to improve Jewish representation in executive ranks of large corporations. Harvey and Janet were devoted to each other and respected their complementary strengths. They built a rich life together with a close group of friends that has been together consistently for over six decades. 1/3
KAUFMAN--Robert. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Robert Kaufman, and send condolences to his family. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert. The staff and trustees of Northwell Health mourn the loss of Life Trustee and past Chair of North Shore Health System Board of Trustees Robert Kaufman. A dedicated benefactor, Bob and his wife Florence supported a wide variety of programs at North Shore University Hospital (NSUH) which greatly contributed to the hospital's success. Thanks to the Kaufmans' foresight and support, the Florence and Robert Kaufman Conference Center was created at NSUH and serves as a focal point for news conferences, celebrations, and discussions of the latest medical advances as well as a place of instruction for the hospital's medical students, house staff, doctoral candidates and physicians. Bob's leadership, enthusiasm, commitment and generosity has helped Northwell remain steadfast in its mission to put patients first and make a difference in their lives by providing the highest quality healthcare available. The Florence and Robert Kaufman Professor of Medical Ethics was created at the Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine for this purpose; to provide our future doctors with the integrity to carry on our mission. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Florence; daughters Ronna DiPersia, Cathy Iger, and Julie Webster; brother Melvin; and grandchildren. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Northwell Health Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, Northwell Health 1/3

GAWANDE--Trimbak Hari Dr. "Aba" Gawande, 92, of Cranbury, NJ was a beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. A lifelong educator, scholar and humanist, he was a school principal in central Indian villages, committed to eradicating the caste system and to equality in gender. His passion for history, philosophy and Indian classical music inspired all. 1/3
KAUFMAN--Robert. Our hearts are broken. We have lost a prince among men. Rest in peace dear friend. Love, Margie & Steve Fiverson and Nancy & Harold Oelbaum 1/3
KAUFMAN--Robert. Florence, Ronna, Cathy, Julie - how lucky you are to be loved by him. We will miss his sweetness and his smile. Always. Peggy Half Silbert & Nancy Half Carter and our family 1/3

KAUFMAN-- Robert The Board of Governors, and the members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member Robert and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Florence and the entire family. Board of Governors Steven Shenfeld, President 1/3

HARPER--Lee. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sadness the death of our esteemed colleague. "To Kill a Mockingbird" remains a primer for the possibility of racial justice. The most-assigned book in American public schools, its looming questions are underwritten with reason and buttressed by a child's pure faith. 1/3

HOCHMAN--Bert, died peacefully on February 17, surrounded by loving family. Born November 23, 1925, Bert graduated Boys High in Brooklyn and Brooklyn College, class of 1946. After college he joined the Brooklyn Eagle, rising from copy boy to Night City Editor. He worked in the public relations department at Lever Brothers from 1955 until retirement. Predeceased by sister Anita Rosenzweig. Bert was remarkably loyal, kind and disarmingly funny. He will be greatly missed by wife of 65 years, Estelle, son Steven, daughter Gail and grandchildren Emily and Jonathan Hochman, Jacob and Elena Levi. Services 11:15, Sunday, at "The Riverside" West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Bert's memory may be made to: The Michael J. Fox Foundation. 1/3

JAHARIS--Michael. The Little Orchestra Society mourns the passing of Michael Jaharis. Michael, his wife Mary, and their family have been generous benefactors over many years. We extend our condolences to Mary, Kathy, and the Jaharis family. The Board and staff of The Little Orchestra Society 1/3

COHEN--Eleanor F.,77, devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister and aunt passed away after a brave struggle with cancer. Ellie moved to New York from Denver, CO to attend Pratt and marry her first husband Dr. Gilbert Winn. (deceased 1997). She was a dedicated mother to her children Mitchell and Maxine Winn, Tracey and Robert Pruzan and doting grandmother to Amanda, Alison, Jason and Benjamin. A successful interior decorator for many years, she was also an avid golfer and a talented artist. In 2002 she married Donald Cohen and built a beautiful new life in East Hampton surrounded by friends where she enjoyed cooking, boating and her gardens. She is also lovingly remembered by Michael, Daphne, Rick and Linda, and by their children Daniel, Ethan, David and Allie. She will be dearly missed by her brothers Richard and Michael Fleischman of Denver, and by her large extended family there and in New York. Services will be on Sunday at noon at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, NY. 1/3

WEINRIB--Jerome The members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member Jerome Weinrib. Our sympathy is extended to his entire family. Paul Friedman, President Doug Simon, M.D., Secretary 1

KAUFMAN--Robert. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Robert Kaufman, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife, children, grandchildren, and other members of his family. Jeffrey B. Lane, President Warren J. Spector, Secretary 1/3

BRUE, Fred A. The Queens County Bar Association records with deep sorrow the passing of its distinguished former Executive Director on February 17, 2016 who served the Association with distinction during his tenure. Paul E. Kerson, President 1/3

LINSTROM--Christopher, M.D. of New York and Ho-Ho-Kus, New Jersey died suddenly on February 17th. He was 65 years old. He had been the Surgeon Director of Otology, Neurotology and Skull Base Surgery at The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, New York City. He was Professor of Otolaryngology at the New York Medical College, Valhalla, New York. He had been a visiting professor in Otolaryngology at The Medical University of Southern Africa (MEDUNSA), Pretoria, RSA. He is a Fellow of the American Board of Otolaryngology, of the Royal College of Surgeons (Canada), and of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. Christopher Linstrom was born in Washington, D.C., and raised in Maryland. He finished degrees in philosophy and music at the University of Maryland. His medical studies and internship were taken at McGill University, Montreal. While in medical school, he founded and was the president of the McGill Faculty of Medicine Refugee Fund to benefit the Boat People from Vietnam. Cherished partner of Swee Khing Hong, brother of Mary (David) Major, John (Karen) Linstrom, Katherine (Jeffrey Griffen) Linstrom, Nora (Stephen Burch) Linstrom, Joan (Kenneth Jones) Linstrom, Gerard (Allison Lentz) Linstrom, Elizabeth (Larry Burch) Linstrom, David (Stacy Humphrey) Linstrom and many nieces and nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday, February 21st from 3pm to 8pm. A second wake will be held on Thursday, February 25th at the Borgwardt Funeral Home, 4400 Powder Mill Road, Beltsville MD from 2pm to 4pm and from 7pm to 9pm. A mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday, February 26th, 10am at Saint Hugh Grenoble Catholic Church of Greenbelt MD followed by internment at Fort Lincoln Cemetery in Bladenburg, MD. In lieu of flowers his family has requested donations be made in Christopher's name to Franciscan Friars, Province of The Sacred Heart P.O.Box 137 Loretto, PA,15940 and/or McGill University Faculty of Medicine 1010 Sherbrooke WestSuite 1210 Montreal Canada H3A2R7 in the name of "The Linstrom Family Fund" to support the medical education of student(s) from low income families. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert, 89, of King's Point, Long Island passed away peacefully at his home on February 17, 2016. A renowned real estate owner/builder for 65 years, Robert is remembered by colleagues as "one of the giants of New York City real estate." He served as president of the William Kaufman Organization, one of the few remaining family-owned, multi-generational real estate firms in the city. His charitable works were highlighted by decades as a trustee and two terms as chairman of the board of North Shore Hospital, which he helped transform into a model health care system. Other endeavors included philanthropy for the arts, education, Israel, and wildlife conservation. He served in the United States Navy, is a graduate of New York University, and received an honorary doctorate from Hofstra University. Robert was the beloved husband of Florence Buck Kaufman for over 65 years. He was a devoted father to three accomplished daughters, Ronna, Cathy, and Julie, and was also the proud grandfather of Blaise, Alexander, Jonathan, Jacqueline, Shane, Derek, and Harlan. His two sons-in-law, Mark and Gordon, benefitted immeasurably from his wisdom and warmth. He fostered in those who knew him the importance of charity, an adventuresome spirit, and the value of family. His hobbies included travel, golf, tennis, fishing, theater, gin rummy, and breeding race horses. He touched the lives of many who will miss him greatly, including family, friends, colleagues, and employees. Services will be held on February 21, 2016 at 12pm at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that any donations be made to Northwell Hospital or the Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine. 1/3

MARKS--Donald, passed peacefully February 14, 2016. Donald was born in NYC on June 4, 1924. He was a WWII veteran and a proud recipient of the French Legion of Honor Medal. He was married for 63 years to his true love, Suzanne May, who predeceased him in 2013. Donald touched the lives of many during his years as an educator and as a camp head counselor. But his real passion was running, for which he credited his long life. He completed the NY Marathon at age 68 and continued to race until the age of 85. Donald is survived by his daughter Nina Rosen (Burt) and his granddaughters Ryan and Alexandra. Donations may be made to the WWII Memorial. 1/3

KRIEGLER--Grace L.,96, of Great Neck, NY passed away February 19, 2016 peacefully in her sleep at home. Beloved wife of the late Raymond M. Kriegler. Proud and devoted mother of Bonnie, Laurie, Benjamin and spouses Neil, Barry and Vonda. Amazing grandmother to Romy and Sadie. Grace loved her family and throughout her active life was a world traveler, volunteer with bilingual pre-k education, avid bridge and tennis player with so many at SRTC. A founder of JCBO Sisterhood and Chorus, and strong supporter of ORT, JTS and NWF. For the family and dear friends Grace leaves a legacy of love, caring, compassion, understanding and the ideal of individual strength to overcome personal adversity. Cared for in her last days by Betty. She will be greatly missed by all. Graveside services will take place on Sunday February 21, 2016 at 10:30am at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Family Shiva details- www.riversidenassaunorth chapels.com -516-487-9600 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert. The Harmonie Club notes with sorrow the passing of our honored member Robert Kaufman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Philip R. Cowen President The Harmonie Club 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert. Florence, Ronna, Cathy, Julie - how lucky you are to be loved by him. We will miss his sweetness and his smile. Always. Peggy Half Silbert & Nancy Half Carter and our family 1/3

LANDAU--David, beloved husband of Miriam and proud father of Dr. Mark (Linda) Landau and Laura (Andrew) Freedman and grandfather of four, passed away on Saturday, February 6, 2016 at age 90. David was a courageous Holocaust survivor and carried his remembrance with quiet dignity. He was born in 1925 in Kybartai, Lithuania. Confined for three years in the Kovna ghetto, then imprisoned with his father in Dachau, David was liberated by the United States Army and reunited with his father in a Displaced Person's camp. David received a mechanical engineering degree from Munich Institute of Technology. In 1950, after President Truman allowed DPs to enter the US, David sailed to America. He served in the US Army from 1951-53, then returned to school earning a Masters degree in engineering from Stevens Institute of Technology, in New Jersey. He pursued a successful career as a mechanical and consulting engineer. David was proud of Israel as a free nation in the same way that he valued his freedom as an American citizen. 1/3

HALE--William Foster, was 89 when he died January 19th. A member of the Cornell V-12 Naval Officer Training Program, Bill graduated with a BME in 1946. In 1948 he joined Sperry Rand's Gyroscope Division in Lake Success, NY and married his college sweetheart Patricia Reinfeld. In 1955 he built the Massapequa, NY house in which he lived until a week before he died. There he raised three children who survive him as do Patricia and two grandchildren. During his career he obtained a Master's in Industrial Engineering from Columbia & was a member of SOLE. He was active in the U.S. Naval Reserve until 1967 and retired from Sperry in 1986. An avid wood carver and maritime enthusiast, Bill loved golfing, sailing, model shipbuilding and traveling. Active in his community, he served the Boy Scouts, New York Blood Services and Grace Episcopal Church. His ashes will be buried in his plot behind Old Grace Church. 1/3

KARP--Bella. January 17, 1929, died February 12, 2016. Was the beloved wife of Stanley, mother of Michael and George, grandmother of Rebecca, Aaron, Jonathan, Sam and Jacob, great grandmother of Johnna and Ruby. Survived the Holocaust in the Lodz Ghetto and Auschwitz, then made a wonderful life for herself and her family in America. Received an MSW from NYU at age 51, then worked as a geriatric social worker until her retirement. She will be greatly missed by all those she touched. Please send donations to World ORT, ort.org, or the charity of your choice. 1/3

BRAMLET--Bryan Charles. Born in Manhattan, July 16, 1963 to Roland Charles Bramlet and Joann Atterberry Bramlet, passed February 7, 2016 in the Mustang region of Nepal of natural causes after a day of trekking with friends. This was one of many trips to the Himalayas Bryan loved. Bryan was also a huge fan of the NFL and the Denver Broncos specifically. He was looking forward to watching the big game on his return. Bryan attended Ithaca high school and was a graduate of the University of Colorado. He made a home in Kaohsiung, Taiwan for the last 20 years where he met the love of his life, Sherrie Huang Bramlet. They had two beautiful children together, Traverse (13) and Alanis (11). In Taiwan Bryan found a passion for teaching and established and taught in his English language school, The Cayuga Academy. Bryan had an adventurous, free spirited, warm nature, a sharp mind and a frequent large smile. He enjoyed life fully. Bryan will be greatly missed by his family, many friends, and many current and former students. We love you Bryan. Bryan is survived by his wife Sherrie, children Traverse, Alanis, father Roland Bramlet, sister Nancy Henry and family and brother Steven Bramlet and family. Memorial services will be conducted in Kaohsiung, Taiwan and at the Bramlet family cemetery, Wallowa, Oregon. 1/3

ERDELL--Paquita de Leon, EdD, RD (retired) of Manhattan passed away on February 23, 2015, in her 91st year. She completed her BS in Dietetics and Institutional Management, Pratt Institute, New York; MA, Professional Diploma in Nutrition and Public Health, and EdD at Teachers College, Columbia University, New York. She was a Registered Dietitian at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City and was one of the earliest renal dietitians. Of Guatemalan descent, Paquita partnered in 1996 to fund the First International Nutritionist/Dietitian (FIND) Fellowship for Study in the USA at the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics (formerly the American Dietetics Association) Foundation. FIND continues to be awarded annually to a foreign national for postgraduate work with the clearly articulated plan to bring knowledge and training back to their home country. A memorial service will be held February 28, 2016, the Church of Notre Dame, 5:30pm. 1/3

CONWAY--John T. (age 91), On February 12, 2016 in Arlington, Virginia. John was born on May 10, 1924, in The Bronx to John J. Conway, a New York City police officer and Hannah Stanley, an Irish immigrant. After graduating DeWitt Clinton High School, John enlisted in the U.S. Navy and, through the V-12 Navy College Training Program, earned a B.S. in Engineering and a B.S. in Naval Science from Tufts University. During World War II John served as a Naval officer on active duty in the North Atlantic. A 1949 graduate of Columbia Law School, John entered the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a Special Agent and became part of an elite counter espionage unit working in Washington, D.C. and New York City. In 1956 John joined the staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, where he rose to the position of Executive Director. In 1968 John was appointed Executive Assistant to the Chairman of the Board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, where he served as Chairman of Con Ed's Nuclear Facilities Safety Committee. In 1978 John became President and CEO of the American Nuclear Energy Council, then the chief government affairs organization for the nuclear industry. John returned to Consolidated Edison in 1982 as Executive Vice President. Upon his retirement from Con Ed in 1989, John was appointed by President George H. W. Bush to be the first Chairman of the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board with oversight for the safety of the government's nuclear facilities. He was reappointed to the NFSB by President William Clinton and served as Chairman until his retirement in 2005 at the age of 81. John is survived by his devoted and beloved wife of 27 years, Virginia (McLaughlin), sons John (Marsha Gransee), Daniel (Susan), Sean (Leon Rottner), Thomas (Elizabeth) and only daughter Johannah Dottori (Mario). John was also much loved by his grandchildren, Matthew, Michael, McKenzie, Gavin, Erin, Devin, Steven, Corinne and Lilah. John was preceded in death by his former wife, Priscilla Conway (Harris); two brothers, Stanley and Daniel; and his fifth son, a decorated combat veteran, Lt. Col. U.S. Army, Christopher D. Conway (Crystal Oliver). Service information: The funeral service will be held at 11am on February 26, 2016, at Arlington Forest United Methodist Church, 4701 Arlington Blvd., Arlington, VA 22203 with interment at a later date in Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to establish a scholarship in John's name may be made to Columbia Law School. Address to Columbia Law School, Jerome Greene Hall, 435 W. 116th St., Box A-2, New York, NY 10027, Attn. Amy Shuga. Checks should be made out to "Columbia Law School" noting in the memo line "in memory of John T. Conway '49." Online donations may be made at https://giving.columbia.edu/ giveonline/?schoolstyle=200 with the words "in memory of John T. Conway '49" in the comments/ notes section. 1/3

BOBROFF--Lewis M.,MD, 69, of Suffern, NY died peacefully at home on February 20, 2016. Born to the late Alexander and Sylvia Bobroff, raised in Brooklyn, NY, graduate of Brooklyn College and Harvard Medical School. A gifted diagnostic radiologist who embraced his profession wholeheartedly, serving as Director of Radiology and President of the Medical Staff were among the highlights of his distinguished 40 year career at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern. Beloved husband of 43 years to Sharyn (nee Fleiss), loving father to Stacy (Jeff) and Brad (Carrie), adored grandfather to Hallie, Josie, Jake and Dani. Devoted brother to Susan Silberzweig (David), brother-in-law to Gail and Raymond Watkins, much loved uncle. His kind heart, gentle, generous and loyal nature, unmatched intelligence and great sense of humor will be remembered by those who were lucky enough to have had their lives touched by him. Funeral services will be held Sunday, February 21, 2016, 1pm at Congregation Shaarey Israel, Montebello, NY. Shiva at the family residence. KAUFMAN--Robert. One of the finest gentleman you could ever want to be a friend of. Arlene and Steve Genatt 1/3

BARTLE--Barbara Bishop 88, February 9. Resident of Cambridge, MA, formerly of Lee and Lenox, MA, New York City and East Hampton, NY, Barbara Bishop Bartle died peacefully surrounded by her children and caregivers. Barbara was the wife of the late Stuart Hall Bartle, M.D., daughter of the late Kathleen Sinclair Bishop and Louis Faugeres Bishop, Jr., M.D., and sister of Anne Bishop Cannon of Vero Beach FL, the late Louis Faugeres Bishop III and Mary Bishop Millspaugh. In addition to her sister Anne, she is survived by her children Christopher Hall (Eva Gardner), Andrew Bishop (Mary Davidson), Elizabeth Dowling (David Boghossian), Marion Stuart (John Packs), 11 grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. She was educated at Miss Hewitt's School ('45), Radcliffe College (A.B.'49), and the University of Virginia (M.A., History '68). Barbara, a/k/a "Bish," "B'kins" and "Grandmere," brought her modesty, charm and an easy elegance, as well as her strong work ethic and high integrity to every part of her life. She was devoted to her husband, family, friends, colleagues and students, to whom she showed unstinting generosity, and a playful, keen, dry sense of humor.At Miss Hewitt's School, Barbara was President of the Student Council and a champion fencer. After graduating from Radcliffe, Barbara married Stuart and moved to Charlottesville, VA, where she raised four children, and earned her M.A. She became active in the civil rights movement, continuing a lifelong dedication to social issues beginning with her thesis on Reconstruction, her later work on the Harlem Renaissance, and her long-term volunteer efforts with the League of Women Voters. Returning to New York, NY in 1968, Barbara worked with radio host Casper Citron; graduated from Columbia University Teachers College; and taught history at the Chapin School for 14 years. In 1986, Barbara and Stuart moved to Zimbabwe where she taught history at the Roosevelt Girls High School in Harare. Upon returning to the U.S. in 1988 and relocating full-time to Lee, MA, Barbara taught history at Berkshire Community College in Great Barrington, lecturing on the history of the Underground Railroad and W.E.B. DuBois. A natural writer, in 2006 she published her memoir, A Vanished World: Growing up in the Thirties and Forties in New York and East Hampton. She was an active member of Trinity Episcopal Church in Lenox, Lenox Garden Club, Mahkeenac Boat Club, the Bluestockings, and the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Barbara was an elegant tennis player, dedicated gardener, raconteur, political activist, and later in life, a beloved grandmother. Memorial Service: 2:00pm Saturday, March 5, Trinity Episcopal Church, Lenox, MA. Contributions in her name: Lenox Library, http://lenoxlib.org/support-th e-library/giving/ or Trinity Church, 88 Walker Street, Lenox, 01240. Thoughts may be left at: http://www.forever missed.com/barbara-bishop-bartle 1/3

HSIA--Sven Erik. Holland Lodge No. 8 F&AM acknowledges with deep regret the death of our brother on February 13, 2016. Our sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. John R. Weber, Master James W. McGovern, Secretary 1/3

LINSTROM--Christopher, M.D. of New York and Ho-Ho-Kus, New Jersey died suddenly on February 17th. He was 65 years old. He had been the Surgeon Director of Otology, Neurotology and Skull Base Surgery at The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, New York City. He was Professor of Otolaryngology at the New York Medical College, Valhalla, New York. He had been a visiting professor in Otolaryngology at The Medical University of Southern Africa (MEDUNSA), Pretoria, RSA. He is a Fellow of the American Board of Otolaryngology, of the Royal College of Surgeons (Canada), and of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. Christopher Linstrom was born in Washington, D.C., and raised in Maryland. He finished degrees in philosophy and music at the University of Maryland. His medical studies and internship were taken at McGill University, Montreal. While in medical school, he founded and was the president of the McGill Faculty of Medicine Refugee Fund to benefit the Boat People from Vietnam. Cherished partner of Swee Khing Hong, brother of Mary (David) Major, John (Karen) Linstrom, Katherine (Jeffrey Griffen) Linstrom, Nora (Stephen Burch) Linstrom, Joan (Kenneth Jones) Linstrom, Gerard (Allison Lentz) Linstrom, Elizabeth (Larry Burch) Linstrom, David (Stacy Humphrey) Linstrom and many nieces and nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday, February 21st from 3pm to 8pm. A second wake will be held on Thursday, February 25th at the Borgwardt Funeral Home, 4400 Powder Mill Road, Beltsville MD from 2pm to 4pm and from 7pm to 9pm. A mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday, February 26th, 10am at Saint Hugh Grenoble Catholic Church of Greenbelt MD followed by internment at Fort Lincoln Cemetery in Bladenburg, MD. In lieu of flowers his family has requested donations be made in Christopher's name to Franciscan Friars, Province of The Sacred Heart P.O.Box 137 Loretto, PA,15940 and/or McGill University Faculty of Medicine 1010 Sherbrooke WestSuite 1210 Montreal Canada H3A2R7 in the name of "The Linstrom Family Fund" to support the medical education of student(s) from low income families. 1/3

GOLEMBIEWSKI--Robert T. (1932-2016). Distinguished Research Professor Emeritus at the School of International and Public Affairs at the University of Georgia, died January 1, 2016 in Athens, GA. A Trenton, NJ native, he was a pioneering scholar and management consultant who shaped corporations and government entities and authored some 75 books and 1,000 scholarly articles. Mourned by colleagues; wife Peggy; children Alice H.G. Phillips, Hope OBrian, Geoffrey; grandchildren Elizabeth, Eleanor; Hannah Griffin; Daniel, Faith OBrian; Matthew, Stephen Phillips. 1/3

COLE--Sheila Barbara, passed away on January 1, 2016. She grew up in Rye Neck, N.Y., attending Bellows High, Wells College, and later New York's Fashion Institute. Sheila was one of the visionary women in the fashion business, instrumental in changing the scope of women's roles and competing at the highest levels. In the 50's and 60's she handled all press and publicity for fashion company Mr. Mort. She was one of the pioneers in the industry for licensing European designers notably Nina Ricci. Ms. Cole conceived new concepts in thematic retail store design. Stores such as Metro done as a subway station and Airport designed like a Boeing 747 were harbingers of a new trend in fashion presentation. From fashion she moved onto publicity for the Public Theater in New York. Eventually Sheila easily moved onto interior design with a very reserved and tasteful talent. In Sonoma, CA she fell in love with the town and it's history, eventually becoming chair of the area's State Park Docents and chair of the League of Historic Preservation as well. Ms. Cole formed a committee to place a statue of Sonoma's founder General Mariano Vallejo in the town's historic plaza. Four sons, Ronald, Tristan, Michael, and James Israel, seven grandchildren, and two great grandchildren survive Sheila. A memorial service will take place at a later date to be announced in the springtime. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be sent to I.S.I. (Inquiring Systems, Inc.) with a notation in the memo line for General Vallejo at P.O. Box 2037, Sonoma, CA 95476. 1/3

STUCKY--Steven. The Directors of the Aaron Copland Fund for Music, Inc. acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our distinguished board member, Steven Stucky. PERLMAN--Claire Field, age 91, died Monday, February 15. Daughter of the late Helen and Sam Field, Claire was born in New York City and lived in Woodmere. She was married to the late Sidney Perlman. Claire is survived by her daughter, Toni Young, son John (Maxine) Perlman, and stepson, Jim Mindling, as well as five grandchildren, Mitchell Young (Katka), Ann Young Saban (Hanoch), Betsy Perlman, Sam Perlman, and Natasha Mindling. She had two great-grandsons, Giladi Shmuel Saban and another who will be named at his bris on February 17, 2016. Special thanks are given to her outstanding team of caregivers in her final years, Patricia Muir, Dawn Hutchinson, Gladys Barnes, Valerie DaCosta, and others. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Samuel Field YM-YWHA, or the charity of your choice. Funeral services handled by Riverside Chapel: 516-295-3100. 1/3

FALK--Dr. Charles. February 11, 2016, 92, was Associate Director, Brookhaven National Lab 1962-66; At the National Science Foundation as Planning Director 1966-70, and Director of the Division of National Science Resources Studies 1970-85. 1/3

CARROLL--Kevin F. , 74, passed away peacefully in his home on February 10, 2016, surrounded by his cherished family. Born in Manhattan on May 15, 1941 to the late Patrick and Nora Carroll, Kevin grew up in Staten Island, N.Y. He later lived in New Jersey, in Franklin Lakes, Montclair, then Cedar Grove, before taking up residency in Scottsdale, Ariz. Kevin had an illustrious career on Wall Street, and retired as CEO of Gintelco, Inc. A true leader and very community-minded, he served on the boards of the Montclair YMCA and Turning Point Addiction Treatment Center, and was a former President of the Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center. He was a longtime member of the Montclair Golf Club, in West Orange, N.J., and the Desert Mountain Club, in Scottsdale. He enjoyed all sports, played football and basketball throughout his school years, and was recruited to play professional football in Montreal. He later competed in tennis and paddle tournaments for the Indian Trail Club, in Franklin Lakes, and became a single- digit golfer. Kevin loved the outdoors, completing three Outward Bound trips, including climbing Mount Kilimanjaro in Africa. He was an avid reader with a love of the English language and was a true gentleman with great charm, intellect, integrity and a wonderful sense of humor. Kevin was unfailingly loyal to family and friends, and proud of his Irish heritage. Predeceased by his son, Kevin (K.J.) Carroll, he is survived by his loving family: wife, Bonnie Strauss Carroll; daughter, Melanie C. KAUFMAN--Robert, 89, of King's Point, Long Island passed away peacefully at his home on February 17, 2016. A renowned real estate owner/builder for 65 years, Robert is remembered by colleagues as "one of the giants of New York City real estate." He served as president of the William Kaufman Organization, one of the few remaining family-owned, multi-generational real estate firms in the city. His charitable works were highlighted by decades as a trustee and two terms as chairman of the board of North Shore Hospital, which he helped transform into a model health care system. Other endeavors included philanthropy for the arts, education, Israel, and wildlife conservation. He served in the United States Navy, is a graduate of New York University, and received an honorary doctorate from Hofstra University. Robert was the beloved husband of Florence Buck Kaufman for over 65 years. He was a devoted father to three accomplished daughters, Ronna, Cathy, and Julie, and was also the proud grandfather of Blaise, Alexander, Jonathan, Jacqueline, Shane, Derek, and Harlan. His two sons-in-law, Mark and Gordon, benefitted immeasurably from his wisdom and warmth. He fostered in those who knew him the importance of charity, an adventuresome spirit, and the value of family. His hobbies included travel, golf, tennis, fishing, theater, gin rummy, and breeding race horses. He touched the lives of many who will miss him greatly, including family, friends, colleagues, and employees. Services will be held on February 21, 2016 at 12pm at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that any donations be made to Northwell Hospital or the Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine. 1/3

KURZWEIL--Edith. 1924 - 2016, a Viennese-born scholar, who served as the final editor of Partisan Review, died February 6, four days after suffering a stroke. She was 91. Born into a family of privilege, her adolescence was marked by hardship that faced all Jews living in Austria after the Anschluss. As a twelve-year-old she witnessed the devastation of Kristallnacht first hand before undertaking a two-year odyssey through war-torn Europe. Separated from her parents, she was compelled to shepherd her younger brother John through Belgium, France, Spain and Portugal - often surviving for days at a time on little more than bread and bananas - before securing passage on the New York-bound S.S. Excalibur in 1940. Newly arrived in the United States, she worked as a milliner, tailor's apprentice, and diamond cutter by day, and attended high school at night. Her scholarly life - as an expert on, among other things, psychoanalysis and French Structuralism - only began after the untimely death of her second husband, Robert Kurzweil, in 1966. That was when she returned to school, eventually earning a Ph.D. in sociology from the New School for Social Research, where she would later serve on its Board of Governors. In 1973, she met, worked with, and eventually married, William Phillips, one of the two founding editors of Partisan Review. The National Endowment of the Humanities honored Kurzweil with its highest award, the National Humanities Medal, in 2003. Professor Kurzweil is survived by her three children Ronald Schmidt, Vivien Schmidt, and Allen Kurzweil, two stepsons, Peter and Leonard Kurzweil, her brother John Weiss, and a cherished grandson, Maximilian Kurzweil. 1/3

AUSTIN--Charles Lee, Jr.,much loved teacher at St. Bernard's School, New York City, died on February 15, 2016 of Alzheimer's Disease. He was 84 years old. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, son of Charles L. He gave finance a good try for a decade, in Boston, London and New York, but happily for hundreds of boys, landed for good on East 98th Street. For 40 years he taught Latin, English and history to Sixth and Seventh Graders while serving for a time as Head of the Middle School. Stuart Johnson III, Headmaster of St. Bernard's recognized in Lee Austin a teacher who went beyond bare academics to affect the entire life of a boy, in an unpredictable way and with a light touch. He was a wizard in the classroom, able to unlock in his twelve and thirteen year old boys things that they did not know they had in themselves. He is survived by Dee Austin, the caterer, his wife of 40 years; a brother, three children: William Robert "Trip" McGleughlin III, Peter McGleughlin, and Julie "Jade" McGleughlin, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Church (91st St. and Park Ave) on Saturday, the 12th of March at 11:30am. Donations in his memory may be made to St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98th Street, NYC 10128. 1/3

GAZARIAN--Jean Bernard. We mourn the sudden passing of Jean Gazarian on January 18, 2016, an international civil servant who, working under every Secretary-General of the United Nations, spent over six decades dedicated to world peace. A mentor to so many, a true humanitarian, a gentle and kind man, he was highly respected for his integrity and generosity, and inspired love and affection to all those who met him. As a former director at Drew University expressed: "When he talked, everyone listened." Jean Gazarian joined the United Nations in 1946, when he was 24. He served first as a translator, then as an editor and, in 1959, was called to work in the Executive Office of the Secretary-General to deal with General Assembly affairs. In 1966, he became Director of the Division of the General Assembly Affairs, a position he held for 18 years. A witness to many world events, he met kings and queens, and presidents, but always remained humble. Ambassador Ahmad Kamal, Senior Fellow at the United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR), told the UN News Centre: "He was absolutely unique as a person. His knowledge, his devotion to the UN and the manner in which he inspired love and affection among thousands of UN diplomats and staff members made him a prince among men." While working for the General Assembly, he traveled extensively as secretary and coordinator of conferences, held in Geneva, Oslo, Vienna, Paris, Rio de Janeiro, Managua, Jakarta, Guatemala, etc. He also assisted Secretary- General U Thant during his official visit in 1970 to eleven Francophone African countries, where he served as his interpreter. From 1983 to 1985, Jean was Principal Advisor to the Under-Secretary-General for General Assembly Affairs and to the President of the General Assembly. From 1985 to 1986, he was Director of the Office for the Commemoration of the Fortieth Anniversary of the United Nations. In 1986, he was Secretary of the High Level Intergovernmental Group of Experts regarding the administrative and financial functioning of the United Nations. In 1987, Jean Gazarian became a Senior Fellow of the United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR), where he taught for 25 years a large number of diplomats through training programs and seminars. He was one of the pioneers of Model UN, spoke to large assemblies of students from all over the world, and was an instrumental figure of the "UN Semester" co-organized by Drew University. Jean Gazarian was recognized by governments and universities for his outstanding contribution to the United Nations and world peace: Officier de l'Ordre de La Pleiade, Organisation internationale de la Francophonie (1977). Chevalier de l'Ordre de la Legion d'honneur, France (1984). Grand Officier de l'Ordre de Vasco Nunez de Balboa, Panama (1984). Doctor of Letters, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, Virginia (1986). Doctor of Laws, Bentley College, Waltham, Massachusetts (1996). Doctor en Administration de la Paix, Cercle de Reflexion des Nations (2004). Doctor of Humane Letters, Drew University, Madison, New Jersey (2007). On December 4, 2013, Ban Ki-moon, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, honored Jean Gazarian during the 50th anniversary of UNITAR. Jean Gazarian is survived by his brother, Pierre Gazarian, columnist for The Suffolk Times, and his sister, Marie- Lise Gazarian, Director of the Graduate Program in Spanish, St. John's University, and the Mirimanoff family, from Geneva, Switzerland. A Prayer Service, at the Church of the Holy Family, United Nations Parish, was held on Friday, January 29, where friends, colleagues and family paid tribute to Jean Gazarian. 1/3

KRONFELD--Harvey S.,Harvey S. Kronfeld, 86, attorney, of Haverford PA and Naples FL died on February 14, 2016 in Philadelphia. He was husband of 61 years of Janet (nee Lubowitz), father of Linda, Andrew and Julia Kronfeld, grandfather of Lily and Claudia Kronfeld and Natalie and Samantha Gay, brother of Adele Cohen and Gerald Kronfeld, and son of Samuel and Lena Kronfeld. He was a graduate of University of Delaware, class of 1949 and Harvard Law School, class of 1952. After beginning his career in Philadelphia at the law firm Wolf Block, he joined the office of general counsel at Ford Motor Company and then returned to private practice in Philadelphia with a specialty in antitrust and class action litigation. In 1987 a spinal cord injury brought him to Magee Rehabilitation Hospital. With Janet's help he resumed a full life, notwithstanding a pivot from tennis to golf. He served on the Magee Hospital Board of Trustees for over 20 years, on the Magee Foundation Board since it began in 1998, and chaired the Hospital's oversight committee. He was recognized in 2010 with the Magee Humanitarian Award for his dedication to helping others, the example he set, and support of individuals with disabilities. He was also on the Board of the American Jewish Committee where he led an initiative to improve Jewish representation in executive ranks of large corporations. Harvey and Janet were devoted to each other and respected their complementary strengths. They built a rich life together with a close group of friends that has been together consistently for over six decades. 1/3

de GUNZBURG--Mary. Mary McFall de Gunzburg, September 23, 1926 -- February 13, 2016. Baroness Mary de Gunzburg died surrounded by her three loving children in her home in Miami Beach. She was 89. Mary was born in Memphis, Tennessee to Otis A. and Lucy Ward McFall, where she was raised with her beloved sister Beverly. She attended the Lausanne Collegiate School and Southwestern College. As a child, Mary discovered and nurtured what would become her lifelong passion for art; she studied and excelled at ballet and spent countless hours drawing and reading. Mary pursued her love for the fine arts in New York. She studied at the Art Students League, where she took classes to develop her craft as an impressionist painter. Mary was a proud New Yorker and found a second home at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, of which she was a patron. She could often be found in the impressionist wing studying and copying masterpieces, working at her easel, color-rich oils bringing her canvases to life. She loved color, and it was this love that engendered in her an admiration and a fondness for the works of her favorite artists, Bonnard and Titian, from whom she drew much inspiration. She was happily married, for over forty years, to Baron Guy de Gunzburg. They shared passions for learning, world travel, reading, and collecting art and antiques. Together they lived in New York, Virginia, and South Florida and traveled extensively in Europe. Mary and Guy were generous benefactors of Baptist Health South Florida in Miami, making possible the creation of the Center for Excellence in Nursing. They also gave generously to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota. Mary was ever elegant, ever beautiful - whether dressed up in evening gown, or down in a Seurat-spattered smock. And her youthful energy and playful humor never faded. She danced until the final curtain - quite literally. Even in the last year, in bed, she would often kick up a leg to showcase the flexibility she had maintained from her ballet-days! Mary is survived by her three children from her first marriage to William E. Buxton: Robert Malcolm Buxton, Lucy Buxton Geppert, and Mary Martin Buxton; her stepchildren, Baron Jean-Louis de Gunzburg, Madame Eliane de Gunzburg Beckman, and Baron Gerard de Gunzburg; and her grandchildren, Jesse, Hannah, Nicky, Henry, and Will. In addition to her sister Beverly, Mary had four lifelong friends who were always there for her and with whom she shared many cherished memories: Imogene Erb, Nancy McFadden Copp, Emily Haizlip, and Lucy Barboro Fisher. Mary would want to express her thanks and gratitude to Alexy Turcios and Thelma Scott for all their years of hard work, for their friendship, and their devotion. Mary was preceded in death by her parents, her sisters Cynthia and Beverly, and her husband Guy. A memorial service and reception will be held on February 27, 2016 at 1:00pm at the Lord's Chapel of Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis, Tennessee. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Museum or Art or the McGovern Institute for Brain Research. Planned Giving, Development Office, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10028-0198, 212.570.3796. The McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT, Attention: Kara Flyg, 43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA 02139, 617.324.0134. 1/3

PFIZER--Beryl Ann. Writer and radio and television producer, died February 12, 2016, of natural causes in her beloved Manhattan brownstone. She was 87, born in 1928, in Morristown NJ. She was predeceased by her father, William R. Pfizer, Vice President of The Panama Line, and her mother, Isabel Morin Pfizer. Beryl grew up in Mt. Lakes, NJ, graduating from Mt. Lakes High School in 1945 and from Hood College in 1949, with a BA in music. She always wanted to live in the city, and moved to Manhattan after college to begin a long and varied career in the radio and television industries. She worked for the Arthur Godfrey Show on CBS-TV, wrote for NBC TV's The Home Show and worked with Dave Garroway on NBC TV's The Today Show, where she was a "Today Girl" feature panelist (1960-61). She received three Emmy Award nominations (1980-82), and won an Emmy in 1980, for producing "Ask NBC News, with John Chancellor." She wrote for NBC TV's broadcasts of The Macy's Thanksgiving Parade (1987-89), for NBC's MONITOR Radio, and for Edwin Newman; imagine the challenge of writing for the author of "Strictly Speaking!" She worked for NBC News at many Democratic National Conventions, including 1968 in Chicago. She produced "The Women's Program" series for the NBC Radio Network, which received a commendation from American Women in Radio and Television in 1979. Beryl also wrote and produced NBC-TV's "The All- New Pink Panther Show" (1971-74), which featured those famous cartoons and live-action segments with The Ritts Puppets and comedian Lenny Schultz reading letters and jokes from viewers. She produced medical and health stories for the NBC flagship TV station in New York City. She was the author of "Poor Woman's Almanac", humorous and pithy quips published in Ladies Home Journal. She received the Distinguished Alumni Award from Hood College, where she sponsored scholarships in writing and theater arts. Beryl was also an avid athlete and enjoyed playing tennis. She took up running and unexpectedly won prizes in the upper age groups of Jersey Shore 5 K's for many years, which tickled her to no end. She was proud to have completed a New York City marathon, and she loved the Midnight Run on New Year's Eve in Central Park, running her last race just last month. Beryl was generous, quietly helping many people. Terence Cardinal Cooke Healthcare Center awarded her the Mary P. Clark award for exceptional care and volunteer work for the Huntington's Disease unit of the hospital. OXLEY--J. Leonard. Pianist, conductor, arrangerrchestrator. Age 87, of Teaneck, formerly of Harrisburg, PA passed away on Friday, February 19, 2016. Beloved husband of Nancy A. Oxley (nee Adams). Devoted father of Jill and her husband Ian. Loving grandfather of Anna. Dear brother of Eric Oxley. Dear brother-in-law to David and Ronald Adams. Predeceased by his sister Laura Lewis. Mr. Oxley had a career in Musical Theatre that spanned nearly 70 years. An extraordinary artist, he trained at Juilliard. Early in his career he was the Music Director at Harrisburg Community Theater, where he met his wife. He was a protege of esteemed Broadway composer Luther Henderson. Mr. Oxley was the Music Director of the New Jersey Tap Ensemble for the past 20 years. He accompanied and worked with some of theater's most celebrated artists, including Gregory Hines, Andre De Shields, Savion Glover, Phylicia Rashad, Nell Carter, Polly Bergen, Carol Channing, Mary Martin and Robert Preston. His numerous credits include Broadway, Off-Broadway, National and International tours of Ain't Misbehavin', Sophisticated Ladies, Black and Blue, Jelly's Last Jam, Big Deal, Andre Heller's Wonderhouse, Play On! and Hello Dolly. Family and friends are invited for a memorial visitation at the Volk Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck on Wednesday from 1-3pm. Service will commence at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 1 W. 53rd St, New York, NY 10019, stthomaschurch.org. To view J. Leonard's tribute page, please visit volkleber.com 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert, 89, of King's Point, Long Island passed away peacefully at his home on February 17, 2016. A renowned real estate owner/builder for 65 years, Robert is remembered by colleagues as "one of the giants of New York City real estate." He served as president of the William Kaufman Organization, one of the few remaining family-owned, multi-generational real estate firms in the city. His charitable works were highlighted by decades as a trustee and two terms as chairman of the board of North Shore Hospital, which he helped transform into a model health care system. Other endeavors included philanthropy for the arts, education, Israel, and wildlife conservation. He served in the United States Navy, is a graduate of New York University, and received an honorary doctorate from Hofstra University. Robert was the beloved husband of Florence Buck Kaufman for over 65 years. He was a devoted father to three accomplished daughters, Ronna, Cathy, and Julie, and was also the proud grandfather of Blaise, Alexander, Jonathan, Jacqueline, Shane, Derek, and Harlan. His two sons-in-law, Mark and Gordon, benefitted immeasurably from his wisdom and warmth. He fostered in those who knew him the importance of charity, an adventuresome spirit, and the value of family. His hobbies included travel, golf, tennis, fishing, theater, gin rummy, and breeding race horses. He touched the lives of many who will miss him greatly, including family, friends, colleagues, and employees. Services will be held on February 21, 2016 at 12pm at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that any donations be made to Northwell Hospital or the Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine. 1/3

GAZARIAN--Jean Bernard. We mourn the sudden passing of Jean Gazarian on January 18, 2016, an international civil servant who, working under every Secretary-General of the United Nations, spent over six decades dedicated to world peace. A mentor to so many, a true humanitarian, a gentle and kind man, he was highly respected for his integrity and generosity, and inspired love and affection to all those who met him. As a former director at Drew University expressed: "When he talked, everyone listened." Jean Gazarian joined the United Nations in 1946, when he was 24. He served first as a translator, then as an editor and, in 1959, was called to work in the Executive Office of the Secretary-General to deal with General Assembly affairs. In 1966, he became Director of the Division of the General Assembly Affairs, a position he held for 18 years. A witness to many world events, he met kings and queens, and presidents, but always remained humble. Ambassador Ahmad Kamal, Senior Fellow at the United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR), told the UN News Centre: "He was absolutely unique as a person. His knowledge, his devotion to the UN and the manner in which he inspired love and affection among thousands of UN diplomats and staff members made him a prince among men." While working for the General Assembly, he traveled extensively as secretary and coordinator of conferences, held in Geneva, Oslo, Vienna, Paris, Rio de Janeiro, Managua, Jakarta, Guatemala, etc. He also assisted Secretary- General U Thant during his official visit in 1970 to eleven Francophone African countries, where he served as his interpreter. From 1983 to 1985, Jean was Principal Advisor to the Under-Secretary-General for General Assembly Affairs and to the President of the General Assembly. From 1985 to 1986, he was Director of the Office for the Commemoration of the Fortieth Anniversary of the United Nations. In 1986, he was Secretary of the High Level Intergovernmental Group of Experts regarding the administrative and financial functioning of the United Nations. In 1987, Jean Gazarian became a Senior Fellow of the United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR), where he taught for 25 years a large number of diplomats through training programs and seminars. He was one of the pioneers of Model UN, spoke to large assemblies of students from all over the world, and was an instrumental figure of the "UN Semester" co-organized by Drew University. Jean Gazarian was recognized by governments and universities for his outstanding contribution to the United Nations and world peace: Officier de l'Ordre de La Pleiade, Organisation internationale de la Francophonie (1977). Chevalier de l'Ordre de la Legion d'honneur, France (1984). Grand Officier de l'Ordre de Vasco Nunez de Balboa, Panama (1984). Doctor of Letters, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, Virginia (1986). Doctor of Laws, Bentley College, Waltham, Massachusetts (1996). Doctor en Administration de la Paix, Cercle de Reflexion des Nations (2004). Doctor of Humane Letters, Drew University, Madison, New Jersey (2007). On December 4, 2013, Ban Ki-moon, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, honored Jean Gazarian during the 50th anniversary of UNITAR. Jean Gazarian is survived by his brother, Pierre Gazarian, columnist for The Suffolk Times, and his sister, Marie- Lise Gazarian, Director of the Graduate Program in Spanish, St. John's University, and the Mirimanoff family, from Geneva, Switzerland. A Prayer Service, at the Church of the Holy Family, United Nations Parish, was held on Friday, January 29, where friends, colleagues and family paid tribute to Jean Gazarian. 1/3

KARP--Bella. January 17, 1929, died February 12, 2016. Was the beloved wife of Stanley, mother of Michael and George, grandmother of Rebecca, Aaron, Jonathan, Sam and Jacob, great grandmother of Johnna and Ruby. Survived the Holocaust in the Lodz Ghetto and Auschwitz, then made a wonderful life for herself and her family in America. Received an MSW from NYU at age 51, then worked as a geriatric social worker until her retirement. She will be greatly missed by all those she touched. Please send donations to World ORT, ort.org, or the charity of your choice. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Robert Kaufman. The Kaufmans supported many of our finest productions, and Bob always approached each show with an open heart and an open mind. He was funny, warm, and caring, and a great favorite of the LCT staff. We extend our condolences to his -- and our -- beloved Florence and his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

LUCAS--Thomas Parker, born on May 31, 1934, grew up in Manhattan before moving to Queens to raise a family. Tom served in the National Guard from 1952-1966 and attained the rank of Captain with 1,000 hours of flying time. Tom believed in the value of education and made a career as a biology teacher at Forest Hills High School. Tom joined Church on the Hill in 1964 where he became a dedicated member to the church and its congregation. Tom was a loving and generous family man. He leaves his wife of 58 years, Helen; three daughters, Linda, Nancy and Susan; and family. He died peacefully at his home on January 19, 2016. 1/3

MYLES--Martin B.,M.D., 89, of Monroe, NY, formerly of New York, NY, died February 20, 2016 at Good Samaritan Hospital, Suffern. He was born on February 23, 1926 to Saul L. and Pearl Peshkin Meylackson. Predeceased by his beloved wife Jeanne Epstein, M.D., a brother, Edward Myles, and dear Epstein family in-laws; survived by his daughter Anne of Waterloo, IA, and loving nieces and nephews. A graduate of Cornell University and SUNY Downstate College of Medicine, he was medical director of the Robert Yeager Health Center in Pomona, NY, and earlier was medical director of French Hospital as well as a physician at NYU and in private practice. The world's most devoted husband, father, and Giants fan, he loved the practice of medicine, fishing, nature, and photography --but most of all took pleasure in caring for, talking to, and helping out his family and friends. ISAACSON--Leonard A, 88, passed away after a brief illness on February 21, 2016. Devoted husband to the late Katy, beloved father of Deborah and Jim, Joel and Alissa, Laurence and Alex, loving son to the late Jack and Lillian, caring brother to the late Rhoda; cherished grandfather and loving friend to so many. He was a distinguished lawyer, a competitive sportsman and a loving person. He also continued and enhanced the family tradition of devotion to AHRC NYC. Services will be held on Wednesday, February 24 at 10:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to AHRC NYC Foundation, 83 Maiden Lane, NY, NY 10038. 1/3

ADES--Robert J. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Robert J. Ades, cherished son of revered YU Trustee Joseph (and Rachel) Ades, of blessed memory, Yeshiva University Benefactors, and the beloved husband of Esther Kassin Ades, a former member of the Board of Directors of the Yeshiva University High Schools and the admired brother of Albert J. Ades, a member of the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers and a co-trustee of the Ades Foundation Inc. with Robert J. Ades, which provides annual support for the Joseph and Rachel Ades Sephardic Outreach Program, the Joseph and Rachel Ades Chair in Health Sciences, and Scholarship aid for deserving and needy students, and brother of their lovely sister, Renee (and Stephen) Levy, scholarship donors for deserving and needy Sephardic students in our undergraduate schools. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Esther Ades, Albert (and Sylvia) Ades, Renee (and Stephen) Levy, her children, Dr. Joseph (and Deborah), Michael (and Lisa), David (and Elana) and Billy (and Aileen), and her 10 grandchildren, and to all of her family's nieces and nephews and their progeny. These are difficult times for Esther Ades, whose revered mother, Selma Kassin, Z"I, passed away in January. May the Almighty grant His healing solace to all the bereaved members of this significant and appreciated Yeshiva University family and to all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Min hashamayim tenuhamu! Richard M. Joel, President, Yeshiva University Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3
BARSH--Susan, 86, on February 21, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Jack Barsh, DDS. Graveside service, today, 11:30am, Kensico Cemetery. 1/3

ISAACSON--Leonard A. The partners and staff of Joel Isaacson & Co. are deeply saddened by the passing of Lenny, our founder's dad. We were lucky to have known him and experienced his charm and wit. Our heartfelt condolences and sympathy to his children Deborah, Joel, Larry, their spouses and his beautiful grandchildren. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Robert. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Robert Kaufman. He (always with his glamorous wife Florence, a longtime and devoted member of our Patron Committee) was a great champion of ours, and an ardent theater lover. The Kaufmans supported many of our finest productions, and Bob always approached each show with an open heart and an open mind. He was funny, warm, and caring, and a great favorite of the LCT staff. We extend our condolences to his -- and our -- beloved Florence and his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

NAHMIAS--Jack. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Jack Nahmias, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jack's beloved daughters, Eileen Bloom (Jay) and Shari Leff; his grandchildren, Jordan, Jennifer, Justin, and Julie; and the entire family. Alisa R. KARP--Bella. January 17, 1929, died February 12, 2016. Was the beloved wife of Stanley, mother of Michael and George, grandmother of Rebecca, Aaron, Jonathan, Sam and Jacob, great grandmother of Johnna and Ruby. Survived the Holocaust in the Lodz Ghetto and Auschwitz, then made a wonderful life for herself and her family in America. Received an MSW from NYU at age 51, then worked as a geriatric social worker until her retirement. She will be greatly missed by all those she touched. Please send donations to World ORT, ort.org, or the charity of your choice. 1/3

SULZBERGER--Jean, Author and Editor, 94, died peacefully on Saturday at her apartment in Manhattan. She lived a full and varied life as a journalist, author and editor. Her book "Search: Journey on the Inner Path" published in 1979, reflected her lifelong interest in spirituality, mysticism and world religions. For many years Jean worked at Time, Inc., including stints as the magazine's religion correspondent and editor. She was active in the Gurdjieff Foundation in New York and was involved with the magazine Parabola for decades. Jean Sulzberger was the oldest child of David H. and Louise B. Sulzberger. She was born in 1922 in New York and lived in Manhattan all her life. She traveled extensively around the world including annual solo trips to Jerusalem until she was in her late 80s. Jean is survived by her sister Ann S. Sand, by seven nieces and nephews, fifteen great-nieces and great-nephews and two great-great nieces. Her sister Ellen S. Straus died in 1995. Services will be private. A memorial will be held on Saturday, February 27th. Memorial gifts may be made to Parabola, 20 West 20th Street, New York, NY 10011. 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald Guy. 67 years, of Aspen, CO and New York City, passed away peacefully on February 22, 2016, surrounded by his loved ones, following a brain injury sustained in Aspen during Presidents' Weekend. Don spent his last day doing one of the things he loved best; skiing in Aspen, where he and his partner Sue Hostetler had lived for the past two years. Don was born on March 1, 1948, and was raised in Queens, NY, and later received a B.A. from Brandeis University in 1968, followed by a J.D. from Columbia University School of Law. Don was founder and Chairman of Casablanca Capital. Most recently, he was Vice Chairman of Lazard International and Chairman of Lazard's Investment Committee and Chairman and CEO of Sapphire Industrials, an $800 million Lazard sponsored SPAC. Prior to joining Lazard in 2007, Don was Vice Chairman and Director of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc. and held similar positions with various affiliates from 1987 to 2007. From 1977 to 1987, he was a partner in the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP. He began his career as an attorney with the firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore from 1971 to 1977 and was a member of the American Bar Association and the New York City Bar Association. Over the course of his 40 year career, Don had been an advisor and a principal in significant securities transactions and business combinations. He was a frequent guest on CNBC, and a panelist at other financial events. Until his death, Don served on the Board of Directors of Tanger Factory Outlet Centers and had previously served on the boards of several other public companies, including: Anthracite Capital Inc., Marvel Holdings Inc., The Molson Companies Limited, Nephros Inc., Playboy Enterprises, Revlon Inc. and SIGA Technologies, among others. Don was also a generous philanthropist, serving on the following boards: New York Special Olympics Annual Metro Tournaments, for which he served as Co-Chairman; Law Enforcement Foundation, Inc.; Jewish Community Center; Brandeis University (Emeritas Member after having served for the twenty-five years); American Lawyer Media, Inc.; the Board of Overseers to the Lemberg Program of Brandeis University; as a Member of Development, Program and Nominating Committees of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars; and, Hope and Heroes Children's Cancer Fund Advisory Board. At the time of his death, he served on the Board of Directors of Lincoln Center Theater, the Aspen Music Festival and School, Theater Aspen, the Federal Enforcement Homeland Security Foundation, Inc.; was a member of the Dean's Council of Columbia Law School; and served as a National Council member of the Anderson Ranch in Aspen/ Snowmass, CO. A huge lover of life, with a twinkle in his eye, and a wry smile that could light up any room, Don was much loved by many. Don was a rare individual who had scores of friends going back four and five decades. Don loved to ski and cycle and was a lifelong theater lover. Don and Sue also enjoyed collecting art together, regularly visiting galleries and art fairs around the world. In addition to Sue, Don is survived by his wife Bernice from whom he had been separated; his son Matthew Drapkin and his wife Annie Drapkin; his daughter Dana Drapkin Baumgarten and her husband Joshua Baumgarten; his daughter Nicole Drapkin Schaffer and her husband Marc Schaffer; his son David Drapkin; and his daughter Amanda Drapkin; adoring grandchildren William, Annabel, Charles and Elizabeth Drapkin; and Lilly, Emma and Georgia Baumgarten; and Sue's daughter Spencer Diamond. Don was preceded in death by his cherished son Dustin; and his parents George and Mildred (Kaufman) Drapkin. Details of the funeral service to be held in New Jersey later this week, and next week in Aspen will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Aspen Music Festival and School (Kat Berg kberg@aspenmusic.org 970-205-5061) or Lincoln Center Theater (Hattie Jutagir jutagir@lct.org 212-501-3250). 1/3
HYMAN--Andrew David, You will always be on our minds and in our hearts. Mom & Dad, Josh & Jon, Susan & Liz, Lily &Than 1/3

FREEDMAN--Norman S. Norman S. Freedman of Larchmont, NY and Saxtons River, VT, died on February 22, 2016 at age 78. His advertising career highlights include the famed hidden case campaign for Canadian Club and the cult classic Schoolhouse Rock. Born May 26, 1937 and raised in Borough Park, Brooklyn, Norman was a graduate of NYU where he served on the Stern School Board of Overseers from 1999 to 2008. He is survived by his wife, Margot, his son and daughter-in-law Douglas and Lauri Freedman, his daughter and son-in- law Amy and Evan Lieberman and his five grandchildren Jack, Lucy, and Henry Freedman and Gideon and Jonah Lieberman. A memorial service will take place at Larchmont Temple at 11am on Friday, February 26th. The family will be receiving guests at their home following the service. The service can be viewed online by visiting: http://larchmonttemple.org/Praying/ Live--at--LT. For those wishing, the family requests a donation to any of the following organizations: The New Jewish Home: http://jewishhome.org/ Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure: http://abc2.org Cancer Research Institute: http://www.cancerresearch.org/memorial 1/3

She was the rock for all of us and will be missed. 1/3

SNYDER--Stanford I. "Stan" died of natural causes on February 19, 2016. Survived by wife Bridget Snyder, brother David Snyder, former wife Jerry Steen, daughter Julie Pildner, son Kyle Snyder, and three grandchildren. Predeceased by sister Sue Johnson. Stan's career began in 1964 at Columbia Records leading to VP of Marketing and VP of Sales. He co-founded Cleveland International Records in 1977 releasing Meat Loaf's "Bat Out of Hell." Born in 1938 in Chicago, IL, Stan was raised in Riverside, CT, attending Riverside Elementary and Brunswick schools. Stan proudly served in the United States Marine Corps from 1958 to 1959. He graduated Yale University in 1962 and attended Columbia Business School. He played jazz piano in bands throughout his life. Stan was a natural storyteller who enjoyed lifelong friendships. He was inseparable from his best friend and wife, Bridget, since they met in 1989. Service on March 2, 2016, 1pm at the Riverside Yacht Club, Riverside, CT. Donations to the Wounded Warrior Project. 1/3
