SONNENFELD--Nathan J. "Sonny." 96, hailed as a legendary lighting industry salesman, educator, mentor, consultant and writer, died peacefully at home on February 10, 2016. Born in New York he began his career as technical director at the 92nd Street YMCA. In 1940 he was drafted and earned a Silver Star for his United States Army service in the Pacific. After the War he returned to New York to begin work at Century Lighting, later becoming a founding partner of Lighting & Electronics and selling dimming equipment for various companies until he joined Electronic Theatre Controls as a consultant. He was President of the New York section of Illuminating Engineering Society, a founding member of USITT and received its 2016 Distinguished Achievement Award. He founded Broadway Lighting Master Classes and Stage Lighting Super Saturday. He is survived by a brother Irving, a sister Naomi Hirsch, his partner Jennifer Tipton, a son Barry, a daughter-in-law Susan, and a granddaughter Chloe. 1/3

ISAACSON--Leonard. So devastating the loss of Len to his family and circle of friends. For me I am forever grateful for the loving companionship and shared six years. Rest in peace. Susan Greenfield 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Andrew S. Beloved husband of MaryAnn, loving brother of Jerry, passed away at age 75 on February 20th after cardiac arrest. Andy loved life, people, classical music, and most of all he loved MaryAnn. May he rest in peace. 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime Board Member, Donald Drapkin. He had recently been designated an LCT Honorary Trustee, and he was very proud to have been admitted into such distinguished company. We send sympathy and love to Sue and his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

UNDERHILL--Jacob Berry, III, retired president and director of the New York Life Insurance Company, a former journalist and New York State government official, died February 20, 2016 in New York after complications from esophageal cancer. He was 89. Born in New York City on October 25, 1926, the son of J. Berry Underhill, Jr. and Dorothy Quinn Underhill, he grew up in Greenwich, CT where he attended the Brunswick School. On graduation from the Phillips Exeter Academy in 1944, he enlisted at 17 in the United States Navy from which he was discharged as an electronics technician's mate, third class, following World War II. He attended Princeton University, graduating in 1950 with a degree in English and American Civilization. Underhill became editor of the Potsdam (New York) Courier and Freeman and later was legislative correspondent and political writer for the Rochester (New York) Democrat and Chronicle and the Gannett News Service Albany Bureau. He became chief editorial writer of the St. Petersburg Times (Florida) in 1956, and returned to New York City in 1959 as a magazine editor for the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company and later as a national affairs writer for Newsweek. In 1964, he joined the staff of Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller as an assistant press secretary. He was deputy superintendent and later first deputy superintendent of insurance for the State of New York, 1968-1972. Underhill joined New York Life in 1972, rising to president and director of the mutual life insurance company before retirement in 1986. At his death he maintained residences in Cocoa, FL and Antigua, West Indies. He was married four times, first to the late Cynthia Lovejoy Underhill, a teacher and newspaper editor, from whom he was divorced. He is survived by their three children, David L. Underhill of Portsmouth, NH, Kate Underhill Kerwin of Naples, FL and Benedict Q. Underhill of Brattleboro, VT, and six grandchildren, Graeme Underhill of Raymond, NH, Meaghan Kerwin of Sugar Grove, NC, Sean Kerwin of Culver City, CA, Jeff John of Brighton, MA, Meghan John of Keene, NH and Chris John of Brattleboro, VT. His second marriage, also terminated by divorce, was to Lois Beachy Underhill, an advertising executive and writer. His third wife was Betsy Finley Ashton, a television producer and reporter; they were divorced in 2007, and Underhill married Nancy McDonnell Maloney of Rockledge, FL, on June 5, 2007. Nancy Maloney was a practicing lawyer for 25 years. Elected in November of 2014, she now serves as Circuit Judge for the 18th Judicial Circuit in the State of Florida. A brother, Martin Quinn Underhill, predeceased him. Underhill was an emeritus trustee of the National Trust for Historic Preservation; honorary chairman of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital; former chairman of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York; former chairman of the Life Insurance Council of New York; former trustee of the Retirement System of the American Red Cross; former director of the Health Insurance Association of America; United Way of Tri-State, and United Way of New York City. He was a member of The Players and The Links clubs of New York City, the Mill Reef Club of Antigua, West Indies, and the Legislative Correspondents Alumni Association of New York State. A memorial service will be arranged at a later date, with private burial. The family asks that memorial contributions may be made to the E.S. Wells Kerr 1944 Scholarship Fund, at Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH 03833. 1/3

SEGUIE--Dr. Munir Nader, died peacefully of natural causes on Tuesday, February 23, 2016 at his home in Elmhurst, Queens. He was born in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic on January 13, 1935. Dr. Nader was married to Barbara Nader DeMagistris, resident of Queens, who died last year after 52 years of marriage. He was the son of Laila Seguie from Beino, Lebanon and Abraham Nader from Tripoli, Lebanon and brother to Odette, Arnold, David, Ricardo and Samir. Dr. Nader graduated from school of Medicine from the Universidad of Santo Domingo on June 19, 1959, and specialized in Psychiatry in New York, working in the Knickerbocker Hospital among others. He practiced in Queens for more than 30 years. He lives behind no children or wife but had many friends that loved him dearly and nieces and nephews that will miss him very much. He was 81 years old. May God rest his soul. A memorial service will be held in his honor on Friday, February 26 at 10:30am at St. Joan of Arc, located at 3527 82nd Street, Jackson Heights, NY 11372. 1/3

ROSENFELD--Leonard, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our devoted longtime member, Leonard Rosenfeld. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life and shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. 1/3

CANTER--Phyllis L.,mother of Mindy, Robin, Richard and Nelson Canter, mother-in-law of Meredith, Nancy, and Lynn Canter, grandmother of Andrew and Amy Blower, Matt Konowe, Alexander, Kyle, Kevin and Amanda Canter, and great-grandmother of Lana Blower, passed away on February 23rd at the age of 88, in Rye Brook, NY after a long battle with cancer. Phyllis Canter was a Past President of the International Association for Psychiatric Research, Chairman of the Board of the Ranachqua Foundation, which was started by her late husband Arnold Canter, and a former Board Member of the Silliman Fund and Purchase Community Chest. Phyllis enjoyed swimming and snorkeling on coral reefs, was an "A" tennis player at Armonk Tennis Club for decades, a proud supporter of the Performing Arts Center at SUNY Purchase, a volunteer at the Greenwich Hospital Thrift Shop and for many years, a docent at the Bronx Zoo. Phyllis travelled to over 100 countries, enjoyed taking large groups to countries near and far as well as short trips to concerts and museums. Phyllis enjoyed bridge and lunch with her many friends, and most of all, enjoyed time with her loving family. Her gregarious optimistic warmth would always light up a room and her "can do" attitude inspired many others to achieve new heights in their own lives. The funeral will be held on Friday, February 26 at 9:15am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY. The family will sit shiva at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester on Friday from 2:00pm - 7:30pm. Donations in Phyllis's honor may be made to Ranachqua Foundation, Inc., Canter Family Memorial Fund, 1732 Astor Avenue, Bronx, NY 10469. May her memory be a blessing. 1/3

GREENHILL--Ira J.,94, attorney, died on February 21, 2016, in New York City. Son of Joseph and Sarah (nee Hoffman) Greenhill, Ira was born and raised in New York City, where he attended Ethical Culture School, before decamping to Swarthmore College, from which he graduated in 1942 magna cum laude. Following graduation, Ira joined the US Army and served proudly during World War II, the Korean conflict and later in the Reserves, before retiring as a major. After World War II ended, he attended Columbia Law School on the GI Bill and then entered private practice in the profession that he loved in New York City for nearly six decades, first with his father and later for a time with two of his sons, as well as partners and colleagues. When not practicing law, Ira relished time spent as a highly accomplished woodworker and cabinetmaker, recreational tennis player, "pretend" golfer (as he put it) and scotch aficionado, dividing time between Rye, NY and Port St. Lucie, FL. Ira is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Elaine D. Greenhill (nee Maltzman), as well as his sons and daughters-in-law, Jonathan S. Greenhill, Zachary R. and Judy L. Greenhill, and Lincoln J. and Kelly M. Greenhill, and four grandchildren, Caitlin, Alexander, Hunter and Gavin. He was predeceased by his sister, Phyllis Meyerson. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Columbia Law School and Swarthmore College. 1/3

ROSENFELD--Leonard, at the age of 97, died peacefully surrounded by family and friends Sunday, February 21, 2016. Beloved husband of the late Sally, devoted brother of the late Morton, loving uncle of Regina and MayLisa and their husbands Derek and John, cherished great-uncle of Casey, her loving husband Jeremy, Kylie, Gabrielle and Rachel, proud great-granduncle of Gavin and Spencer and honorary uncle to Michael. The family will hold private services. In lieu of flowers, donations to Temple Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, New York, NY 10065, would be appreciated. 1/3

FREEDMAN--Norman S. Norman S. Freedman of Larchmont, NY and Saxtons River, VT, died on February 22, 2016 at age 78. His advertising career highlights include the famed hidden case campaign for Canadian Club and the cult classic Schoolhouse Rock. Born May 26, 1937 and raised in Borough Park, Brooklyn, Norman was a graduate of NYU where he served on the Stern School Board of Overseers from 1999 to 2008. He is survived by his wife, Margot, his son and daughter-in-law Douglas and Lauri Freedman, his daughter and son-in- law Amy and Evan Lieberman and his five grandchildren Jack, Lucy, and Henry Freedman and Gideon and Jonah Lieberman. A memorial service will take place at Larchmont Temple at 11am on Friday, February 26th. The family will be receiving guests at their home following the service. The service can be viewed online by visiting: http://larchmonttemple.org/Praying/ Live--at--LT. For those wishing, the family requests a donation to any of the following organizations: The New Jewish Home: http://jewishhome.org/ Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure: http://abc2.org Cancer Research Institute: http://www.cancerresearch.org/memorial 1/3

VASSALLO--Edward F. We miss you every minute of every day Ed, as do your countless friends and admirers, who have established a scholarship, a land preserve, awards and theater readings in your honor. They still post on your Facebook page everyday. Mom, Dad, Elena & Johnny 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald Guy. 67 years, of Aspen, CO and New York City, passed away peacefully on February 22, 2016, surrounded by his loved ones, following a brain injury sustained in Aspen during Presidents' Weekend. Don spent his last day doing one of the things he loved best; skiing in Aspen, where he and his partner Sue Hostetler had lived for the past two years. Don was born on March 1, 1948, and was raised in Queens, NY, and later received a B.A. from Brandeis University in 1968, followed by a J.D. from Columbia University School of Law. Don was founder and Chairman of Casablanca Capital. Most recently, he was Vice Chairman of Lazard International and Chairman of Lazard's Investment Committee and Chairman and CEO of Sapphire Industrials, an $800 million Lazard sponsored SPAC. Prior to joining Lazard in 2007, Don was Vice Chairman and Director of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc. and held similar positions with various affiliates from 1987 to 2007. From 1977 to 1987, he was a partner in the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP. He began his career as an attorney with the firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore from 1971 to 1977 and was a member of the American Bar Association and the New York City Bar Association. Over the course of his 40 year career, Don had been an advisor and a principal in significant securities transactions and business combinations. He was a frequent guest on CNBC, and a panelist at other financial events. Until his death, Don served on the Board of Directors of Tanger Factory Outlet Centers and had previously served on the boards of several other public companies, including: Anthracite Capital Inc., Marvel Holdings Inc., The Molson Companies Limited, Nephros Inc., Playboy Enterprises, Revlon Inc. and SIGA Technologies, among others. Don was also a generous philanthropist, serving on the following boards: New York Special Olympics Annual Metro Tournaments, for which he served as Co-Chairman; Law Enforcement Foundation, Inc.; Jewish Community Center; Brandeis University (Emeritas Member after having served for the twenty-five years); American Lawyer Media, Inc.; the Board of Overseers to the Lemberg Program of Brandeis University; as a Member of Development, Program and Nominating Committees of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars; and, Hope and Heroes Children's Cancer Fund Advisory Board. At the time of his death, he served on the Board of Directors of Lincoln Center Theater, the Aspen Music Festival and School, Theater Aspen, the Federal Enforcement Homeland Security Foundation, Inc.; was a member of the Dean's Council of Columbia Law School; and served as a National Council member of the Anderson Ranch in Aspen/ Snowmass, CO. A huge lover of life, with a twinkle in his eye, and a wry smile that could light up any room, Don was much loved by many. Don was a rare individual who had scores of friends going back four and five decades. Don loved to ski and cycle and was a lifelong theater lover. Don and Sue also enjoyed collecting art together, regularly visiting galleries and art fairs around the world. In addition to Sue, Don is survived by his wife Bernice from whom he had been separated; his son Matthew Drapkin and his wife Annie Drapkin; his daughter Dana Drapkin Baumgarten and her husband Joshua Baumgarten; his daughter Nicole Drapkin Schaffer and her husband Marc Schaffer; his son David Drapkin; and his daughter Amanda Drapkin; adoring grandchildren William, Annabel, Charles and Elizabeth Drapkin; and Lilly, Emma and Georgia Baumgarten; and Sue's daughter Spencer Diamond. Don was preceded in death by his cherished son Dustin; and his parents George and Mildred (Kaufman) Drapkin. The funeral will be held at 11am, today, Thursday, February 25 at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, 1 Engle Street, Tenafly, NJ 07670. Details of the Celebration of Life to be held in Aspen next week will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Aspen Music Festival and School (Kat Berg kberg@aspenmusic.org 970-205-5061) or Lincoln Center Theater (Hattie Jutagir jutagir@lct.org 212-501-3250). 1/3

JONES--Ira Snow, M.D. March 31, 1917 - February 9, 2016. Dr. Ira Snow Jones passed away peacefully in his sleep at his home in New York City where he lived with his wife Vasso for over 45 years. Dr. Jones was a professor in the Department of Ophthalmology at Columbia University Medical Center, Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute. Dr. Jones was a member of the College of Physicians and Surgeons and the American Society of Ophthalmic Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery. In 1982, Dr. Jones was honored as Clinical Professor Emeritus of Ophthalmology. Dr. Jones and his wife Vasso, an RN and OR nurse, both worked together in his private office at 215 East 72nd St., in New York City. He retired at the age 86. God needed a good doctor by his side so He chose Dr. Jones. He will be missed by family and friends. 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald. Our dear friend has left us too early. His love of life, brilliance, loyalty, and magnetic personality will never be forgotten. He was a visionary and rare gem, a giant amongst men, whom we loved and will forever remember. Our love and deepest condolences to the Drapkin and Baumgarten families. The Browns and Sweetwoods 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime Board Member, Donald Drapkin. He was a great champion of our Theater -- generous, enthusiastic, irreverent, and funny. He had recently been designated an LCT Honorary Trustee, and he was very proud to have been admitted into such distinguished company. We send sympathy and love to Sue and his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

CULLEN--Thomas Ward, Jr.,88, of Jupiter, Florida, Westhampton Beach and formerly of Plandome, NY, passed away peacefully on February 22, 2016 surrounded by his beloved family. Born in Brooklyn, NY on October 5, 1927, son of Thomas and Marion Cullen. Beloved husband to Michele Connell Cullen for 61 years, formerly of Jersey City and Sea Girt, NJ. Cherished by his adoring family, Thomas (Elizabeth) Cullen, Mary Lou (Peter) Burns, Lisa Coleman, Suzanne (John) Donovan, Jim (Sue) Cullen, John (Lisa) Cullen, Paul (Suzanne) Cullen. Proud and devoted grandfather to 19 grandchildren and five great- grandchildren. Loving oldest brother of eight, Gene (Ginger) Cullen, Bill (Vina) Cullen, Maryanne Manning, Robert (Eileen) Cullen, Eileen (Jake) Blake, Cathleen (Dan) Pratt, Suzanne (Peter) Riebling. Predeceased by Rosemary (Perry) Griffith and William Manning. Served two years in the US Navy, graduated Villanova in 1952. Tom was a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1957, along with his three brothers. He was a devout daily communicant. As the Cullen family leader, Tom was a compassionate, kind, humble and loving counselor to all. Family will receive friends at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY on Sunday, February 28th 3-7pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, February 29th, 10am at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church at 1300 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations in Tom's memory may be sent to Little Flower Children and Family Services, Wading River, NY. 1/3

CLAYTON--Helen Elizabeth Tracie (Betty). Two months short of her 94th birthday. Predeceased in 2008 by Robert, her husband of 54 years. Mother of William C. and Tracie E. and esteemed mother-in-law of Peter Hom. 1/3

BLOM--Marybeth McCloskey, of Bronxville, NY, died on February 23, 2016, after a courageous battle with Glioblastoma Multiforme. Beloved wife of Henry A. Blom, loving mother of Ian, Kaia and Lara. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4pm and 6-9pm Friday. Funeral service at Christ Church Bronxville, on Saturday, February 27 at 2pm. ZEFF--Leon H.,Ph.D., died in Oakland, CA. Formerly of Westport, CT, he was born and raised in St. Paul, MN, enlisted in the Army Air Corp, and served in India and Burma. Earned a B.A and M.A. from NYU and a doctorate in psychology from Adelphi University. Son of Jennie and Abe Zeff, youngest brother of Dave, Milton and William, all of whom predecease him. Father of Carl Douglass, Jonathan S. and Joshua Adam Zeff. Grandfather of Jennifer Chan and Daren Chan. Husband of Norma Eisendorf for 67 years. Died of complications of Parkinson's disease. Memorial contributions may be made to The Southern Poverty Law Center or Doctors without Borders in his honor. 1/3

BROD--Sheldon J.,78, of NYC, passed away sadly and unexpectedly on February 22, 2016. Devoted husband of Sandy for 48 years, beloved father of Melissa and Rachel, loving father-in-law to David, caring brother to Alan and late sister Lila Arnold. Proud and adorning "Papa" to the lights of his life, Sadie and Ezra. Services Friday, February 26 at 9am, "The Riverside," NYC. 1/3
DRAPKIN--Donald G. Larger than life, you will never be gone, as you can never be forgotten. Abigail, Hillary and Scott Weinshank 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald. The board and staff of Anderson Ranch Arts Center mourn the death of Donald Drapkin, a highly involved member of our National Council. Donald's enthusiasm, humor and generosity have had a tremendous impact on Anderson Ranch and the entire Aspen/Snowmass community. We extend our deepest sympathies to his partner and our Board Member Sue Hostetler and her daughter, Donald's children, and the Drapkin family. Ann Korologos, Chair, Board of Trustees; Nancy Wilhelms, Executive Director 1/3

HENDRICKS--Carmen Ortiz. The faculty and staff of the Silberman School of Social Work at Hunter College are profoundly saddened by the untimely loss of our good friend and distinguished colleague, Carmen Ortiz Hendricks. A member of our faculty for more than 20 years, Dr. Hendricks was a gifted teacher, skilled administrator, and nationally renowned scholar. Her seminal research and publication in the area of cultural competence won widespread recognition, and her collaborative persona made her a sought after leader in our profession. We all mourn her loss and will treasure her memory. Mary M. Cavanaugh, Acting Dean, Silberman School of Social Work at Hunter College 1/3
KOEVES--Eliane, 102, passed away on February 13, 2016. She lived with courage, love for art and gardening. 1/3

NATTMAN--Gertrude S.,91, passed away from cancer on February 22, 2016. Retired psychotherapist with MSW from Columbia University. Devoted wife to the late Nathan Nattman. Survived by sons Ford H. and Steven C. Weisberg, daughter-in-law Nancy, grandchildren Alexander, Nathaniel and Joseph, and cousins and nephews from the Novzen and Krepisman families. Loved theater, music, and, above all, family. Burial at The Kensico Cemetery, Sharon Gardens, Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, NY on Friday, February 26, 2016 at 9:30am. 1/3

STEINMULLER--Lillian. May 5, 1931 - February 21, 2016. My beloved wife Lillian died from complications of her longstanding Parkinson's Disease. She was an incredible woman, filled with an indomitable zest for life, for growth and for learning. She continually reinvented herself from school teacher to artist and, eventually at age 59, entered a graduate program, earning a PHD and becoming a gifted and sought after Psychologist. She is survived by her son Bennett and her daughter Franci McFarland and grandsons Sawyer and Turner. She lives on in our hearts forever. The funeral will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Friday at 12. The family will be sitting Shiva Friday from 4:30 on at 205 East 69th Street. 1/3

MELTZER--Monroe "Mickey." Born in Brooklyn on June 20, 1925. Devoted husband of Joan for 68 years, beloved father of Ileane, Sara, Amy and Marjorie, loving father-in-law to Jerry and Scott. Proud Papa who bonded with grandchildren: Joshua, Jeremy, Jennifer, Jackson, Sara and her husband Michael. He brought laughter to all. He will be greatly missed. Cheers Dad! 1/3

STAMLER--Joseph Sr. The Board of Trustees and families of Ocean Beach Club mourn the passing of Joseph Stamler, Sr. Joe was a longtime member of Ocean Beach Club and he will be missed by all. Our sympathies are with his wife Susie, and all the members of the Stamler family. William Herrman II, President, Shawn Wallach, Secretary 1/3

GOLDWEBER--Max, 96, died peacefully on February 24th. Family, community, and the law were his lifelong passions. Born and raised in the Bronx, Max was the second youngest of eight children. He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. Married to his wife Dorothy for 56 years, a southern belle whom he met while guarding the James River in Virginia during WWII. Max inspired two generations of Goldweber women with his deeply held social values. His daughter Elyse is the founding partner of the law firm of Goldweber Epstein. Ann is a professor and Director of Clinical Education at St. John's Law School. His beloved granddaughter Gabrielle Sloss is pursuing a doctorate in psychology. Max supported many charitable institutions and co-founded Temple Sholom of Westbury over 60 years ago. He was president of the Long Island UJA, B'nai Brith, the Anti-Defamation League and served on the ADL Lawyer's Committee. Max's political activism led to his run for state senate and the presidency of the East Meadow Democratic Club. Max was a prominent litigation attorney for 65 years. A feminist before his time, he established a partnership with a female colleague in the 1950's. He was respected by peers and clients alike. He will be missed by all. Donations in memory of Max Goldweber may be made to Temple Sholom, 675 Brookside Court, Westbury, NY. 1/3

FRANCIS--Joseph H.,95, February 5, 2016 of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY and St. Petersburg, Florida. Beloved husband of Ada and Rose (August 20, 1997); father of Jo (John Fuegi), Barb (Keith O'Neal), Judi (Roy Sloane), Louise (Dennis Cusack), Paul (Joan Nielsen), Kerry (Chris Dunne); stepfather to Diane Capezzera (Mike), Gregory Piacente (Lucinda); thirteen grandchildren, seven and one half great-grandchildren. BS, Fordham University, 1940, where he also studied law. Twice decorated in WWII in the largest-ever naval battle at Leyte Gulf. At 23, personally congratulated by Secretary of War Henry Stimson for winning an artillery competition against the British on Cape Cod. Legislative tax executive at Texaco and J.C. Penney. Led Reformed Church of Hastings consistory and was longtime trustee. In retirement, guest editor, St. Petersburg Times, where he advocated the importance of taxes to our democracy. Sine pari. 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime Board Member, Donald Drapkin. He was a great champion of our Theater -- generous, enthusiastic, irreverent, and funny. He had recently been designated an LCT Honorary Trustee, and he was very proud to have been admitted into such distinguished company. We send sympathy and love to Sue and his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

BLOM--Marybeth McCloskey, of Bronxville, NY, died on February 23, 2016, after a courageous battle with Glioblastoma Multiforme. Beloved wife of Henry A. Blom, loving mother of Ian, Kaia and Lara. Dear daughter of Robert and Florence McCloskey. Sister of Robert, Ann, Kate and the late Jim. Marybeth attended Keene State College in New Hampshire. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4pm and 6-9pm Friday. Funeral service at Christ Church Bronxville, on Saturday, February 27 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Marybeth's memory to Young at Arts of Christ Church Bronxville, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, NY 10708. 1/3
SNEDEKER--Robert A.,of Belleville, NJ and Massachusetts, beloved husband of Patricia, father of William, Brian, and Lee Anne, grandfather of Garrett and Tatiana, died February 3, 2016. 1/3

MOST--Barbara, age 93, passed away on February 24, 2016 surrounded by her family. Predeceased by her husband Robert, her parents, sister Geraldine, brothers Joseph and Murray. Survived by loving sons Michael and Larry, daughter-in-law Jodi, and grandchildren Danielle and Evan, along with many adored nieces and nephews. Barbara's memory will always be a blessing to all who knew her. Funeral will be Sunday, February 28, 10:45am at Robert Schoem's Memorial Chapel, Paramus, NJ. 1/3
GERINGER--Harold. Dear Harold: I'm going to miss all the terrific laughs we had together. With great affection, your loving friend, Phyllis 1/3

GERINGER--Harold Irving, a remarkable father and grandfather, devoted husband, wonderful friend, loving brother, and dedicated lawyer passed away February 23, 2016, at the age of 84. Harold was preceded by his beloved wife Eleanore, parents, Nathan and Betty, and brother, Martin. Left to cherish his memory are his children Geoffrey Geringer, Laura Gross and husband Fredric, Elizabeth Lieberman and husband Gary, devoted grandchildren, Benjamin, Alyson, and Rachel Gross, and Spencer Lieberman, sister Ann Lieberman (Leo), brother Saul Geringer (Martha), Harold and Sylvia Nissen, special friend Phyllis Gershon and many nieces and nephews, and lifelong friends who supported Harold until the end. A founding partner of Geringer, McNamara, & Horowitz, LLP, originally Lian & Geringer, Harold graduated from City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School, and practiced law until two weeks before his death. Harold loved being with his family, especially on his boat the "We II." He was also devoted to serving his community and never said no to a charitable request - resulting in a collection of "give aways" from various groups. Harold was President of Temple Israel of South Merrick and supported many organizations committed to Israel. A graveside service will be on Sunday, February 28, 2016 at 10:30am at the New Montefiore Cemetery, after which the family will be at Harold's apartment to receive friends. Memorial contributions may be made in memory of Harold to the Icahn School of Medicine, Mt. Sinai Hospital, for MDS/AML Research/Dr. Navada Fund. 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald. The partners of Lazard mourn the passing of our former colleague Donald Drapkin. We admired his intelligence, humor and kindness, and we benefitted from his mentorship. We share our deepest condolences with his family. 1/3

VOLPE--Robert G.,84, of West Windsor died on Sunday, February 21, 2016 at RWJ University Hospital in New Brunswick. Robert was born in Brooklyn and lived in Long Island before moving to West Windsor in 1972. Robert received his Bachelors in Business Administration from St. John's University and his MBA from NYU. He worked for the New York Stock Exchange, DuPont, Glore Forgan & Co. and finally Merrill Lynch where he worked for 25 years until his retirement in 1999. He enjoyed following the stock market, reading about WWII history, watching professional boxing and New York Rangers games and spending time with his family. Robert was preceded in death by his son Kenneth Volpe. He is survived by two sons: Robert A. Volpe of West Windsor and Matthew Volpe of Holly Springs, NC, one daughter, Laura Dolan and her husband James of Princeton Junction, one sister, Lorraine Dashiell of Portsmouth, VA and five grandchildren: Kevin, Benjamin, Jack and Lexi Dolan and Broden Volpe. Visitation will be 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Sunday, February 28, 2016 at the M. David DeMarco Funeral Home, 205 Rhode Hall Rd., Monroe Twp., NJ 08831, 732-521-0555. demarcofuneralhome.com Funeral services will begin at 8:30am on Monday, February 29, 2016 from the funeral home. A funeral liturgy will be 9:30am at St. David the King Catholic Church, Princeton Junction, followed by entombment in Cemetery of the Holy Rood Mausoleum, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers and for those who desire, memorial contributions may be made to the Epilepsy Foundation: epilepsy.com. 1/3

GREENHILL--Ira J.,94, attorney, died on February 21, 2016, in New York City. Son of Joseph and Sarah (nee Hoffman) Greenhill, Ira was born and raised in New York City, where he attended Ethical Culture School, before decamping to Swarthmore College, from which he graduated in 1942 magna cum laude. Following graduation, Ira joined the US Army and served proudly during World War II, the Korean conflict and later in the Reserves, before retiring as a major. After World War II ended, he attended Columbia Law School on the GI Bill and then entered private practice in the profession that he loved in New York City for nearly six decades, first with his father and later for a time with two of his sons, as well as partners and colleagues. When not practicing law, Ira relished time spent as a highly accomplished woodworker and cabinetmaker, recreational tennis player, "pretend" golfer (as he put it) and scotch aficionado, dividing time between Rye, NY and Port St. Lucie, FL. Ira is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Elaine D. Greenhill (nee Maltzman), as well as his sons and daughters-in-law, Jonathan S. Greenhill, Zachary R. and Judy L. Greenhill, and Lincoln J. and Kelly M. Greenhill, and four grandchildren, Caitlin, Alexander, Hunter and Gavin. He was predeceased by his sister, Phyllis Meyerson. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Columbia Law School and Swarthmore College. 1/3

BERTACCINI--Barbara Ann Levy, passed away peacefully on February 16 at the age of 90. Preceded in death by her husband of 62 years, Paul F. Bertaccini, she is survived by her children - Paul, Lisa, David and Donna, nine grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. From Buffalo, New York she raised her family in Freeport, Long Island where she taught English and Humanities to a generation of high school students. Upon retirement, she became a member of the board of trustees of the Freeport Memorial Library where she spent a decade leading adult education seminars that deepened her engagement with classical Greek literature, Chaucer and Shakespeare. An extraordinary teacher, storyteller, avid swimmer and world traveler, she loved animals, Jones Beach and all things Italian. Grief is too limited a word to describe the profound sense of loss for all family members. Donations can be made to: WCHOB Foundation, Women and Children's Hospital of Buffalo's Pediatric Cardiology Division. 1/3

LUBELL--Daniel S. The partners of Hughes Hubbard extend our deepest sympathy to the family of our former partner Daniel S. Lubell. Dan served with distinction as a bankruptcy lawyer in our firm for 28 years and leaves behind many friends and admirers in our firm and among our clients. 1/3

DIAMOND--Henry. The Boards of The Woodstock Foundation, Inc. and Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc. mourn the death of Henry Diamond, longtime board member and giant in the field of conservation. His guidance will be greatly missed. Ellen R.C. Pomeroy, Chair, Board of Trustees 1/3

STEINMULLER--Lillian. May 5, 1931 - February 21, 2016. My beloved wife Lillian died from complications of her longstanding Parkinson's Disease. She was an incredible woman, filled with an indomitable zest for life, for growth and for learning. She continually reinvented herself from school teacher to artist and, eventually at age 59, entered a graduate program, earning a PHD and becoming a gifted and sought after Psychologist. She is survived by her son Bennett and her daughter Franci McFarland and grandsons Sawyer and Turner. She lives on in our hearts forever. The funeral will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Friday at 12. The family will be sitting Shiva Friday from 4:30 on at 205 East 69th Street. 1/3

DRAPKIN--Donald. The Garden School community notes with sadness the passing of Donald Drapkin '64, our esteemed alumnus and friend. Our thoughts are with his family, friends and classmates. Richard Marotta, Ph.D., Headmaster Michael Rakosi '64, Board President Jackson Heights, NY 1/3

MURRAY--Heather. Born August 4, 1973, died February 16, 2016. She was the beloved daughter of Conal and Betty. Wake, 2-4 and 6-8pm, Sunday, Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, NY. Service, 9:30am, Monday, St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Francis Memorial Hospital, San Francisco, CA. 1/3
GRACE--Roy. 12/5/36 -2/26/03 Alive in our hearts forever. Love Always, Marcia, Jess and Tom, Nick and Annie 1/3
GERINGER--Harold. We mourn the loss of our dear friend, Harold. Harold & Sally, Norman & Sandi, Paula 1/3

STAMLER--Joseph Charles, of Rumson, NJ, died peacefully on February 24th at age 81. Loving husband of Susan, father of J.C., Kimberly, John and Audrey, grandfather of Charlie and Henry. He graduated from Lafayette College. He served as lieutenant commander in the United States Navy prior to becoming a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1962 where he remained a specialist on the floor until 2000. He was a remarkable human being who graciously put the needs and concerns of others before his own. He taught us to live life to the fullest, to take joy in the accomplishments of others, to face the challenges of work and life with indomitable spirit and to look even the hardest problems straight in the eye and face it with courage and confidence. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to New York Service for the Handicapped, 1140 Broadway, New York, New York 10001. His family will receive at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. from 2-5pm on Saturday, February 27th. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Eman- El, 65th St. at 5th Ave. at 2pm on Sunday, February 28th. 1/3

STAMLER--Joseph, Sr. The Directors and staff of New York Service for the Handicapped are deeply saddened by the passing of Joseph Stamler, Sr., who with his wife Susan have been longtime generous supporters of Camp Oakhurst. Their deep commitment to our work with children and adults with disabilities has also been expressed through Susan's long and valued service on our Board of Directors. The Stamler family's interest in the welfare of children and adults with disabilities has been so helpful to our mission to provide adapted facilities and scholarships so all could enjoy Camp Oakhurst. To Sue and to Joe's extended family we offer our heartfelt condolences. Marilyn Friedman, President; Robert Pacenza, Executive Director 1/3

STAMLER--Joseph. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Joseph Stamler. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memory brings comfort to those who mourn his passing. 1/3
BAUMAN--Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague, died on February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC 1/3

NASH--Jeffrey Paul, 69, son of Harry and Naomi Kane Nash, died peacefully of unexpected heart failure on February 20th at his home in Manhattan. A lifelong New Yorker, Jeff began his investment banking career at DuPont Walston and then A.G. Becker before founding Rector Street Capital. Friend and confidant for half a century. Brilliant, exceedingly funny, loyal, bold when appropriate. Humble, sincere, passionate and hard working, he will be missed by all his colleagues and his many friends. Loving husband of Cassandra. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date. Rest in peace RR Dog. 1/3

ROBBINS--Jack, 73, of New York City, died January 5, 2016. Born April 20, 1942, in Comanche County, KS, he grew up in Wichita. At 21, he moved to Washington, D.C., then to New York City. He worked at the New York Post as a copyboy, then reporter and feature writer. He spent five years as a full-time parent and freelance copy- editor, and finished his career on the copy desk at Business Week. In retirement he indulged in his passions: movies, the gym, and the New York Mets. He is survived by his wife, Sonia; their daughter, Christie; his brother Jim; nieces and nephews; and numerous friends around the world. He will be remembered for his wit and generosity. A memorial will be held on March 5, 2pm, at Judson Memorial Church Assembly Hall, 239 Thompson St., New York, NY. In lieu of donations, take a family member or a friend to the movies. 1/3

GOLD--Gerald, of Manhattan and Westhampton Beach, NY, died after a brave struggle with Lewy Body Dementia with Parkinson's Disease at the age of 77. He was born in Philadelphia, PA, eldest son of the late Morris and Edith Feldman Gold. He is survived by his beloved wife Judith Witryol Gold, loving daughter Allison Gold, brother Rabbi Aaron Gold (Esther) and several nieces and nephews. He moved to New York City in 1965 to become a securities analyst at Hallgarten & Co. and rose to Director of Research at companies including New York Life Insurance, Brown Brothers Harriman and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. He was a CFA and past member of the Board of Directors of the New York Society of Securities Analysts. He was also a member of the Union League Club of New York and The Surf Club of Quogue. Contributions may be made to Lewy Body Dementia Association (lbda.org) or MJHS Hospice (www.mjhshospice.org). 1/3

QUINLIVAN--William Francis, 94, of Boca Raton, FL passed away on February 24, 2016. Funeral services will be held tomorrow. Visit: glickfamilyfuneralhome.com or call 561-672-1880 for obituary and funeral details. 1/3
STAMLER--Joseph. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Joe. One of only a very few truly nice guys. Eddie & DiAnne H. 1/3
MOSKOWITZ--Leon. 6/6/1926 - 2/27/2012. Always in our thoughts. Robin, Elaine, Coco, Artie, Daniel, Max, Jordan & Casey 1/3

ADLER--Ian, 43, passed away on February 19, 2016, after a long illness, which he never let define him. Ian maintained a wonderful attitude and strong sense of determination throughout. He is survived by his loving wife, Jennifer Livingston. He is also survived by his parents, Gerald and Judith Adler, his sister, Marlo (Evan) Feldman, Jennifer's parents, Andrew and Anne Livingston, Jennifer's sisters, Julie (Jeffrey) Echt, Karen (Craig) Lewis, and eight nieces and nephews, all of whom loved and adored him greatly. Ian was the Senior Director of Healthcare at Marwood Group, where he was responsible for overall healthcare strategy and policy for the past 15 years. His family, many friends and colleagues shared a mutual admiration for Ian's loving, generous and genuine character. Ian received a Masters of Public Administration in Healthcare Financial Management and Policy from New York University and a Bachelor of Science degree from Skidmore College. Contributions in Ian's name may be made to the Leukemia-Lymphoma Society and The Bone Marrow Foundation. 1/3

MANN--Alfred E. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Mr. Alfred E. Mann, of Beverly Hills, CA. A noted scientist, and entrepreneur, Mr. Mann was a loyal supporter who established the Alfred Mann Institute for Biomedical Development at the Technion, focused on enabling commercialization of innovative biomedical technologies that improve human health. Together with his wife, Claude, Mr. Mann was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. He was awarded a Technion Honorary Doctorate in 2005. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Claude, and the entire Mann family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Zahava Bar-Nir, President Scott Leemaster, Chairman of the Board Jeffrey Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3
BAUMAN--Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague, died on February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC 1/3

NASH--Jeffrey Paul, 69, son of Harry and Naomi Kane Nash, died peacefully of unexpected heart failure on February 20th at his home in Manhattan. A lifelong New Yorker, Jeff began his investment banking career at DuPont Walston and then A.G. Becker before founding Rector Street Capital. Friend and confidant for half a century. Brilliant, exceedingly funny, loyal, bold when appropriate. Humble, sincere, passionate and hard working, he will be missed by all his colleagues and his many friends. Loving husband of Cassandra. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date. Rest in peace RR Dog. 1/3

STAMLER--Joseph Charles, of Rumson, NJ, died peacefully on February 24th at age 81. Loving husband of Susan, father of J.C., Kimberly, John and Audrey, grandfather of Charlie and Henry. He graduated from Lafayette College. He served as lieutenant commander in the United States Navy prior to becoming a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1962 where he remained a specialist on the floor until 2000. He was a remarkable human being who graciously put the needs and concerns of others before his own. He taught us to live life to the fullest, to take joy in the accomplishments of others, to face the challenges of work and life with indomitable spirit and to look even the hardest problems straight in the eye and face it with courage and confidence. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to New York Service for the Handicapped, 1140 Broadway, New York, New York 10001. His family will receive at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. from 2-5pm on Saturday, February 27th. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Emanu- El, 65th St. at 5th Ave. at 2pm on Sunday, February 28th. 1/3

de JONG--Kersen J.,passed away February 17, 2016 while vacationing in Hawaii. He was born in The Netherlands on March 13, 1950. He was the Managing Director of The Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in the U.S., was a consummate networker, and hired many Dutch interns which was the start of his history of helping and mentoring young people. At age 26, he lost both legs in a car accident. Kersen was soon walking again with two artificial legs. He dedicated his entire life to not being handicapped. He became an outspoken defender of equality and social justice for the handicapped, underserved, and the underrepresented. Kersen was dedicated to creating educational and cultural opportunities for young people. His passion for music led to his association with the Boys Choir of Harlem often funding their high school and college education. He started a new foundation called The Netherlands American Community Trust. Many have gone on to become successful opera singers, playwrights, and entertainers. He was a member of the Board of Governors for the Roosevelt Institute and The Four Freedoms, a member and judge of the United Nations Franklin D. Roosevelt International Disability Rights Award Advisory Board, board member of A Leg to Stand On, instrumental in setting up the Chicago Boys Choir, and helped start the Choir Academy of Chicago. Queen Beatrix of The Netherlands considered his contributions to Dutch interests in the United States so valuable that she granted him a Knighthood in the Order of Orange-Nassau. Kersen will be remembered for his passion for living and most of all his generosity. He gave to many unconditionally. He believed he could make the world a better place. He will be fondly remembered for the lives he touched and the lasting impact he had on the communities he served. His life is living proof that you can change things in this world. He is survived by Phillip Perkins, his life-long partner of 37 years, and a brother, Martin De Jong. Donation in lieu of flowers to Shake-a-Leg, Miami. For online condolences visit: www.forevermissed.com/ kersen-de-jong. 1/3

DORNBUSCH--Sanford M. Sanford ("Sandy") Dornbusch, born in New York City on June 5, 1926, died at home in Palo Alto, CA, February 9, 2016. He and his wife and sweetheart Barbara ("Red") enjoyed a rich and adventurous marriage of 65 years. He spent most of his career as a sociologist at Stanford University, where he was a recognized researcher in the social sciences and was one of the founders of the Program in Human Biology. He was the first President of the Stanford University Faculty Senate. He loved teaching and mentoring his students, maintaining lifelong connections. He was a lively and loving husband and father. Sandy was an engaging storyteller and the center of our family. He is survived by his wife Barbara (Palo Alto), sons Steven (Los Angeles) and Jeff (Albuquerque, NM), sister Doris Lowenthal (New York, NY), and his adoring granddaughters Leah Dornbusch (San Francisco) and Hannah Martinelli (Madison, WI). Sandy's unique intelligence, wit and charm will be sorely missed by numerous friends, relatives and colleagues. A celebration of his life will take place at 3pm Saturday, March 19, 2016 in the Auditorium at the Vi, 620 Sand Hill Road, Palo Alto, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations payable to Stanford University, directed to the Professor Sandy Dornbusch Fund (benefitting areas in Sociology, Human Biology, and Art), may be made via Stanford Development Services, PO Box 20466, Stanford, CA 94309-0466 (credit card by phone, 866-543-0243). 1/3

ASTREDO--Humbert Allen Jr "Bud", passed into the universe on February 19, 2016. A consummate actor, story teller and entertainer, he honed his skills during the Korean War doing stand- up and entertaining the troops. He carried a weapon but always preferred bullets of laughter. Born in Pasadena, California on April 4, 1929, Bud grew up in San Francisco and Pasadena. His mother Bessie taught young Humbert to play the piano and this accomplishment made him the life of every party. As a teenager he loved souping up hot rods and burning rubber on the streets. His father Humbert Sr. infused his son with a passion for all the arts. Bud learned to sail a boat and to hunt and fish with his father on the Russian River and in the Sierra Nevadas. After the military, Humbert studied acting at the Pasadena Playhouse, worked in local theaters in Los Angeles and established a classical theater company, The Hollywood Center Theatre. In 1965 he loaded his possessions into his truck and drove to New York City, where he was immediately recognized as a very special talent and cast by Joe Papp for Shakespeare in the Park, which led to his big break playing Sergius in "Arms and the Man". Humbert was an early client and lifelong friend of agent Don Buchwald. He performed with James Earl Jones in "Othello", and became a fixture in off- broadway and regional theaters. He became wildly popular as a star of "Dark Shadows", the innovative gothic TV soap opera of the late 60's. Humbert toured nationally with both Frank Langella and Martin Landau in "Dracula". On Broadway he performed in Gore Vidal's "An Evening with Richard Nixon", Lorraine Hansberry's "Les Blancs" and the world tour of "Little Foxes" with Elizabeth Taylor. For 10 years he made his sailboat the "Whimsey" his home and later retired to a historical farm house in Guilford, Connecticut, where he continued to receive fan mail from followers of his career. Humbert is predeceased by his daughter Jennifer "Jenny" and survived by the Hanson Family and the Small Family. 1/3

Beloved husband of the late Sally, devoted brother of the late Morton, loving uncle of Regina and MayLisa and their husbands Derek and John, cherished great-uncle of Casey, her loving husband Jeremy, Kylie, Gabrielle and Rachel, proud great-granduncle of Gavin and Spencer and honorary uncle to Michael. Carr and Anita Carr Shapiro, loving father-in-law to Harvey Shapiro, wonderful brother to Robert Carr and great friend to many. His incredible strength, kindness, warmth, devotion and keen sense of humor will be greatly missed. VOLLERS--Joseph E. Jr.,77, on February 17, 2016. Graduated Alfred University; a pioneer in software systems design, founder of Systems and Communications Group, Inc. He leaves behind his wife, Annette, five children and six grandchildren. 1/3

GASSELL--Sylvia, 92, actor, passed away February 24, 2016 in New York. Predeceased by her husband Joel Friedman. Survived by loving friends and family who will remember her brilliance, energy and accomplished acting career. 1/3

ADLER--Ian, 43, passed away on February 19, 2016, after a long illness, which he never let define him. Ian maintained a wonderful attitude and strong sense of determination throughout. He is survived by his loving wife, Jennifer Livingston. He is also survived by his parents, Gerald and Judith Adler, his sister, Marlo (Evan) Feldman, Jennifer's parents, Andrew and Anne Livingston, Jennifer's sisters, Julie (Jeffrey) Echt, Karen (Craig) Lewis, and eight nieces and nephews, all of whom loved and adored him greatly. Ian was the Senior Director of Healthcare at Marwood Group, where he was responsible for overall healthcare strategy and policy for the past 15 years. His family, many friends and colleagues shared a mutual admiration for Ian's loving, generous and genuine character. Ian received a Masters of Public Administration in Healthcare Financial Management and Policy from New York University and a Bachelor of Science degree from Skidmore College. Contributions in Ian's name may be made to the Leukemia-Lymphoma Society and The Bone Marrow Foundation. 1/3

GETHERS--Judith, 93, Cookbook Author and Mentor to Many Chefs. Born Judith Harmatz on August 30, 1922, her father, Jacob Harmatz, founded Ratner's, NYC's legendary dairy restaurant. At age 53, she took her first job, at Los Angeles' Ma Maison, in the kitchen and became a mother figure and mentor to such chefs as Wolfgang Puck, Jonathan Waxman and Nancy Silverton. She ran the cooking school Ma Cuisine, teaching alongside Julia Child, Maida Heatter and Paula Wolfert, and was known as "The Ma of Ma Maison." She wrote or co- wrote six cookbooks. She was married to Steven Gethers, television writer/director, until his death in 1989. Mrs. Gethers died on February 1, 2016. She will be greatly missed by all her real and surrogate children and grandchildren. 1/3

TYLER--Jean Cadwell, of New York City died February 3, 2016. She was born to Cadwell Tyler II and Jean Keller Tyler December 15, 1940, in Goshen, NY. A graduate of Wellesley College, she spent a career of almost 30 years in health education at New York City's Maternity, Infant Care, and Family Planning Projects (MIC), including serving as Director of Health Education and finally as Director of Communications and Education. She helped found and was president of the Greater New York Chapter of the Society of Public Health Educators. Services will be April 30, 2016, at 11am at St. James Episcopal Church, Goshen, NY. Memorial contributions can be made to: City Harvest (www.cityharvest.org); the Doe Fund (www.doe.org); or to a charity of the donor's choice. 1/3

GREENFIELD--Lenore. Lenore died peacefully February 16, 2016. Knowing she was terminal, she spent her last six weeks welcoming family and friends with whom she would reminisce, with lots of laughter and joy. Born in the Bronx, to Felix and Eva Hirschberg, she was a fervent New Yorker. An artist and teacher, she was an advocate of creativity, peace and tolerance. Predeceased by her husband, William, she is survived by her truly loving sons and their spouses Stephen and Kit and Paul and Martha, her grandchildren Sarah and Ilan, who were so supportive of her, and great- grandchildren Luna, Balthazar and Keila, as well as cousins and an international circle of friends who were her extended family. A memorial celebration will be held in New York in the future. 1/3
HYMAN--Andrew David, You will always be on our minds and in our hearts. Mom & Dad, Josh & Jon, Susan & Liz, Lily &Than 1/3

SCHUMANN--Otho Douglas. Age 91, passed away Saturday, February 20, 2016. A retired United States Navy Rear Admiral and resident of Rio Rancho, NM since 1988. He was born September 10, 1924, in New Orleans, LA to Otho Charles Schumann and Grace Douglas Schumann. He was a graduate of Tulane University and he earned his MBA degree from New York University. He was a Navy Veteran who served in World War II and the Berlin Recall in the Southwest Pacific during which he rose to command of PC 1138. Doug attained the rank of Captain in the Navy and a Rear Admiral in the New York Militia by the time his military career concluded. During his lifetime, his career primarily was in the area of textiles and importing fresh gourmet foods from around the globe. His employers included: Lane Cotton Mills in New Orleans, Pomona Manufacturing Company in Greensboro, NC, Morgan Cotton Mill in North Carolina, U.S. Rubber-Textile Division of Air Reduction Company in New York, Aberfoyle Manufacturing in New York, Springs Mills in New York, the Milliken Company in New York and Schumann Inter Group. Doug has extensive memberships in military, professional and civic organizations. His life memberships include; Military Order of the U.S. Navy, U.S. Naval Institute, Patrol Craft Sailors Association, Naval Enlisted Reserve Association, Reserve Officers Association, Fleet Reserve Association, and Navy League. Doug also was a member and past president of the Naval Reserve Association Island Chapel NY and Navy League U.S. Rio Grande chapter Members American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists, American Association for Textile Technology (AATT), chairman of Knitted Outwear Association, committee chairman of the Carpet and Rug Institute, member American Legion, Kiwanis in which he was distinguished lieutenant governor in District II Southwest division. He also served on the board of directors of the Albuquerque and Rio Rancho Boys and Girls Club, which now bears his and Marie's name. While growing up in New Orleans, he was active in Sunday school and in Tulane University Theater and debating society. He traveled extensively in his military and civilian professions. He was preceded in death by his wife of 51 years, Marie who died August 2003. He is survived by his sister, Mrs. Frank Monteleone; his nephews, Lance and Stuart Monteleone and wife Olga: and grandniece, Mary Elizabeth. Doug and wife Marie also established the Rear Admiral O Douglas and Marie Schumann Foundation that helps Rio Rancho students financially attend college or a trade school. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Schumann Foundation at www. schumannfoundation.com. A Visitation will be held Friday, March 4, 2016 from 9am to 10am at Daniels Family Funeral Services, 4310 Sara Road SE, Rio Rancho, NM 87124, followed by a Funeral Service at 11am at St. Francis Episcopal Church at 2903 Cabezon Rd., Rio Rancho, NM 87124. Interment with full military honors will take place at Arlington National Cemetery at a later date. To view information or leave a condolence, please visit: www.danielsfuneral.com. 1/3

RHOTON--Albert, Jr.,M.D. Albert Loren Rhoton, Jr., M.D. age 83, of Gainesville, FL passed away Sunday, February 21, 2016 at his home. He was born in 1932 in Parvin, Kentucky to Albert Loren and Hazel Van Cleve Rhoton. He began in the poverty stricken Kentucky Appalachians. A lifetime of influential achievements in his field gained him respect of his peers worldwide. He was the R.D. Keene Family Professor of Neurosurgery; Dr. Rhoton had the honor of meeting two presidents, President Ronald Reagan and President Jimmy Carter. His passion was Micro Neuro Surgical education, mentoring young Neuro Surgeons, exercise and family time. Dr. Albert L. Rhoton, Jr. attended Washington University School of Medicine, graduating with the highest academic standing in the class of 1959. He completed his neurosurgical training at Washington University and joined the staff of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota in 1965. He became Professor and Chairman of the Department of Neurological Surgery at the University of Florida in 1972. Dr. Rhoton had served as President of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons, the Congress of Neurological Surgeons, the Society of Neurological Surgeons, the North American Skull Base Society, the International Interdisciplinary Congress on Craniofacial and Skull Base Surgery, the Florida Neurosurgical Society, and the International Society for Neurosurgical Technology and Instrument Invention. He served as the Honored Guest of the Congress of Neurological Surgeons in 1993 and was awarded the Cushing Medal of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons in 1998, the highest honor given by the two largest neurosurgical societies in the United States. In 2001, he was awarded the Medal of Honor of the World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies. He had served as the Honored Guest or been elected to Honorary Membership in neurosurgical societies in Africa, Asia, Australia, Europe, and North and South America. He had published nearly 500 scientific papers. He had completed a textbook, Cranial Anatomy and Surgical Approaches which has been published in English, Chinese, Portuguese and further translations are in progress. His definitive neurosurgical lectures are available free on ITunes University and at multiple internet sites. He had received an Alumni Achievement Award from Washington University School of Medicine and both a Distinguished Faculty Award and a lifetime Achievement Award from the University of Florida. In 1998, the University of Florida completed a Brain Institute which houses the activities of the neurosurgical group and the microsurgical laboratory. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Joyce L. Mike and Suzanne were patrons and collectors of art, and well known within the New York art community. Mark most recently worked several years for Microsoft Corporation. He previously worked with Merrill Lynch at the World Trade Center, New York City, including the time of the September 11th attacks, but was in Seattle that very day interviewing for Microsoft. A longtime science fiction fan, Mark eagerly shared his enthusiasm and extensive collection of related books, movies, comics, games and other materials. His online presence was broad as well, as a gamer and significant Wikipedia editor known as Dreadstar. BEIT--Hugo Herbert Beit von Speyer, died peacefully at home on February 26th, 2016 surrounded by his loving family. Born in Frankfurt am Main, the son of Elisabeth de Neufville Beit von Speyer and Eduard Beit von Speyer, he was a member of several distinguished families whose accomplishments lasted over several centuries, and included the families Beit, Speyer, Merton and de Neufville. Marcus Salomon Beit founded Norddeutsch Affinerie AG in Hamburg, Germany, in 1770, the second largest copper company in the world, which acquired Cumerio in 2008, and was renamed Aurubis AG. The Beit family home in Frankfurt am Main is now the Rocco Forte Hotel Villa Kennedy in the Kennedyalle. Alfred Beit, the South African diamond magnate, and Nathan Meyer Rothschild funded Cecil Rhoades, founder of the DeBeers diamond mines in South Africa. Alfred Beit's nephew, Sir Alfred Beit and Lady Clementine Beit moved their renowned art collection from their home in Kensington Palace Gardens to Russborough House in County Wicklow, Ireland in 1952, one of the most beautiful Palladian houses in Ireland. The Speyers were bankers in Frankfurt since the 14th century with family firms in Paris, London and New York. The Speyer Bank, a leading investment house in Frankfurt, was usually ranked just behind the Rothschilds. Hugo Beit's great uncle, James Speyer, founded the Museum of the City of New York with John D. Rockefeller Jr., and James' brother, Edgar Speyer, founded the London tube system. Wilhelm Merton was the founder of Metallgesellschaft AG in Frankfurt in 1881, the largest non-ferrous mining company in the world. Sebastien de Neufville founded the de Neufville bank in the 16th century, which closed in the early 20th century. Hugo Beit's education began in Switzerland at the Ecole Nouvelle de Paudex, Lausanne, and upon coming to this country continued at Eaglebrook, Deerfield, Yale University, Bachelor of Engineering, and Columbia Business School. Upon graduation from Yale, he became an engineer for Babcock and Wilcox, and upon graduation from Columbia Business School, he became a. private investor, but never lost his love of engineering, serving as the Secretary of Yale Science and Engineering for 40 years. His love of all feats of engineering, including buildings, bridges, airplanes, etc., were the inspiration of his life. He was above all a gentleman, affable, kind, elegant and generous. His deep love for family and friends all over the world touched many lives. Surviving are his wife, Louise, and their daughter, Lili Beit Enloe, granddaughter, Sabrina, and son-in-law, Charles Enloe, of Washington, DC. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Tuesday, March 1st, from 7:00pm to 9:00pm, Mass at St. Ignatius Church at Park Avenue and 83rd Street, burial at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. 1/3

COHEN--Abram D. With deepest sadness, we mourn the passing of Abram D. Cohen, 91 years old, on February 2, 2016 at his home in Fishkill, NY after a long battle with dementia. Abram was born in Brooklyn, NY on October 25, 1924. He was a devoted husband of his wife Simone for 57 blessed years. Together they have two daughters, Solange and Diane, two sons-in-law Ely and Gary, and three grandchildren, Jonathan, Nina and Daniel. Abram also leaves a sister, Eve Siegel, and a caring and close family of nieces, nephews and cousins. Abram was a veteran of World War II, serving from 1943-1946. A life-long athlete, Abram was an avid and decorated fencer. He competed on the U.S. team in the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne, Australia, the World Championships in 1958 and 1961, and the Pan American Games in 1955. Abram was the U.S. National Men's Epee Champion in 1955 and 1956. As a collegiate fencer, he was a member of the NCAA Champion CCNY team in 1948 and was inducted into the CCNY Athletic Hall of Fame in 1971. Abram was also inducted into the US Fencing Hall of Fame in 2005. In addition to fencing, he also enjoyed model trains, building intricate displays in his home, and had a great talent for drawing and photography. Abram was a businessman in the paper converting industry. A gentle man, a loving man, a real gentleman! He will greatly be missed by his family and friends. 1/3

BRICKMAN--Leon, Esq. The entire Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Leon Brickman, Z"l, the beloved husband of the late Roslyn Brickman, Z"l, who was admired and respected by the entire community of Belle Harbour, NY and beyond. A man of extraordinary compassion and generosity for all individuals with special needs he led in the establishment of HIDEC, the Hebrew Institute for the Deaf and Exceptional Children, which he served as its President. He was a loyal citizen of America and was a navy veteran. His kindness, aristocratic demeanor, and pride in his Jewish heritage, caused him to be respected and appreciated by all who knew him. Leon Brickman, Z"l was the proud father of his wonderful children and their achievements: Rena (and Mordy) Rosen, Zahava (and Moshael) Straus and Noah (and Barbara) Brickman and a loving and beloved, grandfather and great grandfather. GRIMM--Robert Dean, Jr.,known as Dean, died suddenly in Lexington, Kentucky on 21 February at the age of 54 years and one month. He was born in Manhattan, New York, the son of Robert Dean Grimm Sr. and Virginia Kraft. His father and his only child Payson Dean Grimm preceded him in death. He leaves his mother Virginia Kraft Payson of Indiantown, Florida, Lexington, Kentucky and Saratoga Springs, New York, three sisters, Tana Aurland Bostian (Jeff) of East Hampton, Massachusetts, Tara Kraft Grimm of Paris, France and Jill Aurland of Vernon Hills, Illinois, a nephew and two nieces. Dean was raised at the Gipsy Trail Club near Carmel, New York. He spent his early years playing tennis, Trap Shooting, (Dean shot his first "perfect round" of trap at age eight using a 20-guage specially retooled shotgun), and downhill skiing at Grayrocks in the Laurentian Mountains of Quebec, Canada. Dean attended Frederick Military Academy in Portsmouth, Virginia, graduated from Salisbury Prepratory School in Salisbury, Connecticut and The University of Kentucky in Lexington, Kentucky, receiving a BA in Political Science. He was the co- breeder with his mother of 1992 Irish Derby winner St. Jovite, who was named after the town in the Laurentians where Dean learned to ski. St. Jovite, who posted the fastest Irish Derby time in 150 years, and was named 1992 European Horse of the Year, stood at stud initially at Dean's solely owned Payson Stud Management, LLC, before moving to Ireland where he stood the better part of his stud career. St. Jovite died earlier this year at age 27. Dean later bred and sold (in partnership with actor Woody Harrelson and Len Green), the highest priced thoroughbred weanling colt in North America, and the last stakes-winning son of Seattle Slew, Council Member, to go to stud. At the time of his death Dean was currently President of The Breeders Association (TBA), owner of the National Stud, LLC, owner of Payson Stud Management, LLC, former Director of Cardinal Bancshares, Vine Street Trust, and World Gaming, 1998 Philanthropist of the Year (National Philanthropic Association of America), Founding Member, co-owner Smoke Switchers.com, Rand Paul Victory Committee. Dean lost his only child, 20- year old Payson Dean Grimm in an auto accident on 15 February 2016. For the twenty years since his son's birth, Dean waged an unsuccessful legal battle with his son's mother, to whom he was never married, for visitation rights to his son. The death of his son put Dean in a state of depression much worse than any he had previously experienced. His many good friends and his loving family were unable to relieve his pain. Six days after his son's death, Dean joined him. May they live side-by- side in perpetual peace until the Lord raises them up to Eternal Glory. Catholic services were held at the Newman Center, University of Kentucky, on Wednesday 24 February with interment on Friday at Raymond Hill Cemetery in Carmel, New York. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in the name of Dean Grimm may be made to The Newman Center, 320 Rose Lane, Lexington, KY 40508. www.milward funeral.com 1/3

Born in New York he began his career as technical director at the 92nd Street YMCA. In 1940 he was drafted and earned a Silver Star for his United States Army service in the Pacific. After the War he returned to New York to begin work at Century Lighting, later becoming a founding partner of Lighting & Electronics and selling dimming equipment for various companies until he joined Electronic Theatre Controls as a consultant. He was President of the New York section of Illuminating Engineering Society, a founding member of USITT and received its 2016 Distinguished Achievement Award. He founded Broadway Lighting Master Classes and Stage Lighting Super Saturday. He is survived by a brother Irving, a sister Naomi Hirsch, his partner Jennifer Tipton, a son Barry, a daughter-in-law Susan, and a granddaughter Chloe. 1/3

WITCHEL--Sam, 91. Died February 27, 2016 in New Rochelle, NY. Beloved husband of Barbara Witchel, father of Alex Witchel, Gregory Witchel and Emmett Witchel. Brother of Marcia Babbitt. Predeceased by adored daughter, Phoebe Kahanov. Father-in-law to Frank Rich, Monica Witchel, Learan Kahanov and Danielle Adler Witchel. Funeral services private. 1/3

COHEN--Sanford. Age 77, of Newton, on Saturday, February 27, 2016. Son of the late Minnie and Jacob Cohen. Beloved husband of the late Barbara Krames Cohen for 54 years. Alumnus of CCNY (Electrical Engineering) and MIT (Master's Degree in Aeronautics and Astronautics Engineering). Awarded the Thomas L. Thurlow Navigational Award for his contribution to the science of navigation. A division leader at the Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, and later in his career, a consultant for the Navy. He was an internationally respected expert in guidance technology. Above all, a devoted husband, father, brother, uncle, grandfather, and friend. Dearly loved father of Craig Cohen, Deborah Cohen and Lisa Cohen Russman. Devoted grandfather of Dara, Jared, Morgan, Benjamin, Abigail, Alyssa, Mia and Sadie. Cherished father-in-law of Lara, George and Matthew. Beloved brother of Eileen Goldman and the late Bernard Cohen, and brother- in-law of Jack Goldman and the late Ann Cohen. His intelligence, wit, generosity, devotion, and hard work were recognized and admired by all who knew him. He will be missed by all. Services at the Chapel at Sharon Memorial Park, 40 Dedham Street, Sharon, MA on Monday, February 29 at 2:00pm. Memorial observance at the home of Deborah and George following the interment. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the American Cancer Society, cancer.org. 1/3

SNYDER--Peggy. We note with sorrow the passing of our member, Peggy Snyder, and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

SHAIO--Anne Dubonnet, 85, widow of the late Victor Shaio, died peacefully at her home in New York City on February 27 after a long illness. She is survived by her son, Alain Foussier and his wife Janka, of Woudsend, the Netherlands; her daughter, Elizabeth Uzielli and her husband Dennis O'Donnell, of New York; and her grandson, Alexander O'Donnell. Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st St. and Madison Ave., Monday, 4pm-7pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Chapin School, New York, NY; or to St. Timothy's School, Stevenson, MD. 1/3

KOREY--Doris Broder, beloved wife of the late Saul R. Korey, mother of three and loving grandmother and great-grandmother, died February 27th, family was by her side. Doris was a talented social worker, an avid reader and the best friend Israel ever had. Shiva at her home Tuesday - Thursday evening. 1/3

MUELLER--Otto-Werner. The Juilliard community is deeply saddened by the death of our former colleague Otto-Werner Mueller. One of the most respected and successful teachers of conducting around the world, he headed the Juilliard conducting program from 1987-2004. A person of exacting standards whose knowledge of the musical score was supreme, he was able to mold orchestras and young conductors in ways that brought out the best in them all. His many students have gone on to highly successful careers as orchestral musicians and conductors. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Ginny, his children and grandchildren and his many friends and colleagues. He will be deeply missed by us all. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean 1/3

ASTREDO--Humbert Allen Jr "Bud", passed into the universe on February 19, 2016. A consummate actor, story teller and entertainer, he honed his skills during the Korean War doing stand- up and entertaining the troops. He carried a weapon but always preferred bullets of laughter. Born in Pasadena, California on April 4, 1929, Bud grew up in San Francisco and Pasadena. His mother Bessie taught young Humbert to play the piano and this accomplishment made him the life of every party. As a teenager he loved souping up hot rods and burning rubber on the streets. His father Humbert Sr. infused his son with a passion for all the arts. Bud learned to sail a boat and to hunt and fish with his father on the Russian River and in the Sierra Nevadas. After the military, Humbert studied acting at the Pasadena Playhouse, worked in local theaters in Los Angeles and established a classical theater company, The Hollywood Center Theatre. In 1965 he loaded his possessions into his truck and drove to New York City, where he was immediately recognized as a very special talent and cast by Joe Papp for Shakespeare in the Park, which led to his big break playing Sergius in "Arms and the Man". Humbert was an early client and lifelong friend of agent Don Buchwald. He performed with James Earl Jones in "Othello", and became a fixture in off- broadway and regional theaters. He became wildly popular as a star of "Dark Shadows", the innovative gothic TV soap opera of the late 60's. Humbert toured nationally with both Frank Langella and Martin Landau in "Dracula". On Broadway he performed in Gore Vidal's "An Evening with Richard Nixon", Lorraine Hansberry's "Les Blancs" and the world tour of "Little Foxes" with Elizabeth Taylor. For 10 years he made his sailboat the "Whimsey" his home and later retired to a historical farm house in Guilford, Connecticut, where he continued to receive fan mail from followers of his career. Humbert is predeceased by his daughter Jennifer "Jenny" and survived by the Hanson Family and the Small Family. 1/3

JONAS--Alan B.,84, of Boca Raton, Florida passed away on February 25, 2016. Alan was predeceased by his loving wife Barbara. He was the devoted father of Daniel Jonas and Lori Jonas, father-in-law of Mimi Hoang and Robert Kruger and grandfather of Ilene and Julia Kruger.
