BEIT--Hugo Herbert Beit von Speyer, died peacefully at home on February 26th, 2016 surrounded by his loving family. Born in Frankfurt am Main, the son of Elisabeth de Neufville Beit von Speyer and Eduard Beit von Speyer, he was a member of several distinguished families whose accomplishments lasted over several centuries, and included the families Beit, Speyer, Merton and de Neufville. Marcus Salomon Beit founded Norddeutsch Affinerie AG in Hamburg, Germany, in 1770, the second largest copper company in the world, which acquired Cumerio in 2008, and was renamed Aurubis AG. The Beit family home in Frankfurt am Main is now the Rocco Forte Hotel Villa Kennedy in the Kennedyalle. Alfred Beit, the South African diamond magnate, and Nathan Meyer Rothschild funded Cecil Rhoades, founder of the DeBeers diamond mines in South Africa. Alfred Beit's nephew, Sir Alfred Beit and Lady Clementine Beit moved their renowned art collection from their home in Kensington Palace Gardens to Russborough House in County Wicklow, Ireland in 1952, one of the most beautiful Palladian houses in Ireland. The Speyers were bankers in Frankfurt since the 14th century with family firms in Paris, London and New York. The Speyer Bank, a leading investment house in Frankfurt, was usually ranked just behind the Rothschilds. Hugo Beit's great uncle, James Speyer, founded the Museum of the City of New York with John D. Rockefeller Jr., and James' brother, Edgar Speyer, founded the London tube system. Wilhelm Merton was the founder of Metallgesellschaft AG in Frankfurt in 1881, the largest non-ferrous mining company in the world. Sebastien de Neufville founded the de Neufville bank in the 16th century, which closed in the early 20th century. Hugo Beit's education began in Switzerland at the Ecole Nouvelle de Paudex, Lausanne, and upon coming to this country continued at Eaglebrook, Deerfield, Yale University, Bachelor of Engineering, and Columbia Business School. Upon graduation from Yale, he became an engineer for Babcock and Wilcox, and upon graduation from Columbia Business School, he became a. private investor, but never lost his love of engineering, serving as the Secretary of Yale Science and Engineering for 40 years. His love of all feats of engineering, including buildings, bridges, airplanes, etc., were the inspiration of his life. He was above all a gentleman, affable, kind, elegant and generous. His deep love for family and friends all over the world touched many lives. Surviving are his wife, Louise, and their daughter, Lili Beit Enloe, granddaughter, Sabrina, and son-in-law, Charles Enloe, of Washington, DC. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Tuesday, March 1st, from 7:00pm to 9:00pm, Mass at St. Ignatius Church at Park Avenue and 83rd Street, burial at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. 1/3

SUSSMAN--Harold, born April 20, 1922, died New York City on February 20, 2016. Served WWII (LCI (G) 461; LCI (G) 373) in eight Pacific invasions. Reported missing/dead, given posthumous BA, University of Illinois, February 1945. Taught anthropology Brooklyn campus New York City Community College and LIU; teacher PS142, Manhattan. Loving husband and father. Survived by wife Madeleine, all three children; sons-in-law, and two grandchildren. Memorial service: Grace Church, 802 Broadway, April 9 at 1pm. 1/3

HADDOW--Robert S.,94, of Greenwich, CT died February 17, 2016. Born in New Castle, PA on September 30, 1921, he was the son of the late George and Agnes Haddow. Raised in California, he proudly attained the rank of Eagle Scout while in the Boy Scouts. Robert graduated from the California Maritime Academy in 1942 and went to sea with Moore-McCormack Lines, serving as chief engineer during World War II. He graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in 1947 with a degree in ocean transportation. He held various administrative positions with Tidewater Oil Company until 1964. He moved to New York to join Standard Oil Co. of Indiana (Amoco) rising to the position of president of Amoco Shipping Company. In 1975, he was appointed shipping advisor to The Burmah Oil Company Ltd. to help resolve the company's tanker crisis. He later served as chief executive of Burmah Oil Tankers and president of Burmah Oil Shipping. He joined Ultramar in 1980 as senior vice president. Before retiring he held the position of president of American Maritime Transport. Robert had a great love of dogs, particularly for Labrador Retrievers, Petit Basset Griffon Vendeens, and one Wire-Hair Fox Terrier. He enjoyed traveling, especially to Scotland where both his parents came from. His hobbies included salmon fishing, grouse shooting, and golfing. Known as "Grumpy" to his grandchildren, he was funny, wise, and generous. Robert is survived by his wife of 65 years, Virginia Dillingham Haddow, daughter Susan Haddow, daughter-in-law Amy Haddow and four grandsons: Tyler, Peter, Matthew, and Michael. A son, Robert Haddow, predeceased him. Services and interment are private. Memorial Contributions may be made to The Boy Scouts of America, www.scouting.org. 1/3

Hugo Beit's education began in Switzerland at the Ecole Nouvelle de Paudex, Lausanne, and upon coming to this country continued at Eaglebrook, Deerfield, Yale University, Bachelor of Engineering, and Columbia Business School. Upon graduation from Yale, he became an engineer for Babcock and Wilcox, and upon graduation from Columbia Business School, he became a. private investor, but never lost his love of engineering, serving as the Secretary of Yale Science and Engineering for 40 years. His love of all feats of engineering, including buildings, bridges, airplanes, etc., were the inspiration of his life. He was above all a gentleman, affable, kind, elegant and generous. His deep love for family and friends all over the world touched many lives. Surviving are his wife, Louise, and their daughter, Lili Beit Enloe, granddaughter, Sabrina, and son-in-law, Charles Enloe, of Washington, DC. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Tuesday, March 1st, from 7:00pm to 9:00pm, Mass at St. Ignatius Church at Park Avenue and 83rd Street, burial at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. 1/3

MUELLER--Otto-Werner. The Juilliard community is deeply saddened by the death of our former colleague Otto-Werner Mueller. One of the most respected and successful teachers of conducting around the world, he headed the Juilliard conducting program from 1987-2004. A person of exacting standards whose knowledge of the musical score was supreme, he was able to mold orchestras and young conductors in ways that brought out the best in them all. His many students have gone on to highly successful careers as orchestral musicians and conductors. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Ginny, his children and grandchildren and his many friends and colleagues. He will be deeply missed by us all. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean 1/3

SAMUELS--Norman Edward. June 3, 1927 - February 27, 2016. Beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, uncle and friend to all. Loved by and loving towards everyone he met. Forever in our hearts. 1/3

SCALICI--Josephine, of Staten Island, NY, died peacefully at age 87 at Calvary Hospice, Manhattan, on February 25, 2016, with her daughter at her side. Sister of Marie Brand, Joseph Depperman, Anthony Depperman, and Grace Roby. Predeceased by husband Carmelo (Mel) in 1981 and sister Lillian Scalici in 2002. Loving mother of sons Joseph, Steven, daughter Susan and two grandchildren. Beloved aunt of many nieces and nephews. Josephine was a jeweler, together with her husband, a gemologist, owned and operated their own jewelry business, was greatly loved and will be missed by many. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, Wednesday, March 2, 2016, 6pm-9pm. Catholic Memorial Mass at Holy Family Chapel at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, New York, NY, Thursday March 3, 2016, at 9:30am. Burial to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. The family sends its sincere thanks to the attending physicians, surgeons, medical interns, residents and nursing staff of 4 Uris and the Palliative Medicine team at Lenox Hill Hospital, for their kindness, compassion and superior care. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lenox Hill Hospital Palliative Medicine Program in memory of Josephine Scalici. Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th Street, New York, NY, 10075, Attn: Development Office, L. McGrain. 1/3

CORWIN--Dorothy J. Beloved wife of Dr. Norman D. Corwin of Westwood, NJ, passed away on February 27, 2016. Adored mother of Janice C. Linett, Michael R. Corwin, and Susan C. Yaros. Honored grandmother of Steven Linett, Jenny Linett, Ethan Yaros, and Matthew Yaros. Dorothy, a native New Yorker, attended Bronx High School of Science. She was a cum laude graduate of Jackson (Tufts) College. She attended Columbia University School of Social Work and was awarded the Masters in Social Work degree from the Boston University School of Social Work. As the children grew she found her true love, books, at the Westwood Public Library where she worked many years. She and her husband enjoyed traveling, especially when chaperoning the Westwood High School band on their European trips. The couple were especially happy to have made it to the Pyramids and the Great Wall of China. The family is honoring her wish for a private funeral service at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity or support your local public library. Lastly, in the words of Jorge Luis Borges hanging on a wall at her home, "I had always imagined paradise as a kind of library." guttermanandmusicant.com. 1/3

JACOBS--Robert F.,71, of New York, NY, passed away peacefully at his home on February 27, 2016, surrounded by his loving family, following a courageous battle with cancer. Bob graduated from CCNY and from Fordham Law School in 1968. He began his legal career with Ernst & Ernst before he became an Assistant Corporation Counsel for the City of New York in its honors program. He then became associated with the Wormser Kiely law firm in 1969 and rapidly rose to partner in 1973. Bob engaged in a wide variety of practice areas on behalf of the firm, including litigation, corporate, commercial, real estate, fiduciary activities and individual counseling for domestic and foreign clients. At the time of his passing, he was a senior partner of the firm and its Deputy Managing Partner. After moving with his family from Westchester to Manhattan, Bob joined the Board of Directors of The Connaught, a large cooperative apartment building on East 54th Street, and was elected President of the Board, a position he held at the time of his death. Bob never allowed his busy professional practice or his Board activities to interfere with his unremitting devotion to his family and friends and his commitment to the game of golf with his longtime friends. Bob is survived by his loving wife Bonnie of 47 years, his son Marc and his wife Samantha, his daughter Jodi and her husband Thomas Sargent, and his wonderful grandchildren Luke, Emma, Simone and Arlo. He is also survived by his sister Helen's children, Michelle and Jeffrey and all of his nieces and nephews. Bob will be dearly missed by all who knew him but especially his beloved family who will have cherished memories of all the good times they had together. A funeral service will be held Tuesday at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, followed by interment. The family will sit Shiva at the family residence in Manhattan and at his son's residence in Westfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers and in recognition of Bob's many contributions to others, his leadership, talents and ready smile, donations in Bob's name may be made to MHO (Manhattan Hematology Oncology) Research Foundation, c/o Arlene Munoz: Donation Processing, 157 East 32nd Street, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10016. 1/3

COHEN--Sanford. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Sanford Cohen who graduated in 1959 with a BS in Electrical Engineering. A champion of urban education, his generosity and foresight allowed City College to establish scholarships for aspiring public school teachers in honor of his late wife, Barbara Krames Cohen, in the School of Education. The City College extends its condolences to his children, Lisa Cohen Russman, Deborah Cohen and Craig Cohen and to his grandchildren. Dr. Lisa S. Coico, President 1/3
BECK--Stuart, adored brother to Susan Champlin (Jim), and devoted uncle to Michael Champlin (Katie) and Julie Daniels (Andrew). A hole has been left in all of our hearts. 1/3

STERN--William. February 6, 1934 - February 28, 2016. Beloved of Joanne, Emily, David, Jody, Alan, Rebecca, Jake, Penelope and Max. Services at 11am at Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple, New Brunswick, NJ, March 1, 2016. Shiva through Sunday, March 6th. 1/3

BENARDETE--Jose Amado, died on February 25 of sudden heart failure. He was born March 24, 1928 in Brooklyn, New York, the son of Mair Jose Benardete and Doris Fox Benardete. He attended Midwood High School in Brooklyn and then went to the University of Virginia for undergraduate studies. He also received his Ph.D. in Philosophy from the University of Virginia. He came to the Philosophy Department at Syracuse University in 1961 where for over fifty years he was an inspiring scholar and teacher. In addition to many scholarly articles, he was the author of three books: 'Infinity' (1964), 'Metaphysics: The Logical Approach' (1989), and 'Greatness of Soul' (2013). In 1961, he married Catherine Lord, also a Professor of Philosophy at Syracuse University. His brother, the classicist and philosopher Seth Gabriel Benardete, died in 2001. Jose is survived by his wife Catherine, his brother Diego, his nephew Ethan, his niece Emma, and by Jane Benardete, the wife of Seth Benardete. A memorial service was held Monday, February 29, 2016 at the Burns Garfield Funeral Home, 3175 East Genesee Street, Syracuse, New York. To leave a message of condolence to the family please visit www.burnsgarfield.com 1/3

SHAIO--Anne Dubonnet, 85, widow of the late Victor Shaio, died peacefully at her home in New York City on February 27 after a long illness. She is survived by her son, Alain Foussier and his wife Janka, of Woudsend, the Netherlands; her daughter, Elizabeth Uzielli and her husband Dennis O'Donnell, of New York; and her grandson, Alexander O'Donnell. Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st St. and Madison Ave., Monday, 4pm-7pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Chapin School, New York, NY; or to St. Timothy's School, Stevenson, MD. 1/3

WEINSTEIN--Dr. Betty C. Buchsbaum, beloved aunt to many nieces and nephews, devoted mother to son Daniel and grandmother of Koan. Dr. Buchsbaum sadly died on February 22, 2016 in Pittsburgh, PA. A gifted psychotherapist, she practiced in Westchester County for over 35 years. Mourned by bereaved spouse William, siblings Gertrude Ostrove, David Buchsbaum and wife Betty. She exuded grace, love, and vitality; a woman of valor. Barbara Miller and James Alleman 1/3

ABRAMS--Lauren. Lauren Denise Abrams, 59, of New York, New York died February, 18 2016. Lauren Abrams passed away at her home in San Diego, CA after a long fight with ovarian cancer. She is survived by her husband Jim Howorth, daughter and son Dana Howorth and Tyler Howorth, sisters Vicki and Nancy Abrams. Abrams led large customer service organizations at IMED, IVAC, Alaris and Cardinal Health and was the CEO of Source Refrigeration before her retirement in 2011. A Remembrance Celebration will be held on March 12, 2016 from 2-5pm at the Escondido Center for the Performing Arts. 1/3
BUTWIN--Lawrence. Since 1951, we have been best friends and as close as brothers. We will never forget you. Rest in peace. Adrienne and Arthur Singer 1/3

MARCUS--Marvin David. (July 31, 1927 - February 20, 2016). A celebration of Marvin's life will be held in Santa Barbara, CA, on May 27, 2016. Those interested in attending, please contact his daughter Karen Melissa at Melissa.Marcus@nau.edu In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Villa Alamar, 45 E. Alamar Ave., Santa Barbara, CA, 93105. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

BUTWIN--Lawrence J.,"Larry," age 82. Tragically on February 29. Beloved husband of Joan for over 60 years. Loving father of Richard and Randi, Robert and Meryl and Ellen Begun. Adoring grandfather of Jonathan and Talia Ziskroit, Spencer and Brittany, Samantha, Brandon, and Benjamin. Brother of Jerome and the late Stanley. Loved by all who knew him. Services 1pm Thursday, March 3 at Gutterman's Inc., 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre. 1/3

WEINSTEIN--Dr. Betty C. Buchsbaum, beloved aunt to many nieces and nephews, devoted mother to son Daniel and grandmother of Koan. Dr. Buchsbaum sadly died on February 22, 2016 in Pittsburgh, PA. A gifted psychotherapist, she practiced in Westchester County for over 35 years. Mourned by bereaved spouse William, siblings Gertrude Ostrove, David Buchsbaum and wife Betty. She exuded grace, love, and vitality; a woman of valor. Barbara Miller and James Alleman 1/3

GOLDENHAR--Paulette, born June 23, 1927, died February 28, 2016. Widow of her beloved Maurice, loving mother of Francine, Didi (and son-in-law William Kornblum) and adoring grandmother of Lucas Schlager. Paulette was a hidden child of WWII, saved by the courage of Fernand Esnault and family in Chenois, Belgium. A lifelong Belgian citizen, she taught English and the ways of America to newcomers at the International Center in New York. Paulette was passionate, compassionate, intuitive, witty, and a splendid raconteuse. She lived her motto: "La vie est courte et il faut se hater d'en jouir." In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Weiner Family Palliative Care Unit at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City. 1/3

FISHMAN--Guglielmina, Stefani, died peacefully at home on Sunday, February 28, 2016. Born in Lugano, Switzerland she leaves behind husband of 56 years Dr. Harvey Fishman, as well as son Dr. Andrew Fishman, daughter-in-law Jelena, and grandson Theodor, son Edward J. Fishman Esq., daughter-in-law Hester, granddaughter Casey, and grandson James. Guglia attended Hofstra University and Adelphi University and had a successful career as a social worker. She spoke five languages and was a great lover of opera. Her cremated remains will be buried in her childhood churchyard in Aquila, Switzerland. 1/3

BILLANTI--Prudence M.,on March 1, 2016 of Westbury at age 90. Beloved sister of the late John and Joseph. Cherished aunt of Rosemarie (Joseph) Moskie and Andrew Spitaleri. Cherished aunt of Frank, Kristin and Frank Jr. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Krauss Funeral Home, Inc., 1097 Hempstead Tpke Franklin Square. Mass of Christian burial Friday 10:30am, St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church Garden City. lnterment St. Charles Cemetery. 1/3

THOMPSON--Laurie. With deepest sadness, we mourn the passing of Laurie Thompson, February 28, 2016, at her Upper West Side home in New York City, after a long battle with pneumonia. She was 90 years old. Laurie Thompson was born April 9, 1925 in Middletown, NY. She was a loving mother to her sons, Stephen Arkin, Wayne Finegan and Jonathan Finegan. She is survived by her son, Wayne Finegan, three grandchildren, Michael Arkin, Cory Finegan and Edward Arkin and two great-grandchildren, Emma and Dylan Arkin. Laurie Thompson was a graduate of Hunter College. In 1981, Laurie Thompson established Laurie Thompson Consultants, a genealogy firm which she owned and operated for over 35 years. She was an internationally known professional genealogist. A celebration of her life will take place at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10021 on March 5, 2016 at 1pm. 1/3

BUTWIN--Lawrence, suddenly and tragically on February 29, 2016. Our hearts go out in sympathy to Joan and the entire Butwin family, whose friendship, with affection and love, we have adored for four generations. The Tolkin Family 1/3

DELANY--Mary Welles, a successful interior designer and descendant of the founding fathers of Connecticut, died on February 27, 2016 in Stamford, CT. The cause of death was complications following surgery. Mary Delany, known to friends and family as Mamie, was born Mary Burnett Welles in Stratford, CT on December 15, 1927. Her beloved father, Charles Ralph Welles, was a gentleman farmer and worked for U.S. Steel. As a girl, Ms. Delany loved visiting his corner office in the Chrysler building to see the gargoyles outside his window. Her mother Helen, nee Graves, was also an interior designer. The Welles family history in America dates back to Thomas Welles who was the first Treasurer of the Colony of Connecticut in 1639 and subsequently the 17th and 20th Governor of the Colony of Connecticut. Another distinguished descendant, Gideon Welles, served as United States Secretary of the Navy under Presidents Abraham Lincoln and Andrew Johnson from 1861 to 1869. Ms. Delany was an avid sailor and grew up on boats on Long Island Sound. She sailed the entire eastern seaboard between Maine and the Caribbean. Her artistic accomplishments included cuisine, art and design. Many homes in Connecticut and New York bear her bold mix of playful color and humor. She is still remembered for the odalisque painting over the bar in Fat Tuesday restaurant in New Canaan, CT. After graduating Goucher College with a BA in fine arts, Ms. Delany moved to Manhattan where she worked as a designer at Norcross Greeting Cards. She was known for her sense of adventure and a distinguishing laugh. After marrying John J. Delany III, President of Coyne and Delany Company, the Connecticut suburbs and family beckoned. Following in her mother's tradition, she started Mary W. Delany Interiors and continued to work. Her daughter, Corey Delany who is also an interior designer, continues the family lineage. The eldest, Sean Delany is the Executive Director of Lawyers Alliance for New York. Her daughter Dana Delany is an actor. She was the proud mother-in-law of Barbara Finkelstein, and loving grandmother of Leah and William Delany. Ms. Delany's marriage ended in divorce. Her beloved companion of twenty-five years, Robert G. Davidson of Stamford, survives her. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Planned Parenthood, 123 William Street, NY, NY 10038 or www.plannedparenthood. org/donate 1/3

McGINNIS--Pauline Oldham, born in Philadelphia on July 1, 1929, died in New York City on February 27, 2016. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, John P. McGinnis, sons, John O. and David E., daughters-in-law, Ardith Spence and Ellen Gibson McGinnis, and grandchildren, Anna, Patrick and Miranda. She was the center of her family. 1/3

SCALICI--Josephine, of Staten Island, NY, died peacefully at age 87 at Calvary Hospice, Manhattan, on February 26, 2016, with her daughter at her side. Sister of Marie Brand, Joseph Depperman, Anthony Depperman, and Grace Roby. Predeceased by husband Carmelo (Mel) in 1981 and sister Lillian Scalici in 2002. Loving mother of sons Joseph, Steven, daughter Susan and two grandchildren. Beloved aunt of many nieces and nephews. Josephine was a jeweler, together with her husband, a gemologist, owned and operated their own jewelry business, was greatly loved and will be missed by many. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, Wednesday, March 2, 2016, 6pm-9pm. Catholic Memorial Mass at Holy Family Chapel at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, New York, NY, Thursday March 3, 2016, at 9:30am. Burial to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. The family sends its sincere thanks to the attending physicians, surgeons, medical interns, residents and nursing staff of 4 Uris and the Palliative Medicine team at Lenox Hill Hospital, for their kindness, compassion and superior care. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lenox Hill Hospital Palliative Medicine Program in memory of Josephine Scalici. Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th Street, New York, NY, 10075, Attn: Development Office, L. McGrain. 1/3

FISHER--Robert Miller "Fish," Bob's oldest partner in crime and best friend. Your wisdom, integrity and friendship are gifts we will all cherish forever. Our hearts and love go out to Linda and the family. Judy, Lisa, Gail, Matt, Darren and the kids (your second family) 1/3

ARLEN--Alice. The board of the Alicia Patterson Foundation celebrates the exceptional life of Alice Arlen, former director, board member and president emeritus. She supported important journalism in all facets of her spirited life. 1/3

LANE--Dr. Stanley L.,Sr. We mourn the passing of Dr. Stanley L. Lane, Sr., the father of our partner, Stanley L. Lane, Jr. We extend our deepest condolences to Stan, his wife, Ina, and their sons, Barrett and Darren, to Stan's sister, Sandra, her husband, Jonathan, and their children Jamie, Sarah, Scott and Joseph, and to Dr. Lane's wife, Alice, and her children, Karyn, her husband, Scott, and their children, Zachary and Alec, Jennifer, her husband, Craig, and their children Jonah, Allegra and Emilia, and Adam, his wife, Marni, and their son, Bennett. Otterbourg P.C. 1/3

IMAMURA--Reginald (Reggie) H.,50, of Larchmont, NY, passed away on Monday, February 29, 2016. He is survived by his loving wife of 27 years, Lisa, daughters Natalie and Sophie, mother Kikuko, brother Anthony, and brother-in-law Bryan Slater. Reggie was predeceased by his father, Hideki Imamura. Reggie was employed in the financial services and banking industry, most recently with PNC Financial. A Celebration of Life memorial service will be held Saturday, March 5, 2016, 10:30am at St. John's Episcopal Church, 4 Fountain Square, Larchmont, NY. A reception will take place immediately following the service at the Larchmont Yacht Club, 1 Woodbine Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Pancreatic Cancer Foundation at pancan.org. Full details and additional information can be found at JJFFH.com. 1/3
FISHER--Robert M. We mourn the passing of our brother-in-love. Our deepest sympathies are with Linda, Helaine, Lawrence and their families. With love, Barbara and Bentley 1/3

FISHER--Robert M. Robert Miller Fisher, a proud 90-year-old, passed away peacefully on March 1, 2016, in the home he loved, in the building in which he lived for 77 years. Adored and devoted son of Jeanette and Samuel, beloved and treasured husband of Linda (Wax) for 55 years, loving and caring father to Helaine (Bob Hebble) and Lawrence (Susan Gavay), Bob was thrilled to be "Poppy" to his grandchildren Cole, Zoe, Will and Remi. They gave him great pleasure, and he was enormously proud of their achievements. Bob was an attorney for over 50 years with the firm of Fisher, Hecht and Fisher, started by his father in the 1902s. He practiced business law and was also a U.S. Bankruptcy Court Trustee. He had an impeccable reputation--for honesty and integrity. During his life, Bob was a member of the Young Men's Philanthropic League, the West Side Democratic Club, the Commercial Law League of America, the Bankruptcy Bar, and Congregation Shaare Zedek, where he sat in his father's seat for many years. He loved golf, his Tuesday night poker games, and all sports (except boxing). He loved his country, and he loved Israel. Bonds for Israel honored him for his devotion to the state of Israel and commitment to its Bond Program. Bob was a generous man, a good friend and confidante, and one who always stood up for what he believed to be right. He was a mensch. The family is grateful to Dr. Leonard Mattes, Dr. David Harnick, Dr. Daniel Popowich, and Dr. Steven Naymagon, not just for their expertise but for their kindness and caring as well. His nurses Aileen, Jillian, Liane, and Maricel tended to his every need with warmth and a smile. Services will be held Thursday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in Bob's memory to Hatzoloh, c/o The Jewish Center, 131 West 86th Street, New York, NY 10024. 1/3

KOREY--Doris Broder. The Saul R. Korey Department of Neurology of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine is deeply saddened by the death of the wife of our late Founding Chair. Although the legacy of Dr. Korey is deep and profound, the societal contributions of his wife and partner have been equally impressive throughout her long life: as a pioneering social worker, as an activist in voter registration drives to support social justice, as a student of genealogy studies, as an ardent supporter of Israel, as a lover of learning and knowledge and as mother to Suzanne, Cathie and the late Barry, the latter two of whom were Einstein medical students, as well as a loving grandmother. We send our heartfelt condolences to the entire extended Korey family. Mark F. Mehler, M.D. Alpern Professor and University Chairman, The Saul R. Korey Department of Neurology Albert Einstein College of Medicine 1/3

JONES--Ira Snow. The Department of Ophthalmology at Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Ira Snow Jones, M.D. who was associated with the institution for over 50 years. After receiving his medical degree from its College of Physicians and Surgeons, he completed his residency at the Harkness Eye Institute here and then joined the faculty. He became a world-renowned expert in orbital tumors during his tenure as Professor of Ophthalmology. We extend our condolences to his wife, Vasso, his children, and extended family. George Cioffi, M.D., Chairman; Stanley Chang, M.D., Chairman Emeritus Dept. of Ophthalmology, Columbia University Medical Center 1/3

HANDELMAN--James Harvey. Beloved husband of Susan Schaell Handelman; son of Natalie and Donald; father of Christopher Metcalf, Zach (Raquel), and Jed; grandfather of Asher; brother of Richard (Joy). Gone too soon, at age 61, Jim died on February 27, 2016. He grew up in Scarsdale, NY; received his undergraduate degree from Trinity College in Connecticut and continued graduate studies at Cornell University in New York. He was the Executive Director of The Mathers Foundation. Services will be private. 1/3

SMITH--Lee Sanders, 78, passed away peacefully at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, NY on February 28th. Born in Los Angeles, CA, she was raised in Rochester, NY and graduated from Rosemary Hall and Skidmore College. In 1952, she left her editorial position at Harpers Bazaar to move to Charlottesville, VA, where her husband, Briscoe "Sandy" Smith was completing law school. In 1964, they settled in the Bronxville vicinity where they lived for more than 50 years raising their three children. Lee was well-known for her engaging and original sense of humor, elegant and glamorous style, and devotion to her family and many friends. She lit up any room she entered and was sought after by all those who knew her. She was especially proud of her children, Radford, and wife JB, Ranson and husband Ken, and Brewster and wife, Heather and her six grandchildren. For many years she was active in her community and church. She was a main stay of the Song Pipers, a celebrated musical therapy singing group. She lead a number of fundraising efforts and completed course work for a masters degree in pastoral counseling. In addition to her husband, children and grandchildren, she is survived by her sister, Lucia Sanders Beer of Angelica, New York and her uncle, James Rush Lee of Newport Beach, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. A memorial service will be held at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Friday, March 4th at 2pm. 1/3

PHILLIOU--Philip J.,age 82, of Closter, NJ peacefully passed away on February 29, 2016 surrounded by loved ones. Philip is survived by his wife Marina; son Philip Jr. and his wife Annitsa, son Christopher and his wife Rachel, son Nicholas and his wife Arava, and son Demetrios; grandchildren Alexander and Paul Andreas, Willow May, and Jack. Philip is also survived by his brother, George Philliou. Philip's brother, Peter and sister, Norma predeceased him. For a man who traveled the world, Philip's two favorite places away from home were Astoria, Queens, New York and Siatista-Kozani, Greece. Siatista-Kozani was the birthplace of his parents and Astoria, his. Philip's youth revolved around school, his father's wholesale fur business and St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox church. Philip excelled at math and science throughout his academic career earning numerous academic achievement awards. Philip earned an academic scholarship to Brooklyn Technical High School. Philip received his Bachelor of Science in Chemical Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1955 and his Master's degree from New York University in 1959. Philip was a senior executive for two international engineering firms over his career. He led major ethanol and petrochemical projects in Brazil, the US and Southeast Asia. Philip served as member of the parish council of the Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, NJ and assisted with Troop 25 Boy Scouts. Donations can be made in Philip's memory to the St. Philothea Philoptochos Society at Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, NJ. Wake to be held at the Barrett Funeral Home in Tenafly, NJ on Thursday, March 3rd from 2-4pm and 7-9pm, Funeral at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, NJ on Friday, March 4th at 11am. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Paul, died peacefully at the age of 80 on Monday, February 22nd in Brooklyn. A former NYC English teacher at New Utrecht High School, Paul was a lover of jazz, literature and movies and believed in education through the arts. Paul was predeceased by his parents Moe and Bertha Friedman, his brother Howard and his sister Barbara Silverman. He is survived by his brother Bernard, sister-in-law Renee, nieces, nephews, and their families. Paul was beloved and will be deeply missed. Donations to "Education through Music" (etmonline.org) would be a fitting tribute. 1/3

JURDEM--Arnold I. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Arnold Jurdem. With his family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. May his memory be a blessing and the beautiful qualities of his life endure. 1/3

IMAMURA--Reginald (Reggie) H.,50, of Larchmont, NY, passed away on Monday, February 29, 2016. He is survived by his loving wife of 27 years, Lisa, daughters Natalie and Sophie, mother Kikuko, brother Anthony, and brother-in-law Bryan Slater. Reggie was predeceased by his father, Hideki Imamura. Reggie was employed in the financial services and banking industry, most recently with PNC Financial. A Celebration of Life memorial service will be held Saturday, March 5, 2016, 10:30am at St. John's Episcopal Church, 4 Fountain Square, Larchmont, NY. A reception will take place immediately following the service at the Larchmont Yacht Club, 1 Woodbine Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Pancreatic Cancer Foundation at pancan.org. Full details and additional information can be found at JJFFH.com. 1/3

LANE--Stanley L.,M.D., DDS, died peacefully at the age of 99 on March 1, 2016. Beloved husband, devoted father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Distinguished maxillofacial surgeon respected by his peers at the many hospitals with which he was affiliated. Revered by patients for his surgical skill and kind care. Proud graduate of NYU Medical School (1939) and Columbia Dental School (1941). A member of the greatest generation, served his country as an army surgeon during WWII. Predeceased by his first wife Sylvia Lane, the mother of his children Stanley (Ina) Lane and Sandra (Jonathan) Ballan. He leaves behind his grieving wife Alice Lane and her children Karyn (Scott) Goffin, Adam (Marni) Gronski, and Jennifer (Craig) Sabal. He is already missed by his grandchildren Barrett and Darren Lane, Sarah, Jamie, Scott and Joseph Ballan, Alec and Zachary Goffin, Bennet Gronski, and Jonah, Allegra and Emilia Sabal. Also mourned by his brother Dr. Jules Lane and many nieces and nephews. 1/3

HOLLISTER--Irene McLean, of Hanover, NH, died on February 22, 2016, at Kendal in Hanover, NH. She was born in Detroit, MI, on June 14, 1920, daughter of Leo and Alice Marie Bohn McLean, originally of New Jersey. She was predeceased by her brother Major Donald R. McLean, United States Army, who was killed in action in New Guinea in World War II. Irene Hollister graduated from the University of Toledo in 1943, with a bachelor's degree in Business Administration. After her move to New York City in the mid-1940s she worked as employment manager at Gimbels New York and Bonwit Teller. She also was employed at Richardson Bellows Henry and Co. where she worked on technical staff procurement for clients. In 1960 she was hired to establish the first permanent office for the not-for-profit Association for Computing Machinery, the world's largest educational and scientific society for computers founded in 1947. The mathematician Franz Alt, a founding member of the Association, noted that her implementation of sound business practices and quality management "marked the beginning of professional administration for the Association for Computing Machinery." During her 26-year tenure as ACM's Director of Membership and Corporate Relations, she oversaw the growth of membership from 8,000 to over 75,000. Working closely with ACM's Executive Committee and Council, and traveling widely in the United States and abroad, provided her with the opportunity to develop a working relationship with computer science leaders in government, education, and research during a period of rapid growth and innovation of the field. In addition to her professionalism, Irene Hollister had a talent for recognizing people of potential whom she supported with training and mentoring. This talent proved invaluable at the time of her retirement which made for a smooth transition. Irene Hollister married the author and artist Paul M. Hollister in 1951, whom she met at Carnegie Hall while she moonlighted as an usher; they were introduced by the author and music critic Louis Biancolli. Paul Hollister was teaching journalism at New York University at the time, and they were married for 53 years until his death in 2004. A noted art critic and author specializing in the history of glass, he wrote many articles for decorative arts publications, such as American Craft, the Corning Museum of Glass Journal of Glass Studies, The Magazine Antiques, and the international publication Neues Glas. His reviews of studio glass exhibitions which appeared in the New York Times during the 1970s and 1980s were especially of note. After Irene's retirement, Irene and Paul traveled extensively, combining sight-seeing with visits to private and public glass collections, where many curators graciously opened storage units to them for study. Irene and Paul Hollister donated their collection of modern Scottish paperweights to the Currier Museum of Art in Manchester, NH. In 2007 Irene established the Paul and Irene Hollister Endowed Lecture on Glass at the Bard Graduate Center in New York where much of Paul Hollister's library on glass is located. According to Forrest Proper of Joslin Hall Rare Books, this was "probably the finest collection of books on glass in private hands in this country," and now forms the basis of BGC's glass library. She was also a major contributor to the Paul Hollister Archives at the Rakow Research Library, Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, NY, which includes an assemblage of his audio lectures and interviews with studio glass artists. Their extensive collection of vintage Kuna mola applique textiles from the San Blas Islands, Panama, was gifted by her to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2008. Her husband's watercolors of interiors of Beauport, the Sleeper-McCann House, a National Historic Landmark at Historic New England in Gloucester, MA, drawn in color when he was 16 years old from black and white photographs, have been gifted to the Beauport Museum. She also co-edited Paul Hollister's "Collected Writings on Studio Glass" with Associate Professor Catherine Whalen of Bard Graduate Center (work in progress). In addition, Irene Hollister was interested in and supported the AVA Gallery in Lebanon, NH; Craft Emergency Relief Fund (CERF+) in Montpelier, VT; Urban Glass in Brooklyn, NY; and the Upper Valley Haven in White River Jct., VT. Contributions in Irene Hollister's memory may be made to the Paul and Irene Hollister Endowed Lecture on Glass at Bard Graduate Center or to the Upper Valley Haven. 1/3

PERRETTI--Peter, Jr. Long time Montclair resident Peter Perretti Jr. passed away peacefully on Saturday, February 27. He was 84. One of New Jersey's top civil litigators, Peter was a senior partner at Riker Danzig Scherer Hyland and Perretti. In 1989 he was appointed state Attorney General by Governor Thomas Kean. His counsel was sought by numerous state officials and several governors and Peter was a valued mentor and friend to many young attorneys. Peter loved Montclair and was active in the First Congregational Church, The Montclair Art Museum, Bloomfield College and the Salvation Army. In the 1960s and 1970s he served on the Board of Montclair Kimberley Academy and as Chairman of the Board was an architect of the merger of Montclair Academy and The Kimberley School. A loving family man, he and his wife Ruth raised their children on South Mountain Avenue. Together they enjoyed gardening, travel to Europe, their farm property in Frelinghuysen Township, summer trips to Lake Geneva, Wisconsin, and time with his many friends. Peter leaves behind his wife Ruth, children Peter, Earl and Ruth, sister Serena, three grandchildren, extended family and many friends. He will be dearly missed, but lived a long, accomplished and happy life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Salvation Army. 1/3

WISE--Alice J.,formerly of Eastchester, gently slipped off her mortal coil on March 2, surrounded by her children. Beloved wife and mother, grandmother and great- grandmother, devoted friend and daughter-in-law, she was an accomplished artist, folksinger, naturalist, and conservationist, and a dedicated civil rights, social justice, and peace activist. She will be dearly missed and long remembered for her wisdom, wit, beauty, and kindness to others... and her enduring love of nature and the arts. 1/3

BURNS--William G.,of Lake Wales, Florida, died Saturday, February 27, 2016. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Margaret, his children Sheila (Paul Roebuck), Eileen Perez (Santiago), Paul (Robin), Timothy (Stacy), Michael (Suzanne), his son-in-law William S. Molloy, Jr., 12 grandchildren and two great grandchildren. He was predeceased by his daughter Patricia Molloy. Also survived by his brother Ronald R. Burns and numerous nieces and nephews. Born November 2, 1932 in Whitehall, NY to William H. and Doris Vermet Burns. He was a graduate of Union College in 1954 earning a degree in Civil Engineering. He spent his entire career with the Bell System until 1984 when he was appointed Vice Chairman/Chief Financial Officer of NYNEX Corporation. He was Trustee Emeritus and former Chairman of Board of Trustees of Union College. He served on various Boards of Directors including New York Life Insurance Company, Gregorian University Foundation, Bok Tower Gardens, Winter Haven Hospital and its Foundation. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 11:00am, Saturday, March 5, 2016 at Holy Spirit Catholic Church, 644 So. 9th St., Lake Wales. Marion Nelson Funeral Home handling services. Contributions may be made to Bok Tower Gardens, 1151 Tower Blvd., Lake Wales, FL 33853; Winter Haven Hospital Foundation, Gregorian University Foundation in Manhattan, New York or the charity of your choice. 1/3

JURDEM--Arnold I.,90, of New York, N.Y. died February 29 of sudden heart failure. He was born July 21, 1925 in Bronx, New York, the son of Louis and Frances Jurdem. A Public relations professional for over fifty years Mr. Jurdem worked with a wide variety of corporate and fashion clients. His wife Ann, son Laurence, daughter Deanne and daughter-in-law Jorie survive him. Mr. Jurdem was a member of New York's Metropolitan Club and enjoyed fine food and the performing arts. He was the center of our family and he will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held on Friday at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Avenue. Interment to follow at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3
LEVY--Theodore "Teddy," age 83, beloved husband of Joyce. Loving and caring father to children Adam, Debbie and Jon. We will always remember him. Our love to the family. Norman and Rosalie Chalif 1/3

POPPER--Beatrice G.,PhD, 92 years, of Floral Park, N.Y., passed away on March 1. Betty was the loving wife of 51 years to the late Walter, sister of the late Theodore Barnett, M.D. and devoted and adored mother of Holly (deceased), Steven and Joseph, and their wives Janet and Cheryl. She adored her grandchildren Aimie, Emily, Rachel, Jessie, Ben and Julia. She loved and cherished her caretakers Bridgette Ivy and Karen Lee. Betty attended Brooklyn College, received her doctorate from New York University, and was Professor of Speech, and chairman of the department, at City College of New York. Until her death she continued to tutor English as a second language. She was an ardent Democrat, committed philanthropist, a bridge player extraordinaire and loyal friend to many. We will always love and miss her dearly. Funeral will be Friday 10am at Gutterman's Inc., 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Holly T. Popper Scholarship Fund at City College. 1/3

SHEVELL--Jon. In loving memory of Jon L. Shevell who passed eight years ago on March 3rd. We miss the unconditional love and laughter you gave to us every day. We know Arlene (Mommy), Uncle Danny, Aunt Janice and your grandparents are with you today. With all our love and kisses, Dad, Nancy, Paul, Susan, Robert, Merissa, Zachary and Arlen. 1/3

HEINE--Andrew Noah, of Bedford Corners, New York, passed away, peacefully, at his home on February 26th, following a lengthy illness. He was 87 years of age. He is survived by his loving wife of 27 years, Randi; two daughters, Priscilla and Nancy; three sons, Jake, Adam, and Jonathan; six grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Andrew was born in Camden, New Jersey, to the late Miriam and Aaron Heine. He attended The Haverford School, Amherst College, and The Yale School of Law. Possessing a brilliant mind and wit, Andrew cut a wide swath in life. He was both an extremely prominent corporate attorney and highly successful private investor. Dapper and elegant, he enjoyed life to the fullest, especially with his family. An excellent athlete, he enjoyed his weekly tennis games, jumping his horses, and skiing, annually, in his beloved Sun Valley, Idaho. He was, also, an avid outdoorsman, traveling to various shooting expeditions around the world. The twinkle in those very blue eyes and his love of martinis will stay with those who knew him, forever. He will be so missed. A celebration of his life will take place in New York, at a future date. 1/3
LEWIS--Matthew D. 9/27/58 - 3/3/96. Gone 20 years, sorely missed each day. Mother, Dad, and Janet 1/3

MARCUS--Richard, 89, of Manhattan and Boca Raton on March 1st. Beloved husband of Helen Anne Marcus and loving father of Gwen Marcus, Nancy Alpert and the late Stuart Marcus. Dick was a WWII medic, 'recovering' lawyer, leading title insurance executive and amateur herpetologist. We will miss his quick wit, abundant charm and the twinkle in his eye. Services on Sunday, March 6th at 11:30am at Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Wildlife Conservation Society headquartered at the Bronx Zoo. 1/3

JENNINGS--Richard Baker. 72, of New York City and Quogue, NY, died peacefully on February 28. He was the loving husband of Nancy Steeger Jennings for 46 years, father of Anne Jennings Staebler, Sally Jennings and Victoria Jennings Diamond; father-in-law of Ned Staebler and Robert Diamond; grandfather of Teddy and Jacob Staebler, Charlotte and Eleanor Diamond; brother of Ellen Jennings Giusti and John Baker Jennings. Rich was born on November 26, 1943, fifteen minutes behind his twin brother John, and grew up in New York City. He graduated Magna Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Yale University, where he was awarded the Corning Glass Works Traveling Fellowship. He received his MBA degree from Harvard Business School. From 1969 to 1986, he oversaw the Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) investment banking business at Goldman, Sachs & Co. During his tenure at Goldman, Sachs & Co. he also founded and managed the Mortgage Finance Group. From 1986 to 1989, he was Managing Director -- Real Estate Finance at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Inc. Rich founded Realty Capital International LLC, an investment banking firm in 1991. He served as the Lead Director for Alexandria Real Estate Equities, Inc.; on the board of directors of National Retail Properties, Inc.; European Investors' International Property Fund; Terra Capital Partners and The Stillwater Insurance Group; and as a trustee of the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction at NYU Medical Center. A celebration of his life will be held at 4pm on Thursday, March 10, 2016 at The River Club, 447 East 52nd Street. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Rich's memory (Office of Development, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017, Attn: Lauren Kelly). 1/3

FISHER--Robert M. Robert Miller Fisher, a proud 90-year-old, passed away peacefully on March 1, 2016, in the home he loved, in the building in which he lived for 77 years. Adored and devoted son of Jeanette and Samuel, beloved and treasured husband of Linda (Wax) for 55 years, loving and caring father to Helaine (Bob Hebble) and Lawrence (Susan Gavay), Bob was thrilled to be "Poppy" to his grandchildren Cole, Zoe, Will and Remi. They gave him great pleasure, and he was enormously proud of their achievements. Bob was an attorney for over 50 years with the firm of Fisher, Hecht and Fisher, started by his father in the 1920s. He practiced business law and was also a U.S. Bankruptcy Court Trustee. He had an impeccable reputation--for honesty and integrity. During his life, Bob was a member of the Young Men's Philanthropic League, the West Side Democratic Club, the Commercial Law League of America, the Bankruptcy Bar, and Congregation Shaare Zedek, where he sat in his father's seat for many years. He loved golf, his Tuesday night poker games, and all sports (except boxing). He loved his country, and he loved Israel. Bonds for Israel honored him for his devotion to the state of Israel and commitment to its Bond Program. Bob was a generous man, a good friend and confidante, and one who always stood up for what he believed to be right. He was a mensch. The family is grateful to Dr. Leonard Mattes, Dr. David Harnick, Dr. Daniel Popowich, and Dr. Steven Naymagon, not just for their expertise but for their kindness and caring as well. His nurses Aileen, Jillian, Liane, and Maricel tended to his every need with warmth and a smile. Services will be held Thursday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in Bob's memory to Hatzoloh, c/o The Jewish Center, 131 West 86th Street, New York, NY 10024. 1/3

JACKTER--Doris G. 3/3/23 - 8/16/13 Happy Birthday, Mom! You were the Universe's Gift to Me & will Remain in My Heart Forever--Especially each March 3rd. You now have 3 Beautiful Great-Grand-Dtrs: Lily Leah, who you met so briefly; sister, Margot Nicole, (For Poppa Norman); & Allison's Dtr, Your Namesake Danica Morgan 10 mos ago. How you would Love them all! Still bring Roses & Balloons, but now, to "new place" I go for our "visits". "No Day Shall Erase You From the Memory of Time" Virgil. Your Loving Daughter, "MAR" 1/3
OBER--Alice Parker, of Monkton, MD. Beloved mother, teacher, grandmother, friend, died February 21, 2016. 1/3

FREY--Audrey, age 89, died January 27, 2016 after a brief illness. A longtime resident of the Bronx, Audrey's wit and wonderful conversation and beautiful British accent will be missed by her friends and family. Audrey was married to Eric K. Frey for 40 years. When he died in 1999, her life continued, but her heart was broken. Born in British India, Audrey was a graduate of St. Theresa's in Calcutta, with honors, Senior Cambridge. She also attended the Calcutta Government School of Art. After WWII, Audrey moved from India to New York City, where she studied with the Art Students League. Audrey was a lifelong artist; her hand-drawn cards depicting flowers and animals delighted their recipients, and her cards and books made from dried plants and flowers are truly remarkable and treasured. She always made sure to depict her signature lady bug on her drawings, cards and letters. While working for McGraw Hill Publications Company, Audrey quickly rose to a management level. Hired in 1950, she traveled the world for her job and relished every adventure. Audrey spoke several languages and was one of the first women to hold advanced management positions. She was a trailblazer for those who followed. She became production manager of Coal Age in 1955, then was appointed as US Business Manager of International Management in 1966. In 1976, Audrey was named Director of US Publication Services for International Management. She became the Manager of Marketing Communications at McGraw Hill in 1985, shortly before her retirement. As an eager and capable volunteer, Audrey worked extensively with The New York Botanical Gardens and with Wave Hill, a public garden and nature center in the Bronx. She loved the natural beauty of flowers and plants and had so many plants in her apartment, she had a reputation as an amateur botanist with her very own at-home greenhouse. Audrey is survived by her loving brother, Douglas Spencer and his wife, Madeleine, of Kelso, Scotland, and her niece, Angela Banks of Edinburgh, Scotland. POPPER--Beatrice G.,PhD, 92 years, of Floral Park, N.Y., passed away on March 1. Betty was the loving wife of 51 years to the late Walter, sister of the late Theodore Barnett, M.D. and devoted and adored mother of Holly (deceased), Steven and Joseph, and their wives Janet and Cheryl. She adored her grandchildren Aimie, Emily, Rachel, Jessie, Ben and Julia. She loved and cherished her caretakers Bridgette Ivy and Karen Lee. Betty attended Brooklyn College, received her doctorate from New York University, and was Professor of Speech, and chairman of the department, at City College of New York. Until her death she continued to tutor English as a second language. She was an ardent Democrat, committed philanthropist, a bridge player extraordinaire and loyal friend to many. We will always love and miss her dearly. Funeral will be Friday 10am at Gutterman's Inc., 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Holly T. Popper Scholarship Fund at City College. 1/3

JURDEM--Arnold I.,90, of New York, N.Y. died February 29 of sudden heart failure. He was born July 21, 1925 in Bronx, New York, the son of Louis and Frances Jurdem. A Public relations professional for over fifty years Mr. Jurdem worked with a wide variety of corporate and fashion clients. His wife Ann, son Laurence, daughter Deanne and daughter-in-law Jorie survive him. Mr. Jurdem was a member of New York's Metropolitan Club and enjoyed fine food and the performing arts. He was the center of our family and he will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held on Friday at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Avenue. Interment to follow at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3
MARSHALL--Robert Keith. Bo, we try to be as selfless as you, but sometimes grief overwhelms us. We miss you so, our valiant son. Mom, Dad, and Oakley 1/3

LANE--Stanley L.,M.D., DDS, died peacefully at the age of 99 on March 1, 2016. Beloved husband, devoted father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Distinguished maxillofacial surgeon respected by his peers at the many hospitals with which he was affiliated. Revered by patients for his surgical skill and kind care. Proud graduate of NYU Medical School (1939) and Columbia Dental School (1941). A member of the greatest generation, served his country as an army surgeon during WWII. Predeceased by his first wife Sylvia Lane, the mother of his children Stanley (Ina) Lane and Sandra (Jonathan) Ballan. He leaves behind his grieving wife Alice Lane and her children Karyn (Scott) Goffin, Adam (Marni) Gronski, and Jennifer (Craig) Sabal. He is already missed by his grandchildren Barrett and Darren Lane, Sarah, Jamie, Scott and Joseph Ballan, Alec and Zachary Goffin, Bennet Gronski, and Jonah, Allegra and Emilia Sabal. Also mourned by his brother Dr. Jules Lane and many nieces and nephews. 1/3

HEINE--Andrew Noah, of Bedford Corners, New York, passed away, peacefully, at his home on February 26th, following a lengthy illness. He was 87 years of age. He is survived by his loving wife of 27 years, Randi; two daughters, Priscilla and Nancy; three sons, Jake, Adam, and Jonathan; six grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Andrew was born in Camden, New Jersey, to the late Miriam and Aaron Heine. He attended The Haverford School, Amherst College, and The Yale School of Law. Possessing a brilliant mind and wit, Andrew cut a wide swath in life. He was both an extremely prominent corporate attorney and highly successful private investor. Dapper and elegant, he enjoyed life to the fullest, especially with his family. An excellent athlete, he enjoyed his weekly tennis games, jumping his horses, and skiing, annually, in his beloved Sun Valley, Idaho. He was, also, an avid outdoorsman, traveling to various shooting expeditions around the world. The twinkle in those very blue eyes and his love of martinis will stay with those who knew him, forever. He will be so missed. A celebration of his life will take place in New York, at a future date. 1/3

HOPKINS--Dr. Robert. The members of the Department of Surgery mourn the loss of Dr. Robert Hopkins, Professor Emeritus of Medical Science at Brown University and former surgeon and Acting Chief-of-Surgery at Miriam Hospital in Providence, RI. Beloved father of Dr. Mary Ann Hopkins, Robert became a surgeon, like his father and grandfather before him. Notably, Robert performed the first kidney transplant in Rhode Island in 1973. He was an active member of numerous medical societies, serving in leadership positions such as President of the American Cancer Society, Rhode Island Division, President of the New England Society for Vascular Surgery and President of the Society of Medical Consultants to the Armed Forces to mention a few. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Hopkins and her family on their loss. H. Leon Pachter M.D., F.A.C.S The George David Stewart Professor and Chair Department of Surgery NYU Langone Medical Center 1/3

KING--Dr. Katherine Rees, 84, a psychoanalyst in New York City died of Alzhiemer's disease at Mary Manning Walsh Hospice on Monday, February 29, 2016. Dr. Rees studied with Anna Freud at the Child Clinic in Hampstead, London. She was a founder of the Child Program at the New York Freudian Society and she saw patients until 2013 when she became ill. Dr. Rees was educated at Oxford University, The London School of Economics, and Norfolk University. She moved to New York in 1965 and earned a PhD in psychology in 1985, at City University in New York. Dr. Rees is survived by her loving husband Charles, her brother Tony, and her twin brother, Alan. A memorial service is planned for some time in April. At John Krtil Funeral Home (212-744-3084) on First Ave and 70th Street in NYC. For information regarding the memorial service, call Charles King at 212-362-6964. 1/3

MARCUS--Richard, 89, of Manhattan and Boca Raton on March 1st. Beloved husband of Helen Anne Marcus and loving father of Gwen Marcus, Nancy Alpert and the late Stuart Marcus. Services on Sunday, March 6th at 11:30am at Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Wildlife Conservation Society headquartered at the Bronx Zoo. 1/3

BARUCH--Ralph M. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Ralph M. Baruch. As the founder of Viacom and a pioneer in the cable television industry, Ralph created an enduring legacy that has profoundly influenced the entertainment field. Elected to the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1986, Ralph served the Hall in several leadership roles during his tenure, including vice chairman of the Board, chairman of the Nominating Committee, and member of the Executive Committee, before becoming an Honorary Trustee in 2007. Ralph was deeply passionate about music, and we are grateful for his personal generosity to Carnegie Hall as well as his dedicated advocacy on behalf of the arts. All of us at Carnegie Hall extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Jean, to his daughters Alice, Eve, Michele, and Renee, and to the entire Baruch family. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

BARUCH--Ralph M.,passed away on March 3, 2016 at the age of 92. Ralph was a founder of Viacom International Inc. and served as its President and CEO from 1971 to 1983 and as Chairman until July 1987. Ralph was born in Frankfurt, Germany. In 1933, as a young child, he was forced to flee from the Nazis with his family to Paris, where he was educated. In 1940, they then escaped Paris. A harrowing three-month journey through France ensued, and Ralph carried his grandmother over the Pyrenees mountains. Eventually, under the auspices of the International Rescue Committee, the family arrived in the United States in December, 1940. He began his communications career in radio and joined the DuMont Television Network in 1950. He moved to CBS in 1954, progressing to CBS Group President, prior to the inception of Viacom. Ralph was instrumental in spinning off Viacom from CBS in 1971. During his tenure, Viacom acquired cable television systems, initiated Showtime, The Cable Health Network (now Lifetime), MTV, Nickelodeon, The Movie Channel, VH-1, and bought back the half of Showtime which had previously been sold to Warner. Eventually, Viacom, in turn, acquired CBS. Ralph authored an autobiography, "Television Tightrope - How I Escaped Hitler, Survived CBS and Fathered Viacom," published in April 2007, and also wrote "How Broadcasting and Cable Happened (in spite of the FCC)." Mr. Baruch served as vice chairman of Carnegie Hall, as a member of its Executive Committee and as chairman or member of various committees of the Board of Trustees of the Hall. He was named an Honorary Trustee in 2007. He served as a member of the Board of WNET and was a Trustee and member of the Executive Committee of Northwell Health. He also served as a Trustee of the Museum of Television and Radio (now the Paley Center for Media). Ralph was a founder and a Fellow of the International Academy of Television Arts & Sciences and served on the Board and Executive Committee of the Academy. He was a past-President of both the International Radio & Television Society and its Foundation. In 1985 the IRTS honored him with its Gold Medal, one of the most prestigious awards in communications for his outstanding contributions to the industry. A former director and member of the Executive Committee of the National Cable Television Association, (now the National Cable & Telecommunications Association), Mr. Baruch served for seven years as Chairman of an NCTA committee instrumental in the passage by Congress of the Cable Act of 1984. Under President Reagan, Ralph served for seven years as Chairman of the USIA's Television Communications Board of Advisors and as a member of the President's International Youth Exchange Initiative. In 1988, he served as a Senior Fellow of the Freedom Forum at Columbia University. Ralph was a co-founder, immediate past Chairman and Chairman Emeritus of the National Academy of Cable Programming. He received the Academy's first "Governor's Award," recognizing his contributions to the development of cable programming. He received the cable television industry's highest honor, the Vanguard Award, three of the NCTA's President's Awards, and its Chairman of the Year Award. In 1994 Ralph was honored with a special award from the International Academy of Television Arts and in 1999, Walter Cronkite presented him with an Emmy for the International Academy of Television Arts& Sciences. Seven years later, he was inducted into the Cable Hall of Fame. Then, in 2011, Ralph was the inaugural recipient of the WNET Distinguished Service Award. Ralph was a co-founder of C- Span, and often testified before regulatory agencies and committees of the Senate and House. He also served as Chairman of the NCTA's Pay Cable Committee, instrumental in removing FCC industry restrictions. Ralph was appointed in 1994 as a member of the New York City Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission by former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. Ralph leaves behind Jean, his beloved wife of 52 years, and four daughters: Eve Baruch, Renee Baruch, Esq., Alice Baruch, M.D., and Michele Baruch Jeffery, son-in-law James Jeffery, and grandchildren Rebecca, Charles and Jane. 1/3

LEVINE--Dr. Leonard J.,died February 29, 2016. A renowned Orlando plastic surgeon and former member of the Air Force Reserve Medical Corps, Len Levine was a truly extraordinary person. He was the most genuine of human beings. His kindness, warmth, laughter and humor will be missed by all. He dedicated his life to making the lives of those around him better, especially his family. Born March 20, 1943, he attended Wake Forest University, transferring to Monmouth University to complete his premedical studies. He received his Medical degree from the University of Bologna, interned at Beth Israel hospital in Newark, then trained in general and plastic surgery at Orlando Regional Medical center. He rose to department chief at Orlando's Lucerne Hospital. Dr. Levine was preceded in death by his mother, Clare. He is survived by his father, Irving Levine (wife Rose) of Boca Raton Florida; his daughter, Thea Rebecca Kovarik (husband Matt) and two granddaughters, Ava and Mila; his sister, Barbara Laufer (husband Sam) of Fair Haven, NJ, his three nephews Michael, David and James, his niece, Kate Laufer Gorenstein (husband Jeff) and great nephew, Will. Len is also survived by his partner in life, Carla DeLoach, with whom he experienced love, laughter, and many adventures. His spirit and generosity will continue on through his alma mater, Monmouth University, where he established an academic scholarship in his name. Donations can be made to this scholarship fund at Monmouth University or to The Orlando Health Foundation. 1/3

GERLI--Anne Harvey, 92, passed away on Thursday, March 3, 2016. She is survived by her daughters Anne G. Shean, Mary G. Clarke and Carol G. Deane, six grandchildren, one great- granddaughter and her cat, Pussywillow. She was pre-deceased by her husbands Carl W. Gram and David C. Gerli. She was the grand- daughter of William H. Woodin, secretary of the Treasury under FDR. She was the youngest president of the New York Junior League, and advocated for the rights of women and the mentally ill as president and board member of The Women's Prison Association, Girls Service League and Fountain House. She was an avid tennis player and figure skater. Anne was a member of The Skating Club of New York, a national figure skating judge for more than 70 years, and has served U.S. Figure Skating as vice president, Olympic representative, and U.S. world team leader. She was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2015. Anne is a past president of the Garden Club of East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the USFSA Memorial Fund or East Hampton Historical Society. There will be a memorial service Friday, March 11 at 2pm at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. 1/3

McALLISTER--Susan. Susan Davidson Marr McAllister of Palm Beach FL and Quogue, NY, died today, Friday, March 4, 2016, under loving Hospice care. Susan was predeceased by her brother James Davidson. She is survived by her sister Ellen Baer, her husband Bruce, her daughter Elizabeth Marr Hallas (husband Jeffrey) of Lantana FL; by her sons David F. Marr III (fiance Sabrina Muheim) of Palm Beach and Anthony J. Marr (wife Amy), of Sag Harbor, NY, three grandsons Jeffrey and Matthew Hallas and Alexander Nanci-Marr, nephew Henry Baer, Jr. and niece Susan Baer (Chan). Susan was born in Manhattan on April 20, 1937, to James A. Davidson and Ann Nicholson Davidson. Susan's children attended Collegiate and Nightingale Bamford schools and, while they were there, Susan joined friends to found Summerhouse Restaurant on Madison Ave. She summered in Quogue NY where she owned and operated the Inn at Quogue and The Patio Restaurant in Westhampton NY. A visitation will be held Monday, March 7, at 5:30 at Quattelbaum Funeral home, 6411 Parker Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33405. A funeral mass will be held Tuesday, March 8, at 1pm at St. Edwards Church, 144 N. County Road, Palm Beach, FL 33480. Susan was our true North with an unbending will and a generous, vibrant and loving heart. Whatever makes life worth living, she had it in full measure and showered it unstintingly on all who knew her. 1/3

BARUCH--Ralph. The staff and trustees of Northwell Health (formerly North Shore-LIJ Health System) mourn the loss of Trustee Ralph Baruch. A dedicated benefactor and advocate of Lenox Hill Hospital since 1987, Ralph served on the Lenox Hill Board of Trustees and Executive Committee after the merge with Northwell. He is a recipient of the Medal of Distinction and past chair of the Development and Public Relations Committee. Ralph's friendship, philanthropic support and dedication helped Lenox Hill Hospital become one of the finest medical institutions in New York City. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jean his children, and grand children. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Northwell Health Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, Northwell Health Paul B. Guenther, Chairman, Lenox Hill Executive Committee 1/3

Loving father of Joseph Jr. (Valerie DeLisa), Robert (Joan), Richard (Karen), and Kenneth. HEDISON--Bridget, wife of actor David Hedison, died of breast cancer on February 22 in her home in Beverly Hills. She was 71. Bridget is survived by her husband David, her daughters Alexandra and Serena, and daughter-in-law Jodie Foster. Bridget is remembered with love by her family in South Africa and London. 1/3

ROWLAND--Benjamin. Benjamin Moore Rowland, 73, died peacefully March 1, following a courageous struggle with recurrent colorectal cancer. A graduate of the Pomfret School, Yale and the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, Ben's career had a global span including service in the Peace Corps, 15 years on Wall Street, and leadership roles at both the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank. An avid watercolorist, he was also a political scholar, world traveler, writer and most of all loving family member and friend. He will be deeply missed by his wife Julia, daughter Katherine, son Ben, son-in-law Eddie McShane, siblings Hugh, Fred and Margaret and cherished grandson Finn. A celebration of his life will be held Saturday, March 12 at 2pm, at the Georgetown Presbyterian Church in Washington, D.C. Gifts in his memory may be made to Smith Center for Healing and the Arts in D.C. 1/3

SLATER--Marylin June. Born February 7, 1937. Died February 21, 2016 after a brief battle with ovarian cancer. Marylin was a special woman. An ESL (English as a Second Language) teacher in Port Washington from the late 1970s to the early 90's, she made meaningful differences in hundreds of students' lives. She moved to the Upper West Side in the 1990s where she continued teaching as a tutor. She enjoyed family, travel, exotic dining, art, music, and theatre. She was also an advocate of the underdog. She is survived by her children, Daniel (Rachel), Zachary (Nancy), and Vivian Votava (Mark), as well as by her grandchildren Jacob, Erich, Samantha, Evan, Leah and Gabe. She is survived by her adoptive children, Le Thu Nguyen, Joseph Arenas, Alex Silva, Fran Aryani, and families. She has donated her body to medicine so as to continue teaching after passing. In lieu of flowers, a donation can be made to the JD Blumenfeld Scholarship Fund (benefits ESL grads), at PO Box 386, Port Washington, NY 11050 or the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, ocrf.org. A celebration of her life is planned for April 10th, 3pm at the Rubin Museum, 150 W. 17th St., NY, NY. 1/3

FISHER--Robert M. Robert Miller Fisher, a proud 90-year-old, passed away peacefully on March 1, 2016, in the home he loved, in the building in which he lived for 77 years. Adored and devoted son of Jeanette and Samuel, beloved and treasured husband of Linda (Wax) for 55 years, loving and caring father to Helaine (Bob Hebble) and Lawrence (Susan Gavay), Bob was thrilled to be "Poppy" to his grandchildren Cole, Zoe, Will and Remi. They gave him great pleasure, and he was enormously proud of their achievements. Bob was an attorney for over 50 years with the firm of Fisher, Hecht and Fisher, started by his father in the 1920s. He practiced business law and was also a U.S. Bankruptcy Court Trustee. He had an impeccable reputation--for honesty and integrity. During his life, Bob was a member of the Young Men's Philanthropic League, the West Side Democratic Club, the Commercial Law League of America, the Bankruptcy Bar, and Congregation Shaare Zedek, where he sat in his father's seat for many years. He loved golf, his Tuesday night poker games, and all sports (except boxing). He loved his country, and he loved Israel. Bonds for Israel honored him for his devotion to the state of Israel and commitment to its Bond Program. Bob was a generous man, a good friend and confidante, and one who always stood up for what he believed to be right. He was a mensch. The family is grateful to Dr. Leonard Mattes, Dr. David Harnick, Dr. Daniel Popowich, and Dr. Steven Naymagon, not just for their expertise but for their kindness and caring as well. His nurses Aileen, Jillian, Liane, and Maricel tended to his every need with warmth and a smile. The family would appreciate donations in Bob's memory to Hatzoloh, c/o The Jewish Center, 131 West 86th Street, New York, NY 10024. 1/3

SINENBERG--Jean R.,passed peacefully in her sleep at her daughters home in Bridgehampton. Jean was an icon in the antique business in the Hamptons with her shop Georgica Creek Antiques. She was well known for her annual summer antique events in Bridgehampton and East Hampton. She leaves behind her son Clifford and his wife Barbara (Eichenberger) and her granddaughters Lindsay and Rachel along with her business partner and daughter, Suzanne Sinenberg. Burial took place February 19, at Edgewood Cemetery in Bridgehampton. 1/3

JENNINGS--Richard Baker. 72, of New York City and Quogue, NY, died peacefully on February 28. He was the loving husband of Nancy Steeger Jennings for 46 years, father of Anne Jennings Staebler, Sally Jennings and Victoria Jennings Diamond; father-in-law of Ned Staebler and Robert Diamond; grandfather of Teddy and Jacob Staebler, Charlotte and Eleanor Diamond; brother of Ellen Jennings Giusti and John Baker Jennings. Rich was born on November 26, 1943, fifteen minutes behind his twin brother John, and grew up in New York City. He graduated Magna Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Yale University, where he was awarded the Corning Glass Works Traveling Fellowship. He received his MBA degree from Harvard Business School. From 1969 to 1986, he oversaw the Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) investment banking business at Goldman, Sachs & Co. During his tenure at Goldman, Sachs & Co. he also founded and managed the Mortgage Finance Group. From 1986 to 1989, he was Managing Director -- Real Estate Finance at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Inc. Rich founded Realty Capital International LLC, an investment banking firm in 1991. He served as the Lead Director for Alexandria Real Estate Equities, Inc.; on the board of directors of National Retail Properties, Inc.; European Investors' International Property Fund; Terra Capital Partners and The Stillwater Insurance Group; and as a trustee of the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction at NYU Medical Center. A celebration of his life will be held at 4pm on Thursday, March 10, 2016 at The River Club, 447 East 52nd Street. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Rich's memory (Office of Development, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017, Attn: Lauren Kelly). 1/3

Woodin, secretary of the Treasury under FDR.
